"Ich bin 75 Jahre alt. Ich bin 1990 aus Konstanz hierhergekommen. Ich war hier in Dresden lange Zeit Richter. Nach meiner Pensionierung war ich Richter im Kosovo. Ich bin wieder hierher zurÃ¼ckgekommen, ich will nicht zurÃ¼ck nach Westdeutschland gehen, sondern werde mit meiner Familie hier in Dresden bleiben, wo wir uns sehr wohl fÃ¼hlen und die meisten Freunde haben. Ich war im Kosovo bei einem Gericht, das von der UNO und von der EU eingerichtet worden ist fÃ¼r die Privatisierung des StaatsvermÃ¶gen. Das ist sehr schwierig, aber ich war auch sehr sehr gerne dort und wÃ¤re am liebsten noch lÃ¤nger geblieben, aber meine Frau wollte, dass ich auch mal zurÃ¼ckkomme. Ich mag die Kosovaren gerne, und es ist ein Volk, das in Not ist und viele groÃe Probleme hat - existenzielle Probleme - und sie einen wirklich brauchen. AuÃerdem sind sie gastlich, warmherzig und dankbar - und nett mit alten MÃ¤nnern. Damals, als die Balkankriege waren, hatte ich nicht viel mit den FlÃ¼chtlingen zu tun. Es gab hier auch nicht diese Mengen. Der richtige FlÃ¼chtlingsstrom, der fÃ¼r uns auch ein Problem war, kam erst als ich wieder zurÃ¼ck war aus dem Kosovo, wir haben ja auch zum Teil Leute aus dem Balkan, auch Kosovaren, gehabt.

Mit FlÃ¼chtlingen habe ich mich erstmals befasst, als der FlÃ¼chtlingsstrom aus Syrien, Afghanistan und Afrika kam. Zum einen war ich nicht mehr berufstÃ¤tig und hatte Zeit. Zum anderen bin ich selbst ein FlÃ¼chtling, ich bin aus Polen nach Deutschland gekommen und sehr gut aufgenommen worden. Ich habe erlebt, wie meine Familie als FlÃ¼chtlingsfamilie wieder neu anfangen musste und wie ihr geholfen wurde. Dann war ich immer Arbeitsrichter. Arbeitsrichter schÃ¼tzen traditionell den SchwÃ¤cheren gegen den StÃ¤rkeren. Und hier ist es auch eine schwache BevÃ¶lkerungsgruppe, denen man helfen muss. Und dann ist es fÃ¼r mich schÃ¶n, mit jungen Leuten zu tun zu haben. Ich habe eine Familie mit vier SÃ¶hnen, die alle ihre Familien haben. Aber bei den FlÃ¼chtlingen sind es solche, die jeden Tag Hilfe brauchten und mir noch mal zuhÃ¶rten, weil sie mich brauchten. Ich habe mich dabei wohl gefÃ¼hlt. Ich sehe nicht gerne junge Leute leiden und ratlos herumlaufen. Ich meinte, man kann ihnen helfen, um sie auch etwas zu schÃ¼tzen gegen Anfeindungen und ihnen zu helfen, sich zu wehren.

Meine Familie ist eine typische deutsche Familie aus dem Baltikum. Wir sind Deutsche. Das war eine Schicht von baltischen Grundbesitzern, die schon vor der russischen Revolution geflohen sind, die dann von Hitler und Stalin umgesiedelt wurden, das war auch wie eine Flucht nach Polen, die dann in Polen vor der Roten Armee geflohen sind, dann in Ostdeutschland waren, dann mussten meine Eltern wieder weg, weil mein Vater politisch verfolgt war. Wir waren eine glÃ¼ckliche Familie, die aber immerfort geflohen ist. Das habe ich damals nicht so bewusst erlebt - ich war bei unserer letzten Flucht erst fÃ¼nf Jahre alt - aber wenn ich heute so darÃ¼ber nachdenke, dann hat es vielleicht damit zu tun. Ich interessiere mich zum Beispiel auch fÃ¼r Islam, ich interessiere mich fÃ¼r fremde LÃ¤nder. Wenn die Leute hierherkommen, ist das ein fruchtbarer Austausch. Ich habe selber sehr profitiert von der Arbeit mit FlÃ¼chtlingen. Das hat mir sehr geholfen, Abstand zu kriegen von unserer zufriedenen Umwelt, zu sehen, wie gut es uns geht. Wenn ich tagsÃ¼ber ein paar Stunden mit jemanden zu tun habe, der nichts hat, seine Kinder sind weg, seine Eltern sind weg, er weiÃ nicht, wie es weitergeht, er weiÃ nicht ob er abgeschoben wird, er ist in einem Sammellager - da kommt man nach Hause und denkt: âMein Gott, wie gut geht es uns!â Das macht einen dann auch zufrieden, wenn man merkt, dass es so nicht sein muss."

Teil 1/2
--
"I am 75 years old. I came here from Constance in 1990. I was a judge here in Dresden for a long time. After my retirement, I was a judge in Kosovo. I came back here â I donât want to go back to west Germany, rather I will stay here with my family in Dresden, where we feel comfortable and have the most friends. 

I was in Kosovo, working on a court that was set up by the UN and the EU for the privatization of state property. That was really difficult, but I also really liked being there and would have preferred to stay longer, but my wife wanted me to come back. I really like the Kosovars, and itâs a nation that is in need and has a lot of big problems â existential problems â and they really need you. Besides that, they are very hospitable, warm-hearted, and thankful â and nice to old men. During the Balkan war, I didnât have so much to do with refugees. There were also not these numbers of people. The real flow of refugees, which became a problem, first started when I was back from Kosovo; we also had people from the Balkans, including Kosovars, in part.

I first got involved with refugees when the flow of refugees from Syria, Afghanistan, and Africa, came. For one thing, I wasnât working anymore and had time. For another, I am myself a refugee; I came to Germany from Poland and was incorporated very well. I experienced how my family, as a refugee family, had to start again and how I was helped. Then I was always a labor judge. Labor judges traditionally protect the weaker against the stronger. And here it is also a weak group of people who you have to help. And then, itâs nice for me to have something to do with young people. I have a family with four sons, who all have families, but among the refugees, there are people who need help every day and listen to me because they need me. I have always felt good doing it. I donât like to see young people suffering, wandering around clueless. I thought, I could help them and maybe even do something to protect them against hostility and help them protect themselves.

My family is a typical German family from the Baltics. We are German. There was a class of Baltic property owners who had already fled from the Russian revolution and then were resettled in Poland by Hitler and Stalin, which was also a kind of flight, then who were in East Germany. My parents had to leave East Germany, because my father was politically persecuted. We were a happy family, which was continually fleeing, however. I didnât experience it so consciously â I was five years old when we fled for the last time â but if I now think about it, then maybe it has something to do with it. I am interested in Islam, for example; I am interested in foreign countries. When people come here, it is a fruitful exchange. I have myself very much profited from my work with refugees. That has really helped me get distance from our satisfied surroundings â to see how well we are doing. If I spend a couple of hours during the day with someone who doesnât have anything, whose children are gone, whose parents are gone, who doesnât know what will happen next, who doesnât know if he is going to be deported, then you come home and think, âMy God, how good we have it!â It makes you content if you know that it doesnât have to be that way."

"Ich arbeite bei einem Projekt mit. Wir machen Mediation und versuchen BÃ¼rgergesprÃ¤che zu organisieren, wo extreme FlÃ¼gel von rechts und links an einen Tisch gebracht werden. Es ist ein kompliziertes Verfahren und nicht immer, nur manchmal, erfolgreich. Aber es ist eine Sache, die in Deutschland sehr wichtig ist. Nicht dass wir die Konflikte lÃ¶sen, aber wir meinen, dass wir durch solche GesprÃ¤che erreichen, dass Menschen sich einÃ¼ben, dass man mit ihnen sprechen muss und keine Gewalt ausÃ¼ben darf. Wir wollen diese FlÃ¼gel heranziehen, damit sie sich in einen politischen Diskurs wieder einfinden kÃ¶nnen, der gewaltlos vorgeht. Wir nehmen selber keine Position ein. Mein politischer Standpunkt â zum Beispiel die FlÃ¼chtlingsarbeit - spielt da Ã¼berhaupt keine Rolle, ich teile ihn nicht mal mit, wenn ich nicht gefragt werde. Aber was eine Rolle spielt - und diese Erfahrung habe ich auch als Richter - ist wie man Menschen in eine friedliche Auseinandersetzung bringen kann, die eigentlich in einem Stadium sind, wo sie sich nicht mehr friedlich auseinandersetzen wollen. Also das VersÃ¶hnen oder den Leuten zu zeigen, man hÃ¶rt bis zum Schluss zu, du darfst endlich mal ausreden. Das machen wir, egal ob das autonome Linke oder Nazis sind. Jeder ist willkommen, wir hÃ¶ren jedem zu und gehen davon aus, wenn ihr zusammen kommt, werdet ihr beide dabei lernen

Im Kosovo war es eine andere Situation, eine Nachkriegssituation. Es gab tiefe Wunden. Es gab die Spaltung, auch wenn der eine Partner der Spaltung, nÃ¤mlich die Serben, die serbische Minderheit, vertrieben oder umgebracht war. In den KÃ¶pfen war die Spaltung ganz extrem. Wir haben Richter gehabt, die gesagt haben, bei mir darf nie ein Serbe gewinnen. Das gibt es hier nicht, das spielt hier keine Rolle, auÃer wenn wir fremdenfeindlich zu FlÃ¼chtlingen sind.

Wir hatten die Aufgabe, dass wir als Westliche dorthin kamen, die am Krieg nicht teilgenommen hatten, friedlich und versÃ¶hnlich waren und in eine Gesellschaft kamen, in der so tiefe Wunden waren, dass oft unser versÃ¶hnlicher Standpunkt gar nicht mehr akzeptiert werden konnte. Ich hatte Angestellte bei meinem Gericht, denen ich sagte: âWie bist du mit dem umgegangen, du warst unhÃ¶flich!â, und dann sagt er: âDu hast gut reden. Die Serben haben meinen Vater im Januar in den Wald gefÃ¼hrt und morgens haben wir ihn erfroren gefunden. Und du predigst jetzt hier Frieden! Dir ist so was nie passiert!â Das ist ein Problem fÃ¼r internationale Organisationen, dass man oft moralisierend reinkommt und vielleicht dazu neigt, zu oberflÃ¤chlich zu sagen, Wunden, die ich nicht habe, sind keine Wunden. Es sind aber Wunden in der ganzen BevÃ¶lkerung; wir haben keine Familie in der so was nicht passiert ist.

So eine Situation haben wir hier nicht. Meine Eltern hatten auch Wunden. Aber erstens liegt es auch immer am Charakter. Meine Eltern waren nicht nachtragend. Sie haben den Krieg Ã¼berlebt und sie haben doch unbewusst das GefÃ¼hl gehabt, wir haben andere LÃ¤nder Ã¼berfallen, wir haben mit Stalin kooperiert, wir haben die Polen Ã¼berfallen. Meine Mutter sagte immer: âWir sind mit dem Leben davon gekommen, Gott sei Dank.â Dass sie nichts mehr hatte, keine Tasche, keinen Koffer mehr, das war fÃ¼r sie gar kein Problem. Meine Eltern hatten das GefÃ¼hl, Deutschland hat Ã¼ber diese LÃ¤nder, die eigentlich unsere Heimat waren, solches UnglÃ¼ck gebracht, sie hÃ¤tten sich geniert zu klagen. Manche FlÃ¼chtlingsverbÃ¤nde tun auch immer so wie âAch, unser Schlesien!â, aber sie sagen nicht, was davor passiert war. Oder Dresden ist bombardiert worden, aber sie versuchen zu vergessen, dass vorher Coventry bombardiert wurde, und da waren wir dabei. Ich hatte nicht das GefÃ¼hl, dass meine Eltern Ã¼berhaupt traumatisiert waren. Sie waren nur glÃ¼cklich, dass sie Ã¼berlebt haben. Dass erlebe ich Ã¼brigens auch hier bei den FlÃ¼chtlingen. Ich erlebe manchmal Menschen, die so robust sind, wo ich denke, was hat der alles verloren, und trotzdem steht ein glÃ¼cklicher Mann vor mir, weil er Ã¼berlebt hat. Der MaÃstab verschiebt sich. Das ist etwas, was uns allen gut tut, wenn man sieht, der MaÃstab ist nicht absolut, es muss nicht alles so sein wie es jetzt hier ist, wie es fÃ¼r uns ist."

Teil 2 von 2
--
"I work in a project â we do mediation and try to organize discussions, where the extreme right and left wing are brought to the table. Itâs a complicated procedure and not always, although sometimes, successful. But it's a very important thing in Germany. Not that we solve the conflicts, but we think that through these discussions people practice the fact that you have speak to the other side, and you arenât allowed use violence. We want to pull these two wings together so that they can find a non-violent political discourse again. We donât take a position. My political point-of-view, for instance the work with refugees, plays absolutely no role. I donât tell them if I am not asked. But what does play a roll â and Iâve also had this experience as a judge â is that you can induce people to have a peaceful debate, who are actually in a place where they donât want to have peaceful debates anymore. So the reconciliation or showing people that you actively listen until the end â you are allowed to finally finish speaking. Thatâs what we do, no matter whether they are autonomist leftists or Nazis. Everyone is welcome; we listen to everyone and assume that if you come together, you are both there to learn.

In Kosovo, it was a different situation, a post-war situation. There were deep wounds. There was a division â even if one half partner of the division, namely the Serbs, the Serbian minority, were driven out or killed. In the minds of the people there, the division was really extreme. We had judges who said that Serbs couldnât win in his court. We donât have that here â it doesnât play a role â except when we are xenophobic to refugees.

We had the task to go to Kosovo as Westerners, who had not taken part in the war, who were peaceful and conciliatory, and we came into a society where there were such deep wounds that our conciliatory point of view couldnât be accepted anymore. I had an employee in my court to whom I said, âHow did you treat that man? You were impolite!â And he said, âYou can talk. The Serbs took my father into the forest in January, and we found him frozen in the morning. And now you preach peace here now! Nothing like that has happened to you!â Thatâs a problem for international organizations. You often come in, moralizing, and maybe tend to superficially say, âWounds that I donât have arenât wounds.â There are wounds in the whole population; we donât have family to whom that has happened.â

We donât have a situation like that here. My parents had wounds, but it primarily depends on character. My parents werenât vindictive. They survived the war, and they unconsciously had the feeling that we had invaded other countries, we had cooperated with Stalin, we had invaded in Poland. My mother always said, âWe came away with our lives. Thank God.â The fact that she didnât have anything, not a bag, not a single suitcase, that was absolutely no problem for her. My parents had the feeling that Germany had delivered such misery to these countries, which were actually our homeland, that they would have been ashamed to complain. So refugee organizations always act like, âAch, our Silesia!â but they donât say what happened before. Or Dresden was bombed, but they try to forget that Coventry was bombed before it, and we did it. I didnât have the feeling at all that my parents were traumatized. They were just happy that they survived. By the way, I see that also with the refugees. I sometimes meet people who are so robust, where I think about everything that he has lost and nevertheless he stands in front of me as a happy man, because he survived. The standards change. That is something what would do us all good â when you see that standards are not absolute. Not everything has to be as it is for us here now."

We want to pull these two wings together so that they can find a non-violent political discourse again. We donât take a position. My political point-of-view, for instance the work with refugees, plays absolutely no role. I donât tell them if I am not asked. But what does play a roll â and Iâve also had this experience as a judge â is that you can induce people to have a peaceful debate, who are actually in a place where they donât want to have peaceful debates anymore. So the reconciliation or showing people that you actively listen until the end â you are allowed to finally finish speaking. Thatâs what we do, no matter whether they are autonomist leftists or Nazis. Everyone is welcome; we listen to everyone and assume that if you come together, you are both there to learn.

In Kosovo, it was a different situation, a post-war situation. There were deep wounds. There was a division â even if one half partner of the division, namely the Serbs, the Serbian minority, were driven out or killed. In the minds of the people there, the division was really extreme. We had judges who said that Serbs couldnât win in his court. We donât have that here â it doesnât play a role â except when we are xenophobic to refugees.

We had the task to go to Kosovo as Westerners, who had not taken part in the war, who were peaceful and conciliatory, and we came into a society where there were such deep wounds that our conciliatory point of view couldnât be accepted anymore. I had an employee in my court to whom I said, âHow did you treat that man? You were impolite!â And he said, âYou can talk. The Serbs took my father into the forest in January, and we found him frozen in the morning. And now you preach peace here now! Nothing like that has happened to you!â Thatâs a problem for international organizations. You often come in, moralizing, and maybe tend to superficially say, âWounds that I donât have arenât wounds.â There are wounds in the whole population; we donât have family to whom that has happened.â

We donât have a situation like that here. My parents had wounds, but it primarily depends on character. My parents werenât vindictive. They survived the war, and they unconsciously had the feeling that we had invaded other countries, we had cooperated with Stalin, we had invaded in Poland. My mother always said, âWe came away with our lives. Thank God.â The fact that she didnât have anything, not a bag, not a single suitcase, that was absolutely no problem for her. My parents had the feeling that Germany had delivered such misery to these countries, which were actually our homeland, that they would have been ashamed to complain. So refugee organizations always act like, âAch, our Silesia!â but they donât say what happened before. Or Dresden was bombed, but they try to forget that Coventry was bombed before it, and we did it. I didnât have the feeling at all that my parents were traumatized. They were just happy that they survived. By the way, I see that also with the refugees. I sometimes meet people who are so robust, where I think about everything that he has lost and nevertheless he stands in front of me as a happy man, because he survived. The standards change. That is something what would do us all good â when you see that standards are not absolute. Not everything has to be as it is for us here now."

Danach habe ich Arbeit gefunden, habe eine Weile gearbeitet und eine Ausbildung zum Krankenpflegehelfer gesucht. 2018 habe ich einen Platz gefunden und mache nun die Ausbildung.

Mein Hobby ist die Malerei. In MeiÃen habe ich schon mal eine eigene Ausstellung gemacht, als ich noch nicht so lange in Deutschland war. Als dann aber das Asylverfahren begann mit den Interviews und so weiter, hatte ich nicht mehr viel Zeit und Lust zum Malen.

Die ABC-Tische finde ich sehr gut. Am Anfang meiner Ausbildung habe ich in meiner Klasse sehr wenig verstanden. Ich habe alles aufgeschrieben und es mir hier von den Lehrern noch mal erklÃ¤ren lassen, das hilft mir sehr bei meiner Ausbildung. FÃ¼r die Ausbildung zum Krankenpflegehelfer hab ich mich entschieden, weil man dort mit Menschen arbeiten kann. Das habe ich frÃ¼her nicht gemacht, in Pakistan habe ich angefangen, Architektur zu lernen, und auch einige Praktika gemacht.

Bisher komme ich gut zurecht bei der Ausbildung, und die Menschen auch mit mir, ich habe bis jetzt noch nichts wirklich Schlimmes gesehen. Ich habe das GefÃ¼hl, dass ich hier am Anfang viel Zeit verloren habe, auch weil ich so lange auf den Deutschkurs warten musste. WÃ¤hrenddessen hab ich selber Deutsch gelernt. Aber es kommt mir vor, als mÃ¼sste ich immer kÃ¤mpfen. Bisher habe ich auch nur eine Duldung, mein Asylantrag ist noch nicht akzeptiert. Aber immerhin habe ich eine Ausbildung. Ich versuche mir deswegen keinen Stress zu machen, denn ich weiÃ, jedes Land hat diesbezÃ¼glich seine Regeln und Gesetze."

"I live in MeiÃen. I have been in Germany for three years, and I am currently doing a training course. When I came from Pakistan, I tried to get into a German class, but I had to wait for a long time. In Pakistan, there arenât any real German courses, so I did a one-and-a-half-month internship that included a German course. After that, I found work, worked for a while, and then I looked for a training course for as a nurseâs assistant. In 2018, I found a place, and I started doing the training.

My hobby is painting. In MeiÃen, I already had my own exhibition, when I hadnât been in Germany for very long. Then when the asylum process started, with interviews, etc, I didnât have any more time or desire to paint.

I like the ABC Tables. At the beginning of my training, I understood very little of my classes. I wrote everything down and had the teachers here explain everything to me again. That helps me a lot with my course. I decided to do the training to be a nurseâs assistant because you can work with people there. I didnât do that before. In Pakistan, I started studied architecture and also did an internship.

Up until now, I am doing ok with the training course, and people also are doing ok with me. I have not yet seen anything really bad. I have the feeling that I lost a lot of time at the beginning because I had to wait so long for a German course. In the meantime, I studied German by myself, but it felt like I was always fighting. At this point, I only have a non-deportation order. My asylum application hasnât yet been accepted. But nevertheless, I have a training course. I try not to stress myself because of the asylum process because I know that every country has its own rules and laws concerning these things."

"After my husband and I had been together for a while, I moved to Dresden where he was teaching at the university. I had a postdoc position at the university, and then we had a baby, and then I couldn't leave. After I finished my postdoc, I realized there werenât many jobs available for art historians in Dresden. The closest place I could work was Berlin and that's not commutable on a daily basis. My son was really young, and I couldn't imagine leaving him in the daycare for ten hours a day.

At this point, there was always the question of whether my husband would get job somewhere else, but he got a fellowship here, so we stayed. I started working as a freelance translator, and at a certain point I felt like my entire self has been subsumed into motherhood. I don't think It's a sacrifice I consciously made for my family, but I couldn't have lived with myself if I had left. The year I started grad school, the Mellon Foundation did a study because it was obvious that the percentage of female grad students was much higher than the percentage of female professors. They wanted to know if it was just because of crazy sexism on the hiring committees or if the men were just better or what, so they went and interviewed every woman who had gotten a PhD in art history in the last ten years. It turns out that many women had made the decision not to pursue a career themselves, because women tend to marry men with equal level of education, and then it's a question of whose career is prioritized. Because of the physical demands of motherhood, it often ends up being the man's career. When I read that study, I said, âThatâs not going to be me!â But you never know. My baby had terrible colic. I had think I myself had postpartum depression, but it was undiagnosed, because it wasnât obvious that I was depressed. If you have a baby who cries all the time, itâs natural that you would be anxious and on edge. But even after he got better, I felt just too weak to fight my way in the professional world.

One of the things that I decided to do to get myself out of the depressive vulnerability of motherhood was to start participating in more things, and one of them was People in Dresden. I wanted to build a life outside of the family. And through People in Dresden, I was able to meet a lot of new people and forge a new identity for myself outside of motherhood and a failed career. 
The downside of any project is managing the logistics; people come in and out, you have conflicts with the people you work with. Itâs like any relationship â you can be hurt. The project itself was also really difficult at first. For someone who already felt vulnerable from depression, going out and asking strangers in a foreign language if they would talk to me and getting the constant rejection was hard. But I found that it was also a way to put the manage the anxiety I felt being in a foreign culture. With my interviewing partner and the photographer, I felt like I had allies. They could say, âYes, that person was being a jerk,â and I didnât have to obsess about whether I had done something wrong. 

Once I got the hang of it, it was exciting to meet random strangers and ask them about themselves. I have always been very curious about people and this gave me license to be nosy. It's such a strange thing to do; it gives me a sense of power. I now have this superpower to approach strangers. We have also started been focusing on initiatives and people who are doing great things in Dresden, and that makes me feel so much better, just on a personal level. Meeting people who have a vision of the world as a better place and are actively working to reach it. It's a very good anti-depressive!

I have been interviewing now for three and a half years. I keep doing it because people seem to appreciate the site and feel encouraged by it, and that's nice. "After my husband and I had been together for a while, I moved to Dresden where he was teaching at the university. I had a postdoc position at the university, and then we had a baby, and then I couldn't leave. After I finished my postdoc, I realized there werenât many jobs available for art historians in Dresden. The closest place I could work was Berlin and that's not commutable on a daily basis. My son was really young, and I couldn't imagine leaving him in the daycare for ten hours a day.

At this point, there was always the question of whether my husband would get job somewhere else, but he got a fellowship here, so we stayed. I started working as a freelance translator, and at a certain point I felt like my entire self has been subsumed into motherhood. I don't think It's a sacrifice I consciously made for my family, but I couldn't have lived with myself if I had left. The year I started grad school, the Mellon Foundation did a study because it was obvious that the percentage of female grad students was much higher than the percentage of female professors. They wanted to know if it was just because of crazy sexism on the hiring committees or if the men were just better or what, so they went and interviewed every woman who had gotten a PhD in art history in the last ten years. It turns out that many women had made the decision not to pursue a career themselves, because women tend to marry men with equal level of education, and then it's a question of whose career is prioritized. Because of the physical demands of motherhood, it often ends up being the man's career. When I read that study, I said, âThatâs not going to be me!â But you never know. My baby had terrible colic. I had think I myself had postpartum depression, but it was undiagnosed, because it wasnât obvious that I was depressed. If you have a baby who cries all the time, itâs natural that you would be anxious and on edge. But even after he got better, I felt just too weak to fight my way in the professional world.

One of the things that I decided to do to get myself out of the depressive vulnerability of motherhood was to start participating in more things, and one of them was People in Dresden. I wanted to build a life outside of the family. And through People in Dresden, I was able to meet a lot of new people and forge a new identity for myself outside of motherhood and a failed career. 
The downside of any project is managing the logistics; people come in and out, you have conflicts with the people you work with. Itâs like any relationship â you can be hurt. The project itself was also really difficult at first. For someone who already felt vulnerable from depression, going out and asking strangers in a foreign language if they would talk to me and getting the constant rejection was hard. But I found that it was also a way to put the manage the anxiety I felt being in a foreign culture. With my interviewing partner and the photographer, I felt like I had allies. They could say, âYes, that person was being a jerk,â and I didnât have to obsess about whether I had done something wrong. 

Once I got the hang of it, it was exciting to meet random strangers and ask them about themselves. I have always been very curious about people and this gave me license to be nosy. It's such a strange thing to do; it gives me a sense of power. I now have this superpower to approach strangers. We have also started been focusing on initiatives and people who are doing great things in Dresden, and that makes me feel so much better, just on a personal level. Meeting people who have a vision of the world as a better place and are actively working to reach it. It's a very good anti-depressive!

I have been interviewing now for three and a half years. I keep doing it because people seem to appreciate the site and feel encouraged by it, and that's nice. I like working my colleagues in the project, and I like having a structure for those friendships. It's something apart from my identity as a mother and a wife and a random American in Germany.

I get asked a lot, âIf you are a student in Germany, why canât you speak German yet?â People assume that I can speak German fluently because I study here, but I wasnât required to. I am learning though. I am just not comfortable yet.

Dresden has its pros and cons. I like the public transportation, the availability of some services. I wouldnât say that the bureaucracy is good, but things are more organized here. In terms of cons, I have faced some intolerance. I have been the victim of hate crimes, twice. In one case, I donât think I am legally allowed to discuss it. Another time, I was at the package station trying to pick up a package, and someone grabbed my passport and tear it up, saying that if it wasnât a German passport, it wasnât a real passport.

But I will finish my degree and see what chances I have. I donât know if I want to stay in Europe yet. I have to weigh different factors. One of them is society, but itâs not the only factor. There is also employment. In Egypt, I wasnât a minority, so I didnât face the same problems. I would say the culture is doing worse in Egypt, but here I am a visible minority. The discrimination I would face in Egypt is because I am a woman. But thatâs another story. Overall, I would say the atmosphere in Europe is a bit less bad. I am pessimistic, sorry.

âI have been playing music since I was three. It was always the only true thing; I always put music above everything else. In the family, I was also the only one who carried it through. My parents are both teachers, both played an instrument at some point, but they didnât stay with it.â

âAnd Manu is the real artist, the clichÃ© artist in other words.â

"Ich bin Dresdner. Ich bin hier geboren. Ich fÃ¼hle mich wohl hier. Das kann man vielleicht nicht unbedingt verstehen, wenn man sich die politische Entwicklung anschaut, aber mir gefÃ¤llt es immer noch hier und ich wollte eigentlich auch bis zum Lebensende hier bleiben. Mal schauen was das Leben so bringt bis dahin.

FÃ¼r mich und fÃ¼r Dresden wÃ¼rde ich sagen, dass die jetzt Zeit die schÃ¶nste Zeit ist. Ich will frÃ¼her nicht schlecht reden - es war eine andere Zeit mit anderen UmstÃ¤nden - aber jetzt hat man viele Freiheiten, die man damals nicht hatte. Man kann sie nutzen, aber man muss sie nicht nutzen. Ich kann mich finden und Ã¼berall einbringen, wo ich mÃ¶chte, in Vereine oder in Veranstaltungen wie hier bei der Offenen BÃ¼hne. Ich bin sehr glÃ¼cklich, gerade zu dieser Zeit jetzt zu leben. Und auch politisch gesehen ist es eigentlich eine Zeit, wo man nur sagen kann, freier waren wir noch nie gewesen. Auch wenn es andere wieder anders sehen und sagen, nein, Europa bestimmt uns alles. Ich fÃ¼hle mich nicht als Deutscher, ich fÃ¼hle mich als EuropÃ¤er. Und EuropÃ¤er zu sein heiÃt, aber eben auch, dass ich dazu stehen muss. Angst vor der nÃ¤chsten Wahl...ich hoffe immer noch auf den gesunden Menschenverstand. Vielleicht ist es auch die falsche Hoffnung, ich weiÃ es nicht. Angst wÃ¼rde ich nicht sagen, es ist eher ein flaues GefÃ¼hl, dass doch Sachen hochkommen, die man schon mal hatte, und die Leute wieder darauf reinfallen und nicht klÃ¼ger geworden sind und wieder den Leuten, die einfache LÃ¶sungen prÃ¤sentieren, hinterherrennen anstatt sich selber mal einen Kopf zu machen und zu sagen, okay hier gibt's etwas, was mir nicht gefÃ¤llt, ich will keinen, der mir eine einfache LÃ¶sung anbietet, sondern ich bringe mich selber mal ein und versuche selber eine LÃ¶sung zu finden.

Ich versuche das im Kleinen, indem ich zum Beispiel ehrenamtlich arbeite. Das ehrenamtliche Arbeiten macht SpaÃ. Man sieht, dass es den Leuten hier bei der Offenen BÃ¼hne gefÃ¤llt. Es kommt auch viel RÃ¼ckmeldung und die Leute sind froh, dass wir das machen. Ich bin zufÃ¤llig dazu gekommen. Ich bin in einer Selbsthilfegruppe fÃ¼r Stotterer und Sozialphobiker, das sind Leute, die Angst haben, auf die StraÃe zu gehen. Ich hatte das Problem, dass ich mit fremden Leuten gar nicht ins GesprÃ¤ch kommen konnte. Inzwischen hat sich das durch diese Gruppe ganz gut gegeben. Aber mit dieser Gruppe bin ich eben rumgekommen und bin so auch hier gelandet. Ich habe gesehen, wie das hier lÃ¤uft, und habe gesagt, okay, ich helfe euch mal mit. So bin ich hÃ¤ngengeblieben und mache jetzt mit. Das ist auch eine gute Therapie. Ich bin zufrieden und auch viel entspannter als frÃ¼her, weil die Ãngste weniger geworden sind. Ich bin zufrieden, wenn die Leute zufrieden sind. So wie es im Moment lÃ¤uft, lÃ¤uft es gut."

"I am a Dresdener. I was born here. I feel comfortable here. You might not be able to understand that necessarily if you look at the political developments, but I still like it here, and I actually want to stay here until the end of my life. Weâll see what life brings until then.

For me and for Dresden, I would say that now is the best time. I donât want to say bad things about before â it was another time with different circumstances â but now you have a lot of freedoms that you didnât have then. You can use these freedoms, but you donât have to. I can find myself anywhere and participate wherever I want to â in associations or events like the Open Stage here. I am very happy to live in especially these times. Even in political terms, itâs actually a time when you can say that we were never more free. Even if other people see it differently and say, âNo, Europe decides everything for us.â I donât feel like a German, I feel like a European. Being a European means that you have to stand up for it. Am I afraid of the next electionâ¦ I always still hope for common sense. Maybe itâs a false hope, I donât know. I wouldnât say I am afraid. Itâs more of a queasy feeling that things will come up that we had before, and people will fall into again, that they havenât gotten smarter, and that the people who put forward easy solutions, run behind instead of thinking for themselves and saying, âOkay, here is something that I donât like. I donât want anyone who offers me an easy solution. I would rather do something and try to find a solution myself.â

I am trying to do that on a small scale in that I volunteer, for example. Volunteering is fun. You see that people like it here at the Open Stage. There is also a lot of response, and people are happy that we do it. I came to it by accident. I was in a self-help group for stutterers and people with social phobias â people who are afraid of going out on the street. I had the problem that I couldnât talk to strangers at all. I have gotten better now because of this group, but with this group, I also went around to different places, and thatâs how I landed here. I saw how it worked and said, âOkay, I will help you out.â And I stayed and now I participate. Itâs also a good therapy. I am happy and much more relaxed than before because my fears have decreased. I am happy when the people are happy. Thatâs how itâs going now, itâs going well."

"Ich habe 2003 mein Psychologiestudium angefangen. Ich bin an rezidivierenden chronischen Depressionen und Angsterkrankungen erkrankt. Ich habe zehn mÃ¼ndliche PrÃ¼fungen ganz gut geschafft, aber durch die Erkrankung ist es mir nicht mehr mÃ¶glich, weitere mÃ¼ndliche PrÃ¼fungen zu machen. Es geht nur schriftlich. Ich kann vor den mÃ¼ndlichen PrÃ¼fungen wochenlang nicht mehr essen und nicht mehr normal schlafen und gerate in eine depressive Episode. Mein Arzt hat daraufhin ein Attest erstellt, dass ich meine letzten zwei PrÃ¼fungen nur schriftlich machen sollte. Das will aber die TU Dresden nicht. Die sagen, meine Erkrankung sei Teil meiner PersÃ¶nlichkeit und damit mÃ¼sse ich zurechtkommen. Ich habe aber eine Erkrankung, es ist nicht Teil meiner PersÃ¶nlichkeit. Rechtlich gesehen gehÃ¶ren chronische psychische Erkrankungen zu den Behinderungen und so steht mir auch das Recht auf einen Nachteilsausgleich zu. Das heiÃt, die UmstÃ¤nde sollten so gestaltet werden, dass es mir mÃ¶glich ist, in einer fÃ¼r meine Behinderung passenden Art und Weise die PrÃ¼fungen abzulegen. Das wÃ¤re dann schriftlich. Es gibt viele UniversitÃ¤ten in Deutschland und Europa, die bereits alle PrÃ¼fungen schriftlich machen. Das sollte eigentlich kein Problem sein. Aber der Vorsitzende des PrÃ¼fungsausschusses hat das so entschieden. Er hat gesagt, er sieht das nicht ein, dass ich die PrÃ¼fung schriftlich machen kann, weil es Teil meiner PersÃ¶nlichkeit ist. Ich fÃ¼hre diesen Rechtsstreit bei Gericht schon seit fast zwei Jahren. Jetzt wurde mir mitgeteilt, dass am 16. Mai Ã¼ber meinen Fall entschieden werden soll. Die Freie Presse in Chemnitz hat schon Ã¼ber den Fall berichtet und mittlerweile haben sich deutschlandweit Studierende, die Ã¤hnliches erlebt haben, bei mir und meiner Initiative Mindcolors gemeldet. Ich habe auch eine Petition an den Deutschen Bundestag geschrieben. Wir wollen dafÃ¼r sorgen, dass psychisch Erkrankte Teil der Gesellschaft sein dÃ¼rfen. Das Problem ist, dass jede Uni fÃ¼r sich selbst entscheiden darf, jeder PrÃ¼fungsausschussvorsitzende darf das fÃ¼r sich entscheiden. Es gibt keine allgemeinen Regelungen. Diese Leute haben die Macht, Ã¼ber das Schicksal von Menschen zu entscheiden. An an anderen UniversitÃ¤ten ist es total selbstverstÃ¤ndlich, dass Menschen in meiner Lage den Nachteilsausgleich erhalten.

Ich konnte meine ersten zehn mÃ¼ndlichen PrÃ¼fungen ablegen, aber es wurde immer schlimmer anstatt besser, bis es dann soweit war, dass es Ã¼berhaupt nicht mehr ging. Aber diese mÃ¼ndlichen PrÃ¼fungen bereiten mir solche Probleme, dass ich nicht hingehen konnte. Es ist eine spezifische Phobie - es muss eine PrÃ¼fung sein mit einer Bewertung und es muss meine Zukunft davon abhÃ¤ngen, damit dieser Zustand in mir da ist. Es ist eine Utopie darÃ¼ber, wie die Gesellschaft sein sollte, wie sie das angsterkrankte Kind aufnehmen und akzeptieren soll. Da gibt es diese Lehrerin, die zeigt, dass sie diese Angst hat. Es soll gezeigt werden, wie man auch mit der SchwÃ¤che gut umgehen kann und ein Leben mit der Erkrankung schaffen kann. Dass man das haben darf, das ist keine Schande, man muss nicht immer stark sein, sondern man kann diese SchwÃ¤che haben und trotzdem in der Gesellschaft gut klar kommen. Es ist ein Buch fÃ¼r Kinder, aber auch fÃ¼r die Erzieher und Erwachsenen. Es hat auch einen psychologischen Hintergrundteil, in dem Ã¼ber die Erkrankung aufgeklÃ¤rt wird. Ich habe beschrieben, wie ich die Gesellschaft gerne hÃ¤tte und wie ich mÃ¶chte, dass die Leute auf mich reagieren. Ich habe auch die Stellen benannt, an denen man Hilfe holen kann. AuÃerdem habe ich diese Initiative gegrÃ¼ndet â Mindcolors, die sich fÃ¼r die Rechte von psychisch kranken Menschen und Studierenden einsetzt und versucht, VerÃ¤nderungen zu erreichen. "I started studying psychology in 2003. I suffer from reoccurring chronic depression and anxiety. I passed ten oral exams very well, but because of my illness, I couldnât do the oral exams anymore. I was only able to do written exams. Before the oral exams, I couldnât eat for weeks or sleep normally, and I fell into a depressive episode. My doctor certified that I should only do my last two exams in written form. But TU Dresden didnât want that. They say that my illness is part of my personality, and I have to deal with it. I have an illness; it is not part of my personality. Legally, chronic psychiatric illnesses are considered disabilities, and so I have the right to compensation for disadvantages. That means that the conditions should be arranged so that it is possible for me to take the tests in a way that works for my disability. That would be in the written form. There are many universities in Germany and Europe that already do the exams in written form. It shouldnât actually be a problem. But the head of the exam committee decided it. He said that he doesnât accept that I take the exams in written form, because itâs part of my personality. The case has been in court for almost two years. Now, I was just told that my case will be decided on May 16. The Chemnitz Free Press reported about the case, and at this point, students from all over Germany who have experienced something similar have gotten in touch with me and my initiative Mindcolors. I wrote a petition to the German parliament. We want to make sure that psychologically ill people are allowed to be part of society. The problem is that every university can decide for itself, every exam committee chair can decide for him or herself. There are no general rules. These people have the power to decide the fate of people. At other universities, it goes without saying that people with my condition have the right to compensation for disadvantages. 

I could take my first ten oral exams, but it got worse instead of better until I couldnât do it anymore. I hold lectures in connection with my book, and I was the frontwoman of a band. I could do that despite my illness. But these oral exams gave me such problems that I couldnât go to them. Itâs a specific phobia â in order to create this condition in me, the exam has to be one with evaluation, and my future has to depend on it. I am excited before a lecture or a performance, but itâs a positive excitement, because I know that the audience wants to hear the music, and it doesnât have any influence on my future. The sickness is really just in this special situation; itâs called a specific phobia.

I had to work through this court case. Thatâs why I wrote a book. Itâs about a utopia, how society should be, how they should incorporate and accept the child who suffers from anxiety. There is a teacher who shows that she has anxiety. It should demonstrate that you can also get along with weakness and that you can succeed in life with the illness. That you are allowed to have an illness, that itâs not shameful; you donât always have to be strong. Instead, you have this weakness and can still get along in society. Itâs a book for children but also for educators and adults. It has a psychological background part where the illness is explained. I described how I would like society to be and how I would like that people react to me. I also named the places where you can get help. Besides that, I founded this initiative â Mindcolors, which is engaged for the rights of psychologically ill people and students and tries to create change. We have got this anti-stigmatizing book series Mindolino off the ground. We write acceptance-oriented books for children in order to make society more accepting and tolerant."

There is no better university for studying acoustic guitar -- in Germany in any case and maybe in all of Europe. "I was in the hospital in 2017. Since then, I have gotten into painting, in order to depict psychological things. I have written a book and many short short stories about depression. I want to explain it; representing the feelings is my ambition.

I was there for eleven weeks. I learned a lot there from my psychologists â that I should make art and stand by it. That helped me a lot. Of course, I nevertheless have negative phases, but I deal with them differently. I changed the way I relate to other people a lot. It wasnât my life before. Now, I have gotten into things that I have never seen before; I read books that I didnât know about before. I now have a totally different group of friends, with a very different kind of connection, which I didnât know before. There are fewer people, but itâs more intense. And there is more acceptance.

Since I was sixteen, I have had dysthymia. That means, for example, that I could never feel joy. Back then, there were things in my life that changed radically. Some of them werenât good. Then I had something, which you call double depression â meaning, a chronic malaise and a serious depression along with it. I was in a locked ward for a night because I had suicidal thoughts.

I noticed that you only do a lot of things because society wants you to, because you think that you wonât be respected otherwise, not accepted. Now, I am moving in another direction, where I say, âThat feels good and this is who I am.â Itâs nice to have contact with people who accept that. Before, I thought people are with me because I do this or that thing that they want me to do.

Art has many facets for me. For one, itâs a form of therapy; I do better because of it. I am looking for a picture or a text that contains everything â the psyche and every point of view about society. But that is not possible, and thatâs why a lot of things are created. They are things that show how it looks inside of me and also in many other people who have psychological diseases. Maybe it will help the people who donât know to have a little more understanding. Or as I often experienced in the hospital -- with pictures as well as when I described feelings â that people said, âI am not able to depict it like that, but the way you have now done it, thatâs how I feel, and it helps me.â

Funnily enough, I have never had a problem speaking about my depression. I saw that there are organizations that can work with you. However, there are a lot of people who donât dare to do anything. Maybe itâs my place in life to show my face and and maybe that will help some people."

"I am a Hamburg boy â born in Hamburg, grew up there, and lived there for sixty years. I moved here last year in November. My childhood was mixed. We had a lot because of my parents â we had a camping place and stuff. We were on the road a lot. I was more of the black sheep â only child, latchkey kid. I could do what I wanted. Well, that was my downfall.
I had a knee operation, and in rehabilitation, I got to know someone whom they had sent all the way to the north from Dresden. He was really decent. I then came here a few times for the Christmas market. I found out from an acquaintance of his that there was a free apartment in Gorbitz. One room, but thatâs enough for me. Then I packed myself and came here.

My parents died within the last five years. Nothing was holding me in Hamburg. I still have an aunt, but like I said, I am the black sheep. No one wants to have anything to do with me. So I took off. I had little contact with my parents. When my father got sick and went to the hospice, I was there more often, of course. When my father died, I had to take care of my mother a bit â or she had to take care of me, financially. But she didnât want to go on anymore without my father. I assume that she helped herself along â I also donât want to really know.

So far, itâs very nice in Gorbitz. Actually, I didnât want to live in a high-rise, but there are a lot of parks and a lot of green. There arenât so many chaotic people living there. A lot of people have told me Prohlis and that area is supposed to be worse. There are a lot of children and old people. Most of the people who live there are foreigners, asylum seekers. I wonât say anything against asylum seekers, but above me there are some that really annoy me. They make a lot of racket up there. I donât know what they are up to. I think there are three or four people in one room. No clue whatâs going on there.

My accent makes people notice me here in Saxony, also because I am now a seller. A lot of people say, âYou are a northern German.â I think Dresdeners are pleasant people. I always think itâs funny when they start babbling, when they start speaking in Saxon. Sometimes, you canât understand them at all. All in all, I am satisfied in Dresden, although truthfully, I havenât seen that much of it. I havenât gotten around to it.
I havenât had any negative experiences selling drObs. And I get to know people who live around me. I only sell up there where I live in Gorbitz at the Kaufland and down in LÃ¶btau at the Sparkasse. I do it to earn some pocket money. Otherwise, I would go stir-crazy. I also tried to work. I was at the Tafel, but then I had problems with my back. Hauling things â putting them in and taking them out â was nothing for my back. I threw in the towel after three days.

I introduced myself here, and the next day I started. At first, you have to work up the courage â well, actually not me. I am a hardened guy, I am not so sensitive. Some people do look at you a bit skeptically. They probably think, âHe should go work instead.â But like I said, I am now in that age when I just donât want to. Normally, I am a painter and varnisher. I donât want to work anymore. I admit that honestly. I also canât work anymore. My body is out of commission. Actually, I would like to retire. I am turning 62. The employment agency should leave me in peace."

Meinen Kassettenrekorder habe ich heute noch. Ich hatte zuletzt einen Konto mit Ã¼ber 160.000 DDR-Mark darauf. Darauf haben wir 3,25% Zinsen bekommen. Ich konnte meine Miete bezahlen, ohne dass ich arbeiten musste. Sehen Sie mal, wie sie heute fÃ¼r die Miete arbeiten mÃ¼ssen. In der DDR war Wohnen ein Menschenrecht, genauso wie das Recht auf Arbeit. Ich habe die Verfassung noch zu Hause.

Ich wohne in Prohlis. Noch ist meine Miete bezahlbar. Ich war lange Zeit in der SED und bin jetzt auch noch in der Linkspartei, weil das die einzige Partei ist, die wirklich auf das Soziale guckt. Das Unsoziale ist nÃ¤mlich auch der Grund, warum der Rechtspopulismus und der Rechtsextremismus und damit der Faschismus wieder erwachen. Ich bin selbst auch der Meinung, wir kÃ¶nnen nicht mehr jeden AuslÃ¤nder bei uns aufnehmen. Das geht nicht mehr. Die Sozialkassen reichen einfach nicht mehr. Als Touristen kÃ¶nnen sie ja kommen. Und dann sollen sie auch wieder in ihre Heimat fahren, da habe ich nichts dagegen. Die Syrier benehmen sich ja manchmal ziemlich daneben. Es hat schon ein paar mal die Polizei eingreifen mÃ¼ssen. Wenn es da mal eine SchlÃ¤gerei gibt, greifen die ja gleich zum Messer.

FrÃ¼her in der DDR gab es ja noch die Polizeistunde, da mussten die GaststÃ¤tten von 23 Uhr bis frÃ¼h um 6 Uhr schlieÃen. Das hat man deswegen gemacht, weil die Leute arbeiten sollten, die sollen ausgeruht auf Arbeit kommen. Das fand ich besser. Nur Samstag und Sonntag gab es mal Ausnahmen und da kam trotzdem ab und zu die Polizei rein und hat Personalausweiskontrollen gemacht. Genauso wÃ¤re ich dafÃ¼r, dass wieder die Grenze bewacht wird. Es fÃ¤llt keinem ein Zacken aus der Krone, wenn ich mal in die Seitentasche fasse und den Personalausweis vorzeige. Die, die gesucht werden, verschwinden ja sonst. Ich bin fÃ¼r eine offene Grenze, aber kontrolliert werden soll sie.

Ich stehe mit meine Zeitungen immer an der Frauenkirche. In der ersten HÃ¤lfte des Monats lÃ¤uft es immer am besten, danach kaufen nicht mehr so viele eine Zeitung. Man kann sagen, es lohnt sich. Es bessert die Haushaltskasse auf. Ich habe auch schon Artikel fÃ¼r die Zeitung geschrieben. Ich muss sagen, meine Artikel werden beachtet, weil sie wirklich dem Sozialen auf den Grund gehen. Als der sowjetische Offiziere sah, dass wir schon allerhand Ziegel aufgebaut hatten, haben sie uns einen Haufen zugewiesen, wo es nicht gefÃ¤hrlich war. Dann kam die FrÃ¼hstÃ¼ckspause und die haben gesehen, dass viele Frauen gar keine Schnitten hatten. Da haben sich die Sowjetsoldaten zu den Frauen gesetzt und ihr FrÃ¼hstÃ¼cksbrot geteilt. Dann ging jemand rÃ¼ber aufs Postamt und hat den Standort angerufen. Dann kam mittags ein kleiner Lastwagen mit einer Gulaschkanone hinten dran. Wissen Sie was das fÃ¼r eine Delikatesse war zu der Zeit, Erbsen mit Speck? Wir Kinder haben auch einen Schlag abbekommen, es war ja genug da. Viele Eltern haben ihre Kinder weg gerufen. Sie haben gesagt, du brauchst das nicht zu essen, du kriegst von uns genug zu essen. Meine Oma hat das auch gemacht. Die Eltern haben ja selber gehungert, um ihre Kinder satt zu kriegen. Der sowjetische Offizier hat gesagt, wenn ich wieder runterkomme, soll ich einen Topf mitbringen. Ich habe bei der Oma einen Topf geklaut und er hat mir den Topf voll mit Erbsen mit Speck gemacht. Meine Oma wollte das gleich ins Klo schÃ¼tten. Ich habe gesagt, mach das nicht, warte erstmal, bis der Opa nach Hause kommt. "I spent my whole life in Dresden. I had a nice childhood. We didnât have to go without during the GDR â sure, we were a little short of coffee and chocolate, but we had enough to eat. I had photo equipment that cost me 1,500 GDR marks. I still have my cassette recorder. I finally had an account with over 160,000 GDR marks. We got 3.25% interest. I could pay my rent without having to work. You see what we have to pay for rent today. In the GDR, housing was a human right, just like the right to work. I still have the constitution at home.

I live in Prohlis. My rent is still affordable. I was in the Socialist Unity Party for a long time and now I am also in the Leftist Party, because itâs the only party that really pays attention to social issues. The unsocial aspect of politics is namely the reason why rightwing populism and rightwing extremism and fascism have risen again. I am myself of the opinion that we canât take in every foreigner. It isnât possible anymore. There isnât enough money for social spending. They can come as tourists, and then they should go back to their homelands. I have nothing against that. The Syrians sometimes misbehave pretty badly. The police have had to intervene a couple times. If thereâs a fight, they grab a knife immediately.
In the GDR, there used to be an official closing hour. All the restaurants and bars had to be closed from 11pm to 6am. They did that because the people were supposed to work, they were supposed to come well rested to work. I thought that was better. There were only exceptions on Saturday and Sunday, and the police came in once and a while nevertheless and looked at IDs. Likewise, I am for the borders being guarded again. It really wouldnât hurt me if I had to reach into my pocket and show my ID. People who are being looked for disappear otherwise. I am for an open border, but it should be checked.

I always stand with my newspapers in front of the Frauenkirche. In the first half of the month, it always goes best. After that, there arenât that many people who buy a newspaper. You can say itâs worth it. It improves the home budget. I have also written articles for the paper. I have to say, my articles are respected because they get to the bottom of social problems. It is a street newspaper, and thatâs what belongs in street newspapers.

For example, I wrote about May 8th. After the surrender of the army, the women, often hungry, went out on the street and removed the rubble. We children, because we werenât yet going to school, were allowed to go along. With our little wagons and our little picks, we dug out the bricks, stacked and brought them for the rubble women. One day, two trucks full of Soviet soldiers, armed with picks and shovels came. They first chased us away. When the Soviet officers saw that we built up all sorts of bricks, they pointed us toward a pile where it wasnât so dangerous. Then came the breakfast break, and the Soviets saw that many women didnât have sandwiches. The Soviet soldiers sat down with the women and shared their breakfast bread. Then someone went to the post office and called the base. Then at lunch, a small truck came with a field kitchen attached to the back. Do you know what a delicacy peas and bacon were at that time? We children also got some. There was enough there. A lot of parents called their children away. They said, âYou donât need to eat that. You get enough to eat from us.â My grandma did that too. Parents were starving themselves in order to give their children enough to eat. The Soviet officers said if I would come down, I should bring a pot. I stole a pot from my grandma, and he filled the pot with peas and bacon. My grandma wanted to empty it into the toilet. I said, âDonât do that. Wait first until grandpa comes home.â Grandpa tasted it and said, âThis is good food. Why do you want to throw it away?â So the next day, we had food. That was what it was like 1945. We started hard, while over in the West â they had the Marshall plan. They got everything for free."

"I spent my whole life in Dresden. I had a nice childhood. We didnât have to go without during the GDR â sure, we were a little short of coffee and chocolate, but we had enough to eat. I had photo equipment that cost me 1,500 GDR marks. I still have my cassette recorder. I finally had an account with over 160,000 GDR marks. We got 3.25% interest. I could pay my rent without having to work. You see what we have to pay for rent today. In the GDR, housing was a human right, just like the right to work. I still have the constitution at home.

I live in Prohlis. My rent is still affordable. I was in the Socialist Unity Party for a long time and now I am also in the Leftist Party, because itâs the only party that really pays attention to social issues. The unsocial aspect of politics is namely the reason why rightwing populism and rightwing extremism and fascism have risen again. I am myself of the opinion that we canât take in every foreigner. It isnât possible anymore. There isnât enough money for social spending. They can come as tourists, and then they should go back to their homelands. I have nothing against that. The Syrians sometimes misbehave pretty badly. The police have had to intervene a couple times. If thereâs a fight, they grab a knife immediately.
In the GDR, there used to be an official closing hour. All the restaurants and bars had to be closed from 11pm to 6am. They did that because the people were supposed to work, they were supposed to come well rested to work. I thought that was better. There were only exceptions on Saturday and Sunday, and the police came in once and a while nevertheless and looked at IDs. Likewise, I am for the borders being guarded again. It really wouldnât hurt me if I had to reach into my pocket and show my ID. People who are being looked for disappear otherwise. I am for an open border, but it should be checked.

I always stand with my newspapers in front of the Frauenkirche. In the first half of the month, it always goes best. After that, there arenât that many people who buy a newspaper. You can say itâs worth it. It improves the home budget. I have also written articles for the paper. I have to say, my articles are respected because they get to the bottom of social problems. It is a street newspaper, and thatâs what belongs in street newspapers.

For example, I wrote about May 8th. After the surrender of the army, the women, often hungry, went out on the street and removed the rubble. We children, because we werenât yet going to school, were allowed to go along. With our little wagons and our little picks, we dug out the bricks, stacked and brought them for the rubble women. One day, two trucks full of Soviet soldiers, armed with picks and shovels came. They first chased us away. When the Soviet officers saw that we built up all sorts of bricks, they pointed us toward a pile where it wasnât so dangerous. Then came the breakfast break, and the Soviets saw that many women didnât have sandwiches. The Soviet soldiers sat down with the women and shared their breakfast bread. Then someone went to the post office and called the base. Then at lunch, a small truck came with a field kitchen attached to the back. Do you know what a delicacy peas and bacon were at that time? We children also got some. There was enough there. A lot of parents called their children away. They said, âYou donât need to eat that. You get enough to eat from us.â My grandma did that too. Parents were starving themselves in order to give their children enough to eat. The Soviet officers said if I would come down, I should bring a pot. I stole a pot from my grandma, and he filled the pot with peas and bacon. My grandma wanted to empty it into the toilet. I said, âDonât do that. Wait first until grandpa comes home.â Grandpa tasted it and said, âThis is good food. Why do you want to throw it away?â So the next day, we had food. That was what it was like 1945. We started hard, while over in the West â they had the Marshall plan. They got everything for free."

"I was trained as a train track builder. I had barely finished my training when the official doctor from the German railway came and said, âNo more. Circulation disorderâ¦ something with my kneeâ¦ itâs too risky to work on the tracks, industrial safety conditions.â Back then, the German railway wouldnât offer you anything else. So I went to Bauelemente Dorfhain. I was in circuit board manufacturing and put together small devices. A lot of things were used in military technology. After the reunification, well, the Japanese and Chinese were cheaper. Although I have to say that just before the end of the GDR, we had the most modern machines. They came from the West. Those were a godsend for the former West Germans. They bought everything for a euro. Machines gone, and I was unemployed. I have been unemployed since 1993.
I had two retraining courses since. First, in the garden and landscape architecture. That was just mowing the lawn and shovelling snow in the winter. In the second one, you could learn a little bit. Paving. That was more interesting. We were partially already employed as support for firms for garden and landscape architecture. During the first retraining course, we mostly just sat in trailers.

In 2002, I was living in Freital and I was caught totally off-guard by the floods. Everything gone. There was water half-a-meter deep in my apartment. I had to move out. There were no other apartments that would work in Freital. Then I moved to Gorbitz. Itâs definitely flood-proof. I live there in a skyscraper. A lot of people say that they would never move in to one, but I was happy to get an affordable apartment. Gorbitz is central; buses and trams go to the city from there, or you can go to the Erzgebirge with a bus. I was on Hartz IV for a long time back then.

I have been selling drObs for three years. With my speech problems, I am inhibited from speaking to people. I just stand there with my newspapers, and if someone buys it, they buy it, and if they donât buy it, itâs not a problem â like that. I do it because I became depressed because of my unemployment. I didnât dare go out of the apartment â only when it was necessary â shopping or to government agencies. I had to go out because of the newspaper. And it brings a bit of money into my bank account. I have places where there are people walking by, and I also have place where my usual customers are, for example on Schillerplatz or Alaunpark, where there are little markets. I donât want to miss contact with people anymore. At first, I was scared how people would react. I also saw it as a kind of begging at first, but now, I feel like a distributor. In the beginning, I thought âNow, finally buy a paper!â But now, I just stand there with my papers. Sometimes, people give me encouragement or say something nice. I only have my small disability pension. That goes mainly for rent, energy, insurance, TV, and telephone."

"drObs is a street newspaper that just celebrated its 20th anniversary. The project was started by people who wanted to do something for homeless people and people affected by poverty. There have been highs and lows, and I think itâs almost a miracle that the whole project still exists today. But it is a worthwhile project and deserves even more attention.

The street newspaper is itself there to give people who suffer from poverty â the long-time unemployed, people who are mentally ill or have addictions or are homeless â an opportunity. We have about thirty sellers, from whom fifteen are regulars. Only a few of our sellers are actually homeless. We have mainly disability pensioners and the long-time unemployed. We also have a few EU nationals. For them, itâs especially difficult because they fall through the social safety net. They really have to sell newspapers in order to pay their living costs.

The project was conceived with a low threshold. There are very few obligations for the sellers. They can come here, we check that they are actually in our target group, and then they can immediately start. They buy the paper for 1 euro and sell it for 1.70 on the street. On one side, we need the money to support the association itself. On the other side, there is also how they value it. If I buy something, then I am not supplicant; instead, I have money â I am buying something. That is the most important thing for my work â that you encounter people with respect and value. I think they often have the experience that that is not the case. They donât have to buy the newspaper here. Itâs their free choice. Some of them only buy five newspapers, others sell a hundred. Itâs totally different. Everyone has the opportunity to use it in the way that works best for them. There are no conditions, only conditions of how they sell them. They have to be polite, have enough change, donât beg, and donât consume any alcohol.

I am the social worker here. I take care of the sellers, their concerns, their worries. I also take care of the networking work. I like the work a lot, because itâs so multifaceted. I get along with the sellers. I would say that I have a good relationship with all of them. Itâs different how people let themselves be approached. There are some who are really open and positive, and there are others who are more reserved, where you have to approach them carefully. You have more a polite, distanced relationship. But you donât have to have a very intimate relationship to all of them. 

The good thing about drObs, I find, is that you donât have any form of pressure. They can decide freely how they would like it to be. "drObs is a street newspaper that just celebrated its 20th anniversary. The project was started by people who wanted to do something for homeless people and people affected by poverty. The street newspaper is itself there to give people who suffer from poverty â the long-time unemployed, people who are mentally ill or have addictions or are homeless â an opportunity. We have about thirty sellers, from whom fifteen are regulars. Only a few of our sellers are actually homeless. We have mainly disability pensioners and the long-time unemployed. We also have a few EU nationals. For them, itâs especially difficult because they fall through the social safety net. They really have to sell newspapers in order to pay their living costs.

The project was conceived with a low threshold. There are very few obligations for the sellers. They can come here, we check that they are actually in our target group, and then they can immediately start. They buy the paper for 1 euro and sell it for 1.70 on the street. If I buy something, then I am not supplicant; instead, I have money â I am buying something. That is the most important thing for my work â that you encounter people with respect and value. I think they often have the experience that that is not the case. They donât have to buy the newspaper here. Itâs their free choice. Some of them only buy five newspapers, others sell a hundred. There are some who are really open and positive, and there are others who are more reserved, where you have to approach them carefully. You have more a polite, distanced relationship. But you donât have to have a very intimate relationship to all of them. 

The good thing about drObs, I find, is that you donât have any form of pressure. They can decide freely how they would like it to be. You could also â if the sellers were up for it â support the sellers more intensively. You could say, âI will visit you once a week on the street and then weâll chat a little.â A kind of seller-sponsorship. I would like to do more project-oriented things with people who have the desire to do it. You wouldnât have to be a member of the association. It would be great if people who were interested just got in touch with us."

"I was born here in Dresden. My mother died at age 20 from tuberculosis. I donât know my father. I grew up with my grandmother. She was the manager of a retail outlet, and she had to work a lot, so I went to a childrenâs home in Goppeln when I was a year old. I stayed there until I four years old. Then my grandmother brought me home. I was there for a while, but my grandmother had to work, and I was all alone, so she decided â because she was Catholic â to put me in a Catholic childrenâs home in a cloister in GÃ¶rlitz, and I stayed there until I was sixteen.
It wasnât good there. Back then, I was somehow an outcast. The other children had foster parents whom they could visit during the vacations, but I didnât have any. They locked me in a room, and everyone else could go on vacation. At some point, my grandmother said that I could visit her during the vacations. Back then, I didnât have anyone besides my grandmother. As a child, I didnât have friends or a girlfriend at all. In the school, I was excluded, because I wasnât allowed to go to the socialist youth club (Free German Youth) because I was Catholic. I wanted to play music, play guitar, but I wasn't allowed to because it was not Catholic somehow. What I was allowed to do was go to school and go to the chapel to pray. Or you had to go to the chapel an hour before school to pray. That was nothing for me. As a child, I just goofed off. They were all nuns, not educators or anything, and when I goofed off, I got a thrashing from the nuns. A lot of other things happened that I canât talk about. You always hear about it on the news that they are abusing children. It was similar there too. When I was seventeen, I just packed my bag and went back to Dresden. My grandmother said, âWhat are you doing here? You were supposed to become a nun.â

I learned about drObs from my former partner. He couldnât read or write. He went to school with someone and asked him if he had a job for his girlfriend. When he came home and told me that he had a job for me as a salesperson who had to approach people on the street, I said I didnât know if I could do it. But I nevertheless went to the boss and said that I would like start, and I hoped that I could do it. She gave me twenty newspapers, and I went with them to the Neustadt. First, I just watched how they sold them. Then they said that I should do it alone, but they would stand by me. I was surprised how well I did. In the Neustadt, people are a little different than other places, friendlier. I like it when people are friendly, better than when they make a face or give dumb answers. I donât like to fight with people, so I swallow it. I just smile. Once, someone took a paper from me and threw it away. I just had to stop because of that â I couldnât work anymore that day. But in general, I donât have problems. Otherwise, I wouldnât have done it for nine years. I think I seem friendly. I am a smiley type. I always sell my papers. I used to sell more papers, but I canât do that anymore for health reasons. I take a hundred papers at the most. These days everything is so expensive, and I also want to get something out of life. I would like to travel, which is something I couldnât do for years."

That was the hook for us: âHey the âLouiseâ is involved, we have to go."

It could be people who are attacked because of their political opinion â so politically divergent thinkers â leftists, punks, etc. Then we also advise people who are affected by homelessness, people with disabilities, Sinti and Roma. But we advise people affected by racism and people who are attacked because of their sexual orientation as well. We offer support in the legal processes. We go with people to the police and support them there, at witness statements and in court proceedings. There we see that there are proxies who can offer legal support.

They are going for a walk, are at the train station, are somewhere on the edge of a demonstration and then are violently attacked. Usually it happens spontaneously, and there is no prehistory.

For the past two years, we have had online advising. You can write your story anonymously, you don't have to say where or when, and you can get help and support. We set this up because this harassment triggers fear and shame. We often see that women especially are ashamed to talk about it, that they are the victims â that no one helped, that they were in the middle of it. In that way, online advising can help to overcome the resistance to coming to face-to-face advising.

Since 2015, since Pegida and the racist mobilization started, our target group has shifted. Before 2015, it was mainly young punks, leftists, those who were active against racism, against Nazis, and since 2015, itâs mainly been people with a migration background, people of color, refugees, who are attacked. The number of attacks here in Saxony exploded. The centers of criminality are especially Dresden and Leipzig, in terms of racist violence â but also in cities in which a mobilization has taken place â Chemnitz, Heidenau, Freital, Bautzen. Since attacks have started increasing, we have also grown. We have a lot to do to keep up with all of the advising. What is a big concern for us and what we hear from the affected people is that there is no civil courage. So, when people are attacked, they arenât usually helped. There are attacks on pregnant women on Prager StraÃe and no one does anything. And that is actually what really hurts people more. That everyone watches and no one helps and supports. Itâs not about stopping the attack somehow but at least going to the person and asking if everything is ok, if they need support. If that means a glass of water or a tissue â it helps just to be there. And I want to actually encourage everyone that if they see something, to go to the person and support them or to make it public.

I donât want to start again with Saxony bashing, but you really have to say that because of the long rule of the CDU government, through such statements as, âSaxony is immune to rightwing extremism,â itâs come about that rightwing structures arenât the focus of police measures, and so they can grow, better organize, and structure themselves. âOriginally, I was a patent professional. A friend from Frankfurt told me about this exchange organization and what she had experienced there, and I was totally excited about it. I chose this profession, because I myself was an au pair abroad after high school, in a suburb of Chicago. That was one of the nicest years of my life. I can really recommend, especially for girls, who donât always have the opportunity to go abroad as an exchange student, to go as an au pair, which is something that boys do less often. Since then, itâs been in my head, and I think itâs cool now having something else to do with the subject, although I myself canât travel so much because I have a family. Itâs totally fun for me to make it possible for other people. I will push my own kids in that direction at the right time. Of course, itâs not always so nice â I also had girls who switched families. But the relationship of good to bad is maybe eighty to twenty.

We always notice one real effect of exchange: the parents and also the kids get a totally different view of the world, whether itâs eating customs, etiquette, the way that you talk to each other, or also the openness of some nations that can be contagious â the Germans are more reserved. I think that everyone involved can change in a positive way in this time. For me, it was that I became more open. I was shy until this au pair year, and I am now more self-confident, more independent, and I found out for myself what kind of people I like, who I want to be friends with.

We are really new in Dresden and are looking for host families in the city and surroundings. Of course, we are trying to make ourselves known. Because itâs a totally new location, you ask acquaintances and relatives or in your childrenâs school or kindergarten. If host families get in touch with us, I first call them to see if it will work. Superficially, itâs of course the case that theoretically everyone could be a host family â only we are a little picky with single men. Ab diesem Zeitpunkt war ich sehr frustriert, weil es keinen Ort gab, an dem ich mich sicher fÃ¼hlen konnte. Die KriminalitÃ¤t in Caracas ist brutal. Ab 18 Uhr haben wir eine selbst auferlegte Ausgangssperre.

Ich habe mich entschieden, als Freiwilliger bei einer evangelischen Kirche in NÃ¼rnberg als Musiklehrer zu arbeiten. Ich bin auch Musiker. Ich bin nach Deutschland mit fast meinen gesamten Papieren gekommen, falls es die Chance gibt, sich fÃ¼r ein Studentenvisum zu bewerben. Mir hat nur mein Studienbuch gefehlt. In der Kirche habe ich einen Arzt gefunden, der mir geholfen hat, mich fÃ¼r einen Platz an der UniversitÃ¤t zu bewerben. Meine Mutter ist fast jeden Tag losgegangen, um nach meinem Studienbuch zu fragen. Ihr wurde gesagt, dass die Unterlagen verloren gegangen sind.

Eines Tages war meine Mutter wieder dort und ein Typ aus dem AuÃenministerium sagte zu ihr: âDie Dokumente tauchen wieder auf, wenn du bezahlst.â Meine Mutter fand das hanebÃ¼chen und hat einen Onkel angerufen, der fÃ¼r die Polizei arbeitet. Sie sind zusammen hingegangen. Der Mann im Ministerium hatte gewisse Verbindungen, und meine Mutter begann Drohungen zu erhalten. Sie sagten, sie hÃ¤tten meinen Namen und alles, und ich wÃ¼rde nie wieder in einem Krankenhaus arbeiten kÃ¶nnen, sie solle lieber ruhig sein.

Mein Freund, der mir geholfen hat, mich an der Uni einzuschreiben, hat davon erfahren. Er meinte, es wÃ¤re riskant fÃ¼r mich, zurÃ¼ck zu gehen, und hat mir empfohlen, dass ich Asyl beantrage."
