--
"I was studying radiology at the Central University in Venezuela at a time when there was constant protests against the government. I lived in a neighborhood where people were very active pro-government, and they constantly organized events, which they said were to bring relief to the community, but they always required that you put your name on a list and checked whether you were a member of the Socialist United Party. In my eyes, it was all to see who thought differently.

I used to do the E.R. shift at 'El Algodonal' hospital. I got a patient around 2 am. I was waiting and waiting, and the orderly wouldn't come to pick him up. I made several calls to the floor where he was, and nobody answered. Then finally someone picked up the phone and said: 'Eric, lock the door and turn off the lights.' The patient was a demonstrator who was shot and some pro-government group broke into the hospital to take him with them. It's such a complex situation when you are taking care of somebody, but then your own life is at risk even for just knowing what happened to that person. From that moment on, I became very frustrated because there was no place where I could feel safe. Criminality in Caracas is brutal. We have there an self-imposed curfew starting at 6 pm.

I decided to work as a volunteer at an evangelical church in Nuremberg as a music teacher. I am also a musician. I came to Germany with almost all my papers ready in case there was a chance I could apply for a student visa. I was just missing my school transcripts. At the church, I met a doctor who helped me to apply for a spot at the university. My mom went almost every day to ask for my papers. They said the papers were lost.

One day, my mom went back, and a guy working in the ministry of exterior affairs told her: 'The documents will appear if you pay'. My mom found that to be outrageous and called an uncle who works for the police department, and they went there together. The man in the ministry had certain connections, and my mom started receiving threats. They said they had my name and everything, and I wouldn't be able to work again in a hospital, and she better be quiet.

My friend who has trying to help me enrol in the university heard about this and said that it would be a risk for me to go back and recommended that I apply for asylum."

Part 1/2

"I am an instructor at the Women's Education House. I do activities there and support women without gainful employment and women who just have problems finding their center. The cuts that are being made by the city council would affect our house. That wouldn't be good. The Women's Education House invites women to inform themselves about forms and structures of female learning and to further educate themselves. 

There are different areas in our house, for example the women's city archive, that is concerned with the history of women who have achieved something great -- so that women can vote, so that they can abort, so that they can work, so that women are perceived at all in this society. It's about preventing women from getting depressed, or if they are depressed, that they are gotten out of their depression and given a new orientation.

I myself had heavy anxiety problems, fell out of the workforce and couldn't function anymore. It was a place where I also got help and where I -- through affirmation and support -- am now able again to find the strength to help women."

Ich hatte ein Zimmer in einer Herberge, und ich durfte Deutsche kennenlernen. NatÃ¼rlich war uns klar, dass wir als Menschen aus kapitalistischen LÃ¤ndern immer unter Beobachtung standen. Ich habe am FlieÃband gearbeitet und leere Flaschen rausgefischt. UngefÃ¤hr um fÃ¼nf oder sechs Uhr konnten wir in der Kantine eine Pause machen. Man konnte immer beobachten, wie die Kubaner zusammensitzen, die Mosambikaner saÃen fÃ¼r sich, die Angolaner saÃen zusammen, und die Deutschen genauso. Ich war der einzige Inder, also habe ich alleine gesessen. Ich habe einen Kubaner gefragt, warum das so ist, und er meinte: âDas sind die Kategorien, nach denen wir hier sitzen mÃ¼ssen.â Es war Vorschrift, sich so getrennt zu setzen. Ich hatte den ganzen Tisch fÃ¼r mich alleine, ich war der KÃ¶nig meines Tischs. Ein deutsches MÃ¤dchen hat sich manchmal zu mir gesetzt. Sie wurde von ihrem Chef ausgeschimpft, weil die sich zu einem AuslÃ¤nder gesetzt hat, aber sie mochte mich sehr. Sie hat mir immer Kuchen gebracht.

Ich habe mit meiner Promotion 1988 angefangen und war 1991 fertig. Ich wollte eigentlich zurÃ¼ck nach Indien, aber ich habe mich in eine Deutsche verliebt. Sie lebt nicht mehr. Wir haben uns hier im Rundkino im Februar 1986 kennengelernt. Sie war die schÃ¶nste Frau, die ich je gesehen habe. Ich habe sie gesehen und nicht gezÃ¶gert. Ich bin einfach zu ihr rÃ¼ber gegangen. Sie dachte, dass sie mit den hygienischen VerhÃ¤ltnissen nicht klarkommt, den Bettwanzen und Kakerlaken.

Unser aktueller Imam ist Aga Khan IV. Ismailiten haben kein Land, wir sind Ã¼ber die ganze Welt verteilt, in Kanada, den USA. Die Ismailiten sind sehr liberale Moslems. I had the whole table to myself, I was the king of my table. One German girl would sit next to me sometimes; she got scolded by the boss for sitting next to a foreigner, but she liked me very much. You are not afraid of approaching new people. She didnât want to come to India. She thought she couldnât deal with the hygienic conditions, the bed bugs, the cockroaches.

Ismailis donât have a country; we are scattered all over the world. In Canada, the USA. The Ismaili are very liberal Muslims. They are more oriented toward Western culture. They are highly educated. Because they donât have a state, they adapt themselves to the cultures where they live. The women donât wear headscarves; fasting on Ramadan is not an obligation. The Ismailis came to India in the 13th century where they studied Hindu philosophy, and then they converted our ancestors."

My fatherâs business went really well, but he didnât like the apartheid system, so we moved back to India.

"Ich lebe seit meinem neunten Lebensjahr in Dresden. Ich bin Ingenieur, Informatiker und Historiker. Ich engagiere mich - und deswegen bin ich heute hier in der Centrum Galerie - seit vielen Jahren in einem Verein âMemorare Pacem - Gesellschaft fÃ¼r Friedenskulturâ. Der hat es sich zur Aufgabe gemacht, generationenÃ¼bergreifend, interkulturell und interreligiÃ¶s fÃ¼r Friedenskultur zu werben. Wir verbinden das ganz stark mit der Auseinandersetzung mit Vergangenheit - nicht allein, aber eben auch. Wir unternehmen AktivitÃ¤ten im Bereich historisch-politische Bildung, Kunstaktionen, SchÃ¼lerbegegnungen, aber auch wissenschaftliche und Diskussionsformate.

Was wir die gesamte Woche Ã¼ber hier in der Centrum Galerie machen, ist ein groÃes Event. Es geht darum, dass wir die Dresdnerinnen und Dresdner einladen, herzukommen und mit uns zusammen darÃ¼ber nachzudenken, welche Vergangenheit unsere Zukunft braucht. Man kann sich das vorstellen wie ein permanentes GesprÃ¤chsangebot. Es ist immer mindestens einer von uns hier. Man kann miteinander reden und es gibt viele unterschiedliche AktivitÃ¤ten wÃ¤hrend dieser Tage, Dinge wie Literaturlesungen, Performances, Konzerte. Am Freitag wird es ein Peace Slam geben. Das sind alles kurze Impulse, aber eigentlich geht es darum, einander zu begegnen und ins GesprÃ¤ch zu kommen.

Es gibt tatsÃ¤chlich nur eine Vergangenheit, aber es gibt ganz viele Erinnerungen daran. Es gibt viel, an das man erinnern kann, aber es gibt noch viel mehr, das vergessen wird und das man vergessen muss. Und es geht darum, was man fÃ¼r die Zukunft nicht vergessen mÃ¶chte aus unserer unendlich komplexen Vergangenheit. Wir glauben, dass, wenn wir verantwortlich mit unserer gemeinsamen Erinnerung umgehen, dann mÃ¼ssen wir zuerst die Frage stellen, wozu erinnern wir. Wenn wir das beantworten - zu welchem Zweck und zu welchem Zweck auch nicht -, dann haben wir starke Indizien dafÃ¼r, was wir erinnern wollen. Und dann ergibt sich die Form quasi zwangslÃ¤ufig. FÃ¼r uns ist ein verantwortlicher Umgang mit Erinnerung, einer, der sich auf Ziele richtet, die wir durch unsere freiheitlich-demokratische Grundordnung gedeckt sehen. Das heiÃt, wir mÃ¶chten erinnern fÃ¼r eine Stadt, die sich als friedlich, demokratisch und menschenwÃ¼rdig versteht und sich genau so entwickelt. Das ist der Rahmen, und der ist sehr weit. Da passen viele ganz unterschiedliche Erinnerungen rein - ganz private, ganz zart, ganz empathisch, wie auch groÃe Geschichten, kollektive ErzÃ¤hlungen, ganze IdentitÃ¤ten kann man da hineinpacken. Aber es gibt eben auch Dinge, die lassen wir drauÃen. Ziele, die wir nicht verfolgen, Ziele, die wir eben nicht fÃ¼r verantwortlich halten. Immer dann, wenn Erinnerung gebraucht wird um fÃ¼r Nationalismus, Rassismus, antidemokratische Haltungen zu werben, ist das auÃerhalb des Rahmens, den wir intellektuell gezeichnet haben. Und dann wÃ¼rden wir einem solchen Erinnern entgegen treten.

Erinnern hier in Dresden, an gerade diesem Datum und gerade mit dieser ErzÃ¤hlung, ist eben ganz besonders konfliktbeladen. Ich habe persÃ¶nlich viele Jahre dazu geforscht. Dieses Konfliktpotenzial kommt aus der starken symbolischen Aufladung dieses Erinnerns. Und die wiederum hat mit politischer Instrumentalisierung zu tun. Die Angriffe auf Dresden sind sofort schon am 14. Februar 1945 politisch benutzt worden, zunÃ¤chst fÃ¼r die Kriegspropaganda der Nazis. Da sind diese ErzÃ¤hlbilder entstanden, die wir heute noch erinnern. Der Wortlaut, mit dem wir an diese BombennÃ¤chte erinnern, ist durch Goebbels Propaganda geprÃ¤gt, bis heute, ohne dass wir das so richtig reflektieren. Nach dem Ende des Zweiten Weltkriegs hÃ¤tte man das dekonstruieren kÃ¶nnen und andere ErzÃ¤hlungen an diese Stelle setzen, aber das hat damals die DDR nicht getan, sondern sie hat diese ErzÃ¤hlung einfach aufgegriffen. Es gab in den 1950er und 1960er Jahren gewaltige Propagandainszenierungen, und dann wieder in den 1980er Jahren. Dresden ist dann Ã¼ber alle diese Auseinandersetzungen, die nach 1990 noch mal viel vielfÃ¤ltiger geworden sind, zu so einer Art geschichtspolitischen BÃ¼hne geworden, auf der jedes Jahr alle aufmarschieren und sich medialer Aufmerksamkeit sicher sein kÃ¶nnen. Dresden ist zu einem Geschichtssymbol geworden. Und wie jedes Symbol ist es immer deutungsoffen. Man kann mit diesem Symbol so ziemlich alles begrÃ¼nden. Ich kann da Nationalismus und Revanchismus, Geschichtsrevisionismus genauso reinpacken wie Friedensengagement, Demokratiebekenntnis, Empathie und Zuwendung, SolidaritÃ¤t unter Menschen. Das macht das Spezifikum dieses Dresdner Erinnerns aus, eine hohe Symbolkraft, und die haben andere StÃ¤dte nicht. Das ist kein Verdienst der Dresdner. Das haben die Dresdner nicht fÃ¼r sich produziert. Das hat auch nichts damit zu tun, dass man in Dresden ganz larmoyant wÃ¤re oder ganz besonders heimatverliebt. Die WÃ¼rzburger, die genauso schlimm zerstÃ¶rt waren wie Dresden, sind genauso heimatverliebt und erinnern das auch, aber sie sind nicht so stark politisch instrumentalisiert worden ist. Das ist ein Spezifikum von Dresden.
 Wir mÃ¼ssen einfach mehr sprechen. Es ist allemal besser, miteinander zu reden, egal welche politische Haltung man hat, als einander aus den SchÃ¼tzengrÃ¤ben die Losungen entgegenzuhalten. Das braucht die Stadt, die braucht eine GesprÃ¤chskultur. Die braucht sie nicht nur am 13. Februar, die braucht sie auch sonst. Es gibt genÃ¼gend Konflikte in dieser Stadt, die eben auch nicht richtig produktiv gelÃ¶st werden, weil uns tatsÃ¤chlich so ein wertschÃ¤tzender Diskurs fÃ¼reinander abhanden gekommen ist. Das ist schade, aber das hat nicht nur mit dem 13. Februar zu tun."

"I have lived in Dresden since I was eight. I am an engineer, computer scientist and historian. I have been involved â and thatâs why I am here in the Centrum Galerie â for many years in an association called âMemorare Pacem â Society for Peace Culture.â It has the task of campaigning â across the lines of generations, cultures, and religions â for a culture of peace. We connect this very strongly with engagement with history â not only, but also. We undertake activities that are historical-political education, art actions, student meet-ups, but also scientific and discussion formats.

The thing that we are doing the whole week here in the Centrum Galerie is a big event. Itâs about inviting Dresdeners to come here and think with us which idea of the past our future needs. You can picture it as a permanent offer of conversation. There is always at least one of us here. You can talk to each other, and there are many different activities during the days â things like literature readings, performances, concerts. On Friday, we will have a Peace Slam. They are all short boosts, but actually, itâs about encounter each other and getting into a conversation.

There is actually only one past, but there are many memories of it. There is a lot that you can remember, but there is even more that will be forgotten and that has to be forgotten. And we are asking what you donât want to forget from our endlessly complex past for the future. We believe that if we want behave responsibly with our collective memories then we have to initially ask the question of why we are remembering. If we answer that â for which purposes we want to remember and for which purposes we do not want to remember âthen we have a strong indication of what we want to remember. And then it is an inevitable result of the form of remembering. For us, a responsible way of handling memory is one that has the goal that is covered by our free democratic constitutional structure. That means, we would like to remember for a city that understands itself as peaceful, democratic, and values human worth and develops in that direction. This is the framework, and it is very broad. A lot of different memories fit within it â totally private, very tender, very empathetic, but also large stories, collective narratives, you can fit whole identities within it. But there are also things that we leave outside. Goals that we canât follow. Goals that we donât believe are responsible. Always when the memories are used to campaign for nationalism, racism, and anti-democratic attitudes â that is outside of the framework that we have intellectually drawn. And then we would stand up against that kind of remembrance.

Remembrance here in Dresden, especially on this date and with this narrative, is loaded with conflict. I have personally researched it for many years. The potential for conflict comes from the strongly symbolic charge of this remembrance. And that in turn has something to do with political instrumentalization. The attacks on Dresden were already being politically used on February 14, 1945 â first of all, for the Nazi war propaganda. Thatâs how these narrative images were created, which we still remember today. The wording with which we continue to remember the bombing night is shaped by Goebbelâs propaganda without really reflecting on it. After the end of the Second World War, you could have deconstructed it and placed different narratives in its place, but the GDR didnât do that. Instead, they just picked up this narrative. In the 1950s and 60s, there were huge propaganda actions and then again in the 1980s. Dresden then became a kind of political-historical stage because of all of these debates that became much more diverse after 1990. And every year, everyone marches on this stage and can be sure of media attention. We have participants here who arenât bound to the history of this place, who donât come from Dresden. Instead, they come because they know if they express themselves â preferably, of course, very provocatively â here, then it is perceived in the media, wide beyond the city framework.

Dresden has become a historical symbol. And like every symbol, it is open to interpretation. You can base pretty much everything on this symbol. I can fit in nationalism, revanchism, and historical revisionism just as much as engagement with peace, commitment to democracy, empathy and care, solidarity among people. That determines the specific nature of the Dresden remembrance, a high symbolic power, and other cities donât have it. You canât credit the Dresdeners with it. The Dresdeners didnât produce it. It also doesnât have anything to do with Dresdeners being especially sentimental or especially in love with their hometown. The people of WÃ¼rzburg, which was just as badly destroyed as Dresden, are just as in love with their hometown and remember just as much, but they havenât been as strongly politically instrumentalized. "I have lived in Dresden since I was eight. I am an engineer, computer scientist and historian. I have been involved â and thatâs why I am here in the Centrum Galerie â for many years in an association called âMemorare Pacem â Society for Peace Culture.â It has the task of campaigning â across the lines of generations, cultures, and religions â for a culture of peace. We connect this very strongly with engagement with history â not only, but also. We undertake activities that are historical-political education, art actions, student meet-ups, but also scientific and discussion formats.

The thing that we are doing the whole week here in the Centrum Galerie is a big event. Itâs about inviting Dresdeners to come here and think with us which idea of the past our future needs. You can picture it as a permanent offer of conversation. There is always at least one of us here. You can talk to each other, and there are many different activities during the days â things like literature readings, performances, concerts. On Friday, we will have a Peace Slam. They are all short boosts, but actually, itâs about encounter each other and getting into a conversation.

There is actually only one past, but there are many memories of it. There is a lot that you can remember, but there is even more that will be forgotten and that has to be forgotten. And we are asking what you donât want to forget from our endlessly complex past for the future. We believe that if we want behave responsibly with our collective memories then we have to initially ask the question of why we are remembering. If we answer that â for which purposes we want to remember and for which purposes we do not want to remember âthen we have a strong indication of what we want to remember. And then it is an inevitable result of the form of remembering. For us, a responsible way of handling memory is one that has the goal that is covered by our free democratic constitutional structure. That means, we would like to remember for a city that understands itself as peaceful, democratic, and values human worth and develops in that direction. This is the framework, and it is very broad. A lot of different memories fit within it â totally private, very tender, very empathetic, but also large stories, collective narratives, you can fit whole identities within it. But there are also things that we leave outside. Goals that we canât follow. Goals that we donât believe are responsible. Always when the memories are used to campaign for nationalism, racism, and anti-democratic attitudes â that is outside of the framework that we have intellectually drawn. And then we would stand up against that kind of remembrance.

Remembrance here in Dresden, especially on this date and with this narrative, is loaded with conflict. I have personally researched it for many years. The potential for conflict comes from the strongly symbolic charge of this remembrance. And that in turn has something to do with political instrumentalization. The attacks on Dresden were already being politically used on February 14, 1945 â first of all, for the Nazi war propaganda. Thatâs how these narrative images were created, which we still remember today. The wording with which we continue to remember the bombing night is shaped by Goebbelâs propaganda without really reflecting on it. After the end of the Second World War, you could have deconstructed it and placed different narratives in its place, but the GDR didnât do that. Instead, they just picked up this narrative. In the 1950s and 60s, there were huge propaganda actions and then again in the 1980s. Dresden then became a kind of political-historical stage because of all of these debates that became much more diverse after 1990. And every year, everyone marches on this stage and can be sure of media attention. We have participants here who arenât bound to the history of this place, who donât come from Dresden. Instead, they come because they know if they express themselves â preferably, of course, very provocatively â here, then it is perceived in the media, wide beyond the city framework.

Dresden has become a historical symbol. And like every symbol, it is open to interpretation. You can base pretty much everything on this symbol. I can fit in nationalism, revanchism, and historical revisionism just as much as engagement with peace, commitment to democracy, empathy and care, solidarity among people. That determines the specific nature of the Dresden remembrance, a high symbolic power, and other cities donât have it. You canât credit the Dresdeners with it. The Dresdeners didnât produce it. It also doesnât have anything to do with Dresdeners being especially sentimental or especially in love with their hometown. The people of WÃ¼rzburg, which was just as badly destroyed as Dresden, are just as in love with their hometown and remember just as much, but they havenât been as strongly politically instrumentalized. That is the specific thing about Dresden.

We just have to speak more. It is better to talk with each other, not matter which political position you have, than to yell the solutions at each other out of our trenches. Thatâs what the city needs, it needs a conversation culture. It doesnât just need it on February 13th. It also needs it otherwise. There are enough conflicts in this city that arenât really productively solved, because such a respectful discourse has gotten lost. Itâs a shame, but it doesnât have anything to do with February 13th."

âIch arbeite beim Panometer. In Dresden-Reick gibt es dieses alte Gasometer, in dem riesige Panoramen ausgestellt werden. Es ist eine sehr emotionale Variante, wie man Geschichte auch vermitteln kann. Das Kind sieht natÃ¼rlich etwas komplett anderes, ist begeistert von Objekten oder Dingen, die es da erkennen kann, wÃ¤hrend der Professor natÃ¼rlich die ZusammenhÃ¤nge erkennt und ganz andere SchlÃ¼sse daraus ziehen kann. Das ist eine sehr intelligente Art der Wissensvermittlung.

Das Besondere in Dresden ist, dass es zwei Panoramen gibt, die sich immer abwechseln, einmal Dresden im Barock und dann Dresden 1945. Dresden im Barock zeigt das augusteische Zeitalter, also das wofÃ¼r Dresden ein StÃ¼ck weit steht beziehungsweise wie sich Dresden selbst gern sieht oder wie es sich touristisch vermarktet. Dresden 1945 ist eigentlich das Gegenteil. Das ist ein sehr prÃ¤sentes Thema in der Stadt und eigentlich der Tiefpunkt, als diese barocke Pracht und der GroÃteil der Fassaden zerstÃ¶rt wurden. Man muss die beiden Panoramen im Zusammenhang betrachten, um die Stadt besser zu verstehen.

In dem Panorama von 1945 sieht man eine Momentaufnahme nach den schweren Bombenangriffen. Man sieht die GroÃflÃ¤chigkeit der ZerstÃ¶rung. Man erkennt, wie punktuell nur noch alte Strukturen vorhanden sind und wie groÃflÃ¤chig nach der ZerstÃ¶rung umgestaltet wurde. Diese gewachsene europÃ¤ische Stadt existiert in dem Sinne nicht mehr. Ein Viertel wurde jetzt neu rekonstruiert, aber da sieht man natÃ¼rlich, dass das neue Fassaden sind. Es dauert vielleicht 100 oder 150 Jahre, bis sich da eine gewisse Patina bildet.

Zum Panorama gibt es auch immer eine Begleitausstellung, die thematisiert, wie es dazu gekommen ist. Es sind einige interessante Punkte, die man nicht vergessen sollte, wenn man darÃ¼ber spricht. Dresden war bei vielen Sachen ganz vorn mit dabei. Hier fanden zum Beispiel die ersten BÃ¼cherverbrennungen statt. Hier gab es im Rathaus auch so eine Art VorlÃ¤uferausstellung zur groÃen Ausstellung âEntartete Kunstâ. Und es gab natÃ¼rlich viele Angriffe, die von Deutschland ausgegangen sind.

Dass das natÃ¼rlich am Ende zurÃ¼ckkommt, sollte nicht verwundern. An sich ist es ja nur konsequent. Beziehungsweise finde ich es etwas Ã¼berflÃ¼ssig, im Krieg nach Regeln zu fragen. Man kann einen Krieg mit Regeln machen - es gab die Kabinettskriege im 18. Jahrhundert, wo zwei ebenbÃ¼rtige Herrscher versucht haben, sich mit ihren Armeen auszumanÃ¶vrieren und dabei die eingesetzten Mittel nach MÃ¶glichkeit zu begrenzen -, aber sobald eine gewisse Grenze Ã¼berschritten ist - das sieht man im DreiÃigjÃ¤hrigen Krieg oder noch viel besser bei den Kriegen im 19. und 20. Jahrhundert - da wird nicht gefragt, darf ich das jetzt oder darf ich das nicht, sondern da wird einfach gemacht, um zu gewinnen. Ich glaube, es sollte jedem klar sein, dass, wenn so etwas einmal entfesselt ist, dass man dann nur Fersengeld geben kann, wenn einem sein Leben lieb ist.â

âI work at the Panometer. In Dresden-Reick, there is old gasometer in which giant panoramas are displayed. It is a very emotional way of conveying history. As the operators, we have had the experience that no matter who we show it to, whether kindergarteners or emeritus professors, everyone gets something out of it. The child will of course see something completely different, is excited about objects and things, which he or she can recognize, while the professor sees the connections and draws other conclusions out of it. Itâs a very intelligent way of conveying information.

The special thing about Dresden is that there are two panoramas, which always alternate â Dresden in the Baroque period and then Dresden 1945. Dresden in the Baroque period shows the August the Strong era â so what Dresden stands for or what Dresden likes to think of itself or market itself. Dresden 1945 is actually the opposite. It is a very current subject in the city and actually the low point when all the baroque finery and the majority of the facades were destroyed. You have to see both panoramas in connection in order to understand the city better.

In the panorama of 1945, you see a snapshot after the heavy bombing. You see the large scale of the destruction. You realize how selectively only a few old structures survived and how large-scale the reshaping of the city was after the destruction. This evolved European city doesnât exist in that sense anymore. An area is now reconstructed but you see of course that they are new facades. It will take maybe 100 or 150 years until they have a certain patina.

In the Panorama, there is always also an accompanying exhibition that thematizes how it came to that. There are some interesting points that you should not forget if you talk about it. Dresden was involved in a lot of things from the start. The first book burnings took place here. Here in the city hall, there was a kind of precursor exhibition to the âDegenerate Artâ exhibition. And there were of course many attacks that came from Germany.

Of course, it shouldnât be surprising that the attacks were returned in the end. It just follows. I think itâs somewhat superfluous to ask about rules during a war. You can conduct war with rules â there were the Cabinet Wars in the 18th century, where two rulers of noble birth tried to outmaneuver each other and thereby limit the employed means as far as possible â but as soon as a certain boundary is passed, you see it in the Thirty Years War or much better in the wars of the 19th and 20th century, no one asks, âMay I now? Or may I not?â Instead, things are just done to win. I think it should be clear to everyone that once something like that is unleashed, the only thing you can do is run away if you want to live.â

Wenn wir durch die Stadt laufen und Interviews fÃ¼hren, wissen wir meistens nicht, mit wem wir es zu tun haben. So war es auch bei diesem Mann, den wir auf dem Altmarkt an der GedenkstÃ¤tte fÃ¼r die Bombenangriffe getroffen haben. Mittlerweile glauben wir, herausgefunden zu haben, wer er ist. Trotzdem ist er ein Mensch in Dresden und wir finden es wichtig, zu zeigen, dass auch solche Menschen existieren, auch wenn wir deren Meinung nicht teilen.

Er war Gauturnwart hier in Dresden, hatte aber immer etwas gegen den Nationalsozialismus. Obwohl seine ganzen Kameraden mit wehenden Fahnen Ã¼bergegangen sind, hat er das immer abgelehnt. Aber wir waren gute Deutsche und wir waren kÃ¶nigstreu, was zur Revolution eigentlich gar nicht passt, aber mein Vater hat damals die Kameraden aus dem Krieg heimholen wollen, den Arbeiter an die Werkbank und den Bauern aufs Feld. Die saÃen da unten in RumÃ¤nien im Dreck, deswegen.

Ich bin 1939 geboren und habe den Angriff hier erlebt. Zum GlÃ¼ck wohnten wir etwas auÃerhalb des Dreiecks, wo die Bomben reingeworfen worden sind. Bei uns steckte nur ein BlindgÃ¤nger im FuÃweg, der nicht hochgegangen ist. Mein Vater war zunÃ¤chst bei der Stadtwacht und ist dann noch eingezogen worden in den Krieg, zum Landsturm. Die waren in einer Schule am Bischofsweg, mein Vater war aber HeimschlÃ¤fer, er konnte also abends mit der StraÃenbahn nach Hause fahren. Da waren sieben Kameraden in der Schule, und die haben sie gerettet, indem sie elf Brandbomben aus dem GebÃ¤lk gezogen und im Sand erstickt haben. Rundherum brannten die HÃ¤user, nur die Schule war gerettet, so dass die Leute dort einquartiert werden konnten, die ihre Wohnungen verloren haben. Die Kameraden wurden dann noch nach Cunnersdorf bei KÃ¶nigstein versetzt zur Verteidigung der SÃ¤chsischen Schweiz. Sie sind dann auch am 8. Mai gegen BÃ¶hmen ausgerÃ¼ckt. Als der Hauptmann dann die ersten russischen Panzer sah, sagte er, dass sich hier ihre Wege trennen wÃ¼rden und hat sich ins GebÃ¼sch geschlagen. Mein Vater konnte als Feldwebel die Truppe dann zurÃ¼ckfÃ¼hren, hat sich Zivilkleidung angezogen und ist die 35 Kilometer nach Dresden zurÃ¼ckmarschiert. Er wurde dann spÃ¤ter abgeholt und ich dachte, jetzt kommt er doch noch in Kriegsgefangenschaft, aber nein: die Russen haben ihn als BÃ¼rgermeister eingesetzt. Er war bekannt als Anti-Nazi, und die konnten da oben auf dem WeiÃen Hirsch, in diesem vornehmen Viertel keinen Kommunisten oder Sozialdemokraten einsetzen. So wurde mein Vater eben eingesetzt, hat aber schon bald hingeschmissen, denn mit den Russen konnte er auch nicht.

Mein Vater war Zimmermann, aber wir besaÃen ein Haus, und somit waren wir Kapitalisten, und ich als Kapitalistenkind wurde dann 1953 nicht zur Oberschule zugelassen. Das war mir damals noch nicht so bewuÃt, aber wenn ich gesagt hÃ¤tte, ich sei Revolutionsveteranenkind, die hÃ¤tten mich ja auf HÃ¤nden tragen mÃ¼ssen. 
Ich bin also abgelehnt worden, aber jetzt kommtâs: Am 17. Juni 1953 hÃ¤tten wir mÃ¼ndliche PrÃ¼fung in Politik gehabt, aber als wir zur Schule kamen, hing da ein Zettel, dass die PrÃ¼fungen ausfallen. Unsere Lehrer waren alle in der Stadt und sind mitmarschiert. Und was macht man als junger Bursche mit dem angebrochenen Tag? Ich fuhr mit der StraÃenbahn in die Stadt, zum Postplatz, da waren massenhaft Leute. Und dann kamen die Russen mit Seitenwagenmaschinen, die Kalaschnikows aufgestellt, und fuhren damit einfach durch die Menge. Dann kam Unruhe auf, die AufstÃ¤ndischen versuchten, in das nahe gelegene Fernmeldeamt zu kommen, damit sie die Verbindung der Kommunisten zu Russland unterbrechen konnten. Die Kasernierte Volkspolizei hat dann auf diese Leute geschossen, und die alten Leute haben zu mir gesagt, ich solle machen, dass ich nach Hause komme, hier wirdâs gefÃ¤hrlich. Ein paar Wochen spÃ¤ter schmiss mir unser Rektor, der selber Kommunist war, einen Brief aus dem Fenster zu. Es war die Zulassung zur Oberschule. Das war zu der Zeit, als die ganze Repressionen zurÃ¼ckgenommen wurden, wir bekamen zum Beispiel unsere Lebensmittelkarten wieder, die uns vorher als Kapitalisten abgenommen wurden.

Ich habe eine Rotkreuz-Ausbildung gemacht, kurz darauf wurde das Rote Kreuz wieder aufgebaut. Weil die Alliierten gemeint haben, es sei eine Nazi-Organisation, war es ja verboten, deswegen sind auf den Rheinwiesen hunderttausende deutsche Soldaten getÃ¶tet worden, weil die Alliierten sich nicht reinreden lassen wollten, wie sie mit ihren Soldaten umgehen. Als ich dem Roten Kreuz beigetreten bin, wurde ich mit 16 Jahren zum BereitschaftsfÃ¼hrer gewÃ¤hlt, ich war somit der jÃ¼ngste beim Roten Kreuz gewÃ¤hlte BereitschaftsfÃ¼hrer in Deutschland, den es je gegeben hat.

Als ich Abitur gemacht habe, kam die Phase, dass viele abgehauen sind, und was macht man? Man braucht ja Ersatz in Form von Hilfsarbeitern, somit sind alle Abiturienten in die Betriebe gesteckt worden fÃ¼r ein Jahr. Ich habe im Flugzeugwerk gearbeitet, direkt beim Rumpfbau, das war noch ganz interessant. Als es dann zum PolitgesprÃ¤ch kam, fÃ¼r die Studienzulassung, habe ich den Politgangstern meine Meinung gesagt. Das hÃ¤tte ich mal lieber nicht machen sollen. Ich bekam natÃ¼rlich keine Studienzulassung. Dann wurde ich zur âCharakterbildungâ zur Nationalen Volksarmee geschickt, sowas hat man da so durchgemacht. Ich habe dann versucht, wenigstens sowas wie Laborant zu werden, ich wollte ja hierbleiben, war ja der einzige Sohn meines Vaters, und der war schon alt. Aber dann schlich die Stasi ums Haus, die kannte man ja. Da hab ich mir dann gedacht, nee, dann geh ich doch lieber und bin 1958 Ã¼ber Berlin in den Westen. Dort hab ich noch mal ein halbes Jahr einen Abiturkurs gemacht, weil unser Abitur ja nicht anerkannt wurde. In TÃ¼bingen habe ich dann Examen in Mathematik und Geografie gemacht. Ich war im Asta aktiv und habe den Nationaldemokratischen Hochschulbund gegrÃ¼ndet, also den Hochschulbund der NPD. Ich habe gesagt, wir mÃ¼ssen auch an der Hochschule vertreten sein, wenn die Sozialisten hier so einen BlÃ¶dsinn reden, mÃ¼ssen wir was dagegen machen. Das war der sozialistische Studentenbund, aus dem spÃ¤ter die R.A.F. hervorging. Ich bin dann aber weg, hab eine pÃ¤dagogische Ausbildung gemacht und war eine zeitlang Lehrer, aber da hat man mich dann auchâ¦.aber ich will lieber noch was zu dem Gedenken hier sagen.

Mein Vater hat mich gleich 1946 am 13. Februar abends um 10 auf dem Blomberg-Blick am WeiÃen Hirsch mitgenommen und wir haben den Gedenkglocken gelauscht. Von meinem Vater sind viele Stahlhelmkameraden ums Leben gekommen, und viele andere, die wir kannten und die zum Zeitpunkt der Bombardierung in der Stadt waren. Ich persÃ¶nlich bin ja entsetzt Ã¼ber diese Historiker-Kommission, die ja unerhÃ¶rte Zahlen hier runtergewirtschaftet hat. Wenn die nur einmal alle Friedhofsverwaltungen angerufen und gefragt hÃ¤tten, wieviel Tote sind bei euch beerdigt, dann haben sie zum Beispiel beim Waldfriedhof 6900, sie haben auf dem Loschwitzer Friedhof 3600, und so geht das weiter, und da kommt doch schon eine Zahl raus, die in die Zigtausende geht und nicht diese 25000, auf die sie die runtergewirtschaftet haben. Was ist geschehen? Sie mÃ¼ssen sich vorstellen, elf Quadratkilometer total verwÃ¼stetes GelÃ¤nde, die ganzen HÃ¤user eingestÃ¼rzt, wie wollen sie denn da die Toten rausholen, das hÃ¤tte ja Jahre gedauert! Und die Russen haben ab September oder November das Aufgraben der Keller verboten! Dann kam die DDR, und die haben gesagt, wir wollen Licht und Luft, und haben angefangen, die neuen HÃ¤user zehn, zwanzig Meter von den StraÃen wegzubauen, um die alten Keller nicht aufgraben zu mÃ¼ssen. Die ganzen Toten liegen da also noch, hunderttausend mindestens! Ein Professor der TU hat sogar eine Rechnung aufgestellt, eine Methode, mit der man die Zahl schÃ¤tzen kann. Nicht zu vergessen die Menschen, die aus den zerbombten StÃ¤dten im Ruhrgebiet nach Dresden kamen im Glauben, Dresden sei eine sichere Stadt. Er hat das auch nachgewiesen, in der SÃ¼dvorstadt, zwischen Hauptbahnhof und Reick, dort ist ja eine wunderschÃ¶ne Kasernenanlage. Dort auf einem Sportplatz sieht er, wie eine Grube ausgehoben wird, und was schmeiÃt der Bagger raus? Ein menschliches Schulterblatt. Also das ist auch einfach zugemacht worden und man hat im wÃ¶rtlichen Sinne Gras Ã¼ber die Sache wachsen lassen. Und wenn man sowas erlebt, wird man wÃ¼tend Ã¼ber diese Historikerkommission."

When we walk through the city and conduct interviews, we usually don't know with whom we are speaking. That was the case with this man, whom we met on the Altmarkt at the memorial for the bombings. Now, we think we have found out who he is. Nevertheless, he is a person in Dresden, and we think it's important to show that such people exist, even if we don't share his opinion.

"I am the son of a revolutionary veteran. My father raised me to be active in society like he was. He was the sports associations officer for Saxony, but he always had something against national socialism. Although his comrades went over to the other side with waving flags, he always refused to. But we were good Germans, and we were loyal to the king, which is something that doesnât fit with the revolution actually, but my father wanted to bring home comrades back from World War I, the workers to the workbench and the farmers to the field â because they were sitting around down there in Romania in the dirt.

I was born in 1939, and I experienced the attack. Luckily, we lived outside of the triangle where the bombs were dropped. Near us, there was just a dud bomb that stuck into the sidewalk and didnât explode. My father was initially with the town watch and then was drafted into the war, into the home guard. They were in a school on Bischofsweg, but my father slept at home. He could take the tram home. There were seven comrades in the school, and they saved it by taking eleven fire bombs from the wood beams and burying them in the sand. All around houses burned; only the school was saved, so that people, who lost their apartments, could be housed there. The comrades were then moved to Cunnersdorf near KÃ¶nigstein to defend Saxon Switzerland. They were marched out on May 8th toward Bohemia. When the captain saw the first Russian tanks, he said that they would part ways here and jumped into the bushes. As sergeant, my father could then return the troupes, put on civilian clothes, marched 35 kilometers back to Dresden. He was later picked up, and I thought he would be taken as a war prisoner, but no. The Russians installed him as a mayor. He was known as an anti-Nazi, and they couldnât put a communist or social democrat up there in the noble district of the WeiÃe Hirsch. So thatâs why my father was put in, but he soon quit, since he didnât get along with Russians either.

My father was a carpenter, but we owned a house, so we were capitalists, and in 1953, I wasnât let into high school as the child of a capitalist. I wasnât so aware of it back then, but if I had said that was the child of revolutionary veteran, they would have had to bear me up in their hands.

So, I was rejected, but here it comes: On June 17th, 1953, we were supposed to have oral exams in politics, but when we got to school, there was a note saying the exams were canceled. Our teachers were all in the city marching. And what do you do as a young lad with a day off? I took the tram into the city, to Postplatz. There were masses of people. And then the Russians came with the sidecars, with kalaschnikovs set up, and just drove through the crowd. Then the riot started. The rebels tried to get near the telecommunications center, so that they could interrupt the communication with the communists in Russia. The Kasernierte Volkspolizei, a paramilitary force, fired on these people, and all of the old people told me that I should get out of there, I should go home, it was getting dangerous here. A couple of weeks later, our rector, who was a communist himself, threw a letter out of the window. It was admission to high school. That was in the time that all of the repression was toned done. For example, we got our ration cards back, which had been taken from us because we were capitalists.

I did Red Cross training, and a short time later, the Red Cross was re-built up. It wasnât allowed because the allies had said that it was a Nazi organization â thatâs why hundreds of thousands of German soldiers were killed along the riverbanks of the Rhine, because the allies wouldnât let anyone tell them how to treat their soldiers. When I joined the Red Cross, I was elected to be in charge of readiness. I was the youngest person who had ever been elected to the post in Germany then.

When I was finishing my high school degree, the phase started when a lot of people took off, and what do you do? You need replacements in the form of unskilled labor, so all the high school students were stuck in factories for a year. I worked in an airplane factory, directly at the aircraft body construction, that was really interesting. When it came to the whole political discussion for admission to university, I told the political gangsters my opinion. I shouldnât have done that. Of course, I didnât get admission. Then I was sent to the army for âcharacter building,â you experienced things like that. I then tried to at least become something like a lab technician. I wanted to stay here. I was my fatherâs only son, and he was already old. But then the Stasi was creeping around the house, you knew. I thought, âNo, I should go,â and in 1958, I went to the West through Berlin. There, I had to do another half of a year of high school, because our high school degree wasnât recognized. In TÃ¼bingen, I did the exams in mathematics and geography. I was active in Asta and founded the National Democratic Higher Education Group, so the university association of the National Democratic Party. I said, we also have to be represented at universities. If there are socialists here are talking such nonsense, we have to do something against it. That was the socialist student group, out of which the R.A.F. came later. I then went away and did a pedagogical training and was a teacher for a while, but then they alsoâ¦but I would rather say something about the commemoration here.

My father took me to the Blomberg-Blick on the WeiÃer Hirsch on February 13, 1946 in the evening at 10pm. A lot of my fatherâs fellow Stahlhelm soldiers , and many others, whom we knew and were in the city at the time of the bombing. I am personally outraged about this historical commission, which ran down the numbers here. If they just called all of the cemetery administrations and asked how many dead they buried, then they would have had 6900 at the Waldfriedhof for example, they would have had 3600 at the Loschwitzer cemetery, etc. until you get a number that is in the tens of thousands, and not this 25,000, which they brought the number down to. What happened? You have to imagine, eleven square kilometers of devastated terrain, all of the buildings collapsed, how could they have gotten all the dead out, that would have taken years! And the Russians forbade digging out cellars starting in September or November! Then came the GDR, and they said, âWe want light and airâ and started to build new buildings ten, twenty meters from the streets, in order not to have to dig out the old basements. All the dead are still buried, one-hundred thousand at least! A professor at the TU even set up an account, a method with which you can estimate the number. Not forgetting the people who came to Dresden from bombed cities in the Ruhrgebiet in the belief that Dresden was a safe city. He also documented in the SÃ¼dvorstadt, between the main train station and Reick, there is a beautiful barracks. There on a sports field, he saw how they dug out a pit, and what did the bull dozer throw out? A human shoulder blade! So they just closed it up, and they literally let the grass grow over it. And when you experience something like that, you get furious about this historical commission."

When we walk through the city and conduct interviews, we usually don't know with whom we are speaking. That was the case with this man, whom we met on the Altmarkt at the memorial for the bombings. Now, we think we have found out who he is. Nevertheless, he is a person in Dresden, and we think it's important to show that such people exist, even if we don't share his opinion.

"I am the son of a revolutionary veteran. My father raised me to be active in society like he was. He was the sports associations officer for Saxony, but he always had something against national socialism. Although his comrades went over to the other side with waving flags, he always refused to. But we were good Germans, and we were loyal to the king, which is something that doesnât fit with the revolution actually, but my father wanted to bring home comrades back from World War I, the workers to the workbench and the farmers to the field â because they were sitting around down there in Romania in the dirt.

I was born in 1939, and I experienced the attack. Luckily, we lived outside of the triangle where the bombs were dropped. Near us, there was just a dud bomb that stuck into the sidewalk and didnât explode. My father was initially with the town watch and then was drafted into the war, into the home guard. They were in a school on Bischofsweg, but my father slept at home. He could take the tram home. There were seven comrades in the school, and they saved it by taking eleven fire bombs from the wood beams and burying them in the sand. All around houses burned; only the school was saved, so that people, who lost their apartments, could be housed there. The comrades were then moved to Cunnersdorf near KÃ¶nigstein to defend Saxon Switzerland. They were marched out on May 8th toward Bohemia. When the captain saw the first Russian tanks, he said that they would part ways here and jumped into the bushes. As sergeant, my father could then return the troupes, put on civilian clothes, marched 35 kilometers back to Dresden. He was later picked up, and I thought he would be taken as a war prisoner, but no. The Russians installed him as a mayor. He was known as an anti-Nazi, and they couldnât put a communist or social democrat up there in the noble district of the WeiÃe Hirsch. So thatâs why my father was put in, but he soon quit, since he didnât get along with Russians either.

My father was a carpenter, but we owned a house, so we were capitalists, and in 1953, I wasnât let into high school as the child of a capitalist. I wasnât so aware of it back then, but if I had said that was the child of revolutionary veteran, they would have had to bear me up in their hands.

So, I was rejected, but here it comes: On June 17th, 1953, we were supposed to have oral exams in politics, but when we got to school, there was a note saying the exams were canceled. Our teachers were all in the city marching. And what do you do as a young lad with a day off? I took the tram into the city, to Postplatz. There were masses of people. And then the Russians came with the sidecars, with kalaschnikovs set up, and just drove through the crowd. Then the riot started. The rebels tried to get near the telecommunications center, so that they could interrupt the communication with the communists in Russia. The Kasernierte Volkspolizei, a paramilitary force, fired on these people, and all of the old people told me that I should get out of there, I should go home, it was getting dangerous here. A couple of weeks later, our rector, who was a communist himself, threw a letter out of the window. It was admission to high school. That was in the time that all of the repression was toned done. For example, we got our ration cards back, which had been taken from us because we were capitalists.

I did Red Cross training, and a short time later, the Red Cross was re-built up. It wasnât allowed because the allies had said that it was a Nazi organization â thatâs why hundreds of thousands of German soldiers were killed along the riverbanks of the Rhine, because the allies wouldnât let anyone tell them how to treat their soldiers. When I joined the Red Cross, I was elected to be in charge of readiness. I was the youngest person who had ever been elected to the post in Germany then.

When I was finishing my high school degree, the phase started when a lot of people took off, and what do you do? You need replacements in the form of unskilled labor, so all the high school students were stuck in factories for a year. I worked in an airplane factory, directly at the aircraft body construction, that was really interesting. When it came to the whole political discussion for admission to university, I told the political gangsters my opinion. I shouldnât have done that. Of course, I didnât get admission. Then I was sent to the army for âcharacter building,â you experienced things like that. I then tried to at least become something like a lab technician. I wanted to stay here. I was my fatherâs only son, and he was already old. But then the Stasi was creeping around the house, you knew. I thought, âNo, I should go,â and in 1958, I went to the West through Berlin. There, I had to do another half of a year of high school, because our high school degree wasnât recognized. In TÃ¼bingen, I did the exams in mathematics and geography. I was active in Asta and founded the National Democratic Higher Education Group, so the university association of the National Democratic Party. I said, we also have to be represented at universities. If there are socialists here are talking such nonsense, we have to do something against it. That was the socialist student group, out of which the R.A.F. came later. I then went away and did a pedagogical training and was a teacher for a while, but then they alsoâ¦but I would rather say something about the commemoration here.

My father took me to the Blomberg-Blick on the WeiÃer Hirsch on February 13, 1946 in the evening at 10pm. A lot of my fatherâs fellow Stahlhelm soldiers , and many others, whom we knew and were in the city at the time of the bombing. I am personally outraged about this historical commission, which ran down the numbers here. If they just called all of the cemetery administrations and asked how many dead they buried, then they would have had 6900 at the Waldfriedhof for example, they would have had 3600 at the Loschwitzer cemetery, etc. until you get a number that is in the tens of thousands, and not this 25,000, which they brought the number down to. What happened? You have to imagine, eleven square kilometers of devastated terrain, all of the buildings collapsed, how could they have gotten all the dead out, that would have taken years! And the Russians forbade digging out cellars starting in September or November! Then came the GDR, and they said, âWe want light and airâ and started to build new buildings ten, twenty meters from the streets, in order not to have to dig out the old basements. All the dead are still buried, one-hundred thousand at least! A professor at the TU even set up an account, a method with which you can estimate the number. Not forgetting the people who came to Dresden from bombed cities in the Ruhrgebiet in the belief that Dresden was a safe city. He also documented in the SÃ¼dvorstadt, between the main train station and Reick, there is a beautiful barracks. There on a sports field, he saw how they dug out a pit, and what did the bull dozer throw out? A human shoulder blade! So they just closed it up, and they literally let the grass grow over it. And when you experience something like that, you get furious about this historical commission."

"Ich bin gebÃ¼rtiger Dresdner, ein Dresdner EigengewÃ¤chs sozusagen, promoviere am Lehrstuhl fÃ¼r SÃ¤chsische Landesgeschichte und arbeite im SÃ¤chsischen Staatsarchiv, Hauptstaatsarchiv Dresden. Hier im Stadtmuseum habe ich vor zwei Jahren fÃ¼r mehrere Wochen an einer Projektarbeit mitgearbeitet und darÃ¼ber hinaus am Begleitband. Fachvorbereitungen und so sind die HintergrundtÃ¤tigkeiten, die ich als Historiker bei einer Ausstellung machen kann. Als Historiker habe ich naturgemÃ¤Ã einen anderen Blick auf Dresden, als der "normale" Dresdner. Ich muss mit einem gewissen Abstand darauf schauen. 

Zum Beispiel ausgehend von meinem Dissertationsprojekt â dort beschÃ¤ftige ich mich damit, wie sich StÃ¤dte im Sozialismus verÃ¤ndert haben â und schon der Blick auf den Plattenbau ist da bei einem Historiker ganz anders. Wir erleben das ja beim Umgang mit KulturdenkmÃ¤lern: Soll der Kulturpalast bleiben, soll er nicht bleiben, soll er eingestampft werden? Da gibt es viele Beispiele, bei denen man als Historiker ganz anders draufguckt und das auch ganz anders wertet. Was die Plattenbauten angeht, so ist mir deren frÃ¼he Geschichte als - wenn manÂ´s jetzt zeitgenÃ¶ssisch nimmt - schÃ¶ne und beliebte Wohngelegenheit, wo man hinziehen wollte, bewusst. Dieser Aspekt hat zu DDR-Zeiten in den 70ern sicher eine Rolle gespielt. Ich sehe sie also als bauliche DenkmÃ¤ler der jeweiligen Zeit, mit all dem FÃ¼r und Wider. Parallel dazu sind dann aber AltstÃ¤dte, InnenstÃ¤dte verfallen. Solche Wahrnehmungen haben immer was mit Zeitgeist zu tun und als Historiker schaut man eben aus der Entfernung auf den Zeitgeist. Dieses Strukturmodell kann man auch auf die Gegenwart beziehen. Wenn zum Beispiel heute neue Bauwerke entstehen, um das mal auf die Gegenwart zu beziehen, wird viel gesagt, dass diese Art Architektur nicht zu Dresden, nicht in die Barockstadt reinpasst. Aber genau diese Architektur ist ja auch wieder ein Zeichen unserer heutigen Zeit. 

In der Ausstellung "Die im Licht stehÂ´n" geht es um Dresden im 19. Jahrhundert, um die Schwelle vom 19. zum 20. Jahrhundert, quasi Dresden in der GroÃstadtwerdung. Es geht um die Umbruchzeit, die Zeit, in der das BÃ¼rgertum das Stadtmodel in der Zeit verteidigt hat, als bÃ¼rgerliches Herrschaftsmodel und Idealfall dafÃ¼r. Mit dem Wandel musste es zurecht kommen, es strÃ¶mten um 1900 viele Arbeiter nach Dresden. Das wird aus dem bÃ¼rgerlichen Selbstbild rausgehalten. Und das ist auch ein Zeichen dieser Ausstellung, dass Dresden damals wie heute viel mehr ist als nur eine Residenz- und/oder Barockstadt, viel mehr als eine Kulturstadt, sondern eben auch eine Stadt der Technik, der Wissenschaft. Die Ausstellung zeigt durch die Abwesenheit von Portraitfotografien von Arbeitern aber auch, dass Dresden eine Arbeiterstadt ist, in der ein gewisses Abwehrverhalten des BÃ¼rgertums in diesem ReprÃ¤sentationsmedium BÃ¼rgerportrait vorhanden ist.

In der Geschichte sollte immer beides da sein: Einerseits kann man auf die groÃen Strukturen, Herrschaftsstrukturen gucken, sozusagen aus der Feldherrenperspektive von oben auf irgendwas draufschauen. Aber Geschichte ist ja immer Konstruktion. Also wenn ich jetzt sage, sich der Wahrheit annÃ¤hern, muss man das AnnÃ¤hern unterstreichen. Es ist also andererseits auch das Alltagsgeschichtliche von unten. Alltagsgeschichte fÃ¼r sich genommen - ich nehme jetzt beispielsweise nur Zeitzeugeninterviews - ist dann immer schwierig, weil die ReprÃ¤sentativitÃ¤t fehlt. Bezogen auf mein Projekt heiÃt das, dass wenn ich nur auf die SED in der DDR-Zeit schaue, dann verfalle ich schnell dahin, dass es eine Diktatur war, in der alles so funktioniert hat, wie sich das die Oberen gewÃ¼nscht haben. Man darf aber nicht vergessen, was unterhalb dieser glÃ¤sernen Decke, dieses Radars passiert und das ist in jeder Zeit so. Das ist 1900 so, genauso wie heute. Deswegen halte ich von solchen Projekten wie "People in Dresden/Leute in Dresden" relativ viel. Es ist nur die Frage, was man dann damit macht."

"I was born in Dresden, a home-grown product. I am writing my dissertation in the department of Saxon Regional History and work in the Saxon State Archive, Dresdenâs Main State Archive. I worked on a project for several weeks here in the City Museum and also on a book to go along with it. Specialist preparation is the background activities for an exhibition that I can do as an historian. As a historian, I naturally have another way of looking at Dresden as the ânormalâ Dresdener. 

For example, if I can refer to my dissertation project in which I focus on how cities changed during socialism, it is true that a historianâs way of looking at high rises is very different. We experience this phenomenon in connection with cultural landmarks. Should the Kulturpalast remain? Should it not remain? Should it be scrapped? There are a lot of examples that a historian sees and evaluates very differently. In terms of the high rises, I think about their early history â if you take the point of view of the time â nice, popular places to live, where you could move. This aspect certainly played a role in the 70s GDR. I see them, in other words, as constructed landmarks of the time with everything pro and con. At the same time, old cities, the inner cities were falling apart. These perceptions always have something to do with the Zeitgeist, and as a historian, you see the Zeitgeist from a distance. You can also apply this structural model to the present. If, for example, a new building is built today, a lot of people say that this kind of architecture doesnât belong in Dresden, it doesnât fit in the Baroque city. But it is exactly this architecture that is a symbol of our time today.

In the exhibition, âThey who stand in the light,â is about Dresden in the 19th century, on the threshold of the 20th century, Dresden in the process of becoming a big city. Itâs about a time of change, the time in which the middle class citizens defended their version of the city, as an ideal case for the middle class rule. It had to come to terms with change â many workers flowed into Dresden around 1900. That was kept out of the middle-class self image. And it is also a sign of this exhibition that Dresden, back then like today, was much more than a royal seat and/or Baroque city, itâs much more than a culture city, but rather also a city of technology, of science. The exhibition also shows that the absence of portrait photographs of workers, that Dresden is a working city, in which there is a certain defensive behavior by the middle class present in this representational medium.

History should always have both â on the one side, you can look at large structures, ruling structures, from a military strategistâs perspective, looking down from above at something. But history is always a construct. So if I now say, that something is approaching the truth, you have to underline approaching. On the other side, there is also the history of everyday life from below. The history of everyday life in and of itself â for example, witness interviews â is then always difficult because representativity is missing. In terms of my project, that means that if I only look at the SED in the GDR period, then I fall into the trap of thinking that it was a dictatorship in which everything functioned as the people above wished that would. But you canât forget what happened underneath this glass ceiling, under the radar, and thatâs true of every time. It was like that in 1900, just like today. Thatâs why I really appreciate projects like People in Dresden. Itâs just a question of what you do with it."

"I am a violin teacher. I studied violin and musical pedagogy here at the music academy. After my studies, I was in Peru for two years, working in a social music project, developing it a bit. I thought that we need here what we were doing there. Of course, we have a different form of poverty here, but nevertheless, there are a lot of children and teenagers, who donât have any access to cultural education â for financial reasons, but also often just because it doesnât occur to them to sign up for something like that. A year and a half ago, we started MUSAIK in the framework of âAt Home in Prohlis.â The first year, we taught in the shopping mall in a store front. There were regularly more than 20 children there. Then we expanded. Now we have between 60 and 70 children.

Our concept â and what distinguishes us from a music school and what makes us into a social project â is that we only teach the children together, group lessons or orchestra. And â and I think that is the biggest and most important difference â we practice three times a week. In the ideal case, the children really come Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. That means that what you expect from a music student â that he practices at home and maybe also has parents who practice with him or support him â that is not a precondition here, necessarily. We can assume that most of the parents have no clue about music, maybe their apartment is so that you canât practice there. That means that we do everything together. We teach, we make music together, we are a group. And we also try to be a real community. If you make music together, some things are totally important â that you listen to each other, that you work together. Itâs not about who is finished first, rather itâs about listening to each other and taking responsibility. Those are the things that we want to pass along with the music.

I always wanted to be a violin teacher. At first, I thought that I would just be a violin teacher and not work in a school, so that I would only have individual students. But now I have noticed that itâs actually totally fun to work with bigger groups. The combination is now totally nice. I am in the music school two days a week and do individual lessons, and here there are a lot of children. Thatâs a lot of variety for me. In any case, I know the children relatively well. I spend three days a week with them for two to three hours. We also try to do a lot of events. I think itâs also very important that the parents are always at the concerts or other events, that they have more contact with each other and us. I have been invited to the homes of some families. That was always nice. I think itâs important that the parents trust us. But I think we have been able to build that up in the past year and a half."

Wir haben das erste Mal richtig was von der Neustadt mitgekriegt, als BRN war. Da waren wir auch als ganz kleine Leute schon. Wir hatten immer das Ziel, vielleicht irgendwann mal auf der BRN zu spielen oder allgemein mal in die Neustadt reinzukommen. Wir dachten, das ist ein ziemlich hohes Niveau in der Neustadt, da mÃ¼ssen wir erstmal ordentlich was raushauen, damit das klappt. Zuerst haben wir auf der offenen BÃ¼hne im Stadtteilhaus gespielt. Dadurch kannten uns schon ein paar Leute in der Neustadt. Irgendwann haben wir es geschafft, im Blue Note zu spielen, in einem vollen Laden. Wir durften dann gleich noch mal dort spielen, und da haben wir schon gedacht, wir haben es jetzt geschafft. Danach wurden wir zum Hechtfest eingeladen - und wir haben dann auch endlich auf der BRN spielen dÃ¼rfen, bei Vier Vogel Pils.

Anfang 2018 haben wir bei einem Wettbewerb teilgenommen und waren im April 2018 auf der Musikmesse in Frankfurt. Wir waren sehr Ã¼berrascht, dass wir gewonnen haben. Es waren acht Bands da, das heiÃt, wir hatten sieben wunderbare Konkurrenten. Wir waren komplett sprachlos, weil wir ja auch wussten, was das fÃ¼r spÃ¤ter bedeutet, was dann alles auf uns zukommt, auch dass wir auf dem Hurricane Festival spielen dÃ¼rfen.

Ich habe kein Lampenfieber. Auch bei 70000 Leuten auf dem Hurricane Festival nicht. Ich bin einfach so glÃ¼cklich, da zu sein, ich mache meine Musik und genieÃe das richtig. Ich bin wie in einer anderen Welt, wenn ich eine Gitarre in der Hand habe und Musik mache. Sobald ich den ersten Ton spiele, bin ich komplett weg, ich bin nur in der Musik und alles andere ist weg.

Ich bin sehr dankbar, Dresdner zu sein, weil die Neustadt mir so viel mÃ¶glich gemacht hat, auch jetzt mit meiner Solotour. Im Moment bin ich auf Tournee, ich habe 94 Konzerte in 15 LÃ¤ndern in ganz Europa."

"My music career really started here in Dresden, in the Neustadt. I am a fan of the Neustadt, of all the clubs and bars and just the people here. We first really got to know the Neustadt at Bunte Republik Neustadt. We were there already when we were just little people. We always had the goal of playing at BRN someday or just getting into the Neustadt. We thought that it was a pretty high level; we had to first really work so that we could do it. First, we played at the open stage at the Stadtteilhaus. Through that, we got to know a few people in the Neustadt. At some point, we were able to play at the Blue Note to a full house. We were allowed to play there again, and we already thought that we had made it. After that, we were invited to Hechtfest â and we could finally play at BRN, on the Vier Vogel Pils stage.

In the beginning of 2018, we took part in a contest, and in April of that year, we were at the music trade fair in Frankfurt. We were really surprised that we won. There were eight bands there, so seven wonderful competitors. We were totally speechless, because we also knew what it would mean for later, everything that was coming at us, that we were going to get to play the Hurricane Festival.

I donât have stage fright â even with 70,000 people at the Hurricane Festival. I am just happy to be there and play my music and really enjoy that. Itâs like I am in another world when I have a guitar in the hand and play music. As soon as I play the first note, I am completely gone. I am just in the music and everything else is gone.

I am very thankful to be a Dresdener, because the Neustadt made so much possible, also now with my solo tour. At the moment, I am on tour. I have 94 concerts in 15 countries all over Europe."

Das ist das SchÃ¶ne an der Arbeit mit anderen Menschen, aber besonders mit Kindern, weil sie auch sehr herausfordernd sein kÃ¶nnen. AuÃer Geduld lernt man noch Struktur. Und auch AuthentizitÃ¤t und Ehrlichkeit - dass man berechenbar ist, dass man Dinge, die man verspricht, dann auch hÃ¤lt. Es geht darum, dass die Kinder wissen, mit dem kann ich so und so umgehen. Die kennen mich, und ich kenne sie. Und dann funktioniert das schon."

"I was born in Dresden. I went to high school in Berlin. I am hearing impaired and during the GDR, children were sent to a school for the hearing impaired. For deaf students, there was only a school in Berlin where you could go to high school. I left home at fourteen. My parents never had any problems with me and my puberty, for example. We always looked forward to seeing each other; I went home every two weeks. I would recommend it to everyone, but you have to want to leave home at fourteen. Maybe not everyone is made for it. At first, it was a little strange, but I found friends quickly. At first, it was like being at summer camp or on a school trip â and then you got used to it. You also had a lot of free time. I did sports or looked around Berlin. It was 1990 â it was exciting; the wall was done, and we were young.

After that, I went to Leipzig and studied to be a sports teacher. I then went to Bavaria and Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg to work. Now, I am back in Dresden. I am a sports teacher, and I work with children at a special education school. That is a lot of fun. I wanted to work with people, and I also wanted to do something with sports, because I am interested in medicine. I think that I was brought to the professional by the mixture of sports, medicine, and people.

Working with children is a lot of fun. Itâs nice when you can do things with children and earn money for it. You learn to be patient. You also learn a lot about yourself. That is something nice about working with other people, but especially with children, because they can be so challenging. Besides patience, you learn structure, and authenticity and honesty â that you have to be reliable, that you keep your promises. Itâs so the children know that they interact with me in a certain way. They know me, and I know them. And that works well."

Finally, a Spanish translator came, and they did all kinds of drug tests, which all came out negative. They made fun of me and said I had no right to complain because I wasn't in my country. Other refugees, mostly Arabs, came into the bathroom when I was taking a shower, took my clothes, pulled my hair. They are not used to having gay people around, and they donât respect us. Fortunately, the Christopher Street Day association helped me move to a gay friendly environment.

At my BAMF interview, they kept asking me why I was here, and why I wanted to be here, and I don't want to be here. They didn't let me tell the story with the police in Frankfurt. It's very difficult to find people who listen here.

"I have lived in Dresden since 1986. I came here for university and then I started working. I met my husband and started a family. Thatâs why I am still here.

The GDR was a little like a foreign country. It wasnât so easy. My colleagues here were also friendly, but somehow different than I was used to.

At the time of reunification, the company I worked in had over a thousand people, and it was reduced to two hundred. Since my husband I were working for the same company, it was clear that one of us had to go, and since I was at home with my small child anyway, it was clear that it would be me. I then had a lot of luck. I went to the airport, because it was near where we lived, and I asked if they were looking for people. Actually, the secretary had told already told me no, but I had my younger son in my arms, and she said to him, âYou are a sweet one! What can mommy do?â Thatâs how I got my job there. I worked at the airport information and learned about everything at the airport that there was to learn from the ground up. You donât need a university degree for it, but it was a great group, and I really enjoyed working there. But at some point the airport changed their policy. The airport gave up its passenger service, and I didnât want to work for Lufthansa. I landed at a travel agency. I worked there for a long time, then I became self-employed. We are a speciality organizer for trips to the Caribbean, and I now have two employees."

I was working, I have my family. But at some point, I got into a situation where the police beat up some young people because they were wearing Free German Youth shirts. I had listened to the young people before that, and I didnât think that what they were saying was bad at all, but they had these shirts. It was totally excessive and not at all necessary. And I just thought, âOh God, they could be your children. Something is wrong here.â The second thing that happened was that we had this refugee camp on the Theaterplatz. A friend took me there, and I first understood how far people will go if their lives become unbearable, that they have to express themselves like that. That upset everything for me.

I am not at all happy with what is going on in my city now. Thatâs why I am on the street every Monday â because I canât get used to all of this racism. Thatâs why I have always been involved with Herz Statt Hetze. I am everything but happy, and I donât understand how people can keep silent, and endure what happens here, and just arenât willing to do something against it. It affects me very much.

It is distressing what you have to hear on Mondays â I hear it less, because I am already old, but especially young people, how they are harassed, also young women. I think itâs terrible, and I will stand up against it as long as I can.

I was at the demonstration on the first birthday of Pegida, when a big anti-Pegida demonstration was organized for the first time. There were a lot of people there, who helped. Then there was this day on which there were 20,000 people on the street on both sides. And the day ended with the Nazis marching unhindered through the city and with the concluding concert being attacked by Nazis. I was there, I helped to get people out of the zone. And then it didnât exist â the police talked about chaotic leftists and I donât know what the next day. Since that day, there hasnât been a civil society in Dresden, because everyone saw that they could go out on the street and be attacked by Nazis and then told that itâs left-extremists, anarchists. 

I am afraid of what is going to happen with the election in the fall â because already now a lot of people are not thinking about how they can do something so that it doesnât happen. Instead, they are thinking, âWhat will I do then in order to get used to this new life?â I think thatâs horrible. We want to do another big event on May 4th with Herz Statt Hetze to inspire people to think about their right to vote. But itâs terrifying."

"I arrived exactly a year ago. I was a general practitioner in Venezuela. In 2017, I did a year of community service, and that was when I decided I wanted to come to Germany. I lived in a beach town two hours away from Caracas, where I am from. I spent two days a week in the town and then I could go home.

The situation at the urgent care clinics and hospitals in Venezuela is very precarious. I was fortunate to work in a clinic that had a few more things. We had to fight to work. I always brought my own first aid kit and instruments.

Once, I was about to finish my twelve-hour shift, and it was one of those exhausting days. Half an hour before I was supposed to leave, this woman came in in labor, holding a three year old boy. She had no money, nobody to help her. She was bleeding profusely, and we couldn't really establish if she was actually having a miscarriage. We had no blood work, ultrasound, nothing. We first tried to stabilize her while finding a way to send her to the hospital. There was only one ambulance serving the whole area, and it was already out with another patient.

When the ambulance arrived three hours later, she was very unstable. I got in the ambulance with her, and we went to the big hospital in town. They didn't accept her because they didn't have hydrating infusions or needles to put the intravenous drip. I was under so much stress, I needed them to see her. They had more experience than me, and obviously, they had an obstetrician. I had to go in and fight with all my colleagues. At that point ,we even had a black out in the clinic, there was no way she would survive more than two hours under those conditions. In the end, we needed to send that woman to Caracas, but the paramedic didn't want to take responsibility for her. We bribed him. I and a bunch of people who were watching what was happening all begged him to do it and collected money to give him.

The thing is that there is no electricity on the roads. It was midnight, and there's a lot of criminality on the road, and additionally, the ambulance wasn't in the best shape. I can't judge the paramedic. It was a very difficult decision to make, and the only thing I had in my head was to save that woman's life.

He finally arrived at Domingo Luciani's hospital in Caracas, and the only thing I know is she was alive, and they took her in.

I love my country and my family very much but I saw the need to develop myself professionally. Around that time, I thought of doing my specialization in Venezuela, because I like the rhythm of work but at the same time, I knew I wouldn't have a good quality of life. I had to live with my parents in Caracas; they were supporting me financially even though I was working.

I had two options: USA or Germany. To apply here for orthopedics is way less complicated, and the idea of learning a new language was appealing. A friend of mine from medical school, whoâs been living here for three years, told me all about it here. I like the city, it's beautiful. I haven't had any problems up until now, and I am very happy with my decision to come here.
My objective is to finish my specialization, I finished the German course and got my credentials approved. I am now doing a German language course for medical practitioners. I will do an internship in a town nearby in a rehabilitation clinic. I have the feeling I will stay here for longer, but maybe at some point, I would like to live in a bigger city like Berlin or Hamburg.
I can't say if I will go back to Venezuela. I miss my people, my food, my weather, my family, but this has taken me a lot of work to get here where I am standing. I wish I could find a way to work some months there but live permanently here.

When I hear about the situation there it affects me a lot, and I feel guilty sometimes, especially since things have deteriorated in the last few weeks with all the blackouts and the kids suffering from malnutrition. Colleagues of mine told me they each had to stay with one intubated kid for hours doing manual reanimation because the hospitalâs electric plant only lasts twenty-four hours. The medical situation in Venezuela is catastrophic. If that's happening in Caracas, I can't imagine how it would be in most rural communities and the interior of the country. That's no-man's land. They are the forgotten people. It makes me really sad.

I have been planning an event with Sandra to create awareness about the humanitarian crisis in Venezuela. It's my way to do something for my people. We want to talk about our experience and collect some money to send to a foundation I know about and that I am very sure will get the money to the correct projects. It's a bunch of volunteer doctors and my best friend is one of the volunteers there. We are very hopeful we can do something, even if it's not much. I think if we all unite as a community -- Venezuelans, Latin Americans, migrants, refugees, Germans, we can make a difference. The owner of the Nosh cafÃ© has generously given us the chance to have a place where people can eat typical Venezuelan food and chat on the first Wednesday of every month. I feel people here are very open to these kinds of initiatives, and I hope something good can develop out of it."
