She had no money, nobody to help her. She was bleeding profusely, and we couldn't really establish if she was actually having a miscarriage. We had no blood work, ultrasound, nothing. We first tried to stabilize her while finding a way to send her to the hospital. There was only one ambulance serving the whole area, and it was already out with another patient.

When the ambulance arrived three hours later, she was very unstable. I got in the ambulance with her, and we went to the big hospital in town. They didn't accept her because they didn't have hydrating infusions or needles to put the intravenous drip. I was under so much stress, I needed them to see her. They had more experience than me, and obviously, they had an obstetrician. I had to go in and fight with all my colleagues. At that point ,we even had a black out in the clinic, there was no way she would survive more than two hours under those conditions. In the end, we needed to send that woman to Caracas, but the paramedic didn't want to take responsibility for her. We bribed him. I and a bunch of people who were watching what was happening all begged him to do it and collected money to give him.

The thing is that there is no electricity on the roads. It was midnight, and there's a lot of criminality on the road, and additionally, the ambulance wasn't in the best shape. I can't judge the paramedic. It was a very difficult decision to make, and the only thing I had in my head was to save that woman's life.

He finally arrived at Domingo Luciani's hospital in Caracas, and the only thing I know is she was alive, and they took her in.

I love my country and my family very much but I saw the need to develop myself professionally. Around that time, I thought of doing my specialization in Venezuela, because I like the rhythm of work but at the same time, I knew I wouldn't have a good quality of life. I had to live with my parents in Caracas; they were supporting me financially even though I was working.

I had two options: USA or Germany. To apply here for orthopedics is way less complicated, and the idea of learning a new language was appealing. A friend of mine from medical school, whoâs been living here for three years, told me all about it here. I like the city, it's beautiful. I haven't had any problems up until now, and I am very happy with my decision to come here.
My objective is to finish my specialization, I finished the German course and got my credentials approved. I am now doing a German language course for medical practitioners. I will do an internship in a town nearby in a rehabilitation clinic. I have the feeling I will stay here for longer, but maybe at some point, I would like to live in a bigger city like Berlin or Hamburg.
I can't say if I will go back to Venezuela. I miss my people, my food, my weather, my family, but this has taken me a lot of work to get here where I am standing. I wish I could find a way to work some months there but live permanently here.

When I hear about the situation there it affects me a lot, and I feel guilty sometimes, especially since things have deteriorated in the last few weeks with all the blackouts and the kids suffering from malnutrition. Colleagues of mine told me they each had to stay with one intubated kid for hours doing manual reanimation because the hospitalâs electric plant only lasts twenty-four hours. The medical situation in Venezuela is catastrophic. If that's happening in Caracas, I can't imagine how it would be in most rural communities and the interior of the country. That's no-man's land. They are the forgotten people. It makes me really sad.

I have been planning an event with Sandra to create awareness about the humanitarian crisis in Venezuela. It's my way to do something for my people. We want to talk about our experience and collect some money to send to a foundation I know about and that I am very sure will get the money to the correct projects. It's a bunch of volunteer doctors and my best friend is one of the volunteers there. We are very hopeful we can do something, even if it's not much. I think if we all unite as a community -- Venezuelans, Latin Americans, migrants, refugees, Germans, we can make a difference. The owner of the Nosh cafÃ© has generously given us the chance to have a place where people can eat typical Venezuelan food and chat on the first Wednesday of every month. I feel people here are very open to these kinds of initiatives, and I hope something good can develop out of it."

Das merkt man auch dadurch, dass sich Pegida hier so lange halten konnte, auch wenn es jetzt immer nur noch so knapp 1.000 sind. Das gibt es in anderen StÃ¤dten in Sachsen in der Form nicht.

Wenn es irgendwie geht, versuche ich, es mir einzurichten, zur Gegendemo zu gehen. Es ist schon manchmal schade, dass so wenig Leute hier sind. In der letzten Zeit war das VerhÃ¤ltnis immer so ungefÃ¤hr ein zu zehn. Damit muss man sich einfach abfinden. Das ist in anderen StÃ¤dten auch etwas anders. Es kÃ¶nnte mehr aus der Dresdner Zivilgesellschaft kommen."
--
"I have lived in Dresden for the past year, and it disturbs me that every Monday, Pegida spreads hate and agitation. I don't want to resign myself to it. And for this reason, I am just here to show that there are people who are against it and don't think it's ok.

I come from Mannheim originally, but I have lived in Saxony for twenty years, so I know about the political conditions here. The political scene in Dresden is a little special because Dresden is very concentrated on itself and doesn't pay attention to what's going on outside of it. âIch bin Joseph. Ich komme aus Uganda in Ostafrika und bin hier, um mit Victoria und Regina bei dem Projekt Architects of Music zusammenzuarbeiten. Wir haben dieses Projekt begonnen, um zu zeigen, dass Ugander mehr als nur ihre eigene Musik spielen kÃ¶nnen. Wir kÃ¶nnen auch hier in Europa arbeiten. 

Ich habe Victoria zum ersten Mal in Eritrea getroffen, und da sind wir auf diese Idee gekommen. Sehr viele junge Menschen kommen zu dem Projekt in Uganda. Wir waren uns nicht sicher, ob es funktionieren wÃ¼rde. Aber sie durch durch Regina und Victoria sehr motiviert, FlÃ¶te zu lernen. Wir kombinieren unsere eigenen traditionellen Instrumente mit dem FlÃ¶tenspiel. WÃ¤hrend wir jetzt sprechen, spielen einige der SchÃ¼ler FlÃ¶te auf der BÃ¼hne.

Einige der jungen Leute waren schon immer daran interessiert, ein Instrument zu lernen, aber sie hatten einfach keinen Zugang. Vielleicht hatten sie gelernt, etwas zu spielen, indem man zusieht oder zuhÃ¶rt, aber jetzt versuchen wir, sie intensiv mit der Musik vertraut zu machen. 

Einige von ihnen wollen teilnehmen wegen der Motivation, die Welt auÃerhalb von Uganda oder Afrika kennenzulernen. Wir haben einen Auftritt bei einem Festival und einige kleine Auftritte in Uganda. Sie wollen bekannt sein und ein wenig Geld fÃ¼r SchulbÃ¼cher verdienen. Wir empfehlen ihnen, ihre Ausbildung fortzusetzen.

Ich spiele A'dungu und einige andere traditionelle Instrumente, aber ich lerne auch FlÃ¶te. Ich habe die besten Lehrer, Victoria und Regina. Es begann damit, dass ich Instrumente im Schulchor und in der Kirche gespielt habe, in der mein Vater Pastor ist. Als wir Kinder lernten, durften wir die Instrumente nicht berÃ¼hren, weil sie Angst hatten, dass wir sie kaputt machen wÃ¼rden, aber jetzt denken wir anders darÃ¼ber. Wir wollen die Kinder einbeziehen. Als Kind wollte ich lernen, weil ich sehen konnte, dass sich die Menschen beim Musizieren entspannen. Der Stress verschwindet und die Leute tanzen. Als Pastor konnte mein Vater auch A'dungu spielen. Ich war ihm sehr nahe. 
 
Ich bin bisher nur einen Tag in Dresden gewesen, aber ich kann bereits sagen, dass diese Stadt gut ist, aber die Leute, mit denen ich hier bin, sind sogar sehr gut.â
--
âI am Joseph. I come from Uganda in East Africa, and I am here to collaborate with Victoria and Regina on the project Architects of Music. We started the collaboration to show that Ugandans can play more than just their own music. We can also work here in Europe. 

I first met Victoria in Eritrea, and thatâs where we came up with the idea. So many young people are showing up for the project in Uganda. We werenât sure it would work out. They are so inspired by Regina and Victoria to learn the flute. We are combining our own traditional instruments with flute playing. As we speak now, some of the students are playing flute on stage.

Some of these young people have always been interested in learning to play an instrument, but they just didnât have access. Maybe they picked up how to play something by watching or listening, but now we are trying to get them deeply involved with music.

Some of them want to participate because they are motivated to learn about the world, outside of Uganda or Africa. We have a performance at a festival, and some small performances in Uganda. They want to be well known and earn a little money for books for school. We advise them to go on with their education.

I play the Aâdungu and some other traditional instruments, but I am learning the flute too. I have the best teachers with Victoria and Regina. I started learning to play instruments in the school choir and in the church where my father is a pastor. When we children were learning, we werenât allowed to touch the instruments, because they were afraid we would break them, but now we think of it differently. We want to bring children on board. As a child, I wanted to learn because I could see that people relaxed when they played music. The stress goes away, and people dance. As a pastor, my father could also play Aâdungu. I was very close to him. 

I have only been in Dresden for one day so far, but I can already tell the place is good, but the people I am here with are so good.â

Sie hat mit so einem Enthusiasmus darÃ¼ber berichtet, dass ich dachte, wie kann man da etwas starten und am besten anfangen. Wir haben erstmal gesagt, wir versuchen Benefizkonzerte zu veranstalten. DarÃ¼ber ist es dann immer enger und immer mehr geworden. Es hat ziemlich lange gedauert, bis wir beide uns so organisieren konnten, dass wir beide wirklich die Zeit und auch den Plan hatten, wir fliegen jetzt noch mal nach Uganda.

Am Anfang konnte ich mir ehrlich gesagt gar nicht vorstellen, wie sehr ich da involviert sein wÃ¼rde. Wir haben einfach langsam angefangen. Aber in dieser IntensitÃ¤t - mit der Reise und dass jetzt direkt der Gegenbesuch stattfinden kann - das hÃ¤tte ich nicht erwartet. Ich bin begeistert, dass es so geworden ist. Auch dadurch, dass wir dort waren und gesehen haben, was unser Engagement und unsere Arbeit fÃ¼r die Leute dort bedeuten, was das dort auslÃ¶st, das zu sehen und mitzuerleben hat noch mal viel dazu beigetragen, dass man sagt, man kann jetzt gar nicht mehr anders.

Dadurch, dass das Projekt nicht hier vor Ort stattfindet, glaube ich, dass es wichtig ist, dass wir hier in den nÃ¤chsten vier Wochen zusammen mit Joseph mÃ¶glichst viel Aufmerksamkeit erregen, dass wir den Leuten diese Art von Kultur ein bisschen nÃ¤her bringen kÃ¶nnen, an viele Schulen gehen und mit mÃ¶glichst vielen Leuten in Kontakt kommen. "After Victoriaâs first trip to Uganda, we had a concert together. We started talking, and Viktoria told me about the workshops that she had done there in the schools and how excited they can be. She reported on it with such enthusiasm that I thought about how to start something and how best to begin. We initially said we would try to put on benefit concerts. Then we got busier and things got more intense. It took a long time until we could get organized, when we both really had the time and a plan -- that we would fly to Uganda again.

At first, I honestly couldnât really imagine how involved I would be. Around that time, I was in Nepal for the first time â maybe it hit a nerve because of that, because I thought, it is so similar there â the children and young people have so many fewer possibilities than we do here. We just started slowly, but in this intensity â with the trip and then that the visit from Joseph can immediately take place â I didnât expect that. I am excited that it turned out that way. Also because we were there and saw what our engagement and what our work means to people, what it has caused there, -- to see that and to experience that again really contributed to my feeling that I wouldnât do it differently.

Because the project doesnât take place here, I think that it is important that we get as much attention as possible in the next four weeks with Joseph, so that we can bring people a little closer to this kind of culture, go to a lot of schools and come into contact with as many people as possible. Of course, in the end, we would like to generate donations. Or that someone would donate an instrument. Unfortunately, we canât do it without money. But itâs not just about raising money. It would be nice if we could find people who already have experience with these kinds of projects and could help us."

An der Uni haben wir daran gearbeitet, BrÃ¼cken zu bauen zwischen den verschiedenen Teilen des politischen Spektrums in Venezuela, also rechts-prowestlichen Nationalisten, traditionellen Sozialdemokraten und Linken, um gemeinsam ein Vorgehen zur Abschaffung der jetzigen MilitÃ¤rdiktatur zu entwickeln. Diese Allianz wurde als vom westlichen Ausland gesteuerte VerschwÃ¶rung bezeichnet. Die meisten Teilnehmer sind im GefÃ¤ngnis geendet.

Sein Plan war ein vollkommen anderes soziales und politischen Modell mit vielen WidersprÃ¼chen, aber alles war noch in der Entwicklung. Wir haben auf eine Transformation gehofft, die die politischen und Ã¶konomischen Strukturen unseres Landes Ã¤ndert. Was wir bekommen haben, ist eine Mafia, die auf den Ruinen unseres Landes regiert.

"I am a university instructor, and a labor union and human rights activist. For many years, I followed the Venezuelan dream of a different world, in which social justice and inclusion are the goals of a self-governed society. Unfortunately, our society was betrayed by an ethno-military mafia who have taken away peopleâs hope, especially that of the Venezuelan working class. It has become a nightmare and has postponed the possibility for a truly democratic and libertarian alternative in Latin America.

I had to leave Venezuela in a rush. At the university, we were working on building bridges between different sectors of the Venezuelan political spectrum -- right- pro-western nationalists, traditional social democrats, and the left -- in order to have a common plan to depose the military tyranny we have now. This alliance was considered as an interventionist conspiracy by western powers, and most of the participants ended up in jail.

From my point of view, after Chavez's death, the ideological pursuit of a better society died too. He proposed a completely different social and political model with a lot of contradictions, but it was still a work in progress. When he died, he took the ideas and the call to rethink everything to the grave with him. When he left, there was just two very polarized and powerful groups, each of which has been supported by huge powerful nations. Respectively, the USA and China-Russia. The dispute is blatantly about how to control Venezuelaâs mineral resources and how to ensure political dominance in the whole region.

Against this background of minimal expectations, the basic rules of the political game had to be respected in order to keep the fight within the limits of a formal democracy.

That's something the 'Chavismo' couldn't do. When they didn't recognize the parliamentary elections of 2015 in which the opposition won the majority of the seats in the assembly, they violated the constitution, and they were exposed as authoritarian and incompliant. That's how we in the pro-democracy movement were pushed to ally with the Venezuelan opposition in hope of restoring constitutionality.

As a theologist, I have to think about the lesser of two evils principle, the code of ethics discussed by Saint Thomas Aquinas. In this case, the lesser evil is the pro-western Venezuelan opposition. It frightens me to think that we have been eroding the very basis of democracy since we irresponsibly gave up our civil rights to a charismatic leader twenty years ago. We hoped for a transformation that would change the political and economic structures of our country. What we got was a mafiocracy that governs from the ruins of what the nation used to be.

I don't think there's a diplomatic solution for Venezuela among Venezuelans. Unfortunately, this conflict has become internationalized and now the only possible solutions are in the hands of the international powers. If Maduro and GuaidÃ³ would sit down and try to negotiate, neither of them would have the authority to decide anything. Much more effective would be a meeting between Trump and Jinping. We can only take this time to reflect on what we want as a society and which alternatives we have. We can just try to gather together, think from different points of view, engaging with others and try to do something with this huge Venezuelan diaspora.

I have worked with people from all the political spectrum. Many of them have had very catastrophic fates. Some have been put in jail and then released (mostly people in the military and Chavismo dissidents). Some of them are banned from entering the country. Others went into exile. There are also those who stepped out of politics and are trying to build a life again.

There's something I would like to say about this: People normally think that persecuted, incarcerated, or people pushed into exile are great activists or important political figures. On the contrary, itâs mostly the participants who have very little influence on decision making. Dictatorships prefer to put down the lower rungs of the operation because it doesn't have huge costs in terms of public opinion. Our Venezuelan dungeons are currently filled with anonymous people who represented no real danger to society."

"I trained as an electrician and took a masterâs examination in the trade. From 1985 until 2013, I was a manager of a factory with 80 employees. It was stressful, and I am thankful that I retired in 2013 at age 63. That was the right decision, which I havenât regretted for an hour. The day-to-day operations of job as a boss makes you tired. I now have time to take care of my grandkids; I have something to do. I inherited a farm house. When I was still working, I didnât have a lot time to potter about; I have caught up on everything. Besides that, I volunteer â on the one side as a functionary for the trade and on the other side in the church, I am a member of the state synod. Thatâs how I spend my time.

It was difficult to be a Christian in the GDR. I was born in the Erzgebirge; there, we were somewhat protected, because the Christian tradition is strong there. And in my trade, they left me alone in terms of my religion. I wasnât persecuted. It is true that I couldnât do some things and study some things. I would have actually liked to get a high school degree, but I couldnât, because I would have had to do the youth initiation ceremony. That was the one thing. But I didnât regret my profession and havenât mourned anything.

The reunification was very stressful for me. We had the great luck that it was a workshop. We went to the customers. We didnât have a stationary production. Thatâs why as boss I only had to let go one employee out of 90 â that was the driver, who we didnât need anymore. In the weak economy of the Erzgebirge, there was no work of course. In 1991, almost everything was closed. So, we had to look for work and were out and about in all of Germany, or even all of Europe. We were in the Stuttgart area a lot, where there was a lot of work. For installers, it was also interesting to get to know the whole federal republic. By now, the installers work more at home of course, but it is possible now. Itâs a totally different situation.

I canât complain. Of course, we would have liked to earn a bit more, but the equalization process progressed little by little, and my people werenât out of work for a day after the reunification. We were cheap labor in the west, cheaper than the locals, but nevertheless, our people earned more there than here. I donât want to yell hallelujah â it was stressful enough with over 50 installers on construction sites. It was tricky and tense that everyone survived the work without accident. I was thankful every Friday that everyone was at home again without having had an accident."

It was stressful, and I am thankful that I retired in 2013 at age 63. That was the right decision, which I havenât regretted for an hour. The day-to-day operations of job as a boss makes you tired. I now have time to take care of my grandkids; I have something to do. I inherited a farm house. When I was still working, I didnât have a lot time to potter about; I have caught up on everything. Besides that, I volunteer â on the one side as a functionary for the trade and on the other side in the church, I am a member of the state synod. Thatâs how I spend my time.

It was difficult to be a Christian in the GDR. I was born in the Erzgebirge; there, we were somewhat protected, because the Christian tradition is strong there. And in my trade, they left me alone in terms of my religion. I wasnât persecuted. It is true that I couldnât do some things and study some things. I would have actually liked to get a high school degree, but I couldnât, because I would have had to do the youth initiation ceremony. That was the one thing. But I didnât regret my profession and havenât mourned anything.

The reunification was very stressful for me. We had the great luck that it was a workshop. We went to the customers. We didnât have a stationary production. Thatâs why as boss I only had to let go one employee out of 90 â that was the driver, who we didnât need anymore. In the weak economy of the Erzgebirge, there was no work of course. In 1991, almost everything was closed. So, we had to look for work and were out and about in all of Germany, or even all of Europe. We were in the Stuttgart area a lot, where there was a lot of work. For installers, it was also interesting to get to know the whole federal republic. By now, the installers work more at home of course, but it is possible now. Itâs a totally different situation.

I canât complain. Of course, we would have liked to earn a bit more, but the equalization process progressed little by little, and my people werenât out of work for a day after the reunification. We were cheap labor in the west, cheaper than the locals, but nevertheless, our people earned more there than here. I donât want to yell hallelujah â it was stressful enough with over 50 installers on construction sites. It was tricky and tense that everyone survived the work without accident. I was thankful every Friday that everyone was at home again without having had an accident."

Ich war Ã¼berwÃ¤ltigt von dieser Erfahrung - ein Onkel von mir wollte das gleiche in Caracas machen, aber eines Tages ist er beim Laufen umgebracht worden, weil Kriminelle seine Schuhe stehlen wollten. Es ist unglaublich, wie viele MÃ¶glichkeiten man hier hat, seine TrÃ¤ume zu erfÃ¼llen.

Sebastian hat mich eingeladen, bei ihm zu wohnen. Er hat mich gefragt, was fÃ¼r Hobbys ich zu Hause in Venezuela hatte, und ich habe gesagt, dass ich gefochten habe. "I applied for asylum around the time that a lot of refugees were arriving from Arab countries. I ended up in Heidenau. We were driven to a 'Baumarkt' that had been made into a huge dorm. There were around 800 of us. When we arrived, there was a bunch of people shouting and protesting. We had to get protection from the police. I didn't understand what was happening. The people in charge in the buses told us to close the curtains and try not to look through the windows. Everyone was grouped together in their different ethnic groups, and everyone could only communicate with their people. They separated us into religions too. They asked me, and I said I was Protestant, and they said they would put me with the Catholics. In the end, we are all Christians. I was together with all the black people. Itâs funny, but it happens to me everywhere. When a black person spots me, they greet me as if we had something in common, which we do -- our color.

I had to try to use the little English I knew. Maybe one thing we Venezuelans have in common is that we need to be in action. I can't sit around looking at Facebook. I tried to find ways to occupy myself. Cleaning up or doing something. In the end, all the security people and staff ended up liking me. I helped them organize all the newcomers. There is one thing I knew: I couldn't let myself fall into depression. It is very easy to become depressed when you are in such situation. Having so many people with different ethnicities in one room can be challenging. Once when we were queuing to get our food, some guys from Iraq exchanged some words with some others from Iran, and it ended up in a huge fight and the special police had to come in calm them down. It looked like in the movies, when the SWAT team breaks in.

Three months later, I was transferred to another camp here in Mickten. One of the volunteers (Sebastian) and I became good friends. He invited me to a jogging group, and we used to go running every Wednesday. I ran my first half marathon. I was very humbled by the experience, because an uncle of mine wanted to do the same back in Caracas, and one day he was killed while he was running because criminals wanted to steal his shoes. It's amazing how many opportunities you have to fulfill your dreams here.

Sebastian invited me to live at his place. He asked me about what I used to do for fun back in Venezuela, and I said I used to do fencing. He found me a club where I could exercise. They accepted me with open arms, offering me all the equipment. I have already been in four competitions.

Then I learned about a project called Paradiesisch Musizieren. I have been playing there every Thursday. I have had so much luck. I am very, very grateful. I am looking forward now to getting my credentials as a radiologist. I need to do a four-month course. Unfortunately, I canât do it here in Dresden. Another possibility for me would be to start another career as an emergency paramedic.

I am in a band here called EMBER/The Christopher Molina Trio, and we already recorded our first CD. I am pretty happy with my life right now."

"I come from Bochum originally. I came to Dresden to study music. Two years ago, I did my Masterâs at the music academy. I am a flautist. When I started, I wanted to be in an orchestra, and I came out totally different. The pressure in the orchestra was too much for me. Besides that, I was looking for something more. I wanted to pass on more of what I had learned. I played a lot more in small groups. I did chamber music. That was more fun for me and gave a lot more back. Besides that, I teach in the music school.

In 2016, we went with a Leipzig orchestra to Eritrea. There, I got to know the Crane Performers from Uganda, and I stayed in contact with them. 
Later, I went to Uganda for a month. I just wanted to get to know the musical culture there and see my friends again. When I was there, we had the idea to get a music project started ourselves. We collected donations from various house concerts in Dresden, so that we could buy the instruments. Then we started slowly. In January 2018, we did the first recorder lesson for the group. There are children age eleven and up there, but the average age was sixteen, seventeen years old. They learned first by listening, so they can get a feeling for the instrument. They played songs that they know from their own culture, also a lot of gospel songs. Then we slowly started learning to read music. Together with the whole team, we staged an African-European Magic Flute with element of Ugandan dances. We played the arrangement of a couple of arias from the Magic Flute on the flute as well as elements from the overture and composed more with them, etc. Now, this group totally identifies with the characters from the Magic Flute. 
When I was there in 2017, my friends took me to two grade schools and said, âJust introduce your instrument. That will definitely be exciting for the kids.â I presented the flute. I played a piece and danced and sang a lot with the children. After that, they all wanted to play the flute. Most people there donât have the possibility to learn it. They see it on TV, but they have absolutely no access to it.

The thing that I noticed about Uganda is that they are very friendly and warm people. You are immediately welcome everywhere, and they take care of you. Of course, I was the exotic there. Most people wanted to talk to me. If you come from here, then sometimes itâs a bit much. But in general, itâs a really welcoming culture. And there is music everywhere. A lot of it is very loud. There is some speaker everywhere, blaring. Music is everywhere.

Joseph from Uganda is with us now for four weeks in Germany. We will introduce his instrument Aâdungu to our music students and a couple of schools in Dresden, so that they can try it out. He would also like to offer lessons on the Aâdungu to anyone with interest. They can reach us by telephone. We are noticing in our project that music can quickly conquer boundaries. It brings people together quickly. If people hear music, it pulls them. They want to find out what it is. Itâs especially the case that when such different cultures make music together, they enrich each other. Then there are no more differences. I would say that music is one of the most important ways of bringing cultures together."

Heâs old, and I had to help take care of his kids. He couldnât speak English or German. When my uncleâs situation improved, I came to Germany, and we got married. I applied for asylum.

First, I was in Chemnitz. I told them that I was married and wanted to live with my wife, and they said, âNo problem, we will transfer you.â They transferred me to Dresden instead of Plauen. I have been in Dresden for a year and two months. 200 people have come through the camp, but I am the only one who stays. They tell me itâs because I already applied in Austria. Recently, I got a letter ordering me to leave Germany. I said, âHow can I leave? I have a wife here. I have been here for three years, why now?â A lawyer is working on it now. I donât know how long it will take.

I donât have anything in my life besides this girl, but sheâs getting tired. And me too, because of this situation. I want to fix this, for me and for her. Sometimes, I tell her, âGo live your life, be like a normal person,â and she says, âNo, we will fix it together.â

And now this injury. This is the worst of all. I was near the camp, hanging out with two friends, one from Palestine. I was joking around with him, and then he left. Then three guys ran up to me and said, âWhy are you talking to that guy like that?â I didnât know these guys. I said, âWhatâs your problem?â and one guy said, âHeâs from Palestine, I am Palestinian.â But my friend didnât have a problem with what I said.

We started fighting. The three guys and me. They hit me with a broken bottle, and I fell with my hand onto the broken bottle, and I got really hurt. The police came and took me to the hospital for six days. When I got out, German people told me that I had to file a police report. One woman recorded it all on her handy, and she said she can show that I didnât do anything wrong.

But I donât know. I just want everything to be like before. I donât know what the police will do. I am a foreigner. They are foreigners. I donât know. Maybe the police wonât do anything. Maybe the guys will get to sent to jail. But I wonât get anything.

I may have a problem with my arm for my whole life. In six months, they will be able to tell me.â

âI have been in Germany for a long time. For 19 years. I helped a lot of people, with translating and stuff. But I have come to a point, where I donât know how to help him or myself. I donât know how to get the papers so that we can just live together and work. I am ready to move back here from Bremen, so that I can live near the camp. "Ich komme eigentlich nicht aus Dresden, sondern aus Plauen. Mein Mann - Freund - wohnt in Dresden. Er ist Asylbewerber in Dresden. Wir sind jetzt schon drei Jahre islamisch verheiratet. Wir versuchen, dass wir irgendwie standesamtlich heiraten.

Wir haben uns 2013 im Libanon im Urlaub kennengelernt und haben uns verliebt. Vor drei Jahren wollte er herkommen, um zu mir bei mir zu sein. Er war zwei Jahre in Ãsterreich. Es hat irgendwie nicht gepasst mit der FamilienzusammenfÃ¼hrung. Dann hat er von Ãsterreich eine Abschiebung bekommen. Er hat versucht, nach Deutschland zu kommen, damit wir wenigstens in einem Land zusammen leben. Er ist erst nach Chemnitz gekommen und seit einem Jahr lebt er hier in der Bremer StraÃe in diesem Container.

Er hat keinen Ausweis, nur einen weiÃen Zettel, auf dem sein Name steht. Er darf Dresden nicht verlassen, er darf nicht arbeiten, er darf keinen Deutschkurs machen, er darf nicht heiraten, er darf gar nichts machen.

Er mÃ¶chte nichts vom Staat, nur dass wir zusammen leben kÃ¶nnen. Seit drei Jahren leben wir in verschiedenen StÃ¤dten. Damals bin ich jedes Wochenende nach Ãsterreich gefahren. Dann haben wir gedacht: âGott sei Dank ist er jetzt in Deutschland, jetzt kÃ¶nnen wir endlich mal in einer Wohnung zusammen leben.â Ich hatte eine Wohnung, aber von einem Lohn geht das nicht. Jetzt sind wir islamisch verheiratet und kÃ¶nnten das im Libanon beglaubigen lassen, aber da unten gibt es Schwierigkeiten, deswegen dauert das alles zu lange. Eigentlich brÃ¤uchte er nur einen Ausweis, damit er mit mir irgendwo leben kann.

Jetzt bin ich von Plauen nach Bremen gezogen, weil wir gesagt haben, dort gibt es bessere MÃ¶glichkeiten zum Arbeiten und wir haben dort mehr FamilienangehÃ¶rige. Aber nun hat er vor einer Woche einen Unfall gehabt und kann ein Jahr lang beide Arme nicht richtig benutzen. Jetzt wohne ich in Bremen und er in Dresden. Ich bin hergekommen, um zu fragen und mich zu kÃ¼mmern, wie ich mit ihm zusammen sein kann, auch in so einer Phase. Ich habe angeboten, dass ich mit im Heim lebe, aber da darf keiner rein und keiner raus. Ich habe gesagt, ich wÃ¼rde ihn gerne mit nach Bremen nehmen, aber er braucht einen Urlaubsschein und einen Krankenschein, damit er dort behandelt werden darf.

Jetzt warten wir seit vier Tagen auf eine Genehmigung, dass er irgendwie mit nach Bremen kommt. Wir mÃ¶chten kein Asyl, wir mÃ¶chten nur zusammen leben, wir mÃ¶chten nur, dass wir irgendwie heiraten kÃ¶nnen. Das groÃe Problem ist das BAMF - wenn er einen Ausweis bekommen wÃ¼rde und wenn wir die Heirat zur Seite legen, kÃ¶nnte er wenigstens versuchen zu arbeiten. Er hat viele MÃ¶glichkeiten gehabt, darf aber nicht, mit seinem weiÃen Zettel mÃ¶chte ihn niemand einstellen, weil er gefÃ¤hrdet ist, abgeschoben zu werden.

Er mÃ¶chte einen Deutschkurs belegen. Er mÃ¶chte nicht im Heim bleiben, weil er bei mir sein will. Sein Leben ist nicht im Heim. Er ist kein normaler FlÃ¼chtling, er ist geflÃ¼chtet wegen seiner Liebe und jetzt ist er eingesperrt in dem Heim. Er darf das Heim nur drei Tage verlassen, danach muss er sich zurÃ¼ck melden, ansonsten fliegt er aus dem System raus.

So leben wir seit drei Jahren. Wir leben von einem Lohn. Er bekommt in dem Heim dreiÃig Euro pro Woche, aber darauf haben wir verzichtet. Wir wÃ¼rden so gern offiziell in einer Stadt zusammen leben und eine Familie grÃ¼nden. Seit 2013 versuchen wir, den ersten Schritt zu machen."

"I actually donât come from Dresden but Plauen. My man â boyfriend â lives in Dresden. He is an asylum seeker in Dresden. We actually got married in the mosque three years ago. We are trying to get married legally.

We met each in Lebanon during a holiday and fell in love. Three years ago, he wanted to come here to be with me. He was in Austria for two years. Somehow it didn't fit with family reunification. Then he got a deportation order from Austria. He tried to come Germany, so that we could at least live in one country together. He first came to Chemnitz and for the past year, heâs lived here on Bremer StraÃe in a container. 

He doesnât have an ID, just a white piece of paper with his name on it. He is not allowed to leave Dresden, he canât work, he canât take German, he canât get married, he canât do anything.

He doesnât want anything from the state, just that we can live together. For the past three years, we have lived in different cities. Before, I went to Austria every weekend. Then we thought, âThank God, he is in Germany, now we can finally live in an apartment together.â I had an apartment, but it doesnât work with one salary. Now, we are married Islamically and could have that authenticated in Lebanon, but down there, there are difficulties so everything takes way too long. Actually, he just needs an ID, so he can live with me somewhere.

Now, I have moved from Plauen to Bremen, because we said, there are better options for work, and we have family members there. But he now had an accident a week ago, and he canât really use both of his arms for a year. Now I live in Bremen, and he lives in Dresden. I came here to ask and work on how I can live with him, also in this phase. I offered to live with him in the hostel, but no one is allowed to go in or out. I said that I would like to take him to Bremen, but he needs a vacation pass and an illness pass, so that he can be treated there.

Now, we have been waiting for four days for a permission so that he can come to Bremen somehow. We donât want asylum. We only want to live together. We only want to get married. The biggest problem is BAMF â if he could get an ID, and if we could put aside getting married, he could at least try to work. He had a lot of possibility but canât do anything. No one wants to hire him with his white piece of paper, because he could be deported.
He wants to take a German course. He doesnât want to stay in the hostel, because he wants to be with me. His life isnât in the hostel. He is not a normal refugee. He fled because of his love and now, heâs locked up in the hostel. He can only leave the hostel for three days at a time, then he has to check in, or he will be thrown out of the system.

Weâve been living this way for three years. We live on one salary. He gets thirty euros a week in the hostel, but we donât take it. We would so like to live in one city officially and start a family. Since 2013, we have been trying to take that step."

Then he got a deportation order from Austria. He tried to come Germany, so that we could at least live in one country together. He first came to Chemnitz and for the past year, heâs lived here on Bremer StraÃe in a container. 

He doesnât have an ID, just a white piece of paper with his name on it. He is not allowed to leave Dresden, he canât work, he canât take German, he canât get married, he canât do anything.

He doesnât want anything from the state, just that we can live together. For the past three years, we have lived in different cities. Before, I went to Austria every weekend. Then we thought, âThank God, he is in Germany, now we can finally live in an apartment together.â I had an apartment, but it doesnât work with one salary. Now, we are married Islamically and could have that authenticated in Lebanon, but down there, there are difficulties so everything takes way too long. Actually, he just needs an ID, so he can live with me somewhere.

Now, I have moved from Plauen to Bremen, because we said, there are better options for work, and we have family members there. But he now had an accident a week ago, and he canât really use both of his arms for a year. Now I live in Bremen, and he lives in Dresden. I came here to ask and work on how I can live with him, also in this phase. I offered to live with him in the hostel, but no one is allowed to go in or out. I said that I would like to take him to Bremen, but he needs a vacation pass and an illness pass, so that he can be treated there.

Now, we have been waiting for four days for a permission so that he can come to Bremen somehow. We donât want asylum. We only want to live together. We only want to get married. The biggest problem is BAMF â if he could get an ID, and if we could put aside getting married, he could at least try to work. He had a lot of possibility but canât do anything. No one wants to hire him with his white piece of paper, because he could be deported.
He wants to take a German course. He doesnât want to stay in the hostel, because he wants to be with me. His life isnât in the hostel. He is not a normal refugee. He fled because of his love and now, heâs locked up in the hostel. He can only leave the hostel for three days at a time, then he has to check in, or he will be thrown out of the system.

Weâve been living this way for three years. We live on one salary. He gets thirty euros a week in the hostel, but we donât take it. We would so like to live in one city officially and start a family. Since 2013, we have been trying to take that step."

Ich fÃ¼hle mich unsicher, wenn ich Fahrrad fahre. Ich fahre jeden Tag vierzehn Kilometer. Gerade bei der Strecke von der Neustadt zur Uni verstehe ich absolut nicht, dass es keine besseren MÃ¶glichkeiten gibt und warum das nicht PrioritÃ¤t sein sollte. Ich fÃ¤nde getrennte Fahrstreifen schÃ¶n, und einfach ernst genommen zu werden und eigenen Raum zu bekommen, der einem aus SicherheitsgrÃ¼nden auch zusteht, dass man einfach anerkennt, dass ich als schwache Verkehrsteilnehmerin ganz andere MaÃnahmen brauche als Autos, fÃ¼r die sonst immer alles ausgelegt ist, gerne eine grÃ¼ne Welle fÃ¼r FahrrÃ¤der zur Uni, auch Alternativen fÃ¼r den Autoverkehr, zu zeigen, dass das nicht sein muss.

Ich finde es einfach schade, dass die Debatte manchmal so hasserfÃ¼llt ist, dass es diese harte Frontenbildung gibt. Die meisten nutzten ja alle Fahrzeugarten, wenn man das zu ein bisschen sinnvoller zusammen denkt, das wÃ¤re einfach schÃ¶n."

"I am here because I like to bike. I have noticed the difference between Dresden and other cities very clearly, when I ride my bike elsewhere or when I ride my bike here. Itâs just important for me to demonstrate that you donât have to give up. Somehow, I have the feeling that there is a lot said about the project to change transportation, and nothing really happens. I think this action is just nice â the mood, the people â thatâs why I am here.

I feel unsafe when I ride my bike. I ride fourteen kilometers every day. I really donât understand the stretch between the Neustadt and the university, why there arenât better options and why this shouldnât be a priority. I would think separate lanes would be nice â just to be taken seriously and to get our own space for safety reasons. It would be nice if it were recognized that I, as the weaker participant in traffic, need other measures than cars for which everything is arranged. It would be good to have a green path to the university, also alternatives to going by car to show that it doesnât have to be like that.

I think itâs just too bad that the debate is sometimes so filled with hate, that these strong fronts are constructed. Most people use all forms of transportation. If we thought more meaningfully together, that would just be nice."

Unser Anliegen ist, das Thema in der Gesellschaft zu etablieren - dass es normal ist und nicht mehr geguckt wird, jetzt laufen hier zwei MÃ¤nner Hand in Hand, sondern dass das einfach dazu gehÃ¶rt. Wir wollen nicht mehr und nicht weniger als die anderen, sondern einfach dazugehÃ¶ren, dass man sagt, das ist ein Teil dieser Stadt. Ich denke mittlerweile haben wir das ziemlich gut hinbekommen.

Man muss mit diesen Menschen, genau wie mit allen Menschen, arbeiten, dass sie nicht homophob, nicht rassistisch, nicht antisemitisch sind. "Ich komme aus Venezuela. Ich habe Venezuela vor sechs Jahren verlassen. Ich bin Nachrichtentechniker und habe einen Abschluss in Management. Nachdem ich Venezuela verlassen hatte, war es ein bisschen schwierig fÃ¼r mich, wieder neu anzufangen, weil ich gezwungen war, mein Land zu verlassen. Ich habe in Restaurants gearbeitet und Englisch unterrichtet.

Damals in Venezuela habe ich bei der Regierung in der Verwaltung gearbeitet. Die Regierung unter Chavez hat sich groÃe MÃ¼he gegeben, offen gegenÃ¼ber homosexuellen Menschen zu sein, aber das Bewusstsein der Leute hatte sich nie geÃ¤ndert. Es gab immer noch Homophobie. Ich weiÃ nicht, warum. Vielleicht, weil es so viel Sexismus gibt? Sie konnten mich nicht kÃ¼ndigen, weil es beim Staat illegal ist, jemanden wegen seiner sexuellen Orientierung rauszuwerfen, also haben sie mich und meinen Freund, der jetzt mein bester Freund ist, in einen anderen Bundesstaat versetzt, und dann versucht, uns zu trennen. Wir haben dann selbst gekÃ¼ndigt, aber die Verfolgung ging weiter. Wir haben keine Morddrohungen bekommen, aber einmal wurden wir verfolgt und beinahe vergewaltigt. Wir mussten dort weg.

In Venezuela gab es schon immer ein Problem mit KriminalitÃ¤t. Wenn mich Leute jetzt fragen, sage ich ihnen, dass es nicht um Politik geht, sondern mehr um unsere Art zu denken. Ich glaube, wir mÃ¼ssen noch lernen. Wir waren immer ein gesetzloses Land. Wenn Venezolaner woanders sind, halten sie sich an die Gesetze, aber in Venezuela kann man machen was man will. Und jetzt ist es noch schlimmer. Die paar Regeln, die man befolgen musste, gibt es nicht mehr. Man kann nirgendwo mehr Straftaten anzeigen. Die Polizei macht nichts.

Zuerst waren wir in Argentinien, dann Panama, Kolumbien, dann wieder Panama. Dann haben mein Freund und ich entschieden, dass wir nach Europa gehen. Das ist eine lustige Sache. Eigentlich sollte es fÃ¼r uns in Lateinamerika einfacher sein, neu anzufangen, aber das war es nicht. Es ist super schwierig fÃ¼r Venezolaner, in anderen lateinamerikanischen LÃ¤ndern eine Aufenthaltsgenehmigung zu bekommen. Wir sind nach Spanien gegangen und sind schlieÃlich in Deutschland gelandet, weil wir hier Freunde hatten. Bekannte haben uns vom CSD erzÃ¤hlt. Der Asylprozess war fÃ¼r mich nicht schwierig. Ich hatte schon so viel durchgemacht, es schien ok zu sein und der CSD hat sehr geholfen. Das Schlimmste war wahrscheinlich das Warten.

Jetzt arbeite ich als Integrationbegleiter beim CSD. Ich glaube, ich habe schon immer gern geholfen. Ich habe angefangen, Englisch zu lernen, weil ich richtig schlecht in der Schule war. Weil ich sie geliebt habe, habe ich angefangen zu lernen. FÃ¼r mich ist es sehr wichtig, zu kommunizieren. Ich spreche viel. Ich erzÃ¤hle den Leuten gern, was ich denke. Als ich neu hier war, hatte ich nicht viel zu tun, also habe ich beschlossen, zu helfen. Ich habe nicht beim CSD gearbeitet, sondern nur ausgeholfen. Ich nehme manche Dinge zu persÃ¶nlich. Es ist toll zu helfen, wenn man weiÃ, dass man Menschen dabei hilft, ihr Leben zu verÃ¤ndern. FÃ¼r mich ist das groÃartig. Und ich habe hier die besten Kollegen. Es ist schÃ¶n, dass ich das teilen kann, was ich selbst mitgemacht habe."

Teil 1/2

"I come from Venezuela. I left Venezuela six years ago. I am a telecommunications engineer and have a degree in management. After I left Venezuela, it was a little difficult for me to start again because I was forced to leave my country. I have worked in restaurants, I taught English.

Back in Venezuela, I was working with the government in the management area. The government under Chavez tried to be really open to gay people, but peopleâs consciousness never changed. There was still homophobia. I donât know why. Maybe because there is so much sexism? They couldnât fire me, because itâs illegal to fire someone on the basis of sexual orientation in the government, so they transferred me and my then boyfriend (now best friend) to another state, and then they tried to split us up. We quit our jobs, but the persecution continued. We didnât have death threats, but one time we were followed and almost raped. We had to leave. 

Venezuela has always had a problem with criminality. When people ask me now, I tell them, itâs not about politics, itâs more our way of thinking. I think we still have to learn. We have always been a lawless country. When Venezuelans leave their country, they follow laws, but within the country, you can do whatever you want. Now itâs even worse. The few rules that you used to have to follow in Venezuela, they are no longer there. Thereâs no longer anyone to report crimes to. The police wonât do anything.

First, we were in Argentina, then Panama, Columbia, then Panama again. Then my boyfriend and I decided to go to Europe. Itâs a funny situation. It should be easier for us to begin again in Latin America, but it wasnât. Itâs super difficult for us Venezuelans to get residency in other Latin American countries. We went to Spain, and then we ended up in Germany because we had friends here. Some people we met introduced us to the CSD. For me, the asylum process was fine. I had been through so much, it didnât seem bad, and the CSD was so helpful. Waiting was probably the worst part.

Now, I work as an integration counselor at CSD. I think I have always liked to help. I began to learn English because I was really bad at school. My mom decided to ask a friend, my best friendâs mom who was like a second mother to me, to tutor me. Because I loved her, I started to learn. For me, itâs really important to communicate. I speak a lot. I like to tell people what I am thinking. When I first got here, I didnât have a lot to do, so I decided to take some time to help. I wasnât working at CSD, just helping. And then Ronald told me there was a job translating, and because I had been through the process myself, he thought I would be good for it.

Working as an integration counselor is hard because sometimes you go home with another personâs problems. Psychologically, itâs a little bit difficult sometimes. I take some things too personally. Itâs great to help knowing that you are helping people change their lives. For me, itâs great. I have the best colleagues here. Itâs nice to be able to share what I am going through."

Part 1/2

"My name is Youmna. I am 29 years old. I am from Egypt. I studied German language and literature in Egypt. I came here in 2012 to do my masterâs. I studied language and cultural studies at TU Dresden. At the moment, I am a Ph.D. student and research assistant. I am also the holder of the Marwa-El-Sherbini fellowship for tolerance and openness. Perhaps you have heard of Marwa-El-Sherbini, the Egyptian pharmacist who was murdered in Dresden. In the context of my fellowship, I do a lot of activities involving intercultural meetings between Dresden natives, refugees, and migrants, in order to dismantle prejudices. Unfortunately, you know what the atmosphere is like in Dresden. Today, I am doing an event that I have wanted to realize for a long time. We are inviting people to eat and drink for free in order to bring them into conversation. I hope that we are successful. We are mixed team of Germans and migrants. We are really hoping for lively discussion. The goal is to talk to each other instead of about each other. There are a lot of prejudices on both sides. We would like to dismantle them and that only happens with speaking, but food connects people as well, of course.

I have been active in diverse ways â socially and civically. I have also been active in refugee work. I noticed that refugees also have prejudices. When they have a bad experience â if they are insulted or abused â they think, âAll Germans are xenophobic.â On the other side, Dresden natives say that everyone who comes here are social parasites and not educated and canât speak any languages.

Seven years ago, I was one of the very, very few women who wore a headscarf here in Dresden. I thought that Germans were more enlightened in terms of religion, but when I got here, I found out that because of the historical background here in the east, people are not religious, that religion doesnât play any role. I pictured it differently. At the start, I was sometimes asked whether there were schools in Egypt or if I was allowed to go to school in Egypt. I thought the people here would be more educated than in Egypt, that they would maybe know that Egypt doesnât consist out of just camels and sand, but that there are also autos, schools, and universities. I have also often had people say to me: âYou speak German, I didnât know that.â Or they are amazed that I went to university. I was a little shocked at first, but with time, I also found it interesting that people come to me and ask why is this so and why is that so, why do I do this, why do I wear a headscarf? I actually found it really nice that people would ask.

To be honest, I have been insulted a lot, but at some point, I developed a thicker skin. I know that people are afraid, that they have prejudices. Some people donât want to have a conversation. There are really unreachable people, no matter how long you stand there and talk. In the end, you are the foreigner, maybe a terrorist, who wants to islamicize the city, and who is definitely oppressed -- because there are no intelligent women who wear headscarves, they have to be dumb and dominated by men. But there are also people who want to talk and be enlightened.

Itâs difficult to reach everyone. I said to myself: âIf someone insults you, who either thinks that all Muslim women are dominated or that I would like to behead people here, who has prejudices in other words, I donât have to engage. Sometimes, I do react so that the people know that I understood what they said. And they walk away. I wish that when people say something that they would stay and stand behind their words, but they walk away. If someone calls me a terrorist, I say, âThank you very much!â or âI am certainly not a terrorist.â Then they look a little surprised and keep walking. They seem to think that they can insult the weaker sex, that maybe women wonât understand or maybe they will be afraid and crawl away.

A lot of my female friends who are Muslim donât wear headscarves. Itâs never been a subject for us. I believe that it is an obligation for Muslim women, but when a woman doesnât do it, that doesnât mean that she isnât Muslim or that sheâs a bad Muslim. According to the Koran, we are not allowed to suggest that because we think that weâre better. It doesnât matter whether itâs a Muslim or non-Muslim, we arenât allowed to. For me, itâs not about all people being the same. In the Koran it says, âI have made you into nations and tribes so that you can get to know each other.â I think that if God had other plans, he would have made it so that we all have the same religion, no matter which one."

"When patriots now pretend to want to save the occident, you often find out in conversation that these patriots canât reasonably define what the occident actually is. For me, patriotism is nothing ethnic, rather it is simply connection to the culture that formed me, that is, however, very open-hearted to other cultures. Maybe itâs a new definition of patriotism. We donât live alone in this world. Instead, this city has become more colorful thanks to not just to the university. The world in general has become more colorful since people have started encountering each other so intensely. That has to be taken into account. What I mean is patriotism is not outdated. Patriotism should be something modern, something culturally conscious with an extra coating of a whole lot of tolerance.

I think that you can be happy that you live in Germany. A lot of people â the people who want to come here and canât because the path is blocked -- envy us because of that. I have lived in Dresden for 30 years. Itâs my homeland. I also got to know the GDR. I was there several times as a visitor. It is very important that I got to know to the GDR because I can understand a lot much better today. You also have to empathetically meet the people who were socialized in the GDR where they stand with their worries and problems. But we canât forget that we must repeatedly explain that people are doing better in general than before the reunification.

You can have a romantic picture of the past in terms of the family spaces, in terms of the sociality of back then. It was somewhat easier for a lot of people than today in this world, that is commercialized, that has become faster, where there is a diversity of media that overwhelms many people. Suddenly these warm family spaces that you built back then arenât there, and a lot of people still miss those warm spaces. But you also canât conjure that up anymore now. On the other side, people want to enjoy this new freedom.

Something that the people who grew up here in the GDR donât like to hear is that the GDR was a dictatorship, but we always have to remember: It was, it was a repressive system that oppressed people. They had to deal with that, and they fled into these family spaces in which they found cohesion. But basically, they were stuck in a relatively small world.

You always have to put this comparison before your mental eye: How would this society today look if the reunification didnât happen? Then we wouldnât have this nice citiy, which we enjoy every day. AltkÃ¶tzschenbroda would have been torn down and our small and middle-sized cities would not have been as beautifully renovated. There are things that you just have to throw on the scales.

If people have problems today, then itâs good that you can talk to them about it. I myself have had the experience that it is only through speaking to each other, that you can also produce more of a community. "Ich bin von Beruf Ingenieurin und komme aus Ãgypten. Ich bin hier, weil mein Mann hier arbeitet; er ist auch Ingenieur. Wir sind seit circa vier Jahren hier. Ich habe zwei Kinder - meine Tochter ist in der vierten Klasse und mein Sohn ist in der zweiten Klasse.

In diesem Projekt geht es darum, dass Leute miteinander sprechen und kommunizieren. Wenn die Leute Fragen haben Ã¼ber andere Kulturen oder Ã¼ber den Islam, kÃ¶nnen Sie einfach herkommen und uns fragen. Viele Menschen sprechen immer Ã¼ber eine andere Kultur, aber sie wissen nicht genau, was der Inhalt dieser Kultur ist. Sie haben nicht versucht, mit jemandem von der anderen Kultur ins GesprÃ¤ch zu kommen. Es gibt viele Leute, die hÃ¶flich nett und auch respektvoll sind. Einmal ist eine Frau zu mir gekommen, um mit mir zu sprechen. Sie war sehr hÃ¶flich und sie hatte viele Fragen. Am Ende hat sie sich bedankt. Sie meinte, dass sie das nicht gewusst hat und jetzt verstanden hat, warum ich Dinge so und so mache. Aber es gibt auch schlechte Erfahrungen. Ich finde das Projekt gut, wenn die Leute kommen und echte Fragen haben, wenn sie wirklich verstehen wollen. Manche Leute fragen auch nur um zu kritisieren."

"I am an engineer, and I am from Egypt. I am here because my husband has a job here; he is also an engineer. We have been here for about four years. I have two children -- my daughter is in fourth grade, and my son is in second grade.

This project is about getting people to speak and communicate with each other. If people have questions about other cultures or about Islam, they just come here and ask us. People talk about another culture without knowing about the content of that culture. They haven't tried to speak to people in that other culture. There are a lot of people, who are politely nice and respectful. Once, a woman came to me to talk to me. She was very polite and had a lot of questions. In the end, she thanked me. She said that she didn't know but now understood why I do things like I do. But there are also bad experiences. I think this project is a good idea if people come and have real questions, if they really want to understand. Some people only ask questions to criticize."

"I have been in Dresden for about six years. I work as a doctor at the cardiac center. I already learned German in Egypt before I came here.

I first came to Germany on July 1, 2009. I went to Regensburg to do an internship. July 1, 2009 was a very special day for Dresden. It was the day that the Egyptian pharmacist Marwa El-Sherbini was killed. That was my first encounter with Dresden. When I then wanted to come to Germany after university, I looked for work all over Germany. I wrote seventeen or eighteen applications, and my acceptance came from here. I had a friend who was already working here in cardiac center, so I said, âOk, I will come here. You have to have your own experiences.â

I personally havenât had any problems. But I have heard from other Egyptians or Arabs that they sometimes have problems with racism. Of course, there are questions from people, even from colleagues, but you notice that when you talk to people and try to enlighten them, it usually works. Whether or not they are convinced by what I say is another story, but at least they know something about the civil war in Syria. I think that helps.

I recently got married. I am waiting now for my wife. Now comes the real challenge. Life for an Arab man in Dresden is different than the life of an Arab woman, especially those who wear head scarves. That is a totally different life, a totally different experience. I donât say that every woman has problems, but the majority of Arab women have had a problem. I have heard about a lot of experiences, ranging from insults to physical attacks. 

I think it is really a big challenge. And thatâs why I think what Youma is doing here is great. She is trying to get in contact with people so that people understand how we think and how we live in this society. Meeting is always good. If we canât convince each other, at least we have heard a different opinion. I might also be wrong in my opinion. No one is right one hundred percent of the time. These events are just a chance for people to talk to each other and hear other opinions.

I just had a conversation about stereotypes with a man. He lived in Yemen for three months, and he saw two cases of marriage. Once was an eighteen-year old man who married a sixteen-year old girl. He hadnât see the girl before the marriage and he was shaking from fear. I explained that that has nothing to do with religion, rather with tradition. The second case was a 32-year old man, who had not yet had sex, because we Muslims arenât allowed to have sex before marriage. The man I was speaking with put everything on religion, that Islam makes our life complicated. I tried to explain that we do it because we are convinced by it and what is even more important is that there are one and a half billion Muslims all over the world. That means that there are different opinions. Itâs not right to make conclusions about a billion and a half people based on two cases that the man saw in Yemen. But he has his idea of Islam. I donât know if he has ever read a book about Islam. If you want to know something, you have to read. We are here in Germany, one of the countries in which people read the most.

"Ich bin hauptberuflich Musiker, aber gleichzeitig auch Vorsitzender eines interreligiÃ¶sen Vereins. Er heiÃt BIRD - BÃ¼ndnis Inter-ReligiÃ¶ses Dresden. In unserem Verein setzen wir uns ein fÃ¼r ein Miteinander von Menschen verschiedener Konfessionen und Weltanschauungen. Ich als Musiker weiÃ natÃ¼rlich um die verbindende Wirkung der Musik. Wir veranstalten jÃ¤hrlich ein interreligiÃ¶ses Friedenskonzert in der Kreuzkirche, wo wir KÃ¼nstler aus den verschiedenen Religionen zusammenbringen und sie gemeinsam Musik machen â Juden, Christen, Muslime, Buddhisten, aber auch SÃ¤kulare. UnabhÃ¤ngig davon, woran jeder glaubt - durch das gemeinsame Musizieren zeigen wir, dass wir nicht nur in Harmonie erklingen, sondern auch in Harmonie existieren kÃ¶nnen.

Ich bin der festen Ãberzeugung, dass die meisten Menschen in Frieden miteinander leben wollen, egal woher sie kommen und woran sie glauben. Unsere Idee ist, dass wir Religionen zusammenbringen und fÃ¼r ein friedliches Miteinander werben lassen, weil die meisten religiÃ¶sen Menschen eigentlich kein Problem miteinander haben. Es sind nur die Extremisten, die uns weismachen wollen, dass wir nicht miteinander kÃ¶nnen. 

Ich glaube, die Medien haben eine groÃe Mitschuld daran, dass so viele Menschen Probleme mit dem Islam haben. Wenn ich mit Muslimen spreche, komme ich sehr schnell zu einer Einigkeit, dass wir an den gleichen Gott glauben, dass wir sagen, wir wollen uns gegenseitig akzeptieren. Die Medien suggerieren uns immer etwas andres. Wenn Sie an die katholische Kirche denken, denken Sie nicht zuerst an die NÃ¤chstenliebe, sondern an Kindesmissbrauch, weil das thematisiert wird. Und so ist es auch beim Islam, da werden die Dinge, die angeblich im Namen des Islam passieren, thematisiert - wenn sich jemand in die Luft sprengt oder wenn es irgendwo Krieg gibt. DarÃ¼ber muss auch berichtet werden, aber es wird nie darÃ¼ber berichtet, dass Menschen zusammenkommen und sagen, wir wollen zusammen miteinander leben. Wir wollten ein Gegengewicht dazu bilden. 

Gerade hier im Osten Deutschlands ist es natÃ¼rlich so - viele Menschen sind Ã¼berhaupt nicht religiÃ¶s, haben keinen Bezug zur Religion. Jetzt kommen auf einmal Menschen von woanders her und bringen ihre fremde Kultur mit, eine Religion, die sie gar nicht kennen, die sie nur Ã¼ber die Medien wahrnehmen. Dadurch entsteht dieses einseitige Bild. Umgekehrt ist es genauso mit Ostdeutschland. Viele Menschen, die in Westdeutschland leben, und gerade AuslÃ¤nder sagen, ich will nicht nach Ostdeutschland, da sind mir zu viele Nazis. Es gibt hier Nazis, aber natÃ¼rlich sind die Mehrheit der Deutschen keine Nazis.

Das sind diese Vorurteile, die man hat, wenn man sich nicht von Mensch zu Mensch begegnet. Menschen pauschal aufgrund ihrer ReligionszugehÃ¶rigkeit zu kategorisieren - das hatten wir in Deutschland schon mal. Ich sehe viele Parallelen zu damals. NatÃ¼rlich haben wir im Moment noch keine Konzentrationslager fÃ¼r Muslime, aber zu sagen, der Muslim ist so und so, wie ich das gerade eben im GesprÃ¤ch mit der AfD erlebt habe, da hat man seine Vorurteile und ist doch nicht bereit, die abzubauen, selbst im persÃ¶nlichen GesprÃ¤ch nicht. FÃ¼r mich ist das schon bedenklich und ich denke, das ist genau die Verantwortung, die wir als Deutsche haben, dass wir sagen, wir begegnen unserem NÃ¤chsten als Mensch und nicht als Jude oder Muslim. Das ist herausfordernd, und wie man sieht, haben wir da noch eine Menge zu tun."

"My main job is as a musician, but at the same time, I am also the chairman of an interreligious association. Itâs called BIRD (alliance for interreligious Dresden). In our association, we are active trying to build a community of people of different confessions and world views. As a musician, I know of course about the effect of music in bringing people together. Every year, we put on an interreligious concert for peace in the Kreuzkirche, where we as artists from different religions bring people together and make music together â Jews, Christians, Muslims, Buddhists, but also secular people. Independent from what everyone believes, we can show that we cannot only harmonize in music but exist in harmony as well.

I am strongly convinced that most people want to live together in freedom, no matter where they come from and what they believe in. Our idea is that we bring religions together and advertise for living peacefully together, because most religious people donât actually have a problem with each other. Itâs just the extremists, who want to make us believe that we canât live together.

I think the media is a lot at fault that so many people have problems with Islam. If I speak to Muslims, I quickly come to a consensus that we believe in the same God, that we say that we want to accept each other. The media is always suggesting something else to us. If you think about the Catholic Church, you donât first think of loving your neighbor but of child abuse, because that has been thematized. And that is the way it is with Islam. The things that allegedly happen in the name of Islam are thematized â if someone blows themselves up or if there is war somewhere. It has to be reported more â but it is never reported â that people come together and say, we want to live together. We want to be counterweight.

Especially here in the eastern Germany, it is of course the case that many people are not at all religious, have no connection to religion. Now, all of sudden, people from somewhere else come and bring their foreign culture with them, a religion that they donât know at all, that they only perceive through the media. Thatâs how they get this one-sided picture. On the other side, itâs exactly the same with eastern Germany. Many people in western Germany, especially foreigners, say, I donât want to go to eastern Germany. There are too many Nazis for me there. There are Nazis here, but of course, the majority of Germans arenât Nazis.

There are these prejudices that people have if you donât meet person to person. Categorizing people just on the basis of their religious affiliation â we had that in Germany already. I see a lot of parallels to back then. Of course, at the moment, we donât have concentration camps for Muslims, but to say âThe Muslim is like this and that,â as I just experienced in conversation with someone from the AfD â they have their prejudices and arenât prepared to take them apart, even in personal conversation. For me, that is already alarming, and I think that we as Germans have the responsibility to say that we will encounter our neighbor as a person and not as a Jew or a Muslim. That is challenging, and as you see, we still have a lot to do."

"I think that it is totally important that you go out on the street, that you show yourself, that you are active against the extreme right. If we don't do it, who will?

Leftwing extremism and rightwing extremism are both awful, just as extremism is always awful -- it is extreme. But you don't have to act so extremely. I am for tolerance and for living together. I think that it isn't a crime if you advocate for tolerance, human rights, freedom, etc.

"Ich arbeite heute hier zusammen mit dem Jugendverein 'Roter Baum', wo ich als Projektmanager des Projektes 'Einmischen' angestellt bin. Damit gehen wir an Jugendliche heran und fragen sie, ob sie Ideen fÃ¼r Projekte haben, wie sie ihr Umfeld verbessern wollen. Ein Projekt ist zum Beispiel gerade, dass Jugendliche einen Skatepark errichten wollen. Wir sind in ganz Sachsen tÃ¤tig.

Wir haben auch Ganztagsangebote. Ich leite gerade jede Woche ein Ganztagsangebot in der Oberschule in Briesnitz namens 'Schule ohne Rassismus - Schule mit Courage' - das wollen sie werden und wir begleiten sie dabei. Um Schule ohne Rassismus zu werden, muss man eine Unterschriftenliste mit mindestens 70 Prozent aller Teilnehmenden der Schule sammeln. DafÃ¼r muss die Aufmerksamkeit geschaffen werden; das erreicht man, indem man zum Beispiel den Tag der offenen TÃ¼r dafÃ¼r nutzt und dafÃ¼r einen Stand baut. Das lÃ¤uft soweit ganz gut. Wir sind jetzt dabei, die Unterschriften zu sammeln. Diese Woche kommt die Leitende des Netzwerkes fÃ¼r Courage zu uns und wir besprechen zusammen, wie wir es endgÃ¼ltig schaffen kÃ¶nnen, unsere Ziele zu erreichen.

Es kommt natÃ¼rlich auf die Schule an. Wir sind zum Beispiel auch in der Laborschule in Gorbitz tÃ¤tig. Das ist natÃ¼rlich eine Musterschule - alle sind sehr aufgeklÃ¤rt, was dieses Thema und andere Themen betrifft, es ist auch eine Inklusionsschule. Ich will nicht sagen, dass dort kein Rassismus herrscht - das sollte man nirgendwo sagen - aber es ist ein relativ gutes Klima. Wir sind dort mehr unterstÃ¼tzend tÃ¤tig, auch fÃ¼r die Lehrer und Lehrerinnen im sÃ¤chsischen Schulsystem, die natÃ¼rlich heillos Ã¼berfordert sind. Deswegen ist es immer ganz gut, wenn wir mit eingreifen dÃ¼rfen. Meistens werden wir von den Lehrerinnen und Lehrern und den SchulsozialarbeiterInnen angesprochen, ob wir mal in die Schule kommen wollen, um zum Beispiel einen Workshop zu machen.

In anderen Schulen ist es schwieriger. In Briesnitz sind wir zum Beispiel darum gebeten worden, weil die SchÃ¼lerinnen und SchÃ¼ler das GefÃ¼hl hatten, das dort etwas getan werden muss, wo sie auch Geschichten erzÃ¤hlen...es ist halt blÃ¶d, wenn man diskriminiert wird. Ich persÃ¶nlich habe aber noch nichts von kÃ¶rperlichen Angriffen bei meinen SchÃ¼lerinnen und SchÃ¼lern gehÃ¶rt. Es ist auch eine DaZ-Schule und da ist es immer ein bisschen das Problem der Inklusion. Sie bemÃ¼hen sich schon sehr, aber durch die Schwierigkeiten der DaZ-SchÃ¼ler mit der deutschen Sprache sind sie natÃ¼rlich fÃ¼r die anderen SchÃ¼lerinnen und SchÃ¼ler erstmal die Anderen. Die wÃ¼rden nicht nach Teneriffa ziehen, weil es dort ruhiger ist, sondern die sehen, dass sie hier eine Aufgabe haben. Das ist sehr anstrengend, aber irgendjemand muss es ja machen."

"I am working here today with the youth association âRed Tree,â where I am a project manager for the project âGet Involved.â In the project, we go to teenagers and ask them if they have ideas for projects to improve their surroundings. One example is a project where teenagers are creating a skate park. We are active in all of Saxony.

We also have afterschool programs. Every week, I lead an afterschool program in the the junior high in Briesnitz called, âSchool without Racism, School with Courage.â Thatâs what they want to be, and we are helping them with it. In order to become a school without racism, you have to collect a list of signatures of at least 70% of all the participants in the school. In order to do that, we have to get attention; you achieve that by building a stand at the open-house day, for example. This week, the leaders of a network for courage are coming to us, and we are talking together about how we can finally achieve our goal.

It depends on the school, of course. We are working in a laboratory school in Gorbitz, for example. Itâs of course a model school â they are very enlightened about this and other subjects. Itâs also an inclusion school. I donât want to say that there is no racism there. You canât say that about any place, but itâs a relatively good climate. We are more there to offer to support to the teachers, among others, who are incredibly overburdened in the Saxon school system. Thatâs why itâs always good when we are allowed to intervene. Usually, we are approached by the teachers and school social workers and asked if we want to come to the school and maybe do a workshop.

In other schools, itâs more difficult. In Briesnitz, we were asked because the students had the feeling that something had to be done there, they told storiesâ¦ itâs just stupid to be discriminated against. I personally havenât heard anything about physical attacks from my students. Itâs also a German as Second Language school, and there is always a little bit of the problem of inclusion. They try a lot, but because the difficulties that the GSL students have with the German language, they are always a little bit âthe otherâ for the other students. Itâs a problem that my group recognized, and they say they would like to help, because the GST students sometimes have trouble with homework, and the teachers canât really help them. There is a students-helping-students group, which also tries to create awareness that the GST students are also cool, normal people whom you can talk to normally, if you try. They try to create that awareness among the kids. They say themselves that sometimes itâs useless. Sometimes, you just canât do anything. Some are so stubborn; they donât care what you are saying. Itâs more about creating a general awareness, something to have in the back of your head, like, âIf something happens to me, if I am affected by racism or discrimination, then I have the knowledge that at least 70% of my school is against it, that I am not alone.â

"Ich bin PerformancekÃ¼nstler aus Berlin. Ich habe fÃ¼r die Tolerade kooperative Schilder vorbereitet, das sind Schilder mit zwei Stielen, die so groÃ sind, dass man sie zu zweit oder zu viert tragen muss. So kÃ¶nnen mehrere Menschen zusammenfinden und einen Spruch generieren, zu dem sie zusammen stehen und damit demonstrieren wollen.

Ich liebe Demos generell. Ich habe schon mal in Jena eine Reihe Montagsdemos produziert, da haben wir vier Montage hintereinander Kunstdemos gemacht. Ich liebe es, dass man die ganze Welt auf ein Schild pressen und sich einen guten Slogan ausdenken muss.

Es ist interessant, wie immer wieder versucht wird, der Kultur Mittel zu streichen, aber es ist gut, dass es nicht so ist wie in Amerika, wo Kunst nur von MÃ¤zenen gefÃ¶rdert wird, dass es hier andere Strukturen gibt, die das mitfinanzieren."
--
"I am a performance artist from Berlin. I prepared cooperative signs for Tolerade. They are signs with two sticks that are big enough so that two or four people have to carry them. People have to come together and generate a saying with which they want to stand together and demonstrate.

I like demonstrations in general. I already produced a series of demonstrations on Monday in Jena; we did cultural demonstrations four Mondays one after each other. I love it that you can compress the whole world onto a sign and have to think up a good slogan.

It's interesting how they are always trying to cut funding for culture, but it's good that it's not like it is in America where art is only supported by rich patrons. It's good that there are other structures here that finance art."

Als Kinder- und Jugendtheater stehen wir gern fÃ¼r eine vielfÃ¤ltige Gesellschaft. Ich finde, eine vielfÃ¤ltige Gesellschaft ist fast das Wichtigste, was es gibt. Was wir Kindern und Jugendlichen erzÃ¤hlen kÃ¶nnen ist, dass es das eine Normal nicht gibt. Normal ist, dass wir alle, jeder Einzelne, ganz unterschiedlich sind.

Ich finde, dass man das oft genug im Stadtbild gar nicht so wahrnimmt, oder dass Menschen, denen zugeschrieben wird, dass sie anders sind, an den Rand gedrÃ¤ngt sind. Ich finde, das macht die Welt langweilig. Und es ist auch eine Illusion; so ist es nicht. Normal gibt es nur als etwas, das sich aus ganz vielen Anders zusammensetzt. Wir als tjg haben es da natÃ¼rlich ganz leicht, weil wir Geschichten Ã¼ber die Welt erzÃ¤hlen, und diese Geschichten wÃ¤hlen wir schon sehr bewusst aus. Wir geben uns MÃ¼he, dass auf unserer BÃ¼hne verschiedene Haltungen zur Welt und verschiedene Menschen reprÃ¤sentiert werden. Und wir versuchen auch, Kinder und Jugendliche, die sonst im politischen und gesellschaftlichen Diskurs gar nicht so oft wahrgenommen werden, eine BÃ¼hne zu geben und mit ihnen kÃ¼nstlerisch so zu arbeiten, dass sie sich zur Politik und Gesellschaft Ã¤uÃern."
