"I am a dramaturge at the theater junge generation â so in the children and youth theater in the city. Tjg is a member of Weltoffenes (Open-to-the-World) Dresden. As a theater for children and teenagers, we are glad to stand for a diverse society. I think a diverse society is almost the most important thing. What we can tell children and teenagers is that there is no such thing as normal. Normal is that we are all, each individual, totally different.

I think that you donât see that often in enough in the way the city presents itself â or people who are called different are forced to the edges. I think that makes the world boring. And itâs an illusion. It just isnât true. Normal is something that we put together out of very many differents. At tjg, we have it easy, because we tell stories about the world, and we choose these stories consciously. We make an effort to represent different positions toward the world and different people on our stage. And we also try to give children and teenagers, who arenât often taken into consideration otherwise, a stage and to work with them artistically so that they can express themselves about politics and society."

Wenn man Kinder hat, mÃ¶chte man ihnen die Welt nicht weiterreichen wie ein schmutziges Tuch.

Es ging darum, Menschen zu interviewen und die Interviews zusammen mit einem Foto auf Facebook zu stellen. Sophie und Robert haben angefangen, Interviews zu machen, und sie haben damit eine Wirkung erzielt. Die Leute haben sich mit den Geschichten identifiziert. Und mir wurde klar, dass diese Geschichten die Macht haben, Leute zu heilen, Empathie zu erzeugen. Ich beschloss, dass das etwas ist, das ich in meinem Leben mÃ¶chte, trotz meiner SchÃ¼chternheit und meinem starken spanischen Akzent, wenn ich Deutsch spreche.

Sophie musste schlieÃlich zurÃ¼ck in die Staaten. Robert hat beschlossen, dass er weitermachen mÃ¶chte, mit mir als Interviewerin."

Sandra was one of the three members of People in Dresden for four years. She is stepping back now for health reasons. We are really sad that we will have to go on without her wonderful interviews in the future.

"I met this guy from KÃ¶nigsbrÃ¼ck through couchsurfing. He stayed with a friend of mine in one of the most dangerous shantytowns in Caracas. Venezuelans are really welcoming, almost euphoric, so he thought it was an exaggeration when people said that Caracas was one of the most dangerous cities in the world. He was living his life as if he were in Germany, and this friend of mine told me, âPlease, I need somebody to take care this crazy German boy.â We became friends.

So, thatâs how I met my now ex-husband. After that, I came to Belgium for a while, and he suddenly started writing more messages, and I donât want to talk about my love life, but we became a couple. He wanted to live in Venezuela. Itâs warm, people are very happy, itâs Caribbean. He visited, took time off of work to figure out if he could live there. Meanwhile, things were getting worse in Caracas. We were mugged. Friends were kidnapped. I was threatened in the metro with a knife, on the streets, near my home.

Caracas has been a dangerous city since I was a teenager, but the few years before I left, it was impossible. You couldnât have a smart phone. They would kill you for it. Life has a completely different significance in a country like Venezuela. But my ex was still in his honeymoon phase with the country. You are very free there. The state isnât watching you all the time, sending you letters about every single thing. I can understand his fascination.

Then one day, I got in the bus to go home from work, my daughter was with me. Some guys got on the bus and closed the doors. That day, I hadnât taken money out of the ATM, but they didnât want to believe that I only had a few coins. They pointed a gun at my daughter. That was the moment when I said, âI donât even care where I move, as long as itâs a little bit safer.â

For the next few months, we thought about what to do. I have a degree in education, and I have worked as an organizer. In Venezuela I was doing projects on domestic violence and the LGBT community, and an ecological project in an especially progressive shantytown in Caracas. My specialty is bringing people together. I had offers in Argentina, and Thailand to work in human rights projects, but I knew that moving anywhere with my daughter was going to cost a lot of money. I knew that I would have to send her to a private school. And I didnât want to move somewhere without a support system. My ex already had a job in Silicon Saxony, and his family lived here, so we moved to Dresden. It felt like the right decision. At the same time, I was very insecure about speaking German. I didnât know if I was going to succeed. I had very low self-esteem at that time. I was afraid to be myself.

When I got to Dresden, I became active in International Friends. I found people all over the world who were open-minded or trying to be open-minded, hanging out together. It was exactly what I needed in those stressful times around 2015. Pegida had started, and the demonstrations reached 25,000 people, I thought, this is not the place I want to raise my children. I had a son with my husband. I have a white son and a brown daughter, and I always wanted my son to be aware of his privilege.

It was also around that time that I experienced my first racist attack. I was giving an interview with the MDR on the street about how the foreign parents at my daughterâs school were picking up their children on Mondays because they were nervous. And some man threatened me with a broken bottle.

All of the people in International Friends wanted to do some kind of action to show that we foreigners were just normal people who want to live normal lives. We wanted to show support to the people who were more vulnerable. Most of us were professionals or scientists or students. We felt like we couldnât let it pass without doing something. I have seen a lot of injustice in my life â in Venezuela, Colombia, the US â and I have the will to make a better world. When you have children, you donât want to pass the world on to your children like a dirty cloth.

We had a lot ideas of how to protest the silence of Dresden society. This American girl Sophie told us about a project that she had been doing in the US, interviewing people and posting the interviews on Facebook with pictures. Sophie and Robert started doing interviews, and they had an impact. People identified with the stories. And I realized that stories have a power to heal people, to create empathy. I decided that it was something I wanted in my life, despite my shyness and my strong Spanish accent in German.

Sophie eventually had to go back to the states, and Robert decided he wanted to keep going with the project, with me doing interviews."

Sandra was one of the three members of People in Dresden for four years. She is stepping back now for health reasons. We are really sad that we will have to go on without her wonderful interviews in the future.

"I met this guy from KÃ¶nigsbrÃ¼ck through couchsurfing. He stayed with a friend of mine in one of the most dangerous shantytowns in Caracas. He was living his life as if he were in Germany, and this friend of mine told me, âPlease, I need somebody to take care this crazy German boy.â We became friends.

So, thatâs how I met my now ex-husband. After that, I came to Belgium for a while, and he suddenly started writing more messages, and I donât want to talk about my love life, but we became a couple. He wanted to live in Venezuela. Itâs warm, people are very happy, itâs Caribbean. He visited, took time off of work to figure out if he could live there. Meanwhile, things were getting worse in Caracas. We were mugged. Friends were kidnapped. I was threatened in the metro with a knife, on the streets, near my home.

I have seen a lot of injustice in my life â in Venezuela, Colombia, the US â and I have the will to make a better world. Itâs all in your head.â You start second-guessing yourself, âAm I imagining all these things?â

I started going to a psychologist, but I couldnât express in German myself well enough to receive the care that I needed. It just became this spiral of bad events. There was Pegida, the extreme cold and darkness of the winter, the problems in my body, I had a little baby and a daughter who was being bullied at school because sheâs brown. My world was falling apart. My illness also caused the relationship with my husband to deteriorate. Itâs not easy seeing your partner get sicker every day. His mental health was also affected. And we had financial problems, because I couldnât work as much as I wanted to.

I am a feminist. I decided to believe in myself and keep looking for a diagnosis. I read a lot online, and I kept seeing chronic illness about autoimmune diseases. I saw a lot about women complaining about painful periods and fatigue and not being listened to. I know that I am sensitive, but that doesnât mean I am not rational. I have always had a personality like a coach, encouraging people, telling them that they are great, and they can do better. I just wanted someone who would do that for me. I finally talked to my friends who were doctors in Venezuela and told them about my blood tests, and they said, âIt sounds like you have Lupus. You need to ask for these tests.â I had to fight to get the tests done because the insurance companies here donât want you to get to the specialized tests right away because they are expensive. I insisted and when we did them, my rheumatological levels were 150 times average.

I can understand in a way why getting the diagnosis here was so difficult. Lupus is most common among women with African descent, Latin American descent, and Asian descent. I guess it was difficult for my German doctors to imagine I would have Lupus. I finally got a diagnosis from an amazing doctor, who has a rheumatology clinic in Berlin. At first, it was a relief to find out I wasnât crazy.

Since 2015, I have been fighting with myself. As such an active person, I have had a really hard time accepting that I canât do the activities I used to do. In the past three years, it has been really tough to keep up with any of my activities. After my stroke, I decided that I should open myself up to receive and not only give. Itâs a lack of compassion for yourself. Itâs been really difficult to show myself.

One of my sources of stress recently has been the situation in Venezuela; itâs is a catastrophe. I think civil war is coming, and it will affect my family, my neighbors, and friends. This is my only project at the moment. All I can do now is advocate for the Venezuelans in Dresden, especially the LGBT refugees. I am also hosting a dinner together with some other Venezuelans is to raise money for medical care in Venezuela. The owner of Nosh has been kind enough to let us use her space to feed people Venezuelan food, educate them a little about the situation there, and raise some money to send home."

In the past three years, it has been really tough to keep up with any of my activities. After my stroke, I decided that I should open myself up to receive and not only give. Itâs a lack of compassion for yourself. Itâs been really difficult to show myself.

One of my sources of stress recently has been the situation in Venezuela; itâs is a catastrophe. I think civil war is coming, and it will affect my family, my neighbors, and friends. Ich habe die letzten zwei Wochen ein Praktikum gemacht in einem Hotel, ich mÃ¶chte vielleicht eine Ausbildung zum Hotelfachmann machen. Aber es ist ziemlich schwer. Dresden gefÃ¤llt mir gut und ich hoffe, dass mein Asylantrag bewilligt wird und ich hier bleiben kann. Aber ich bin nicht sicher, ob es klappt. 

Ich wohne in Cossebaude, das ist weit drauÃen und wenn ich in Dresden Leute treffen will, muss ich mit dem Zug oder dem Bus eine halbe Stunde herfahren. Dort wohne ich in einer WG, schon recht lange, das ist ok fÃ¼r mich, mit mehreren Leuten zusammen zu wohnen.

Meine Mutter und meine beiden Schwestern leben noch in Eritrea, mein Vater ist in Israel. Ich hoffe, dass mein Vater nach Deutschland kommt, er hat das vor und mÃ¶chte auch hier leben. Zu ihm habe ich mehr Kontakt als zu meiner Mutter, ich weiÃ aber, dass es ihnen gut geht und ich vermisse sie auch."

"I am from Eritrea, and I have been in Dresden for three years. Right now, I am doing a German course at level B1. I have done an internship in a hotel for two weeks. Maybe I wanted to do a training course to work in a hotel. But it's pretty difficult. I like Dresden, and I hope that my application for asylum is approved, and I can stay here, but I am not sure if it will work. I live in Cossebaude. That's far outside of the city and when I want to meet people in Dresden, I have to travel for half an hour with a tram or bus. I live in a shared apartment there. It's ok for me to live with other people.

My mother and my two sisters still live in Eritrea. My father is in Israel. I hope that my father comes to Germany. He wants to come and live here. I have more contact with him than with my mother, but I know that they are doing well, and I miss them too."

"I have lived in Dresden for a few years, and I studied music and jazz singing at the Hochschule fÃ¼r Musik here. Originally, I am from southern Germany, but I have adjusted so well by now that I would almost call myself a Dresdener.

I am part of a duo with another singer. We have two loop stations, and we do crazy things. Then I have another band thatâs called nouk with strings and acoustic guitar. Also, I basically do my own music, write a lot, and am always out presenting my music, including in Dresden.

And then I do individual projects like this one here now, the âspontaneous choir.â The project is also new to me â I am doing it for the first time. It takes place in front of the Scheune, and they asked me if once a month during the summer, I would study a piece for an hour, together with people who are spontaneous and participate. Itâs about offering people the experience of how it is to sing in a choir or to stand in an open place in the middle of the city and sing freely. Today was my premiere, and I thought it was cool. It is exciting because you can never say before hand whether people can sing or want to at all or whether they will like the song or not. But it was very positive today, and the people were able to sing and were open to everything. That was fun.

First, I feel so happy in Dresden because of the people I have gotten to know in the course of the years, who are really close to my heart. Second, I am happy here because of the music scene now. There are super good musicians here, especially at the Hochschule. Itâs a crazy singing class. I got so much inspiration, which brings me further again and again. At the beginning of my studies, I founded way too many projects. I suddenly had ten bands, because I wanted to make music with everyone. I had to break this down pretty quickly because it became too much. Nevertheless, I like the impressions that bombard you here. Itâs cool how much you can do. Itâs a strength of the city that things like âspontaneous choirâ are possible, and I think that you can do even more with this strength. For example, I opened a series of jam sessions in the Palais Palette. Thatâs something where I say, âI can give something back to the city. I can add expressive possibilities to the scene.â 

I think the most important thing in life is to listen to your gut feelings, even if reason says, âHey, whatâs this now?â You should nevertheless dare to do what is good for you and what you need in the moment."

Heimat bleibt immer die erste Heimat, wo man aufgewachsen ist, wo man zur Schule gegangen ist, wo man die erste Liebe gehabt hat.

Mit den Menschen in Kontakt zu kommen, ist schwierig fÃ¼r jeden. Das sind tiefe kulturelle Sachen und es dauert, bis man seinen Platz in der Gesellschaft findet. Das fÃ¤ngt fÃ¼r die jungen Menschen mit ganz normalen Beziehungen, Mann-Frau, an. Ich war damals fÃ¼nfunddreiÃig und verheiratet, deswegen hat es fÃ¼r mich mit der Arbeit angefangen. In this framework, we do some things, cultural events, we try to help people integrate, that they can find work or training. We introduce them to governmental institutions. "I have been in Dresden since 2009. After volunteering for a year after high school, I applied to study medicine. I didnât get in. Instead of that I did a nursing internship and a physiotherapy training, and then I studied for a year in Canada. I came back to Dresden, because I like it. I was then a physiotherapist in the Uniklinik, and then I started studied medicine in 2016.

I am here with the critical doctors. In addition to the critical doctors, we founded a health collective. We are trying to build up a solidarity clinic so that all people can get good medical care, without discrimination, no matter their insurance or residence status, without paying money. We founded it last year and have been an association since this year. Within the next few years, we want a social-psychological advising station. We are doing everything on a volunteer basis and on the side. At the moment, itâs about acquiring money, so that we can have two 300 Euro positions, so that people can work there for eight to ten hours per week in addition to their studies or other jobs, because itâs an incredible amount of work. A lot depends on the next regional election and what will happen in the city council in the future â how much money will be made available for social projects. But we donât want to be dependent. We want to be able do everything somehow without all that.

People who live on the street have no address and donât pay for insurance. They are only compulsorily insured through the cheapest insurance company They would only pay for an emergency â that means that if they have something, for example, fall or often they have an addiction, only the emergency condition is paid. But there are so many people who live on the street and need normal care â a vaccination, having a foot examine, everything imaginable. And then there are all the people, who donât have residence permits in Germany, who are also not insured. A lot of people have problems going to a doctor, because they have been out for so long. That means that thereâs a lot involved in building up the social center and taking done barriers and being an open house for everyone.

We do social-psychological advising so that we already have a space. I think that when we are known in the city, it will be easier to take these hurdles, that we will be accepted. I think there is still a lot of work, but it is something that Dresden just needs â institutions and places where people are there, regardless of for what, that offer an open door and an open ear.

We are always happy to have people who want to participate. There are no requirements. You just have to have the desire and time and should be open for diversity."

Von der politischen Orientierung her bin ich Kommunist, seit ich 17 Jahre alt war. Ich habe viele BÃ¼cher von Marx und Lenin und so weiter. Ich war sehr kritisch gegen Assad, und das hat mir und meiner Familie Probleme verursacht. Ich finde, Assads Regime ist ein Tyrannen-Regime. Ich wÃ¼rde nicht dafÃ¼r kÃ¤mpfen. Aber gleichzeitig konnte ich auch nicht die sogenannte Revolution unterstÃ¼tzen, weil die andere Seite, die âOppositionâ sehr gewalttÃ¤tig und gegen die religiÃ¶se Minderheit ist. Ich hÃ¤tte mir gewÃ¼nscht, dass die Revolution eine sÃ¤kulare Richtung behalten hÃ¤tte. Aber leider ist die UnterstÃ¼tzung von auÃen daran schuld, dass die Revolution sektiererisch polarisiert hat. 

In Deutschland habe ich Weiterbildungen gemacht. Bei der Caritas habe ich ehrenamtlich als Dolmetscher gearbeitet. Nach einem Praktikum habe ich eine Zusage von einer Firma bekommen, um eine Weiterbildung zum CNC-Techniker zu machen. Ich habe die Weiterbildung abgeschlossen, aber ich konnte nicht lÃ¤nger dort arbeiten. Es lag am Rassismus dort. Manche Mitarbeiter haben auf meiner Anlage âVolltrottelingenieurâ oder âWas ist das fÃ¼r eine ScheiÃeâ geschrieben; sie waren stolz darauf, dass sie fÃ¼r die AfD sind. Aber der Chef war nett zu mir. Seit einem Monat bewerbe ich mich weiter. Ich habe demnÃ¤chst VorstellungsgesprÃ¤che. Ich bin optimistisch, dass ich eine Stelle bekomme. Ich bin nicht daran gewÃ¶hnt, nichts zu machen, ich war immer in BeschÃ¤ftigung.

Ich definiere Integration als Sprache beherrschen. Wenn man die Sprache kann, hat man weniger Probleme. Integration bedeutet nicht, dass ich etwas tue, das meinen Werten widerspricht. Aber gleichzeitig tue ich auch nichts, das gegen die deutschen Werte ist. Man muss dazwischen leben.

Leider habe ich mich selber fÃ¼r Dresden entscheiden, weil es ziemlich einfach war, hier einen Studienplatz zu bekommen. Es ist eine wunderschÃ¶ne Stadt und sie hat eine besondere Magie, aber der Rassismus ist das schlimmste. Das war klar und deutlich in der letzten Wahl zu sehen. Wenn ein Drittel der WÃ¤hler in Sachsen die AfD wÃ¤hlen, finde ich das katastrophal. Sie sind gegen die FlÃ¼chtlinge und benutzen den Islam, um mehr WÃ¤hler zu bekommen. Und vor allem unterstÃ¼tzen sie Assads Regime."

"I came to Germany with a study visa almost three years ago. After five months, I applied for asylum. At first, I only got a residency permit for a year. But now, I have three years. I am an engineer for ship technology. In Syria, I worked at a harbor. Because of the war and military service, I left Syria. In my hometown of Tartus, the situation was really difficult because the city is friendly to Assad; it was like a human reservoir for the regime. In terms of political orientation, I have been a communist since I was 17. I read a lot of books by Marx and Lenin, etc. I think that Assadâs regime is a tyrannical one. I wouldnât fight for it. But at the same time, I couldnât support the so-called revolution, because the other side, the âoppositionâ is very violent and against religious minorities. I would have liked the revolution to have continued in a secular direction. But unfortunately, the support from outside the country is guilty of polarizing the revolution into sectarian situation.

In Germany, I did a further education course. I volunteered at Caritas as a translator. After an internship. I got an acceptance from a company to do further training to become a CNC technician. I finished the training, but I couldnât work there anymore, because of the racism there. Some employees wrote âfull-idiot engineerâ or âwhat kind of shit is thisâ on my equipment. They were proud of being for the AfD. But the boss was nice to me. I have been applying for other jobs for about a month. I have a job interview coming up. I am optimistic that I will get the job. I am used to doing nothing. I was always doing something.

I would define integration as being able to speak the language. If you can speak the language, you have fewer problems. Integration doesnât mean that I will do something that contradict my values. But at the same time, I wonât do anything that contradict German values. You have to live in-between. 

Unfortunately, I decided myself to come to Dresden, because it was pretty easy to get accepted for a study program here. Itâs a beautiful city, and it has a special magic, but the racism is the worst. You could see that clearly in the last election. I think itâs a catastrophe that a third of the voters in Saxony vote for the AfD. They are against refugees and use Islam to get more voters. And most importantly, they support Assadâs regime."

Wir haben dort zwei GemeinschaftsunterkÃ¼nfte und ansonsten Wohnungen von der Stadt.

So 2015, 2016 habe ich auch viel noch mit deutschen Nachbarn gesprochen. Sie waren immer sehr aggressiv und haben sich beschwert, oder sie haben viele Vorurteile gehabt. Ich habe den Leuten immer gesagt: âIch habe wirklich 300 bis 400 geflÃ¼chtete Menschen gesehen, ich weiÃ nicht, wovon Sie sprechen.â Ich habe immer nur die Leute kennengelernt, die sehr gastfreundlich sind. Als ich frÃ¼her noch als Sozialarbeiter gearbeitet habe und wir zu jemandem nach Hause gegangen sind, hast du immer einen Tee bekommen oder was zu essen. Ich musste stÃ¤ndig auf Toilette gehen, weil die Leute immer was zu Trinken angeboten haben. Oder sie haben immer gesagt, kommt noch mal essen, oder kommt nÃ¤chste Woche noch mal vorbei. Ich glaube, ich habe bei dieser Arbeit eher kennengelernt, was Gastfreundschaft heiÃt, das ist zum Beispiel in Deutschland gar nicht so, dass man fremde Leute so zum Essen einlÃ¤dt oder einfach so offen ist. Ich wÃ¼rde sagen, da ist die Dankbarkeit sehr groÃ.

Wir diskutieren auf Arbeit die aktuellen Entwicklungen, weil wir wissen, wenn sich irgendwann die politischen VerhÃ¤ltnisse verÃ¤ndern, dann ist zum Beispiel unser Projekt vielleicht irgendwann weg. Die Gelder die wir von der Stadt bekommen, das ist alles freiwillig, und wenn wir irgendwann eine Mehrheit haben, die das nicht mehr unterstÃ¼tzt, dann werden wir die Gelder nicht mehr bekommen. Die Leute sagen jetzt schon 25 bis 30 Prozent fÃ¼r die AfD voraus. Ich glaube, in den fÃ¼nf Jahren wird man wirklich sehen, wie sich das mit der AfD entwickelt hat - wird sie wieder kleiner oder sind sie wirklich so in der Politik angekommen, dass auch die CDU sagt, gut dann machen wir jetzt was mit euch.

Bei uns in Prohlis haben auch viele AfD gewÃ¤hlt. Was ich gelernt habe ist, dass die Leute ganz unterschiedliche GrÃ¼nde haben, wieso sie die AfD wÃ¤hlen. Manche haben einfach nur das GefÃ¼hl, irgendwas in Deutschland lÃ¤uft schief, oder jetzt gibt es auf einmal viele Menschen auf der StraÃe in Prohlis, die mir irgendwie fremd sind, vor denen ich irgendwie Angst habe. Und dann sagen die einfach, die AfD wird sich darum kÃ¼mmern - wie auch immer. Ich glaube, es ist ein groÃes Problem, dass viele Leute noch nicht begriffen haben, dass die AfD zum Beispiel fÃ¼r die Geringverdiener oder fÃ¼r die Leute, die Hartz IV bekommen, gar keine Politik machen will. Ich glaube, vielleicht muss die AfD auch irgendwann mal regiert haben, damit die Leute sehen, was dann passiert. Trotzdem wÃ¼nsche ich mir das eigentlich nicht.

Wenn ich sehe, was in Dresden fÃ¼r eine Stimmung herrscht: Ich habe mich in den letzten Jahren mit vielen Leuten unterhalten, die gesagt haben, ich habe keinen Bock mehr auf Dresden, mit Pegida, das nervt alles, auch diese konservative Einstellung. Viele sind nach Leipzig oder Berlin gegangen. Ich Ã¼berlege auch, irgendwann mal wieder nach Leipzig zu gehen, weil es dort noch um ganz andere Dinge geht, es FreirÃ¤ume gibt, die es hier vielleicht nicht so gibt. Aber auf der anderen Seite denke ich mir, es braucht auch Orte wie zum Beispiel das AZ Conni und Leute, die offen sind. Auch wenn sich Dinge jetzt erst mal politisch nach rechts verschieben, sollten wir das nicht als Anlass nehmen zu sagen, dann gehen wir eben in den Westen oder in eine andere Stadt. Ich glaube, es ist wichtig, dass die Leute hier auch vor Ort kÃ¤mpfen."

"I work in Prohlis and Leuben as a project leader with Caritas at an advising center for refugees. We have fifteen employees who offer support on subjects like social services, job center, appointments with doctors, getting translators for refugees â families, but also men and women on their own â who live in Prohlis. We have two group homes there and other apartments from the city council.

So in 2015 and 2016, I also spoke a lot with German neighbors. They were always really aggressive and complained or had prejudices. I always said to people, âI have really seen 300 or 400 refugees, I donât know what you are talking about.â I just got to know people who were very hospitable. When I worked as a social worker before, and we would go to some at home, you always got tea and something to eat. I always had to go to the bathroom because people offered me so much tea. Or they always said, âCome back to eat or come back next week.â I think that I got to know what hospitality meant in this work. In Germany, for example, itâs not the case that you ask strange people to come eat or are just so open. I would say that there is a lot of thankfulness. 

We discuss the current developments at work because we know that when political circumstances change then our project is finished, for example. The money that we get from the city, that is all voluntary, and if we at some point have a majority that doesnât support it, then we wonât get the money anymore. People predict now that the AfD will get 25 to 30 percent. I think we will really see in the next five years how the AfD develops â if they get bigger or if they are really accepted into politics so that the CDU says, âOk, we will work with you.â

A lot of people in Prohlis voted for the AfD. What I learned is that people have totally different reasons for why they vote for the AfD. Some just have the feeling that something is going wrong in Germany or now there are suddenly a lot of people on the street in Prohlis who are strange to me, of whom I am afraid. And then they just say, the AfD will take care of it â somehow. I think it is a big problem that a lot of people havenât understood that the AfD donât want to do anything for people who earn very little or get Hartz IV, for example. I think that maybe the AfD has to have governed so that people see what happens. Nevertheless, I donât actually want that.

When I see what kind of mood is prevalent in Dresden â I have talked to a lot of people who say that I donât want to be in Dresden anymore, with Pegida, thatâs all annoying, this conservative attitude. A lot of people have gone to Leipzig or Berlin. I also think about going to Leipzig at some point, because other things are possible there â there is free spaces, which there arenât too many of here. But on the other side, I think, Dresden also needs places like AZ Conni for example and people who donât take it as an occasion to say, âThen we will go to the west or another city.â I think it is important that the people here locally fight."

âWir machen beide eine Ausbildung zur Ergotherapeutin. Wir sind im zweiten Lehrjahr. Das ist ein Beruf, der sehr interessant, vielseitig und unterschÃ¤tzt ist. Es ist eine sehr harte Ausbildung und man hat das GefÃ¼hl, dass die meisten Leute den Beruf gar nicht so richtig kennen. Man hilft den Menschen, den Alltag selbst zu bewÃ¤ltigen, so selbststÃ¤ndig wie mÃ¶glich. Manchmal gibt es auch Krankheiten, die nicht aufzuhalten sind, dann geht es darum, das BestmÃ¶gliche aus der Situation zu machen - die KÃ¼che neu zu gestalten oder Dinge fÃ¼r sie zu bauen. Man richtet sich nach Ihren WÃ¼nschen und versucht das zusammen zu verwirklichen.â

âMein schÃ¶nstes Erlebnis war im Zusammenhang mit einer Patientin, die ich im ersten Praktikum kennengelernt habe. Sie war 23 Jahre alt und lag seit Jahren im Wachkoma. Sie konnte weder essen noch trinken, noch selber schlucken. Ich bin dann aus dem Praktikum raus und hatte ganz oft wieder immer wieder an sie gedacht. Meine neue Mitbewohnerin ist auch Ergotherapeutin und arbeitet jetzt in der Einrichtung, wo dieses MÃ¤dchen war. Ich habe sie gefragt, wie es ihr geht, und sie hat mir erzÃ¤hlt, dass sie jetzt wieder laufen kann. Das war cool.â

âIch habe jetzt einen Patienten kennengelernt, so Mitte/Ende 40. Er hat mit seinen SÃ¶hnen FuÃball gespielt und sich am Tor gehangelt. Das Tor ist auf sein Frontalhirn gefallen. Er lag neun Wochen im Wachkoma. Als er aufgewacht ist, konnte er auf einem Auge gar nichts mehr sehen und auf dem anderen ganz, ganz wenig. Er konnte sich auch nicht bewegen. Mittlerweile ist er soweit, dass er seine SehfÃ¤higkeit auf dem einen Auge sehr stark trainiert und jetzt ein bisschen SehfÃ¤higkeit hat. Er kann hell und dunkel unterscheiden, kann sogar Motive sehen. Und er kann auch wieder gehen, mittlerweile mit nur noch einem Gehstock, teilweise auch ohne. Er ist sehr sehr positiv und lebensbejahend und meint, dass es ein lebenswertes Leben ist, das er lebt. So etwas zu hÃ¶ren ist es dann schon wert, dass man die Situation annimmt und trotzdem ein schÃ¶nes Leben fÃ¼hren kann, auch wenn so einem solche unvorhergesehenen Sachen passieren.â

âAm Anfang konnte ich mit vielen Situationen nicht so umgehen wie inzwischen. Mittlerweile kann ich mich besser davon entfernen. DarÃ¼ber reden finde ich wichtig, und versuchen, das wirklich in der Arbeit zu lassen. Am Anfang, als ich dieses MÃ¤dchen kennengelernt habe, habe ich Rotz und Wasser geheult. Ich habe ganz viel an sie gedacht; mir ging es echt schlecht. Jetzt hatte ich einen Patienten, der sich letzte Woche das Leben genommen hat. Das war sehr traurig, aber ich konnte das dort lassen. Ich wusste, ich war fÃ¼r den da und vielleicht ist jetzt wirklich dort, wo es besser ist.â

âDie Schicksale sind uns natÃ¼rlich nicht egal, aber ich glaube, es wÃ¼rde mir schlechter gehen, wenn ich nichts machen wÃ¼rde und weggucken wÃ¼rde. Aber es gibt auch so FÃ¤lle - ich habe jetzt einen Patienten kennengelernt, der ist zwÃ¶lf Jahre alt. Mit zehn ist bei ihm die Krankheit ALD ausgebrochen. Das ist eine Stoffwechselkrankheit. Wenn die ausbricht, ist sie nicht mehr aufzuhalten. Es bildet sich alles zurÃ¼ck. Mittlerweile kann er nicht mehr sprechen, wird Ã¼ber eine Sonde ernÃ¤hrt, kann keine Bewegungen mehr ansteuern. Er wird mit hoher Wahrscheinlichkeit in den nÃ¤chsten Monaten oder Jahren sterben. Jedes Mal, wenn ich bei ihm war, bin ich danach schlecht gelaunt und traurig.â

âIch glaube, es ist auch einfach okay, traurig zu sein, wenn man sich davon nicht abhalten lÃ¤sst, seine Arbeit zu machen und sein Leben trotzdem zu genieÃen.â

âWe are both training to be occupational therapists. We are in the second year. Itâs a job thatâs very interesting, multi-faceted and underestimated. Itâs a very difficult training, and you have the feeling that most people donât really know the profession. You help people handle everyday life themselves, as independently as possible. Sometimes, there are illnesses that are incurable, and then itâs about making the best possible out of the situation â setting up the kitchen in a new way or building things for them. You do things according to their wishes and try to realize everything together.â

âMy nicest experience was with a patient who I got to know during my first internship. She was 23 years old and had been in a vegetative state for years. She couldnât eat or drink or even swallow. I came out of that internship thinking about her, again and again. My new roommate is also an occupational therapist and works in the institution where this girl is. I asked her how she was doing, and she told me that she can walk again. That was cool.â

âI just got to know a patient in the middle/end of his 40s. He was playing football with his sons and he was hanging on the goal. The goal fell on his frontal lobe. He lay in a coma for nine weeks. When he woke up, he couldnât see at all out of one eye and very little out of the other. He also couldnât move himself. At this point, he has intensely trained his vision in one eye and now can see a little. He can see the difference between light and dark, he can even see shapes. And he can also walk again, now with only one cane, sometimes even without. He is very, very positive and life-affirming and says that he is living a life worth living. Hearing something like this has value, that you can accept the situation and nevertheless lead a good life, even when such unforeseen things happen to you.â

âAt first, I couldnât deal with a lot of situation like I can now. Now, I can better distance myself. I think that talking about it is important and trying to really leave it at work. At the beginning, when I met this girl, I cried my eyes out. I thought a lot about her; I was doing really badly. Last week, one of my patients killed himself. It was really sad, but I could leave it at work. I know that I was really there for him, and maybe he is better off where he is now.â

âWe do care about the fates of our patients, but I think I would do worse if I didnât do it and looked away. But there are also those cases â I have a patient now who is twelve years old. He has come down with the disease ALD. Itâs a metabolic disorder. If it breaks out, you canât cure it. Everything declines. He canât speak anymore at this point, is fed through a tube, and he canât control his movements anymore. He will very probably die in the next months or years. Every time, I have an appointment with him, I have a bad mood and am sad afterward.â

âI think itâs just ok to be sad if it doesnât keep you from doing your work and enjoying your life nevertheless.â

âWe are both training to be occupational therapists. We are in the second year. Itâs a job thatâs very interesting, multi-faceted and underestimated. Itâs a very difficult training, and you have the feeling that most people donât really know the profession. You help people handle everyday life themselves, as independently as possible. Sometimes, there are illnesses that are incurable, and then itâs about making the best possible out of the situation â setting up the kitchen in a new way or building things for them. You do things according to their wishes and try to realize everything together.â

âMy nicest experience was with a patient who I got to know during my first internship. She was 23 years old and had been in a vegetative state for years. She couldnât eat or drink or even swallow. I came out of that internship thinking about her, again and again. My new roommate is also an occupational therapist and works in the institution where this girl is. I asked her how she was doing, and she told me that she can walk again. That was cool.â

âI just got to know a patient in the middle/end of his 40s. He was playing football with his sons and he was hanging on the goal. The goal fell on his frontal lobe. He lay in a coma for nine weeks. When he woke up, he couldnât see at all out of one eye and very little out of the other. He also couldnât move himself. At this point, he has intensely trained his vision in one eye and now can see a little. He can see the difference between light and dark, he can even see shapes. And he can also walk again, now with only one cane, sometimes even without. He is very, very positive and life-affirming and says that he is living a life worth living. Hearing something like this has value, that you can accept the situation and nevertheless lead a good life, even when such unforeseen things happen to you.â

âAt first, I couldnât deal with a lot of situation like I can now. Now, I can better distance myself. I think that talking about it is important and trying to really leave it at work. It was really sad, but I could leave it at work. I know that I was really there for him, and maybe he is better off where he is now.â

âWe do care about the fates of our patients, but I think I would do worse if I didnât do it and looked away. But there are also those cases â I have a patient now who is twelve years old. He has come down with the disease ALD. Itâs a metabolic disorder. If it breaks out, you canât cure it. Everything declines. âI think itâs just ok to be sad if it doesnât keep you from doing your work and enjoying your life nevertheless.â

âWir sind hier im Hechtviertel, und auch in der Neustadt, in einer vÃ¶lligen Blase. Wir sind wie in einer Glocke hier drin. âWe were just over in the Neustadt, in the beer garden, and we were talking about life in the Hechtviertel. We have lived here for more than ten years. We have seen how it is more and more gentrified and more and more people move here. When I moved here, the residents were a lot more diverse. In the GDR, the Hechtviertel was a socially disadvantaged quarter, where families with a lot of kids lived, and it was more working class. When I moved here, the remainders of this old group of residents still lived here. Thatâs why I moved here. I never wanted to move to the Neustadt. I watched as they all died or had to move out , because the apartments were renovated, and they couldnât afford anything anymore. I think thatâs too bad. Back then it was a bit quainter â now itâs hip and stylish and is becoming like the Neustadt. But we think you are still a little out of the way and have the luck that it is not yet like in the Neustadt. Itâs become more of a family neighborhood in the last few years. We really like living here. I wouldnât want to live in another part of the city. We rarely leave the Hechtviertel â maybe we go over to the Neustadt. We decided before that the Neustadt is something like a big city, and the Hechtviertel is a small city next to it.â

âBefore I moved to the Hechtviertel, I spent ten years in the Neustadt. It has changed a lot. That was a reason for me to move out, because it just got too loud and too much. I just didnât want it anymore at some point.â

âItâs not just about partying, and I think that a lot of people use it just to go out â which is totally ok, but I canât imagine living there.â

âMaybe everything has its time. Before, I enjoyed it and took part. But at the middle/end of the nineties, it really still was more relaxed. Back then, it was used much more by people who lived there. It was a totally different atmosphere.â

âHere in the Hechtviertel and the Neustadt, we are in a total bubble. We are in a bell jar here. I work in child services, and I have a lot to do with families that come from the rest of Dresden, not here in our bell jar. Itâs a completely different world, like a different planet. I am not so familiar with Gorbitz and Prohlis, the socially problematic areas. I only know the addresses and the streets, and when I read them, I know â ok, that it will be a little more difficult. I have a colleague who comes from Prohlis who says that there are beautiful parts; it just has a bad reputation. And there are actually particular streets and addresses that you know are a bit more difficult. I nevertheless like to do my work and am happy that I can come back here. Itâs a little more cozy, and here, I have distance from job, which can be a little difficult.â

"I am an artist, making black-humor cartoons that I sell to customers with a corresponding sense of humor. Since at least the last election results, I have focused a bit more on the political events and picked out the weirdnesses and graphically processed them as a neutral observer. The city has a lot of potential for being parodied, either visually or in texts. I have resolved to parody the political events more urgently. When Pegida, the AfD, and the other parties want to kill me, I have done my job right. I try to stay neutral and pick out the oddness from all directions, although here the rightwing sticks out first, because they are the most clearly represented here. I recently visited an acquaintance in Bautzen; the city is beautiful, but something is bubbling under the surface. It has a lot of potential; purely in terms of humor, itâs great here.

I always thought of illustrators as artists. I didnât get classical art. For me, it was always the emperorâs new clothes. I wanted something with a message, and thatâs why I always got the worst aggravation at the art academy. As Pegida started, I did an exhibition in which I parodied Pegida, but not clearly enough. That means that in the end, I had violent threats from Pegida and Antifa. That was weird of course. I love this kind of âsitting between chairs.â I think itâs funny that both sides reacted the same. I think itâs interesting that people would rather kill the messenger than question the message. People are more inclined to shoot a satirist as just not buy a newspaper. That is a very interesting phenomenon and occurs in all possible groups â with Nazis as well as with strongly religious people or Islamicists. However, I have to say that shooting people is not so polite.

I want to apply to work at Charlie Hebdo. I will give myself that pleasure some time. Charlie Hebdo is sometimes a little too obvious; I could bring a little sophistication. For Charlie Hebdo, I had the idea to make a picture where an assassin comes into the office and wants to shoot them, and an employee says, âNormally, you have to cancel your subscription in writing!â I would like to ask, âDo I have to storm the office to present myself?â"

"Ich komme aus Somalia. Ich bis seit 1998 in Europa. Zwischendurch war ich auch mal in Norwegen. Das war, weil es damals in Dresden zu schwer war. Leute hatten unser Asylheim angezÃ¼ndet. Deswegen bin ich gegangen. 2012 bin ich wieder nach Dresden gekommen. Norwegen war sehr schÃ¶n, aber ich durfte nicht dort bleiben, weil ich in Deutschland Asyl beantragt hatte.

Ich habe eine Aufenthaltserlaubnis und eine Arbeitserlaubnis bekommen. Ich habe eine kleine Wohnung. Ich habe ein stabiles Leben. In Somalia habe ich niemanden mehr. Ich komme aus einem Kriegsgebiet; alle sind weg. Es gibt immer noch Unruhen, Krieg, den IS, Verbrecher - seit 27 Jahren, das ist traurig. Aber so ist das Leben.

Ich bin nicht zufrieden, dass ich hier sein muss. Ich werde in den Westen gehen. Hier ist es schwer. Es gibt Rassismus, Diskriminierung und Ungerechtigkeit. Ende des Jahres werde ich wegziehen, nach KÃ¶ln, dort habe ich gute Freunde."

"I am from Somalia. I have been in Europe since 1998. During that time, I was also in Norway because back then Dresden was too difficult. People lit an asylum hostel on fire. That's why I left. In 2012, I came back to Dresden. Norway was really nice, but I wasn't allowed to stay there because I had applied for asylum in Germany.

I have gotten a residence permit and a work permit. I have a small apartment. I have a stable life. In Somalia, I don't have anyone anymore. I come from a war zone . Everyone is gone. There is still unrest, war, the IS, criminals -- for 27 years. It's sad. But that's life.

I am not happy that I have to be here. I am going to the west. It's hard here. There is racism, discrimination, and injustice. I will move away at the end of the year, to Cologne. I have good friends there."

"I came to Dresden in 2015. I am a dancer and choreographer. I like the quietness here. Working in theater, you work in a public situation, and here, you can disassociate yourself from that. As soon as you leave the theater, things are entirely different and completely anonymous.

Before this, I was working in Monaco. Before that, I was in Antwerp. Before that, I was in New York, but I actually grew up in Baden-Wurttemberg in a little town near Speyer. My father was in the American army, but he would always introduce himself as a musician. He was in the army band. I went to an international school, with some classes in German and some in English. Living in Belgium really screwed up my German, but I still think Vlaams is wonderfully charming.

I was one of those children. My mother was a singer, and we watched a lot of old movies as when I was a kid. Judy Garland was one of my heroes. I remember watching her on her TV show. When she would sing, she would always touch her arm once and her hair once. I remember thinking, âOk, two gestures a song. This is how you do it.â It was intrinsic. My parents were supportive. Maybe they looked at each other and shrugged and thought, âWell, we did this to ourselves.â

I started ballet classes at 4. I saw a Sondheim birthday celebration, also on TV, and Liza Minelli was there, singing on a piano in a glittery black skirt, and she had very short hair. She was really aggressive and wonderful and happy, and I thought, âThatâs going to be me. Thatâs my life.â My parents told me I should start with ballet.

I trained at the School of American Ballet in New York. Itâs a little more akin to a modern dance situation, but with point shoes. Thereâs a mythos around it and an agreement that Americans do things differently â itâs jazz based and performance based school, and thatâs served me well in what I do now. I loved it.

Also, moving to New York when you are 13 â who doesnât want to do that? When you are sick of your parentsâ¦ There was a boarding school. It was great but also really traumatizing. The other kids were the same. They were either from small towns or from very wealthy families. I work with three people I went to school with here at the Semperoper, and we all look back at the school with a kind of nostalgic trauma lens. Weâre like, âIt was wonderful, and it was awful.â

After I graduated, I got my dream job, and I was immediately fired because I injured my ankle. I thought, âWhat am I going to do?â I went through a really rebellious period of taking classes at the New School. I was like, âI am going to study feminism now!â I had nothing to fall back on. That was the time that I regretted my focus the most. I also regret not having the earlier education that would inform what I am doing now. I am currently doing a kind of remedial academic education."

"Ich komme aus Indien und lebe in Deutschland seit neunzehn Jahren. Mein Sohn wird zwÃ¶lf, wir leben in Chemnitz und sind heute spontan in Dresden. Wir wollten mal ein bisschen gucken und einen kleinen Ausflug machen.

In Chemnitz lebe ich schon seit ich in Deutschland bin, ich bin dort selbstÃ¤ndig, habe eine Pizzeria in Limbach-Oberfrohna. Heute haben wir Ruhetag, deshalb sind wir hier. Chemnitz ist eine kleine ruhige Stadt, dort sind nicht so viele Leute wie hier.

Nebenbei arbeite ich als freiberuflich als Dolmetscher, aber nur Montags, und wenn ich mal Zeit habe, also nicht so oft.

Mein Bruder lebt auch in Deutschland, in Frankfurt. Er hat frÃ¼her mal in Dresden gewohnt. Sonst habe ich noch Onkel und Cousins, die wohnen aber alle im Westen, im Raum KÃ¶ln, Frankfurt und in Richtung Hamburg.

Ich fÃ¼hle mich ganz wohl in Deutschland. Zweimal im Jahr fliege ich in meine Heimat. Meine Eltern leben in Indien, meine Schwester wohnt in Amerika, in New York. Wir haben auch vor, dorthin zu fliegen dieses Jahr. Ich wollte mir New York schon immer mal angucken, es ist eine groÃe Stadt, das mÃ¶chte ich mal erleben, wie es dort ist."

"I am from India, and I have lived in Germany for nineteen years. My son is turning twelve. We live in Chemnitz and came to Dresden today on a whim. We wanted to look around a little, do a little outing.

I have lived in Chemnitz since I have been in Germany. I run my own business there. I have a pizzeria in Limbach-Oberfrohna. Today, we are closed, thatâs why we are here. Chemnitz is a small quiet city. There arenât as many people there as here.

On the side, I work as an interpreter but just on Mondays, and if I have time, which is not that often.

My brother also lives in Germany, in Frankfurt. He used to live in Dresden. Other than that, I have an uncle and cousins, but they all live in the west in the area of Cologne, Frankfurt, and in the direction of Hamburg.

I feel happy in Germany. I fly home twice a year. My parents live in India. My sister lives in America, in New York. We are planning to fly there this year. I also wanted to see New York. Itâs a big city. I would like to see how it is there."

"I am a totally normal citizen here with Arab roots. According to my passport, I am a German citizen. I grew up in Kiel, and I have been in Dresden since 2010.

I liked Dresden nine years ago better than now. The atmosphere is so tense, the prejudices of Dresdeners, stereotyping everyone who doesnât look German â I think itâs just not ok. There are a lot of people who donât look German but were born in Dresden, and they are integrated here. But they donât get that in Dresden. Everyone who doesnât look German is immediately branded a criminal or a terrorist or something like that. You can feel that since 2015/2016, that the atmosphere is totally tense.

When people hear that I speak fluent German, the situation is totally different. Then thereâs some respect there, like, âOh, he can German, High German fluently, and not even Saxon.â I havenât had any bad experiences until now â I mean, itâs not that I am being attacked by Nazis, I havenât had that luck yet. You just notice it in the small things. For example, that old people especially when they already see you from far away go out of their way so that they donât have to stand next to âone of those guys.â In that case, you have to stand in their place and think that they listen to too much news, or even fake news.

On one side, it is always said, foreigners need to integrate themselves, but if the Germans donât go along, how are they supposed to integrate? The distance between the native Dresdeners and the foreigners will just get bigger and bigger and then, logically, there will be conflicts.

In Kiel, itâs totally different. I sometimes play with the thought of moving back. The whole West is somehow opener. I was born in 1978, and we grew up there with Turks, Russians, even with GDR citizens. They were foreigners to us in a certain way. Life there is more harmonized. In the West, guest workers from all over the world came at the end of the 50s, and the Wessis can deal with it somehow. But here in the East, and I am talking mostly about Saxony, itâs a whole new experience for people.

This street here is not dangerous, thatâs propaganda. Just because there are five or six Arab businesses here in the street, it does not mean that it is a âcriminalâ street. Just this accusation is criminal, I think, also from the media. The Arab mentality is just that they gather where there are Arab activities. They are not like Germans who all do their own thing. They meet here, talk, laugh together, etc. Sometimes there is conflict, but the Germans are just as much a part of that. But they say then immediately, âItâs a criminal street, and we have here a situation like in Berlin or Cologne.â Itâs dirty here, etc., but it was also dirty here before! The âErotic Maxâ actually started everything because his clients felt threatened and stuff. Of course, for Arabs, itâs new that such a store even exists, openly selling erotic stuff, but thatâs why itâs fully legitimate. They just stand there in front of the store and look. What should be so bad about that? The city also has allowed the stores to be here; they are commercially registered. And if here only Arabs open stores, what is the problem? If the Germans donât want to or donât have any ideasâ¦ and the stores also bring in money, pay all their taxes, and Dresden needs that too.

I can understand the people who live here and the Dresdeners too. The Arab mentality is just loud. You think that they are fighting, but they are just talking about football. But they wonât let anyone say anything. If someone comes and says that they should be quiet then they would just try to provoke. But thatâs what they do at home too; itâs nothing new. There are also enough German teenagers who beat each other up.

If some Dresdeners would spend time in New York or Chicago, they would probably freak out. There, people from a lot of nationalities have always lived together. Thatâs something that I noticed: If a Afro-American says where heâs from, itâs clear to everyone that he is American. No one asks about his origins. But if I say that I am a German citizen, people always ask me right away, âyeah, but where do you come from originally?â I think, though, that that is none of their business. I am German, I was born and grew up here, so why do they absolutely need to know what my origins are? The German-Sudanese, the German-Turk, the German-Lebanese, that all needs to go away. German is German, Tunisian is Tunisian. I donât say to Will Smith, âYou are a Jamaican American.â No, heâs American. Itâs just the case. 

Foreigners are in Dresden now. And we have to somehow try to get along with each other, in some way or another. Of course, there are criminals among the Arabs. But there are also criminals among the Germans, the Russians, the Poles, etc. You canât just set up the Arab as the scapegoat, while he is trying to integrate himself. A lot has to change here."

Wenn man alt wird, ist bezÃ¼glich des heutigen Dresdens viel EnttÃ¤uschung dabei. "I was born in Dresden in 1951 and have spent almost my whole life here. When I went to the city with my Mamutschka, it was just ashes here. There were some things that were rebuilt â for example city hall, the Altmarkt, but up to Prager StraÃe, it was completely empty. There was just the Hotel Excelsior back there and Central Station â it was orderly but empty all around. The Parliament was in ruins, the Sophienkirche, the Schloss were in ruins, the Zwinger was standing and was restored. Then I was a witness to everything that happened over all the years. I think itâs wrong to try to find some special statement about this time during my childhood, to construe a political situation from it. It was just a given. Dresden burned down quite a few times within the city walls, and it was rebuilt quite a few times. 

Dresden was still a territory that contained the inner city two-hundred years ago; there were still walls around it. There is a print in the city museum, and that was after the Vienna Congress. That was actually the point where it was settled with Napoleon and his allies, including the Wettiner. Saxon had lost half of its territory to the Prussians, the king was locked up, and 25,000 of the Saxon natives stayed in Russia â and this in a country that, by todayâs standards, was almost empty. On this print by the anonymous printmaker, you can see almost no settlements; there are at best little villages, little nests.

I have eclectic interests, and when I am asked by genteel and important people, I will just natter on a bit. I am a talker, letâs just say that. 

When you get old, there is a lot of disappointment with todayâs Dresden. I am not actually a real patriot, and I was never a communist â the old era, the zone, we all complained. But today itâs much more contradictory. These days, you canât bring things up, then you get put in the corner and peed on, terrible. In that case, if you can say that when you are healthy and full and arenât hanging around on the streets, then you can be satisfied. And at my age, in any case."

"Ich habe nach dem Abitur die Stadt erstmal verlassen. Ich glaube, ich musste damals erstmal raus. Und ich wollte woanders studieren. Ich bin nach Leipzig an die UniversitÃ¤t gegangen und habe dann ein Erasmus-Semester in Wien gemacht. Ich glaube, das war fÃ¼r mich die InitialzÃ¼ndung, sich auch noch mal anders als EuropÃ¤erin zu begreifen. Ich habe Theaterwissenschaften, Kulturwissenschaften und Soziologie studiert. Ich war kurze Zeit als Dramaturgin am Theater tÃ¤tig, dann einige Jahre in der Jugendhilfe als Projektleiterin, habe aber auch mal als Redakteurin fÃ¼r den SPIESSER gearbeitet. Dann war ich sechs Jahre Abgeordnete im SÃ¤chsischen Landtag fÃ¼r Die Linke. Und jetzt bin ich seit dreieinhalb Jahren BÃ¼rgermeisterin fÃ¼r Kultur und Tourismus in Dresden.

Ich glaube, politisch sozialisiert hat mich die Zeit nach der Wende, der Transformationsprozess, als hier alles neu hier gestaltet wurde. Ich wÃ¤re damals mit sechzehn in keine Partei eingetreten. Eigentlich wollte ich zu den GrÃ¼nen, aber das hat sich dann anders entwickelt und ich bin erst mit Mitte 20 In Die Linke eingetreten. Da war ich schon berufstÃ¤tig und hatte ein Kind. Damals hatte ich beruflich auch mit Hartz-IV-EmpfÃ¤ngern und Langzeitarbeitslosen zu tun. Ich hatte das GefÃ¼hl, man muss sich irgendwo engagieren und nicht nur zu Hause meckern. Mein erstes politisches Mandat war im Ortsbeirat Pieschen, dann war ich im Ortsbeirat Neustadt, und dann kam die Chance, fÃ¼r den Landtag zu kandidieren. Das waren fÃ¼r mich immer lehrreiche Stationen - auch immer der Perspektivwechsel, das hilft mir heute bei meiner Arbeit zu verstehen, warum diskutiert der Stadtrat so und warum wollen bestimmte Menschen politische Prozesse noch einmal erklÃ¤rt haben.

Kunst ist zunÃ¤chst erst einmal frei, und es ist immer die individuelle Entscheidung eines KÃ¼nstlers, was das Thema seines Kunstwerkes ist. Ich finde Kunst, die einen politischen Anspruch hat, sogar besonders wichtig - nicht im parteipolitischen Sinn, sondern Kunst hÃ¤lt uns einen Spiegel vor, Kunst reflektiert unser gesellschaftliches Zusammenleben und unser Dasein als Mensch. Insofern ist Kunst ein Korrektiv zur Politik. Kunst irritiert, Kunst hinterfragt, Kunst lÃ¶st Diskussionen aus. Das finde ich etwas ganz Wunderbares. Das heiÃt nicht, dass jedes Kunstwerk jedem gefallen muss. Es geht nicht um Ãsthetik, sondern auch um die Inhalte. Ich finde auch, man darf da der AfD nicht auf den Leim gehen. Die AfD hat die Strategie, Themen zu setzen; sie will polarisieren, sie statuiert Exempel und sagt jetzt, sie will politische Kunst nicht mehr finanzieren. Das tut sie, weil sie will, dass alle darÃ¼ber sprechen. Ich will nicht darÃ¼ber diskutieren. Ich will darÃ¼ber diskutieren, was Kunst leisten kann fÃ¼r uns - kann Kunst uns bereichern, wie kÃ¶nnen wir Kunst fÃ¶rdern, wie kÃ¶nnen wir KÃ¼nstlerinnen und KÃ¼nstler unterstÃ¼tzen.

Ich glaube, wir sind in Dresden mit der Vielzahl an Kultureinrichtungen, an Vereinen, an Initiativen sehr gut ausgestattet im Vergleich zu anderen GroÃstÃ¤dten. Es geht darum, Menschen eben nicht nur als Konsumenten von Kunst zu verstehen, sondern sie auch zu beteiligen. DafÃ¼r gibt es wunderbare Beispiele auch in Dresden - die BÃ¼rgerbÃ¼hne des Staatsschauspiels macht das wunderbar, die Theaterakademie des theaters junge generation oder jetzt auch das Projekt âZU HAUSE in Prohlisâ vom Societaetstheater. Die machen Menschen zu Akteuren, sie geben Menschen eine BÃ¼hne, die sonst vielleicht nicht vorkommen.

Wir sind im dreiÃigsten Jahr nach dem Mauerfall. Anfang der neunziger Jahre war es wichtig, die ganzen groÃen Kultureinrichtungen aus den Zeiten der DDR erstmal zu erhalten. Das ist gelungen, aber die Stadtteilkultur, die kleine nichtkommerzielle Ortskultur in den Stadtteilen, das ist damals weggefallen. Es gibt einige, wir fÃ¼ttern auch einige, aber es gibt eben auch Stadtteile, wo etwas fehlt. Ich glaube, es ist unsere Aufgabe, solche Orte jetzt wieder zu denken, zu schaffen, zu befÃ¶rdern. Und das tun wir, zum Beispiel auch im Rahmen der Kulturhauptstadt-Bewerbung."

"I left the city after finishing high school. I think I just had to get out. And I wanted to study somewhere else. I went to the university in Leipzig and did a study abroad in Vienna. I think that was my initial impulse to understand being a European differently. I studied theater, cultural studies and sociology. I worked as a dramaturge for a short time in a theater, then I was the project leader for some years for youth welfare, I also worked as an editor for the SPIESSER magazine. Then I was a delegate for the Linke in the Saxon parliament. And now for the past three and a half years, I have been the mayor in charge of culture and tourism.

I think that I was socialized by the era after the reunification, the transformation process when everything was newly formed here. I wouldnât have joined a party at sixteen. Actually, I wanted to join the Greens, but things developed differently, and I first joined the Linke in the middle of my twenties. I was already working and had a child. Back then, I also was professionally involved with Hartz-IV recipients and the long-time unemployed. I had the feeling that you had engage yourself somewhere and not just sit at home and complain. My first political job was in the advisory council in Peischen, then the advisory council in the Neustadt, and the came the chance to run for the parliament. Those position taught me a lot â also the constant change of perspective helps me understand today in my work why the city council discusses in this way and why certain people wanted to have political processes explained again. 

First of all, art is free, and it is always the individual choice of the artist what the subject of his or her art work will be. I think that art that has a political ambition is especially important â not in the party politics sense â but art holds up a mirror to us, art reflects our social life and our existence as people. In that way, art is a corrective to politics. Art irritates, art questions, art provokes discussions. I think that is something totally wonderful. It doesnât mean that everyone has to like every piece of art. Itâs not about aesthetics but about content. I think that we also should allow the AfD to set the discussion. The AfD has the strategy of setting subjects. They want to polarize, they make an example, now sazing that they donât want to fund political art any more. They do that because they want everyone to talk about it. I donât want to discuss it. I want discuss what art can do for us â can art enrich us, how can we support art, how can we support artistsâ

I think we are very well equipped with a multitude of cultural institutions in Dresden, associations, initiatives in comparison to other large cities. What we might notice now is that outside of the large renown cultural institutions there is a vacuum that wants to be filled. Itâs about participation. Itâs about not only thinking of people as the consumers of art but also as participants. There is also a wonderful examples of that in Dresden â the citizensâ stage of the Staatschauspiel does it wonderfully. The theater academy of the theater junge generation or now the project âZU HAUSE in Prohlisâ from the Societaetstheater. They make people into agents and actors, they give people a stage who might now otherwise appear.

We are in the thirtieth year after the fall of the Wall. At the beginning of the nineties, it was important that all the big cultural institutions from the GDR era would survive. They were able to do that, but the culture of the city neighborhood, the small, not-commercial structures in parts of the city â these fell away back then. There are some, we feed some, but there also parts of the city that are missing something. I think that it is our job to think about those places again, to create and promote things there. And thatâs what we are doing, for example as part of the application to be European cultural capital."

They may not understand the words, because I sing more and more in German, but we understand each other musically very well. I am happy that we put together the tour and that we have a very full program. We are touring all across Germany."

In den letzten zwei Jahren habe ich ein bisschen Politische Philosophie gemacht, Internationale Beziehungen und auch viel Kulturwissenschaften, und im letzten Jahr auch einiges Richtung Identity Studies. Und ich habe mich viel mit Rassismus beschÃ¤ftigt. 

Ich habe mich fÃ¼r ein Praktikum in Dresden beworben, weil ist gerade ganz gut gepasst hat mit dem Sommer. Ich hatte zwei ganze Monate frei. Ich komme jetzt ins vierte Jahr mit meinem Bachelorstudiengang und weiÃ immer noch nicht so richtig, was ich danach machen mÃ¶chte. Ich wollte jetzt gerne mal wieder Berufserfahrung in Deutschland machen und mich mehr mit der deutschen Politik beschÃ¤ftigen. WÃ¤hrend des Studiums in Deutschland zu wohnen - und besonders im Osten - ist schon noch etwas anderes. 

Ich komme aus dem Westen, meine ganze Familie kommt aus dem Westen. Ich glaube, dass es nach wie vor eine ganz andere Erfahrung ist, wenn man hier aufwÃ¤chst. Deshalb war mir das jetzt ganz wichtig, dass ich auch mal eine Zeitlang hier wohne. Ich glaube, dass ich ganz sicher Vorurteile Ã¼ber den Osten hatte - nicht bewusst, aber unbewusst. Es fÃ¤ngt ja schon im Geschichtsunterricht an, dass man Ã¼ber die DDR in einer sehr speziellen Art und Weise spricht - und sehr eingeschrÃ¤nkt, wie ich finde. 

Ich war in Dresden das erste Mal vor vier Jahren. An der Hochschule fÃ¼r Bildende KÃ¼nste habe ich eine Woche einen Workshop gemacht. Das war auch die Hochzeit von Pegida, da hat man vieles mitbekommen. Und gerade jetzt nach den EU-Wahlen, wenn man sich da die Deutschlandkarte anguckt und sieht, wer was wÃ¤hlt, natÃ¼rlich kommen da Vorurteile hoch, und man erwartet, dass das politische Klima hier sehr anstrengend ist und sich mittlerweile sehr, sehr weit nach rechts bewegt. Ich muss aber ehrlicherweise sagen, obwohl ich gerade nach den EU-Wahlen Bedenken hatte, wie das wohl wird, was jetzt los ist, bin ich hier ganz positiv Ã¼berrascht.

Es gibt so viele Aktionen dagegen. Klar gibt es Pegida montags. Ich glaube, fÃ¼r die Menschen, die da hingehen, ist es sehr prÃ¤sent, aber ansonsten in Dresden gar nicht so prÃ¤sent. Ich finde hier sehr viel mehr politisches Statements als ich das aus MÃ¼nster kenne, weil die Leute sich damit befassen mÃ¼ssen. Ich habe auch das GefÃ¼hl, dass es hier sehr viele interkulturelle Veranstaltungen gibt. Ich glaube, ich sehe gerade auch nur die positiven Seiten von Dresden.

Das war interessant, als ich in die Niederlande zum Studium gezogen bin. Es gibt in Maastricht auch sehr viele Deutsche, und gerade an meiner FakultÃ¤t auch sehr viele, die woanders herkommen. Auch viele Austauschstudierende, die das Ã¼berhaupt nicht gewohnt waren, dass man einfach so Ã¼ber die Grenze fahren kann. Und ich bin so aufgewachsen; das gehÃ¶rt fÃ¼r mich schon mit dazu. Da ist es gar nicht so ein groÃer Schritt, in die Niederlande zu ziehen. Ich kann bis zu einem gewissen Grad verstehen, dass die Leute gegen die EU sind. Ich verstehe, dass da Angst ist. Ich glaube, dass da einfach noch sehr viele Vorurteile herrschen und dass das auch nicht so richtig thematisiert wird. Diese ganze Integrationsdebatte, dass es jetzt eine Leitkultur gibt und alle mÃ¼ssen sich anpassen - ich glaube, dass viele noch immer eine sehr eingeschrÃ¤nkte Idee davon haben, wie Deutschland aussieht, wie Deutsche aussehen, und dass in ihnen die Angst entstehen kann, dass jetzt Fremde kommen und sich einmischen und vielleicht einen Anspruch auf etwas stellen, von dem manche eigentlich denken, dass es ihnen gehÃ¶rt. Ich kann das schon verstehen, aber ich glaube auch, gerade weil ich nie negative Erfahrungen gemacht habe, habe ich da eine ganz andere Auffassung, weil ich nur die VorzÃ¼ge der EU erlebt habe. Ich glaube, als Kind von Akademikern und im Westen aufgewachsen ist es auch irgendwie einfacher zu sagen, es ist doch alles super hier und die EU ist doch ein gutes Projekt."

"I am from MÃ¼nster. I am actually studying liberal arts in Maastricht. I am just coming back from a semester abroad. I was in Vermont. My focus is social and humanistic studies. In the last two years, I studied a little political philosophy, international relations, and also cultural studies, and in the last year, a bit in the direction of Identity Studies. And I am really interested in racism.

I applied for the internship in Dresden because it works really well with my plans for the summer. I had two whole months free. I am now in the fourth year of my bachelorâs studies and still donât really know what I would like to do after. I would like to get some job experience in Germany and get involved with German politics. Living in Germany, and especially in the east, during my studies, is really something different.

I come from the west, my whole family comes from the west. I think that it is still a totally different experience how you grow up here. Thatâs why it was really important to me to live here for a while. I think that I certainly have prejudices against the east â unconscious. It starts with history classes, that you talk about the GDR in a very special way â and very limited, I think.

I was first in Dresden four years ago. I did a weeklong workshop at the Academy for Visual Arts. That was the highpoint of Pegida. You heard a lot. And now, after the EU elections, when you look at the map of Germany and see who voted for what â of course, the prejudices are very strong, and you expect the political climate to be really exhausting and is very far to the right. I have to honestly say that although I had concerns because of the EU election, how it would be, I was very positively surprised.

There are so many efforts against the rightwing extremism. Of course, there is Pegida on Monday, and for the people who go, itâs very present, but otherwise, Itâs not that present in Dresden. I think that there a lot more political statements here than in MÃ¼nster, because people have to engage with it. I have the feeling that there are a lot of intercultural events here. I think that right now I see only the positive sides of Dresden.

It was interesting when I moved to the Netherlands for university. There are a lot of Germans in Maastricht, and in my school in particular there were also a lot of people who come from elsewhere. There were also a lot exchange students, who werenât at all used the fact that you could just drive over the border. And I grew up like that, that was just how it was. It wasnât a big step to move to the Netherlands. I understand to a point that people would be against the EU. I understand that there is fear. I understand that in parts of Germany, that there arenât as many foreigners or people who donât look like they would belong to Germany. I think that there are just a lot of prejudices that dominate and that arenât really thematized. This whole integration debate, that there is a dominant culture, and everyone has to conform to it â I think that a lot of people have a very limited idea of what Germany looks like, how Germans look, and that they can get scared that now the foreigners are coming and mixing with us and maybe claiming something that some people think belongs to them, I can understand that, but I also think that especially because I have never had a bad experience, I have a totally different opinion, because I have only experienced the advantages of the EU. I think that as the child of academics who grew up in the west, itâs also somehow easier to say that everything is great here, and the EU is a good project."

"Ich komme aus Rotterdam in Holland und mache hier in Dresden Urlaub. Das ist das achte mal, dass ich in Dresden bin, und mein sechstes mal bei der Sommerakademie. Ich habe die Sommerakademie vom riesa efau vor Jahren entdeckt. Ich wollte einen Siebdruckkurs machen und habe im Internet gesehen, dass sie einen anbieten. Ich war hier, mir hat es hier gefallen und ich habe Freunde gefunden. Ich bin wieder hier, um Kunst zu machen und alte Freunde wiederzusehen.

In meinem normalen Leben arbeite ich fÃ¼r das Bildungsminsterium der Niederlande. Ich bin nur HobbykÃ¼nstler. Ich habe alles ausprobiert â Siebdruck, Zeichnen, Holzschnitt, jetzt Installation. Mein aktuelles Projekt ist eine Installation mit Vasen. Ich habe hier sechs Vasen in verschiedenen Stilen gekauft, und ich werde wahrscheinlich Menschen zu ihnen interviewen. Wir waren heute in Gorbitz, einem Plattenbauviertel, der nicht den besten Ruf hat. Ich werde die Menschen dort fragen, wie ihnen ihre Gegend gefÃ¤llt, und sie bitten, eine Vase auszusuchen, die sie reprÃ¤sentiert. Ich glaube, jeder Teil von Dresden hat seinen eigenen Charme und seine eigene Art von Menschen. Hier in der Friedrichstadt ist es ganz anders als in der Neustadt. Ich mÃ¶chte diese Unterschiede erforschen
.
Ich bin ein AuÃenstehender. Ich komme einmal im Jahr her und kenne nicht die Geschichte der verschiedenen Orte. Die Leute hier kennen nicht nur die Geschichte, sie haben auch Vorurteile. Ich mÃ¶chte herausfinden, was das fÃ¼r Vorurteile sind. Rotterdam hat natÃ¼rlich auch Vorurteile. Die gibt es in jeder Stadt. Zum Beispiel Gorbitz â alle sagen, das ist schlechter Teil der Stadt, aber ich war dort und denke, dass es ein schÃ¶ner Ort ist. Vieles ist neu gemacht. Einerseits hat es einen Ruf. Andererseits mÃ¶chte ich dort leben.

Es gibt immer Klischees Ã¼ber Stadtviertel und StÃ¤dte. Ich wÃ¼rde diese Klischees gern zerstÃ¶ren, aber dafÃ¼r muss ich sie zuerst kennen. Ich wÃ¼rde den Menschen raten, Dresden selbst kennenzulernen."
--
"I am from Rotterdam in Holland, and I am here for a holiday in Dresden. This is the eighth time I have been in Dresden, and itâs the sixth time I was at the summer academy. I discovered the riesa efau summer academy years ago. I wanted to do a silkscreen course, and I found that they were offering one in the internet. I came, and I liked it here, and I made some friends here. I come back for art making and for meeting friends again.

In my normal life, I work for the ministry of education in the Netherlands. I am just a hobby artist. I have tried everything out â silkscreen, drawing, woodcut, now installation. My current project is an installation with vases. I bought six vases here with different styles, and I will probably interview people about them. We went to Gorbitz yesterday, a Plattenbau district, and it doesnât have the best reputation. I am going to ask people there how they feel about their neighborhood and ask them to pick a vase that represents it. I think every part of Dresden has its own charm and its own kind of people. Here in Friedrichsstadt, there is something is very different from Neustadt. I want to discover these differences.

I am an outsider. I come here once a year, and I donât know the history of places. The people who live here not only know the history but have prejudices. I want to find out about these prejudices. Of course, Rotterdam has these prejudices as well. Every city has them. Gorbitz, for example -- everyone said it was a bad part of town, but I went there, and I think itâs a beautiful place. There is a lot that is renovated. On one side, it has a reputation. On the other side, I want to live there.

There always clichÃ©s about neighborhoods and cities. I would like to destroy the clichÃ©s, but first I need to know what they are. I would tell people that they have to discover Dresden for themselves."

Photo credit: Hans Hochheim
