Meine HauptfÃ¤cher waren Spanisch und Grafikdesign. Im Anschluss ziehe ich nach Spanien, um Englisch zu unterrichten, aber irgendwann will ich Grafikdesign machen oder Veranstaltungsorganisation fÃ¼r Non-Profit-Organisationen oder so etwas. 

Ich habe letztes Jahr in Spanien gelebt und als ich heim kam, wollte ich unbedingt zurÃ¼ck nach Europa. Die GrÃ¼nderin von âGerman Lessons for Refugeesâ, Dana, war an meiner UniversitÃ¤t und ich habe mitbekommen, was sie machen. Ich habe ihr Nachrichten geschrieben, bis sie mir endlich geantwortet hat â sie ist wirklich eine vielbeschÃ¤ftigte Person. Es gab ein paar MissverstÃ¤ndnisse, weil es âGERMAN Lessons for Refugeesâ heiÃt und ich kein Deutsch spreche. Aber wir haben uns angepasst.

Ich bringe ein paar GeflÃ¼chteten Englisch bei. Es ist so interessant. Einer meiner SchÃ¼ler ist aus Damaskus, er hat FranzÃ¶sisch gelernt und ich sehr gebildet, und dann gibt es jemanden, der nie gelernt hat, seine Muttersprache zu schreiben. Er kommt aus Kabul. Ich musste ihm beibringen, wie man lernt, wie man Notizen macht. Wir haben ein System entwickelt. Aber er liebt es, zu lernen. Es ist so schwierig, eine Sprache zu lernen, die man nie zuvor gehÃ¶rt hat, aber er ist mit Begeisterung dabei. Es war eine tolle Erfahrung.

Ich habe auch Veranstaltungen organisiert. Am 1. August gibt es einen Sofa-Talk im Weltklub. Wir sprechen Ã¼ber Liebe und wie Liebe in verschiedenen Kulturen gezeigt wird. Ich habe ein paar Karten vorbereitet, um die Diskussion zu starten - âWie hÃ¤ngen intelektuelle und kÃ¶rperliche Liebe zusammen?â oder âWann hast du das letzte mal deine Mutter angerufen?â, um die Leute dazu zu bekommen, sich zu Ã¶ffnen und Empathie zu erzeugen. Wir haben eine Zeichenecke, damit Menschen, die nicht schreiben kÃ¶nnen, zeichnen kÃ¶nnen, wie sie sich fÃ¼hlen.

Alle in Dresden sind eingeladen. Wir mÃ¶chten, dass Deutsche, AuslÃ¤nder, alle, kommen und etwas beitragen. Das einzige, was wir nicht wollen, sind Rassismus und Homophobie."

"I am from Alabama, and I am in Dresden doing my last internship with German Lessons for Refugees before graduating from college. I majored in Spanish and visual design. After this, I am moving to Spain to teach English, but eventually I want to do graphic design or event planning for non-profits or something.

I lived in Spain last year, and when I got home, I was desperate to come back to Europe. The founder of German Lessons for Refugees, Dana, went to my university, and I heard about what she was doing. I just kept messaging her until she answered me â she is actually a really busy person. We had a bit of a miscommunication though, because itâs _German_ Lessons for Refugees, and I donât speak any German. But weâve adapted.

I have been teaching English to a couple of refugees. Itâs so interesting. One of my students is from Damascus, and heâs learned French, and heâs really well educated, and the other one never learned to write his native language. Heâs from Kabul. I have had to teach him how to study, how to take notes. We developed a system. But he loves to learn. Itâs so difficult to learn a language youâve basically never heard, but he is passionate about it, so itâs been a great experience.

I have also been planning events. We have a Sofa Talk coming up at the WeltClub on August 1st. We are talking about love, and the ways love is expressed in different cultures. I have been made some cards to start off discussion â âhow are intellectual love and physical love related?â Or "when is the last time you called your mom?â to get people to open up and create empathy. We have a drawing station so that people who canât write can draw how they feel.

Everyone in Dresden is invited. We want Germans, foreigners, everyone to come and share. The only thing we donât want are racism or homophobia."

Photo credit: Hans Hochheim

"Mein Vater ist gebÃ¼rtiger Dresdner. Dadurch bin ich mein ganzes Leben lang in Dresden gewesen, immer mehr oder weniger zu Besuch. Aufgewachsen bin ich in GÃ¼tersloh. Mein Vater ist nach dem Krieg nicht wieder hierher gegangen, weil alles zerbombt war.

Nach der Wende bin ich nicht nur einmal im Jahr hier gewesen, sondern laufend, weil mein Onkel und meine Tante noch lebten. Die Wende habe ich leider nicht in Dresden erlebt. Damals habe ich im Harz gearbeitet. Ich habe unter TrÃ¤nen vorm Fernseher gesessen und das verfolgt. Mein Vater hat immer gesagt: âIch werde es wahrscheinlich nicht mehr erleben, aber ihr werdet es noch erleben: Es wird wieder ein Deutschland werden.â Und wir haben immer gesagt, der Alte spinnt. Ich habe mich riesig darÃ¼ber gefreut.

Ich persÃ¶nlich habe eine unheimlich intensive Beziehung zu Dresden. Ich habe meine Frau hier kennengelernt, auch in der Sommerakademie. Wir sind seit zwÃ¶lf Jahren zusammen und haben jetzt gerade im Januar geheiratet. Dresden hat sich toll entwickelt, wenn man Dresden von frÃ¼her gekannt hat, auch zu der DDR-Zeit, wo diese Riesenblocks standen, die sogenannten Arbeiterregale. Dresden ist meine Lieblingsstadt. "Ich bin Soziologin, und ich hatte schon immer ein Herz fÃ¼r die Kunst. Es hat mich interessiert. Aus der soziologischen Perspektive guckt man ja auch, wo kann ich Gesellschaft beobachten. Kultur und Kunst sind ja ein Spiegelbild der Gesellschaft, und das fand ich spannend. Da es eher die gegenwÃ¤rtige Gesellschaft ist, die mich interessiert, ist es entsprechend auch die zeitgenÃ¶ssische Kunst. Ich habe mich schon wÃ¤hrend meines Studiums damit beschÃ¤ftigt und an verschiedenen Projekten mitgearbeitet. Dann gab es die MÃ¶glichkeit, hier im riesa efau eine Anstellung zu bekommen. Ich habe hier den Bereich Kunst und Gesellschaft, was natÃ¼rlich beides wunderbar miteinander verbindet. Ich bin extrem glÃ¼cklich darÃ¼ber und das auch schon eine Weile. Ich bin jetzt im zehnten Jahr hier und habe viele spannende Projekte mitmachen dÃ¼rfen, spannende GÃ¤ste gehabt, spannende GesprÃ¤che, Performances, Ausstellungen und KÃ¼nstler. Es ist sehr abwechslungsreich, man hat immer die Auseinandersetzung, neue Menschen. Man hat die MÃ¶glichkeit, Diskurse zu initiieren, Diskurse mitzugestalten, das ist toll.

Ich bin in Dresden aufgewachsen. Den riesa efau kenne ich, glaube ich, seit ich siebzehn bin und hier im Keller mein erstes Konzert besucht habe. Seitdem war ich immer mal wieder auf Veranstaltungen hier. Als ich hier angefangen habe, gab es ein Projekt, das hieÃ âOhne unsâ, was sich mit der widerstÃ¤ndigen Kunst und Kulturszene in der DDR beschÃ¤ftigt hatte. Aus dieser Geisteshaltung heraus ist ja der riesa efau auch ein bisschen entstanden. Ich habe dann mit den GrÃ¼ndungsmitgliedern und Leuten, die schon sehr zeitig mitgewirkt haben, Interviews gefÃ¼hrt und habe auf diese Weise verschiedene Geschichten gehÃ¶rt, und jede Geschichte wird ein bisschen anders erzÃ¤hlt. Die spannende Geschichte war eigentlich, dass am 9. November 1989, als hier in der SchÃ¤ferstraÃe in der Friedrichstadt die erste freie BÃ¼rgerversammlung stattfand, zwei Journalisten anwesend waren. Der eine hatte wohl einen Knopf im Ohr und hat dann gefragt, was die Anwesenden denn machen wÃ¼rden, wenn sie hÃ¶ren wÃ¼rden, dass die Grenzen offen sind und die Mauer weg ist. Mir wurde erzÃ¤hlt, dass damals der Mann der Vorstandsvorsitzenden gesagt habe: âDann bleiben wir hier und machen genauso weiter.â Und die wussten wirklich noch nicht, dass die Mauer offen war. Die haben das die ganze Nacht nicht gewusst. Im Dezember 89 haben dann Frank Eckhardt und Andreas DÃ¶rfel den riesa efau besetzt, das Eckhaus hier in der Adlergasse 16. Man wollte das relativ schnell auch auf legale FÃ¼Ãe stellen. Damals musste man das noch bei der Volkspolizei anmelden. Im ersten Versuch ist man gescheitert, beim zweiten Mal hat es dann geklappt, und der riesa efau ist tatsÃ¤chlich noch als neunter Verein, also als letzter einstelliger Verein ins Vereinsregister aufgenommen worden.

Im Interview wurde auch gesagt, was fÃ¼r eine verrÃ¼ckte Zeit das damals war. Es ging vieles, man konnte viel machen. Ich glaube, da ist eine tolle Energie gewesen damals, und das ist auch spannend bei den Interviews zu hÃ¶ren. Die haben einfach losgemacht. Viele KÃ¼nstler, die hier mitgewirkt haben, haben dann auch als ABM-KrÃ¤fte die WerkstÃ¤tten mit aufgebaut. Zuerst ist die Galerie Adlergasse, die Kneipe, wieder flottgemacht worden. Im MÃ¤rz 1990 war dann die ErÃ¶ffnung der Galerie Adlergasse, und dann sind die WerkstÃ¤tten dazu gekommen. Seit 92/93 gibt es die Internationale Sommerakademie, seit 2003 die Motorenhalle und seit 2015 dann den tollen Neubau mit tollen WerkstÃ¤tten und Veranstaltungsraum.

Irgendwann kam dann der sogenannte âinstitutional turn,â also der Punkt, an dem viele ehrenamtliche Mitarbeiter zu Festangestellten wurden, was sicher noch mal eine andere Form der Organisation ausmacht. Ich gehÃ¶re glÃ¼cklicherweise zu denen, die in einer Festanstellung sind und hoffe immer noch, selber Angebote mitmachen zu dÃ¼rfen, die andere toll finden und wo sozusagen noch der Geist von damals ein bisschen drinsteckt, dass man reflektierende Fragen stellt.

Die Sommerakademie ist fÃ¼r mich immer ein bisschen wie Urlaub. Es ist toll, weil der Verein, das ganze Haus, alles, was er an Potenzial hat, gleichzeitig auslebt, auch durch die tollen Menschen, die hier da sind und die GÃ¤ste, die das natÃ¼rlich mitgestalten. Es ist aufregend, was durch die Teilnehmer innerhalb von ein oder zwei Wochen an Arbeiten entsteht. Es gibt Teilnehmer, die schon lÃ¤nger hierher kommen als ich hier bin. Es ist schÃ¶n, dass die Leute wiederkommen, dass es ihnen hier gefÃ¤llt. 

Wir haben hier tolle Abendprogramme sowie die Intermezzi, die fÃ¼r alle offen sind. Das kann man auf Facebook oder auf unserer Website nachlesen, dazu sind alle herzlich eingeladen. Nach wie vor haben wir auch fÃ¼r Leute, die Kunst studieren wollen, ein Stipendiaten-Programm."

"I am a sociologist, and I always had an affection for art. It interested me. From a sociological perspective, you ask, âwhere can I observe society?â Culture and art provide a reflection of society, and I thought that was exciting. Because I am mostly interested in contemporary art, I am therefore interested in contemporary art. During my studies, I was occupied with that and worked on various projects. Then there was the possibility to be employed here at riese efau. I work in the area of art and society, which come together wonderfully. I am extremely happy about it and to be able to participate, to have had exciting guests, exciting conversations, performances, exhibitions, and artists. Itâs very varied. You always have the engagement, the new people. You have the opportunity to initiate new discourses, to shape discourses, thatâs great.

I grew up in Dresden. I think I have known about riesa efau since I was seventeen and went to a concert here in the basement. Since then, I came back for events every once in a while. When I started, there was project that was called âWithout Us,â which was about the resistant art and culture scene in the GDR. The riesa efau developed a little out of this attitude. I did interviews with the founding members and people, who were already involved at an early point, so I heard different stories in this way, and every story is told a bit differently. The most exciting story was that actually on November 9, 1989, when the first meeting of citizens took place here on SchÃ¤ferstraÃe in Friedrichstadt, two journalists were present. One of them had a speaker in his ear and asked what the people present would do if they would hear that the borders were open and the wall was down. I was told that back then the husband of the chairwoman, âThen we will stay here and keep doing this.â And they really didnât know yet that the wall was open. They didnât know for the whole night. In December 1989, Frank Eckhardt and Andreas DÃ¶rfel then occupied riesa efau, the corner house here at Adlergasse 16. They wanted to get it onto a legal footing fairly quickly. Back then, you still had to register at the Volkspolizei. The first attempt failed, but the second was successful, and riesa efau is actually still as the ninth association â meaning, the last association with one-digit to be registered.

In the interviews, people also talked about what a crazy time it was back then. A lot was possible, you could do a lot. I think there was a great energy back then, and it is also exciting to hear about it in the interviews. They just got going. Many artists who helped here then helped build the workshops as part of an anti-unemployment program. First the Galerie Adlergasse, the bar was started up again. In March, 1990, was the opening of the Galerie Adlergasse and then the workshops came. Since 92/93, we have had the international summer academy. We have had the motor hall since 2003, and since 2015, the great new building with the great workshops and event space.

At some point came the so-called âinstitutional turn,â meaning the point when a lot of volunteer workers got permanent jobs, something that surely made it a different form of organization. Luckily, I belong to those who have a permanent position and still hope to be able to do projects that other people think are great and in which the spirit from back then resides a bit, that pose reflective questions.

The summer academy is always a little like vacation for me. Itâs great because the association, the whole building, expresses its potential at the same time, also through the great people who are here and the guests, who help shape it of course. It is exciting what works are created by the participants within one or two weeks. There are participants who have come here longer than I have been here. Itâs great that people come back, that they like it."

Ich gehÃ¶re glÃ¼cklicherweise zu denen, die in einer Festanstellung sind und hoffe immer noch, selber Angebote mitmachen zu dÃ¼rfen, die andere toll finden und wo sozusagen noch der Geist von damals ein bisschen drinsteckt, dass man reflektierende Fragen stellt.

Die Sommerakademie ist fÃ¼r mich immer ein bisschen wie Urlaub. Es ist toll, weil der Verein, das ganze Haus, alles, was er an Potenzial hat, gleichzeitig auslebt, auch durch die tollen Menschen, die hier da sind und die GÃ¤ste, die das natÃ¼rlich mitgestalten. Es ist aufregend, was durch die Teilnehmer innerhalb von ein oder zwei Wochen an Arbeiten entsteht. Es gibt Teilnehmer, die schon lÃ¤nger hierher kommen als ich hier bin. Es ist schÃ¶n, dass die Leute wiederkommen, dass es ihnen hier gefÃ¤llt. 

Wir haben hier tolle Abendprogramme sowie die Intermezzi, die fÃ¼r alle offen sind. Das kann man auf Facebook oder auf unserer Website nachlesen, dazu sind alle herzlich eingeladen. Nach wie vor haben wir auch fÃ¼r Leute, die Kunst studieren wollen, ein Stipendiaten-Programm."

"I am a sociologist, and I always had an affection for art. It interested me. From a sociological perspective, you ask, âwhere can I observe society?â Culture and art provide a reflection of society, and I thought that was exciting. Because I am mostly interested in contemporary art, I am therefore interested in contemporary art. During my studies, I was occupied with that and worked on various projects. Then there was the possibility to be employed here at riese efau. I work in the area of art and society, which come together wonderfully. I am extremely happy about it and to be able to participate, to have had exciting guests, exciting conversations, performances, exhibitions, and artists. Itâs very varied. You always have the engagement, the new people. You have the opportunity to initiate new discourses, to shape discourses, thatâs great.

I grew up in Dresden. I think I have known about riesa efau since I was seventeen and went to a concert here in the basement. Since then, I came back for events every once in a while. When I started, there was project that was called âWithout Us,â which was about the resistant art and culture scene in the GDR. The riesa efau developed a little out of this attitude. I did interviews with the founding members and people, who were already involved at an early point, so I heard different stories in this way, and every story is told a bit differently. The most exciting story was that actually on November 9, 1989, when the first meeting of citizens took place here on SchÃ¤ferstraÃe in Friedrichstadt, two journalists were present. One of them had a speaker in his ear and asked what the people present would do if they would hear that the borders were open and the wall was down. I was told that back then the husband of the chairwoman, âThen we will stay here and keep doing this.â And they really didnât know yet that the wall was open. They didnât know for the whole night. In December 1989, Frank Eckhardt and Andreas DÃ¶rfel then occupied riesa efau, the corner house here at Adlergasse 16. They wanted to get it onto a legal footing fairly quickly. Back then, you still had to register at the Volkspolizei. The first attempt failed, but the second was successful, and riesa efau is actually still as the ninth association â meaning, the last association with one-digit to be registered.

In the interviews, people also talked about what a crazy time it was back then. A lot was possible, you could do a lot. I think there was a great energy back then, and it is also exciting to hear about it in the interviews. They just got going. Many artists who helped here then helped build the workshops as part of an anti-unemployment program. First the Galerie Adlergasse, the bar was started up again. In March, 1990, was the opening of the Galerie Adlergasse and then the workshops came. Since 92/93, we have had the international summer academy. We have had the motor hall since 2003, and since 2015, the great new building with the great workshops and event space.

At some point came the so-called âinstitutional turn,â meaning the point when a lot of volunteer workers got permanent jobs, something that surely made it a different form of organization. Luckily, I belong to those who have a permanent position and still hope to be able to do projects that other people think are great and in which the spirit from back then resides a bit, that pose reflective questions.

The summer academy is always a little like vacation for me. Itâs great because the association, the whole building, expresses its potential at the same time, also through the great people who are here and the guests, who help shape it of course. It is exciting what works are created by the participants within one or two weeks. There are participants who have come here longer than I have been here. Itâs great that people come back, that they like it."

Dann hatten wir Veranstaltungen zum System der Einkommensteuer in Deutschland â um die Frage zu beantworten, wohin unser ganzes Geld verschwindet. Wir sitzen im Impact Hub am Hauptbahnhof.

Im Moment haben wir nur sehr wenige SchÃ¼ler; die Leute kommen hauptsÃ¤chlich zu uns, wenn sie eine PrÃ¼fung haben oder so. Heute haben wir eine Veranstaltung mit dem Namen âLove without Bordersâ. Meine Praktikantin hatte die Idee, Leute zusammenzubringen und Ã¼ber Beziehungen und sowas zu sprechen. Sie hat eine andere Sicht auf die Dinge, weil sie erst seit kurzem in Deutschland ist. Wir wollen darÃ¼ber sprechen, was Liebe bedeutet, wie man seine GefÃ¼hle ausdrÃ¼ckt und wer zur Familie gehÃ¶rt, weil das sehr wichtig ist. Meine Familie besteht aus Menschen aus siebzehn unterschiedlichen LÃ¤ndern.

Es war mir schon immer wichtig, zu zeigen, dass Familie auch etwas anderes sein kann als Menschen, mit denen man blutsverwandt ist. Wir haben im Impact Hub auch eine dreiteilige Dokumentation mit dem Titel âHumanâ gezeigt. Wir wollten zeigen, dass wir alle die gleichen Werte haben; wir zeigen sie vielleicht auf unterschiedliche Weise, aber am Ende wollen wir alle das gleiche. Wir wollen, dass unsere Familien sicher, satt, frei, nicht durch Krieg bedroht, sind. Das sind universelle GrundbedÃ¼rfnisse von uns allen.

Die Zeit war wunderbar fÃ¼r mich. Ich habe so viele Leute getroffen. Es war der am meisten bereichernde Teil meines Lebens. Manchmal war es hart. Am schlimmsten war der bÃ¼rokratische Mist. Es muss mehr FlexibilitÃ¤t im deutschen Sprachlernsystem geben, und die staatliche UnterstÃ¼tzung bei der Finanzierung und der organisatorischen UnterstÃ¼tzung der Vereine, die die LÃ¼cken im System fÃ¼llen, muss besser werden.

Dresden ist immer noch meine Lieblingsstadt, und ich hoffe, dass die Integration in fÃ¼nfzehn Jahren vorangeschritten ist. Das ist meine Mission. Dresden zu einem Ort mit mehr Akzeptanz zu machen. Wir mÃ¶gen nicht alle groÃ und blond und blauÃ¤ugig sein, aber das heiÃt nicht, dass wir nicht hierher gehÃ¶ren."

"You interviewed me in 2015. I was bringing bags of clothes to a refugee camp. A lot has changed. We are not in panic mode anymore, because we donât have a bunch of people coming at the same time. I think things are now a lot more organized, but there are still a lot of holes in the system that need to be plugged with non-profits that actually want to do the work, and I am still doing it.

I founded an association called German Lessons for Refugees. It took me about a year, but I did it. First, we were teaching German, then we had a couple classes on politics â on the German constitution, why the laws are the way they are, and what it means for people who live here. Then we had a couple of classes on the income tax system in Germany â to answer the question of where all our money is going. We are based at the Impact Hub near Hauptbahnhof.

We have very few students right now; people mostly come to us for help if they have any exam or that kind of thing. Today, we are doing an event called âLove without Borders.â My intern came up with the idea to bring people together and talk about relationships and stuff. She has a different perspective having only been in Germany a short amount of time. We want to talk about what love means, how you express your feelings, and who belongs to your family, because thatâs really important. My family consists of people from seventeen different countries.

Showing that family can mean something different than people who are related to you by blood has been really important to me; we also did a three-part documentary called âHumanâ at the Impact Hub. We wanted to show that we all have the same values, we may show them differently, but in the end, we all want the same thing. We want our families to be safe, fed, free, not trapped by war. These are universal basic things that we all need.

This time has been wonderful for me. I have met so many people. Itâs been the most enriching part of my life. It has been hard sometimes. The bureaucratic bullshit has been the worst. There needs to be more flexibility built into the German language lesson system, and there needs to be a better way for the state to fund and organizationally support the associations that fill the gaps in the system.

Dresden is still my favorite city, and I hope it will be more integrated in fifteen years. Thatâs my mission. To make Dresden a more accepting place. We may not be all tall and blond and blue eyed, but it doesnât mean that we donât belong here."

"Ich bin 52 Jahre alt. Von Beruf bin ich Krankenpfleger. Ich komme ursprÃ¼nglich aus Mosambik, aber lebe schon seit 1986 in Deutschland. Ich gehÃ¶re zu den Vertragsarbeitern in der ehemaligen DDR. Es gab damals ein Abkommen zwischen Mosambik und der DDR. Junge Leute wurden in Mosambik rekrutiert und hierher geschickt, um einerseits den ArbeitskrÃ¤ftemangel, den die DDR hatte, abzudecken, und andererseits auch den jungen Leuten eine Perspektive zu geben, damit, wenn sie wieder in ihre LÃ¤nder zurÃ¼ckgehen, sie beim Aufbau helfen. SpÃ¤ter haben wir aber festgestellt, dass wir auch als ein Teil der Schuldentilgung gedient haben. Unser Gehalt wurde teilweise einfach einbehalten, um die Schulden, die die Regierung von Mosambik hatte, zu begleichen. Man lehnt zwar das Wort Sklaverei offiziell ab, aber anders kann man das eigentlich nicht bezeichnen. Das Geld sollte uns angeblich in Mosambik wieder ausgezahlt werden, tatsÃ¤chlich ist aber gar kein Geld nach Mosambik geflossen.

Wir sind mit der Hoffnung gekommen, dass wir die Berufe lernen werden, die wir tatsÃ¤chlich brauchen. Die Ausbildung in Europa hat natÃ¼rlich einen guten Ruf in Afrika. Ich bin damals sehr gern hergekommen und bin auch herzlich empfangen worden. Bei der Wiedervereinigung hat man uns vergessen. Bei den Verhandlungen zum Einigungsvertrag hat man uns ausgeklammert. Man ist davon ausgegangen, dass die LÃ¤nder ihre Leute zurÃ¼cknehmen; es sollte sogar zusÃ¤tzlich Geld bezahlt werden, um die Leute in ihrer Heimat wieder zu integrieren. Mir war aber klar, dass das ein fauler Kompromiss ist, weil die Regierung nie eingehalten hat, was sie versprochen hat. Und den Beruf, den ich damals gelernt habe - GieÃereifacharbeiter -, hÃ¤tte ich in Mosambik niemals ausÃ¼ben kÃ¶nnen. Ich habe gedacht, dass ich nie wieder die Chance bekomme, nach Europa zu kommen. Mir war klar, dass ich zuerst eine andere Ausbildung machen muss. Das war aber nicht so einfach. Zuerst musste ich eine Arbeit und eine Wohnung haben, bevor ich bleiben durfte. Ich habe tatsÃ¤chlich eine Einstellung und einen Ausbildungsplatz bei der Post bekommen. Als ich mit meinem Ausbildungsvertrag zur AuslÃ¤nderbehÃ¶rde gegangen bin, haben die mir erstmal den Pass abgenommen und ungÃ¼ltig gestempelt, ein Arbeitsverbot erteilt und eine Ausreisepflicht verhÃ¤ngt. Ich sollte innerhalb von einem Monat ausreisen. Mir wurde gesagt, dass es keine gesetzliche Grundlage gebe; die VertrÃ¤ge sein ausgelaufen. Meine Rettung war eine Organisation der Kirche, die Leute, die Schwierigkeiten hatten, gesammelt und ein Projekt mit ihnen gemacht haben. Es gab noch einmal eine MaÃnahme, eine Vorbereitung fÃ¼r die Berufsausbildung. Im Anschluss haben sie Ausbildungen in verschiedenen Berufszweigen angeboten. So bin ich wieder in der System reingekommen.

Das war meine Motivation, in Vereinen mitzuarbeiten, die Leuten helfen, die in Schwierigkeiten geraten sind. Seitdem arbeite ich ehrenamtlich in Vereinen. Ich bin seitdem nie stehen geblieben, weil ich gemerkt habe, dass man etwas machen muss."

Teil 1/2
--
"I am 52 years old. I am a nurse by profession. I come from Mozambique originally, but I have lived in Germany since 1986. I am one of the contract workers from the former GDR. There was an agreement back then between Mozambique and the GDR. Young people were recruited in Mozambique and sent here to fill in for the GDRâs lack of workers on the one side and on the other side, give young people a prospect, so that they could go home back to their countries and help develop them. Later, we realized, however, that we served as part of a debt repayment scheme. Our wages were held back in part in order to pay back, settle the debts that the government of Mozambique had. People reject the word âslaveryâ officially, but you canât actually call it anything else. The money was supposed to be paid back to us in Mozambique, but actually no money went to Mozambique.

We came here with the hope that we would learn professions that we actually needed. Training in Europe had a good reputation in Africa, of course. I was happy to come here back then and was very warmly received. At the time of the reunification, people forgot us. In the negotiations in the reunification agreement, we were excluded. People assumed that the countries would take back their people; there was actually extra money paid so that people could integrate into their home countries again. It was clear to me that it was a lazy compromise because the government never followed through on what they promised. And the profession that I learned back then â foundry worker -- is something that I would never be able to do it Mozambique. I thought, I am never going to get the chance to come back to Europe. It was clear to me that I had to do another training course, but that wasnât so simple. First, I had to have work and an apartment before I would be allowed to stay. I actually received a recruitment letter and acceptance for a training course in the mail. When I went to the immigration office with my contract for the training course, they first took my ID and stamped it with âinvalid,â forbid me from working and ordered me to leave the country. I was supposed to leave within a month. I was told that there was no legal basis; the contracts were expired. My savior was a church organization that brought together people who were having difficulties and did a project with them. There was still one more measure, a preparation for professional training. After that, they offered training courses in various professional branches. Thatâs how I got back into the system.

That was my motivation to work in non-profit associations that help people who are having difficulties. Since then, I have volunteered in associations. Since then, I have never stood still because I saw that you have to do something."

Part 1/2

Ich bin immer wieder angerannt und habe gekÃ¤mpft und versucht, einen gesellschaftlichen Zusammenhalt zu schaffen, Transparenz und VerstÃ¤ndigung. Man investiert sehr viel Zeit, um etwas zu erreichen. Es gibt kaum eine Gruppe, die so wenig Lobby hat wie Migranten. Ich habe aber ungemein viel gelernt dabei und bin froh, dass ich diese groÃen Herausforderungen gemeistert habe.

Was die Zukunft mit sich bringt, wird sich zeigen. Wir befinden uns ja wieder in so einer Krisensituation, wo es darum geht, ob die Demokratie Ã¼berleben kann oder nicht. Wenn es um solche BrÃ¼che geht, leiden letztendlich immer die Minderheiten zuerst. Davor habe ich keine Angst, aber schon ein mulmiges GefÃ¼hl, ob wir es auch schaffen, wieder zum Normalen zurÃ¼ckzukehren, wo wir von einer Gesellschaft insgesamt sprechen kÃ¶nnen und wo wir nicht wieder anfangen, uns zu trennen, und jeder gegen jeden kÃ¤mpft.

Gleich am ersten Tag meiner Ausbildung bin ich in die Gewerkschaft gegangen, weil ich wusste, die Gewerkschaften sind der Vertreter meiner Interessen. Die Gewerkschaft hat traditionell natÃ¼rlich eine sehr starke Bindung zur SPD. Deswegen bin ich auch mit der SPD in BerÃ¼hrung gekommen, habe aber sehr lange Ã¼berlegt, ob ich in die SPD gehe oder in die Linkspartei. Mit der Linkspartei hatte ich sehr viel praktische Erfahrung und viel UnterstÃ¼tzung bekommen. FÃ¼r mich war es schlieÃlich die Tradition der SPD als Ã¤lteste sozialdemokratische Partei der Arbeiter und die KÃ¶pfe, die dahinter stehen. Willy Brandt, Helmut Schmidt, das sind Namen, die sich um die Demokratie verdient gemacht haben, die etwas fÃ¼r den gesellschaftlichen Zusammenhalt getan haben, unabhÃ¤ngig von Einkommen oder Bildungssituation. Heute versucht die SPD ja, in die gesellschaftliche Mitte zu kommen und alle Bereiche abzudecken. Ist ja klar - Parteien links der Mitte werden meistens mit Sozialismus und Kommunismus verbunden und das ist natÃ¼rlich der erste Feind des Kapitalismus. Das hat man gemerkt, immer wenn die SPD an der Regierung war, hat die Industrie mit Wegzug gedroht. Wenn die CDU an der Macht war, waren die Gelder plÃ¶tzlich alle wieder da.

Ich liebe es eben, fÃ¼r den kleinen Mann zu kÃ¤mpfen. Und ich bin ein treuer Mensch, ich kann nicht nur weil die Partei jetzt Schwierigkeiten hat, einfach in eine andere Partei wechseln. Das ist nicht die LÃ¶sung, die LÃ¶sung ist, die Partei wieder dorthin zu fÃ¼hren, wo ihre Tradition liegt. Man hat natÃ¼rlich Schwierigkeiten mit dem Wandel der Industrie, die Arbeiterschaft brÃ¶ckelt auseinander. Durch den Kapitalismus lÃ¤uft alles aus Lohndumping und Flexibilisierung hinaus, das hat die Kernklientel der SPD geschwÃ¤cht. Und dann kommt natÃ¼rlich noch die Agenda 2010. Das war eine ZÃ¤sur in der SPD Politik; die soziale Marktwirtschaft ist dadurch kaputt gegangen. Ich finde die Agenda 2010 per se nicht falsch. Ich bin der Meinung, das hat Deutschland gerettet vor dieser Riesenkrise, die die ganze Welt getroffen hat. Aber man hÃ¤tte sofort danach wieder eine Reform machen mÃ¼ssen. Die SPD kriegt jetzt dafÃ¼r die Quittung, weil wir nicht mehr die MÃ¶glichkeit haben, das zu korrigieren.

Die SPD ist fÃ¼r mich die Partei, die sehr gut in der Migrationspolitik unterwegs ist und die das auch umsetzt. Sachsen hat noch nie ein Integrationskonzept mit finanzieller Untersetzung gehabt. Man hat immer gesagt: âWir wollen integrieren - also macht mal.â All die Jahre wurde nur punktuell etwas ehrenamtlich gemacht, ohne richtiges Konzept. Aber man braucht Geld fÃ¼r Sachen, die man nicht ehrenamtlich machen kann. Und Spendenfinanzierung fÃ¼r eine Sache, die keine Lobby hat, ist auch schwierig. 2014 haben wir durchgesetzt, dass es ein Ministerium fÃ¼r Integration und Gleichstellung gibt. Seitdem sprechen wir von Integration, weil tatsÃ¤chlich umsetzungsfÃ¤hige Konzepte entstanden sind, die finanziert werden. FlÃ¼chtlinge haben die MÃ¶glichkeit, Sprachkurse zu machen und dezentral untergebracht zu werden. Wir versuchen tatsÃ¤chlich, die Menschen zu integrieren und nicht irgendwo versauern zu lassen, bis sie demotiviert sind und resignieren. Seit 2014 sitzt die SPD dieses Programm konsequent um."

"For me personally, the time in Dresden has been turbulent. Life in Dresden has always been a challenge for me. On the one side, I want to be an ambassador, to show that immigrants belong to society. I have always fought for participation. I co-founded the Dresden Foreignersâ Advisory Council. There is barely an association that I havenât worked with. I always ran around and fought and tried to create social cohesion, transparency, and mutual understanding. You invest so much time in trying to achieve something. There is barely a group that has as little representation as migrants. I have learned a lot doing it, and I am happy that I have mastered these huge challenges.

We will see what the future brings for me. We find ourselves now in a crisis situation where itâs about whether democracy will survive or not. When itâs about fractures like that, the minorities are always the one who suffer first. I am not afraid of that, but I do have an uneasy feeling about whether we can get back to normality, where we can speak of one society in total and where we donât start pulling apart and fighting against each other.

Right away on the first day of my training, I joined the trade union, because I knew that unions are the representatives of my interests. Of course, the union traditionally has a strong connection to the SPD. Thatâs how I came into the contact with the SPD. I thought for a long time if I should join the SPD or the Left Party. I had a lot of practical experience with the Left Party and had gotten a lot of support from them. For me, in the end, it was the tradition of the SPD as the oldest social democratic party of workers and the minds who built it. Willy Brandt, Helmut Schmidt, these are people who loved democracy, who did something for social cohesion, regardless of income or education. Today, the SPD is trying to reach the social middle and cover all the areas. It is clear â parties to the left of the middle are usually associated with socialism and communism, and that is of course, the first enemy of capitalism. You see that whenever the SPD was in power, industry threatened to pulling back. When the CDU is in power, suddenly all the money is available again.

I just fighting for the little man. And I am a loyal person. I canât switch to another party just because the party is having trouble. That is not the solution. The solution is lead the party back to where itâs tradition is. We have of course problems with the shift in industry, the working class is crumbling apart. Because of capitalism, everything is about wage dumping and flexibility, that has weakened the basic constituency of the SPD. And then we of course have the Agenda 2010. That was a turning point in SPD politics, destroying the social market economy.  I think the Agenda 2010 was not wrong per se. I think that it saved Germany from the huge crisis that hit the whole world. But you would have had to do a reform immediately after it. The SPD now gets the responsibility, because we didnât have the opportunity to fix things.

For me, the SPD is the party that is doing well in migration politics, and that is also implementing them. Saxony hasnât yet had an integration concept with financial support. People always say, âWe want integration â so do it.â During all the years, there were only occasional attempts on a volunteer basis, without a real concept. But you need money for things that volunteers canât do. And donations for a thing that doesnât have a lobby is also difficult. In 2014, we were able to push a ministry for integration and equality through. Since then, we talk of integration because there is actually concepts that could be implemented, that were financed. Refugees have the opportunity to take language courses and be lodged in a decentralized way. We are actually trying to integrate people and not let them stagnate somewhere until they are demotivated and resigned. The SPD has been working on this plan consequently since 2014."

Part 2/2

"Ich bin aus Madagaskar. Ich bin seit 2013 hier in Dresden. Davor habe ich in der Lausitz gelebt. Nach Deutschland bin ich nach der Wende gekommen. Ich hatte keine Papiere, weil ich in Tschechien gelebt habe.Ich hatte schon vorher Kontakt mit Sorben; sie haben mich eingeladen, nach Deutschland zu kommen. Ich war Lehrer im sorbischen Gymnasium und habe Tschechisch und FranzÃ¶sisch unterrichtet. Von der Ausbildung her bin ich eigentlich Politologe und Ãkonom.

2005 habe ich endlich meine Aufenthaltserlaubnis fÃ¼r hier bekommen. Es war sehr, sehr, sehr schwer. Es war auch schwer, die deutsche Sprache zu lernen. Ich hatte keinen Deutschkurs. Meiner Meinung nach ist die Situation jetzt aber besser als vor 20, 30 Jahren. Als ich hierher gekommen bin, haben uns Leute auf der Prager StraÃe angegriffen. Alle haben zugesehen. Eine einzige Person hat gesagt: âWas machst du da?â Er hat mein Leben gerettet. Trotzdem habe ich mich entschieden, in Deutschland und in Dresden zu bleiben. Ich habe schon viele LÃ¤nder gesehen - Deutschland hat sich zum Positiven verÃ¤ndert, besonders in Dresden. Ich lebe hier in der Neustadt. Ich habe schon von vielen Dingen gehÃ¶rt, aber mir ist nichts passiert. Ich lebe sehr gut hier. Es ist eine sehr gute Nachbarschaft. Leute, die ich nicht kenne, grÃ¼Ãen mich auf der StraÃe.

Positiv ist auch, dass Dresden International geworden ist, dass die Leute mehr lÃ¤cheln. Es gibt jetzt die MÃ¶glichkeit, Deutsch zu lernen. Ich bin traurig, dass ich diese MÃ¶glichkeit nicht richtig gehabt habe. Am Anfang waren die jungen Leute sehr aggressiv. Jetzt sehe ich in Dresden verschiedene Hautfarben. In Madagaskar ist auch alles bunt gemischt. Das gefÃ¤llt mir jetzt sehr gut hier. Auch wenn dieses Montagsdemonstrationen nicht gut fÃ¼r unser Image sind, denke ich, dass das nur eine Episode ist."
--
"I am from Madagascar. I have been in Dresden since 2013. Before that, I lived in the Lausitz. I came to Germany after the reunification. I didnât have any papers because was living in the Czech Republic. I had had contact with Sorbs; they invited me to come to Germany. I was teacher in a Sorbian high school, where I taught Czech and French. In terms of my education, I am actually a political scientist and economist.

In 2005, I finally got my German residence permit. It was very, very, very hard. It was also hard to learn German. I didnât have a German course. In my opinion, the situation is nevertheless better than it was 20 or 30 years ago. When I came here, people on Prager StraÃe attacked us. Everyone saw. One single person said, âWhat are you doing there?â He saved my life. Nevertheless, I decided to stay in Germany and in Dresden. I have already seen a lot of countries â Germany has changed in a positive direction, especially in Dresden. I live here in the Neustadt. I have heard about a lot of things, but nothing has happened to me. I live here really well. It is a really good neighborhood. People I donât know say hi to me on the street.

It is also positive how international Dresden has become, that more people smile. There is the possibility now to learn German. I am sad that I didnât really have this opportunity. At first, the young people were really aggressive. Now, I see different skin colors in Dresden. It is also mixed in Madagascar. I like it a lot now. Even when these Monday demonstrations are good for our image, I think that is only one episode."

Ich habe auf der StraÃe gespielt und Leute meinten, dass ich wirklich gut bin und versuchen sollte, etwas daraus zu machen. Aber ich bin schÃ¼chtern. Ich glaube nicht, dass ich das allein schaffen kann.

Im Moment arbeite ich und lerne Deutsch, damit ich eine Ausbildung machen kann. Ich hatte hier noch keine Probleme, aber ich bin alleine. Ich vermisse meine Familie; mein Bruder und seine Frau sind vor acht Monaten gestorben. Aber ich versuche, stark zu sein, weil ich an meine Zukunft denke.

Ich mag Dresden sehr. Wenn ich nach Dresden zurÃ¼ckkomme, fÃ¼hle ich mich, als wÃ¼rde ich nach Hause kommen."

I really like Dresden. When I come back to Dresden, I feel like I am coming home."

"Ich komme aus Syrien. Ich bin 25 Jahre alt. Ich bin seit April 2015 in Deutschland. Zuerst habe ich in Zeitz gewohnt, bis ich meinen Aufenthalt bekommen habe. Dann bin ich nach Bautzen umgezogen. In Bautzen habe ich fast drei Jahre gewohnt. Ich habe mir mein Leben aufgebaut, die deutsche Sprache gelernt, ich habe mir einen Freundeskreis aufgebaut, ich habe in einer arabischen Tanzgruppe mitgemacht. Es war sehr schÃ¶n dort.

In Bautzen habe ich eine Ausbildung als Krankenpflegehelfer gemacht. Durch die vielen Kontakte mit Deutschen konnte ich meine Sprache dabei noch verbessern. More people in Dresden should actually get out on the street. Thatâs why I really hope that a lot of people come to Indivisible."

"I was born in Hessen. About four years ago, I moved to Saxony, in particular to Bautzen/ BudyÅ¡in. Relatively soon after getting there, I started advocating on behalf of refugees and democratic work in the area, and in May, against my expectation, I was elected for the Green Party to serve as an independent city councilor on the city council in Bautzen. I didnât expect it because in the last decades, there was always only one person from the Greens on the city council. And the social mood was not absolutely one where you could expect that the result would be doubled. The local elections are elections for a person. It strongly depends on who is on the list. And because I have been involved in engagement for Democracy for years, I already had a public presence.

I expect that itâs going to be relatively difficult. The city council in Bautzen consists of thirty people, and there are only seven people there from the Greens, the Linke, and the SPD. About one half of the city council is from the AfD and a rather rightwing coalition. The other fifteen places are shared between the CDU, FDP, and the SPD, Linke and Greens. That means the policies made wonât be for everyone but policies for white Bautzners, to put it meanly, and not open, tolerant, social politics that also take people into consideration who donât have a vote in the election because they have come to the city as refugees, for example. We are afraid that the volunteer services will cut for social cultural centers, self-administered youth clubs, democracy projects, etc. We are looking at the future with fear, in terms of local politics in the city.

In Bautzen, there is a very dangerous conflict situation because of one person who has quite a bit of money, who invests in events having to do with rightwing populism and conspiracy theories, which have pulled a certain kind of voter onto the side of the citizen coalition. On the other side, the AfD already got very high approval ratings in the federal elections in 2017, with over 33 percent. Of course, the AfD doesnât necessarily make policies on behalf of their people who voted for them. For that, they would have to make social, fair policies. The problem is that the voters of the AfD havenât read what is in their program. They just vote out of protest. Itâs not about content or values, but only that you show the âold partiesâ your opinion. Itâs too bad because people are hurting themselves by voting for the AfD.

I will take part in Indivisible. Last year, in Berlin, I didnât take part because I was disillusioned then by what you experience in Dresden on Mondays, for example. How often do we stand here on Mondays, with fifty, maybe one hundred people, against Pegida. Then people celebrated in Chemnitz, âWe are more!,â celebrated this big demonstration Indivisible and here in Dresden, we think, âNo, weâre not more. Stop using the hashtag âwe are more,â stop with Indivisible, come to Dresden.â I think itâs an incredibly important sign that Indivisible is in Dresden this year, in the week before the state elections in Saxony and Brandenburg. Thatâs why I am going to take part, of course. Itâs a little bit of âself-empowerment,â to go and participate and take home strength for what is going to come after the state elections, and for what is going to come again and again on the following Mondays, when we still arenât more and only stand on the street with a few people against Pegida."

And you can see what has happened through statistics, for example criminality. No one likes to go out anymore on the street in the evening, because people are afraid. That is a fact. There are problematic areas here in Dresden â the former high-rise housing blocks. Itâs a catastrophe. The criminality is a result of the immigration. Islam equals terrorism, since everywhere where there is terrorism, Islam is behind it. Islam is not a belief; itâs always only been about ruling the world. They have been trying that for centuries.

They have always done somewhat better; they could build up their prosperity and have been able to maintain it, in large part. I canât say anything general, but it has also gotten worse in the old West Germany. There are so many âNo Go Areas,â from example Marxloh. Berlin is now also totally awful. There are quarters where there are only foreigners. I avoid Berlin now. I donât like to go there anymore.

In East Germany, we already had a dictatorship. And at the time of the reunification, we had democracy. We had hopes, and it actually went forward for a long time. But then starting in 2000, it went downhill, and since 2010, itâs taken big steps toward the cellar. Now, we are almost in the cellar. I am of the opinion that our whole government only takes care of itself and does nothing for the people. That canât go well over the long term. At some point, the people will rise up again, and probably first here in the east."

It is fulfilling every time that I am here, because I have a good connection to the boys and get along with them really well. We play things â foosball or billiards, for example. A couple times, we had an old man come in here. Once, there was an old man who came in and grabbed a bike intended for the boys and said, âI pay taxes, and the city of Dresden paid for this bike with my tax money, so it belongs to me too.â

I try to find a compromise. It was difficult to show authority during my volunteer year. I did try, and when that didnât help, then I approached them like a friend.

And you can never really calm down â thatâs the most depressing thing for the guys. The road is endlessly long and has a lot of obstacles, and they need help from us."

Ich habe in Dresden und Leipzig studiert und dann noch ein bisschen in Russland. Ich habe mich wÃ¤hrend des Studiums ein bisschen der russischen Kunstgeschichte gewidmet, der russischen Avantgarde - Design, Architektur und Kunst des 20. Jahrhunderts. Ich habe auch die Sprache gelernt und dann gesagt, ich gehe, um die Sache richtig zu lernen, noch mal ein Jahr nach Russland. Es hat viel SpaÃ gemacht, Russisch zu lernen. Ich hatte wÃ¤hrend meiner Kindheit und Schulzeit Ã¼berhaupt keinen Bezug zu Russisch gehabt; das war fÃ¼r mich ein richtiger Exotismus. Ich will nicht mehr lÃ¤nger als ein Jahr nach Russland zurÃ¼ckgehen. Ich war froh, als ich wieder hier zurÃ¼ck war. Es ist schon sehr anstrengend. Es war sehr, sehr cool, aber grundsÃ¤tzlich ist die russische Gesellschaft schon sehr schwer. Es ist einfach hart, das alltÃ¤gliche Leben ist sehr schwierig.

An der russischen Kunstgeschichte hat mich vor allem die Sache mit Design und Architektur der zwanziger Jahre interessiert. Ich fand den gesamtgesellschaftlichen Einfluss und die Energie, die die KÃ¼nstler, Architekten und Designer auf die NeugrÃ¼ndung einer Gesellschaft nach der Revolution hatten, sehr interessant - dass sie so einen enormen Einfluss auf die politischen Prozesse hatten.

Ich bin eigentlich sehr glÃ¼cklich in Dresden. Ich fÃ¼hle mich hier sehr wohl. Ich glaube, mich beschÃ¤ftigt das, was uns alle momentan beschÃ¤ftigt, diese furchtbaren Landtagswahlen und die furchtbare politische Stimmung. Im Grunde genommen kann man nur hoffen, dass die Leute, die sich hier engagieren, auch weiterhin bleiben und das auch weiterhin tun. Ich habe jetzt auch gerade die Entscheidung getroffen, obwohl es fÃ¼r mich auch eine MÃ¶glichkeit gab, wegzugehen, doch noch ein Weilchen in Dresden zu bleiben. Ich hoffe, dass sich das hier doch wieder ein bisschen zum Besseren verÃ¤ndert oder sich zumindest nicht zum Schlechteren wandelt."

I actually come from the Lower Rhine region, but I have lived in Dresden since 2011. I work in the art- and culture sector. I moved here to go to university, and then I stayed here for work. I studied in Dresden and Leipzig and then in Russia a little. I focused a little on Russian art history â the Russian avant-garde, design, architecture, and art of the 20th century. I learned the language, and then said, âI am going to spend a year in Russia in order to really learn the language.â It was really fun to learn Russian. I had no connection to Russian during my childhood and school years; it was really exotic for me. I wouldnât want to go back to Russia for more than a year. I was happy when I got back here. It was really exhausting. It was very, very cool, but basically Russian society is very difficult. It is just hard, daily life is very difficult.
In terms of Russian art history, I was interested in design and architecture of the 1920s. I found the total social influence and the energy that artists, architects and designers had on the new foundation of a society after the revolution very interesting â that they had such an enormous influence on the political processes.
I am actually very happy in Dresden. I feel very comfortable. I think I have been occupied, as we are all occupied at the moment, by this horrible parliamentary election and the terrible political atmosphere. Basically, you can only hope that people will be active here, continue to do so, and will stay here. I just made the decision to stay a while in Dresden even though I had the opportunity to go. I hope that things here do change for the better or at least donât get worse.

Aber es wird auch viel gestritten Ã¼ber Kultur - was ist richtige Kultur, was sollte man tun, wohin sollte es sich entwickeln. Das machen wir ja auch mit der Kulturhauptstadtbewerbung. "I am in my early forties and have lived in Dresden for twelve years. I studied music here and got a doctorate in it. I have worked in the Dresden cultural administration for twelve years; right now, I am head of the Capital of Culture Dresden 2025 office. I am married, have three children, and live in Friedrichstadt. We really like living in Dresden, even if we werenât born here and didnât grow up here. We think cultural life in Dresden is really exciting."

I come from the Erzgebirge. As a child, I definitely wanted to be a famous musician. I came from a home in which no one played music â it was all technicians, engineers, scientists. Probably, it was the impression made by the concerts that I went to with my parents. I thought it was great that the conductor stood in front, the musicians on the stage, making great music. I wanted to become that. In the GDR, there was only the possibility of going to what was the specialized school back then if you want to follow this career path. We decided for Weimar. It wasnât easy at first. It was during the era of the reunification, where the school was a bit on the edge. You didnât know if the school would go on. Aside from that, I was twelve or thirteen at first, and it was far from home. But in retrospect, it was also a time that gave me a lot in terms of my way of life, my personality. I would chose to do it again anytime. 

Besides being the technology and engineering state, Saxony is also a culture land. The spending on culture per capita is among the highest in Germany. I think the consciousness of Dresden is especially shaped by centuries-old culture. In that respect, itâs not particularly difficult for cultural subjects to permeate. But there are a lot of fights about culture â what is real culture, what should you do, in which direction it should develop. We are doing that with the capital of culture application as well. Dresden is apply to be Europeâs capital of culture 2025. We are not in the first decisive phase. We are just turning in our first application. By the end of the December, we will know if we have come farther in the competition among the German candidate cities.

Of course, my goal is for Dresden to get this title with the strategy that we have developed. My team and I are working on it really hard. If I as a private person look at Dresdenâs cultural landscape, I find very little lacking. The title and the application and the years until then are first of all a kind of stipend for the city. You can address subjects with this kind of application that you wouldnât address in the normal business of culture, because they are simply just not that operationalizable. Weâve been working on it now for three or four years. Our application strategy relies a lot on people in Dresden â professionals, but also lay people â developing their own projects for the application. I think this is something new for Dresden, that we are using a very participatory approach. It has brought us in the cultural scene into contact with people with whom we wouldnât have had contact otherwise â for example, in terms of projects in Prohlis, there is a tent theater there, but also an exhibition project in the Kunsthaus where they will work with people with small gardens and Dynamo fans. "I have lived in Dresden for a year â itâs my chosen home and the first city in a long time where I can say that I could imagine staying here. 

I work as a documentary film maker for TV films, cinema films, and promotional films on the subject of sustainability. So, I have a clear political orientation. I want to bring together sustainability and media. They are equally great passions of mine. I couldnât say which is predominate. For me, they function well together. Itâs my aspiration to make films that inspire and are emotionally moving and show solutions, because I think this is lacking in our everyday media. The knowledge about the environment was never as great as today, but at the same time, we donât have the courage and the creativity to come up with solutions. I want to make positive films. I want to make films that people enjoy seeing and where you donât leave still feeling powerless. 

My current film is called âFridays -- It's Our Future.â It will be a cinema film, made on six different continents. We follow six teenagers from six continents, who, on the one side, are connected to the biggest environmental movement of all time â Fridays for Future, and on the other side are very personally confronted with obstacles in their struggle for solutions for global environmental problems. We should start filming in November. We are financed through crowd funding; that means that people can still take part.

I was surprised that Fridays for Future became so big. I went to see Greta in February, and there were maybe fifty people at the event. It gives me a lot of hope, and I think thatâs really nice â this youthful energy that they have. They really believe that change is possible. And that gives me strength in turn. "My daughter has been doing synchronized skating for twelve years. She started in the first grade. She went to see the Ice Fairy Tale and afterward, she said, âMama, I want to be a snow flake at some point.â It was very difficult for her at first, but she pushed through and stayed with it. She is now eighteen years old now; it developed her whole character â team sports, competitive sports, spending three hours a day, three times a week at the skating rink, it makes you an athletic, ambitious person. It was difficult financially, because itâs a very expensive sport, but it gave me a nice new job in life, watching children grow up. We have become a big, big community here in Dresden.

My daughter has now stopped. As an enthusiastic synchronized skating mom, I and another ice mom put together the big First Cup of Dresden, an international synchronized skating competition in recent years â all on a volunteer basis. Of course, we hope that we will get more financing from the city in order to have this great international sport and all the countries here in our wonderful regional capital. Germany is still just starting, but at the moment, thereâs more interest. At every competition, people are amazed about what we do. The ice rink was full last year, and we found new fans. "Ich lebe seit 1991 in Dresden, mittlerweile in Radebeul. Ich bin in KÃ¶ln geboren. Ich bin nach Dresden der Liebe wegen umgezogen. Mein Mann war aus MÃ¼nchen und hatte hier eine Stelle bekommen. Ein Jahr spÃ¤ter bin ich nachgekommen.

Es gibt natÃ¼rlich einen groÃen Unterschied zwischen Dresden 1991 und jetzt. Als ich nach Dresden gekommen, war das kurz nach der Wende. Wir haben entschieden, wir gehen ins ehemalige Ausland. Das hat uns sehr gedient, weil wir nicht mit der Idee hierhergekommen sind, wir beschreiben, wie es besser laufen mÃ¼sste. Die Erfahrungen, die ich in meinem Leben davor gemacht habe, habe ich natÃ¼rlich mitgebracht. Aber ich habe gut daran getan, erst mal den Mund zu halten und zu gucken und zuzuhÃ¶ren. Das war hilfreich, weil es darÃ¼ber mÃ¶glich war, Ã¼berhaupt gute Kontakte mit Dresdnerinnen und Dresdnern. Ich kann heute sagen, ich bin sehr eng befreundet mit vielen Menschen, die hier geboren sind. Es war eine gute Entscheidung, sich nicht so eine Enklave zurÃ¼ckzuziehen von Menschen, die aus dem Westen kommen und sich untereinander wie in einem Kolonialsystem bewegen. Und 1991/1992 war das aber so.

Obwohl beschworen wird, dass es keine Unterschiede mehr gibt, glaube ich nicht daran. Ich glaube, dass es nach wie vor Unterschiede gibt. Die Erwachsenen die hier leben - es sei denn, sie sind unter dreiÃig, und auch da bin ich mir nicht sicher, weil sie ja von Menschen erzogen wurden, die in dem einen oder anderen System groÃ geworden sind - ich glaube, dass es nach wie vor etwas Unterschiedliches gibt. Das halte ich auch gar nicht fÃ¼r schlimm. Was ich fÃ¼r problematisch halte ist, wenn man so tut, als wÃ¤re das nicht.

Ich finde es problematisch, dass wir immer noch PegidaaufmÃ¤rsche haben, auch wenn die deutlich geringfÃ¼giger sind. Ich finde es schwierig, dass es Menschen gibt, die sich in den letzten Jahren zunehmend abgehÃ¤ngt fÃ¼hlen. Ich finde es schwierig, dass sie das jetzt artikulieren und die andere Seite nicht wirklich zuhÃ¶rt oder nicht zugehÃ¶rt hat, was zu einer politischen Situation gefÃ¼hrt hat, die uns jetzt dazu bringt, sagen zu mÃ¼ssen, die Politikerinnen und Politiker hier haben dieses Feld den Rechten Ã¼berlassen. Das ist etwas, was mich tatsÃ¤chlich umtreibt."

Teil 1/2
--
"I have lived in Dresden since 1991 and now in Radebeul. I was born in Cologne. I moved to Dresden because of love. My husband was from Munich, and he got a job here. I came a year later.

Of course, there is a big difference between Dresden in 1991 and now. When I came to Dresden, it was shortly after the reunification. We decided we would go to what used to be a foreign country. That served us well, because we didnât come here with the idea that we would say how things have to be done better. I, of course, brought the experiences that I had before with me, but I did well to keep my mouth shut at first and to observe and listen. It was helpful because then it made it possible to have good contact with Dresdeners. I can say today that I am close friends with a lot of people who were born here. It was a good decision not to withdraw into an enclave of people from the West who interacted with each other as if they were in a colonial system. And in 1991/1992, it was like that.

Although people swear that there are no differences anymore, I donât believe that. I believe that there are still differences. The adults who live here â unless itâs people under thirty, and even then I am not certain because they were raised by people who grew up in another system â I think that there is still something different. I donât think thatâs bad at all. What I think is problematic is when one acts if it werenât the case.

What I think is problematic is the development here in Dresden, the political development. I think itâs problematic that we still have Pegida marches, even if they are clearly smaller. I think itâs difficult that there are people who have been feeling increasingly left behind. I think itâs difficult that they now articulate that, and the other side doesnât really listen or hasnât listened, which has led to a political situation where we have to say that the politicians have abandoned the field to the rightwing. It is something that really plagues me."

Part 1/2

Das ist mit der FlÃ¼chtlingswelle aufgetaucht und hat da sehr viel Futter bekommen, auch weil unsere Politikerinnen und Politiker nicht wirklich gut erklÃ¤rt haben, wie wir es schaffen sollen - wenn wir es denn schaffen. Und ich vermute auch, dass die Ideen nicht soweit gereicht haben, wie wir ja auch sehen, und das ist schade - das ist fÃ¼r uns schade, das ist fÃ¼r die Menschen schade, die hierherkommen und Schutz suchen. Ich will auch gar nicht verhehlen, dass ich mir Gedanken darÃ¼ber mache, ob Bleiberecht fÃ¼r alle wirklich eine gute Option ist. Aber darÃ¼ber muss man sprechen, und es reicht nicht, von der einen und von der anderen Seite Parolen zu proklamieren. Aber es fÃ¼hlt sich vielleicht Ã¤hnlich an fÃ¼r die Menschen, die das rufen. Ich bin auch nicht sicher, was deren DemokratieverstÃ¤ndnis ist. Dresden hat sehr viel Kulturelles zu bieten. Es ist eine Stadt, die an manchen Stellen ein bisschen verlangsamt ist. An manchen Stellen ist das Ã¤rgerlich und an anderen Stellen ist das sehr wohltuend. Ich habe es nie bereut, hierhergekommen zu sein."

"I can remember many years ago that Frank Richter created a situation where people of different political views would meet and have a discussion on a podium. And he was incredibly attacked for it. I am now no fan of Frank Richter, but it is a totally misguided idea of democracy to not listen to the people I donât agree with, and I think itâs a huge gate that all of the people walk through who donât feel listened to.

I donât always get it because I am in a different living situation. And even if I listen closely, I find that the description of the frustration is rather diffuse. It popped up with the wave of refugees, and it got a lot of fuel from that, also because our politicians didnât really explain how we were supposed to do it â when we would do it. And I think itâs difficult if you infantilize people â citizens â and say, âYeah, we can do it, but we arenât going to tell you how.â Itâs like when mama and papa explain to the children that they donât need to worry. But the children are already adults. They are concerned, and it is disastrous if you donât tell them what ideas you have. And I also suspect that the ideas werenât enough, as we now see, and itâs too bad â itâs too bad for us, and it is too bad for the people who came here and looked for protection. I also donât want to hide the fact that I have doubts whether letting everyone stay is a good option. But you have to talk about it, and itâs not enough for one side or the other to proclaim slogans. I think itâs difficult if civil society canât be responsible because they donât know what the people in charge have in mind.

Pegida members say, âYou up there, and we are the people,â which by the way, I think is a difficult appropriation of this slogan from thirty years ago. But it maybe it feels similar for people who yell it. I am not sure what their understanding of democracy is. I havenât been able to get in contact with people who think that way. There are also limits for me. If someone denies the Holocaust or if someone speaks degradingly about other people, then I leave the discussion. I suspect that if the AfD came into power â which a lot of people I know are worried about â there would be something of an intellectual vacuum. I suspect that there is no real sound political idea on how to rule this country. Itâs relatively simple to be in the opposition and to say that you donât want this, and youâd prefer that. But realizing it, according to our democratic principles, is something else.

In 1991, I did not expect that the political situation would develop this way. I also wouldnât have expected it in 2010 â that there would be so much resentment, but we can say with Marshall Rosenberg, who developed Nonviolent Communication, people do everything for a good reason. The question of whether the reason that someone does something makes sense to me is something else. I could make an effort and find out what needs lie behind it. My idea is that in the last thirty years, there has been a lot of rancor among the people who were born here and lived here and worked here, because they have the impression â whether rightly or wrongly â that their much discussed life achievements have actually not been valued enough. I didnât expect that back then.

In addition to these political things, which I have just vented about, I live a very interesting life. I am very grateful that this opportunity was opened to me or that we have used this opportunity. It is a wonderful city. It is a little bit provincial, if you come from another, really big city. But as I age, I find it very pleasant. Dresden has a lot of cultural things to offer. It is a city that is a little slowed down in places. In some places, thatâs annoying and in other places, itâs very soothing. I have never regretted coming here."

"I can remember many years ago that Frank Richter created a situation where people of different political views would meet and have a discussion on a podium. And he was incredibly attacked for it. I am now no fan of Frank Richter, but it is a totally misguided idea of democracy to not listen to the people I donât agree with, and I think itâs a huge gate that all of the people walk through who donât feel listened to.

I donât always get it because I am in a different living situation. And even if I listen closely, I find that the description of the frustration is rather diffuse. It popped up with the wave of refugees, and it got a lot of fuel from that, also because our politicians didnât really explain how we were supposed to do it â when we would do it. And I think itâs difficult if you infantilize people â citizens â and say, âYeah, we can do it, but we arenât going to tell you how.â Itâs like when mama and papa explain to the children that they donât need to worry. But the children are already adults. They are concerned, and it is disastrous if you donât tell them what ideas you have. And I also suspect that the ideas werenât enough, as we now see, and itâs too bad â itâs too bad for us, and it is too bad for the people who came here and looked for protection. I also donât want to hide the fact that I have doubts whether letting everyone stay is a good option. But you have to talk about it, and itâs not enough for one side or the other to proclaim slogans. I think itâs difficult if civil society canât be responsible because they donât know what the people in charge have in mind.

Pegida members say, âYou up there, and we are the people,â which by the way, I think is a difficult appropriation of this slogan from thirty years ago. But it maybe it feels similar for people who yell it. I am not sure what their understanding of democracy is. I havenât been able to get in contact with people who think that way. There are also limits for me. If someone denies the Holocaust or if someone speaks degradingly about other people, then I leave the discussion. I suspect that if the AfD came into power â which a lot of people I know are worried about â there would be something of an intellectual vacuum. I suspect that there is no real sound political idea on how to rule this country. Itâs relatively simple to be in the opposition and to say that you donât want this, and youâd prefer that. But realizing it, according to our democratic principles, is something else.

In 1991, I did not expect that the political situation would develop this way. I also wouldnât have expected it in 2010 â that there would be so much resentment, but we can say with Marshall Rosenberg, who developed Nonviolent Communication, people do everything for a good reason. The question of whether the reason that someone does something makes sense to me is something else. I could make an effort and find out what needs lie behind it. My idea is that in the last thirty years, there has been a lot of rancor among the people who were born here and lived here and worked here, because they have the impression â whether rightly or wrongly â that their much discussed life achievements have actually not been valued enough. I didnât expect that back then.

In addition to these political things, which I have just vented about, I live a very interesting life. I am very grateful that this opportunity was opened to me or that we have used this opportunity. It is a wonderful city. It is a little bit provincial, if you come from another, really big city. But as I age, I find it very pleasant. Dresden has a lot of cultural things to offer. It is a city that is a little slowed down in places. In some places, thatâs annoying and in other places, itâs very soothing. I have never regretted coming here."

"I am a zoologist. I really love animals, thatâs the reason I started the profession. Specifically, I work with reptiles. I saw them for the first time in my country, Peru, when I was ten years old, and I really liked them, how they behaved. I decided to study zoology so that I could learn more about them, why they are how they are, and how to protect them. We have a lot of animal trafficking in Peru, especially of snakes and turtles. People buy turtles on the street illegally.

I am now studying at TU Dresden. I was reading something about biodiversity, and here there are less than twenty species of reptiles. I am now doing my Masterâs thesis on snakes in Peru, and there are two hundred species of just snakes there. I did my Bachelorâs in Brazil. I got a scholarship to study, and I moved there by myself when I was eighteen. Before I finished, I did an internship with a professor in Frankfurt, and he supervised my Bachelorâs thesis on lizards. He told me to apply for a scholarship to do my Masterâs in Germany, but I didnât get it. So, my father and I made a deal and borrowed some money from the bank to do an international Masterâs here at the TU in GÃ¶rlitz and Zittau.

I just had enough money for one year. Now, I have a semester to write my Masterâs thesis, and I donât have money to support myself. I am writing right now. I want to get a mini-job, just to pay my rent, but my big problem is that I donât speak German. I didnât need it for my studies, and I didnât have time to learn because I had classes. Everything was in English.

When I finish my Masterâs, I want to get a PhD somewhere in Germany. I know that these days to work as a scientist, you have to have a PhD. You can earn more money. Most of the jobs in the research industry require a PhD. I want to stay in Germany because they have good resources and equipment. I would still do my research in South America, but I donât want to live there again. I think Germany is a really good country. It is more organized. South America has a lot of security and social problems. Germany is quiet, especially GÃ¶rlitz where I live.

I have been here for a year, and I know that I need just 450 euros a month to live. I have a student ticket, so I could commute to Dresden. If anyone has a suggestion, I would be grateful."

"Ich komme aus Pakistan. Ich habe in meinem Heimatland Probleme mit einer muslimischen Gruppe, obwohl ich selbst auch Muslim bin. Deswegen habe ich Pakistan verlassen. Wenn ich zurÃ¼ck nach Pakistan muss, muss ich sofort wieder fliehen, weil diese Gruppe noch aktiv ist. Ich mÃ¼sste nach Iran, Afghanistan oder China, ich weiÃ es nicht.

Ich habe in meinem Heimatland Krankenpfleger gelernt und in einem Krankenhaus gearbeitet. In meinem Wohnheim habe ich mit der Heimleitung geredet und sie haben mich gefragt, warum ich nicht arbeite. Dann haben die Heimleitung und ich zusammen eine Bewerbung an die AWO geschrieben. Dort habe ich drei Monate Praktikum gemacht und danach angefangen, in einem Seniorenheim in Steinbach zu arbeiten, neun Monate lang. Steinbach ist ein bisschen weit, aber es hat mir dort gefallen. Die Bewohner kennen und mÃ¶gen mich.

Seit acht Monaten darf ich nicht arbeiten, aber ich bin trotzdem jede Woche dorthin gegangen und habe die Leute besucht. Ich weiÃ nicht, warum ich nicht arbeiten darf. Ich habe meinen Reisepass in der AuslÃ¤nderbehÃ¶rde vorgelegt. Dann habe ich einen Brief bekommen, dass ich meine Arbeitserlaubnis abholen soll. Als ich dann dort war, hat jemand gesagt, dass das falsch gedruckt war. Ich habe Widerspruch eingelegt. Als ich den in der AuslÃ¤nderbehÃ¶rde abgegeben habe, sollte ich meinen Ausweis zeigen und drauÃen warten. Als ich wieder rein kam, hat er mir einen Zettel gegeben, dass ich in Dresden bleiben muss und ausreisepflichtig bin. Danach konnte ich die Leute in Steinbach nicht mehr besuchen.

Ich arbeite gern. Alle meine Kollegen und die Leute, die ich pflege, wissen, dass ich meine Arbeit mit Herz mache. Die Situation ist sehr deprimierend. Ich habe nichts zu tun. Mir ist langweilig. Ich sitze zu Hause. Deswegen bin ich immer traurig.

An den Wochenenden mache ich Fahrschule. Ich habe die theoretische PrÃ¼fung schon lange bestanden, und wenn ich Geld habe, nehme ich Fahrstunden. Ich habe meine Freundin mit Hilfe einer Agentur in Mexiko geheiratet. Wir kennen uns schon drei Jahre. Sie kommt aus Brandenburg. Wir haben uns durch Facebook kennengelernt. Die Heiratsurkunde haben wir auch in der AuslÃ¤nderbehÃ¶rde abgegeben; das wird aber auch nicht anerkannt.

Ich will sehr gerne arbeiten und ich weiÃ auch, dass Deutschland FachkrÃ¤fte sucht. Ich muss eine Chance bekommen."
--
"I am from Pakistan. I had problems with Muslim groups in my homeland, even though I am Muslim myself. Thatâs why I left Pakistan. If I have to go back there, I would have to flee again immediately, because this group is still active. I would have to go to Iran, Afghanistan, or China. I donât know.

I studied nursing in Pakistan, and I worked in a hospital. At my hostel, I talked to the people in charge, and they asked me why I donât work. Then we wrote an application to the AWO. There, I did an internship for three months and after that, I started to work in a retirement home in Steinbach, where I was for nine months. Steinbach is a little far, but I liked it there. The residents know and like me.

I havenât been allowed to work for eight months, but I still went every week and visit the people. I donât know what I am not allowed to work. I gave my passport to the foreign residentsâ office. Then I got a letter that I should pick up my work permit. When I was there, someone said that it was wrongly printed. I submitted an objection. When I turned that in at the foreign residentsâ office, I was asked to show my ID and wait outside. When I came in again, he gave me a piece of paper saying I had to remain in Dresden and be deported. After that, I couldnât visit the people in Steinbach anymore. I like to work. All of my colleagues and the people who I took care know that I put my heart in my work. The situation is really depressing. I have nothing to do. I am bored. I sit at home Thatâs why I am always sad.

I married my girlfriend with the help of an agency in Mexico. We have known each other for three years. She is from Brandenburg. We got to know each other through Facebook. We submitted the marriage license in the foreign residentsâ office, but they didnât accept it.
I really want to work, and I know that Germany needs skilled labor. I need to get a chance!"

"Ich komme aus Afghanistan. Ich wohne in Coswig. Ich arbeite seit einem Jahr als Einpacker in einer Druckerei in Radebeul. Zurzeit bin ich wegen meiner Hand arbeitslos. Wir waren auf einem Fest in Riesa und haben mit den Freunden ein bisschen Quatsch gemacht. Dabei habe ich mir die Hand gebrochen. Noch zwei Wochen kann ich nicht arbeiten, dann gehe ich wieder zur Arbeit.

Ich glaube, wenn ich mich so radikal verÃ¤ndern wÃ¼rde, wÃ¤re ich auch kein KÃ¼nstler mehr. Dann wÃ¤re ich wahrscheinlich SchÃ¤fer. Das angenehme am SchÃ¤fer sein ist die Verbundenheit zur Natur, zu Lebewesen, die Ruhe, wenig neue, schnelle Technik. Als Mediengestalter hat man immer wieder Neuerungen - neue Software, neue Anforderungen, die Kunden entdecken neue Sachen, wollen immer das Neueste haben. "I am a graphic designer, musician, and I like to photograph. I have lived in Neustadt for about four years, and I would like to live here for another sixty years -- at least. I have often thought about going away, but in the sense of going to Iceland, for instance. A herd of sheep, totally in nature, no stress -- ok, stress, but different.

I think that if I would change myself so radically, I wouldn't be an artist anymore. Then I would probably be a shepherd. The pleasant thing about being a shepherd is being connected to nature, to living beings, the quiet -- less new, fast technology. Ich glaube, den Leuten muss klar sein, dass man bei einer Ehe in einem anderen Land nicht die gleichen MÃ¶glichkeiten der UnterstÃ¼tzung hat, man weiÃ nicht, wie das System funktioniert. Es hat den Anschein, als wÃ¼rde alles gegen einen arbeiten, wenn man ein Problem hat, und es gibt niemanden, an den man sich wenden kann, weil die Familie deines Ex-Partners auf seiner Seite ist.

Als ich meine Scheidung hatte, hatte ich nicht viele Freunde. Ich war im Grunde genommen ein Jahr lang allein. Meine Scheidung hat fÃ¼nf Jahre gedauert.
