"I was born in Columbus, Ohio, and I moved to Atlanta, Georgia when I was 14. I went to university in England; I would go on to study at three different universities after that. I wanted to go to England because I was always very perplexed by the social structures in America. I always felt out of place there. In a way, it got worse when I moved to Atlanta, but it opened my eyes even more to what was going on. I feel like racism in Ohio is more hidden; itâs more structural. Because the black population is bigger in Georgia, there is more confrontation between whites and blacks, but that actually makes things kind of work because people talk; they get into dialogue, and they sort it out.

I went back to the US, and I met this guy who was German, and I moved here because of him. He was from western Germany, and he ended up working in Dresden. I definitely would not recommend moving internationally for a relationship. When it doesnât last, the consequences are more severe.

I had to stay in Germany, because my kids grew up here. This was their foundation, this was their base, this was everything they knew. I felt it would be best for them to stay in this environment. It was also really difficult to move abroad when you are going through a divorce. Getting a divorce in Germany is very different than in the US. Itâs very technical, unfortunately, because it means your whole situation doesnât get factored in. I think what is important for people to know is that when you get married in a foreign country, you donât have the same support system you would have had in your own country, you donât know how the system functions. It seems like everything is working against you if there is a problem, and there is no one for you to turn to, because your ex-partnerâs family is on their side.

When I went through my divorce, I didnât have many friends. I was basically alone for a year. My divorce took five years, and at the end of that, I just wanted to have something for myself, so I opened my burrito place. I opened it because I was really disappointed by other burrito places in Dresden. I was amazed that they put things like cucumbers and mushrooms and zucchini and dill sauce in their burritos. I had done short apprenticeship in a really good restaurant in Ohio when I was younger, so I had always had a love of cooking.

I am happy with the shop. I am happy about the people that I meet, with sides of peopleâs personalities that I get to know. I like my customers, I like the interaction with them. I love Dresden. I think itâs possibly one of the most beautiful places to live in the world. I love riding my bicycle along the Elbe. I think people in Dresden are misunderstood sometimes, and I wish they would be a little bit more open to new things and new people."

Man kann eben keinen zwingen, herzukommen. Aber bei den Anlaufstellen, die ich habe, haben BÃ¼cher noch eine wichtige Rolle, und das freut mich ."

And because I had always been a tourist in Dresden since the reunification and thought Dresden was great, I did it. I moved here from the Ruhrgebiet. I have never been sorry, although my friends, family, colleagues all said, âYou canât do it!â But always when I visit the Ruhrgebiet, and I am on my way back, I think âSo, now I am going home.â Itâs become my home.

Not long after I moved here, I learned that the project âLesestark!â was looking for reading mentors. So, I got in touch. Since then, I go to a kindergarten once a month and read to the children. Itâs a lot of fun. The children are always happy when I come. I read to them, and I always have some crafts with me. Sometimes, we are also in the library. The children can go look through the shelves, and I read aloud. They have a lot of time to look around, and you can have a book box delivered. What happens here is great.

There are some young people who are reading mentors, but itâs mostly older people, because we have the time. And there arenât too many men â itâs often women. The organization âLesestark!â does a lot. Last week was another training session. New publications are introduced, then there is a Christmas party, and we were invited to âThe Christmas Goose Augusteâ in the Kulturpalast. Itâs nice to meet the other mentors at these events. You can talk to each other; you have a lot to tell.

I used to be a grade school teacher. I always read to my students . We always had a circle on Monday mornings. I thought it was really important to read to children, also my own children, and now my grandchildren. I notice that children are interested. There was a time when everyone was saying that books have run their course, no one reads any more, they all have a tablet or watch TV. I donât meet people from all classes, but the people with whom I have contact read; the children are interested in books. I think that you wonât reach some people, but you have to recognize that, because they donât come to events like these, because they donât bring their children to the library, but just stick them in front of the TV. You canât force anyone to come here. But in the places I go, books still play an important role, and that makes me happy."

"1985 habe ich hier in der Bibliothek meinen Dienst begonnen. Ich habe zwei Jahre lang meine Ausbildung zum Assistenten absolviert und dann habe ich Diplombibliothekar studiert - alles hier in der Neustadt. Ich bin heute noch dankbar dafÃ¼r, dass ich vor meinem Studium erstmal die Praxis kennenlernen konnte.

Die Neustadt hat sich wahnsinnig verÃ¤ndert in dieser Zeit, und das ist etwas sehr SchÃ¶nes. Das Publikum ist noch bunter geworden. Die Neustadt ist ja Ã¤uÃerlich restauriert worden, aber die Menschen, die sind so schÃ¶n multikulturell und vielfÃ¤ltig. Deshalb habe ich mir immer gesagt, ich bleibe hier an dem Standort, weil es hier am buntesten ist. NatÃ¼rlich ist auch Vieles anders geworden, so dass manchmal der Charme von der Neustadt auch ein StÃ¼ck verloren gegangen ist, aber ich habe das GefÃ¼hl, durch die ganzen Familien, die wir jetzt hier haben, durch den groÃen multikulturellen Hintergrund wird das alles wieder belebt.

Die Wende war fÃ¼r mich keine groÃe Umstellung. Ich hatte schon Weltliteratur studiert. Ich war dankbar und froh, dass sich das alles so Ã¶ffnet. Ich bin ein Mensch der sagt: Immer nach vorne. Das da hinten kann man nicht mehr Ã¤ndern, das Heute muss man leben und immer nach vorne in die Zukunft gucken. Das ist das, was ich auch immer hier probiere - dass wir Neues ausprobieren. Es wird nie langweilig, weil jeder Tag anders ist. Wir haben so eine Vielfalt an VeranstaltungstÃ¤tigkeit, wir haben so eine Vielfalt an Leuten die zu uns kommen - das sind Studenten, das sind Doktoren, das sind Professoren, das sind RechtsanwÃ¤lte, die hier teilweise arbeiten, das sind Leute die kein Internet zu Hause haben. Vor allem haben wir viele Familien mit Kindern, aber auch viele Ã¤ltere Leute, die gerne noch beraten werden wollen. Diese Vielfalt macht es gerade aus. Wir mÃ¼ssten noch anbauen - ich wÃ¼rde gerne noch DachbegrÃ¼nung haben, mit den Kindern ein grÃ¼nes Dach errichten, einen Musikraum, ein CafÃ©, oder noch eine Tischtennisplatte - so etwas wie ein Medienhaus, ein groÃes Literaturhaus, das kÃ¶nnte ich mir vorstellen."

" I started working here in the library in 1985. I trained for two years to become an assistant and then I studied to become a qualified librarian â all in the Neustadt. I am thankful today that I was able to get to know the practical side before I went to university.

The Neustadt has changed an amazing amount in this time, and it is really nice. The public has gotten more colorful. The Neustadt has been extremely renovated, but the people are so multi-cultural and diverse. Thatâs why I always said, âI want to stay at this location, because itâs the most colorful.â Of course, a lot of other things are different so that sometimes the charm of the Neustadt is lost a bit, but I have the feeling, with all of these families that we now have here, through all the multicultural background, everything is enlivened again.

The reunification was not a big adjustment for me. I had already studied world literature. I was thankful and happy that everything opened up. I am a person who says: âAlways go forward.â You canât change what is behind you. You have to live in the present and always look forward into the future. That is what I always try to do here â that we are always trying out something new. It is never boring, because every day is different. We have such a diversity of events, we have such a diversity of people who come to us â they are students, doctors, professors, lawyers, who work here in part, they are people who donât have internet at home. Mostly, we have families with children, but also a lot of older people who like to be advised. This diversity defines us. We have to continue to expand â I would like to have a plants on the roof, to create it with children, a music room, a cafÃ©, or a pingpong table â I can imagine something like a media house, a big literature house."

media.description:
"Ich bin seit zwÃ¶lf Jahren Nutzer der Bibliothek, auch schon am alten Standort und jetzt seit fÃ¼nf Jahren hier. Ich komme regelmÃ¤Ãig her. Ich bin immer wieder beeindruckt Ã¼ber die Vielfalt der AusleihmÃ¶glichkeiten und Ã¼ber die Freundlichkeit und ProfessionalitÃ¤t des Personals. Ich komme selten zu Veranstaltungen, aber wenn, dann gefallen sie mir.

Mein JÃ¼ngster ist jetzt sechzehn. Er liest nicht mehr so viel wie noch vor vier Jahren, aber ich glaube das liegt an der PubertÃ¤t. Ich war mit meinen Kindern oft in der Bibliothek. Die Bibliothek Neustadt hat ja auch eine Kindergartenbetreuung. Dadurch kennen die die Bibliothek schon.

Meine Mutter war selbst Bibliothekarin. Dadurch bin ich zeitig selbst rangefÃ¼hrt worden und dadurch habe ich das Interesse gehabt und habe viel gelesen. Zwischen fÃ¼nfzehn und siebzehn weniger, aber dann ging es wieder los. Wenn ich bei meiner Mutter mal auf Arbeit sein musste - oder durfte -, war das spannend, zwischen den Regalen und dann der Ausleihe - die hatten so eine Systematik an der Ausleihe, die man als Kind nicht verstanden hat. Und dann waren die immer so begeistert und ernst zugleich; das hat mich immer fasziniert.

Ich bin Lehrer, ich arbeite in der Schulleitung fÃ¼r eine Berufsschule in Gorbitz. Wir bilden Erzieher aus. Eines der Lernfelder ist Lust an der Sprache zu vermitteln, wie man das erzeugt durch eigenes Vorbild und Anregungen. Ich glaube, man braucht dafÃ¼r ein gewisses Talent. Der eine kann sehr gut gestalten, der andere kann ganz doll singen, aber dafÃ¼r nicht basteln, und der nÃ¤chste kann mit Sprache ganz viel zum Ausdruck bringen und theatral, also Ã¼ber nonverbale bis zu paraverbaler Gestaltung. Aber man kann die Leselust oder die Lust an der Sprache ein bisschen erwecken. Man kann sie nicht fordern, aber man kann sie auch bei den Leuten, die sich nicht trauen, durchaus erwecken. Die GrÃ¶Ãe, zu der man sie erweckt, ist dann wiederum eine Frage von Anlage und Talent.

Meine SchÃ¼ler sind zwischen zwanzig und sechzig. Es gibt heutzutage eine Tendenz zur berufsbegleitenden Ausbildung, wo man in einer Kindertageseinrichtung arbeitet und nebenbei die Ausbildung macht. Das wird sehr gefÃ¶rdert. Das heiÃt, viele Leute, die vorher schon andere Berufe hatten, fangen an, darÃ¼ber nachzudenken, mehr mit Menschen, mehr mit Kindern, sinnhafter zu arbeiten. Ich empfinde das als Bereicherung, dass das geht und dass Menschen mit Bibliothek und mit BÃ¼chern und mit Sprachlust in BerÃ¼hrung kommen und vielleicht Talente entdecken die sie zehn, zwanzig, dreiÃig Jahre gar nicht kannten."
--
"I have been a user of the library for twelve years, also at the old location and now here for the past five years. I come here regularly. I am always impressed by the range of things you can check out and the friendliness and professionalism of the personnel. I come to events too rarely, but when I do, I like them.

My youngest is now sixteen. He doesnât read as much as he did four years ago, but I think thatâs puberty. I brought my children to library often. The Neustadt library also hosts kindergartens. They knew the library through that already.

My mother was a librarian. I was introduced early, and I became interested and read a lot. Between fifteen and seventeen, I read less, but then I started again. When I had to go to work with my mother â or when I was allowed to â it was exciting, between the shelves and the checkout â they had a system for checking that you didnât understand as a child. And then the librarians were always so excited and serious at the same time. That always fascinated me. 

I am a teacher. I work in the school administration at a professional school in Gorbitz. We train kindergarten and preschool educators. One of the fields is conveying the love of language, how you create that through your own example and encouragement. I think that you need a certain talent for it. One person can design well, another can sing well, but isnât able to do crafts, and the next can express a lot with language and be theatrical, from nonverbal to paraverbal presentation. But you can awake the desire to read or the love of language a little. You canât require them to, but you can awaken it in the people who arenât confident. The extent to which you can awaken them is again a question of gifts and disposition.

My students are between twenty and sixty. There is a tendency to do training alongside of a job these days, where you work in a childcare facility and also do training. Thatâs very much supported. That means that a lot of people who previously had another profession start thinking about doing more with people, more with children, working in a more meaningful way. I think it is an enrichment that it is possible and that people come into contact with the library and books and with the love of language and maybe awaken a talent that they didnât know they had for ten, twenty, or thirty years."

"I was born in West Berlin in 1980. In 2011, I moved to Dresden. I want to make a new start here.
It started really extremely when I was five years old â typical abuse by a neighbor â until I was seven years old. My family said that they didnât know about the abuse â they even said it to the police â but I told them. I went to the police when I was sixteen. But no one cared. Itâs often the case.

In school, there was bullying and hitting, from teachers and the directors as well. The bullying wasnât that bad for me; it was more what I didnât get. I was actually supposed to be in a class for gifted students, but my family was against it. They said, âYou are not better than us.â My mother always stood by me, but with things like that she always said that she didnât want to fight with my older siblings and didnât want her children to disagree with each other. So the older ones always decided, âNo, heâs not going to school. No, heâs not going to university, heâs not getting a signature. We donât want him to get professional training.â I always did my own thing. I said, âI am not relying on you. I can educate myself; there are books, there is the internet.â

My voice changed at nine, and at twelve, it was 
still too high. The doctors said that it would come with age. But it wasnât fast enough for my father. He wanted it to be treated, but he didnât find anyone, and then we had it done privately. And it was a total mess â resuscitation and stuff. Then I had big medical problems. When I was sixteen, I had mononucleosis. The doctor said, âWe are having such problems, we wonât be able to pull you through. We have to treat it now. You are in the middle of a big growth spurt. We have to end your growth. The problem is that we donât have enough time. We arenât going to be able to wait for your voice.â He asked if that was ok for me. I said that I was happy with my voice. I like to sing soprano. Then we did it. He got into real trouble, and they stopped the treatment because they saw that my brain wasnât growing any more, the neurological connections. I have a kind of epilepsy common in teenagers â I am 39, and I still have it. I can deal with it. You learn to live with it. I can do everything, without medication, but it is just unusual because I am not grown up. I mature and get old, but there are a couple things that just stopped biologically. You donât see it, but I notice up here. I noticed that all of my classmates made real advances until they were eighteen. I also noticed that I experience it a bit differently. Itâs hard to describe.

Now, I have worked my way up. I found a nice piece of land in Ottendorf-Okrilla, which I am leasing. I am building a tiny house there. I raise plants; I am very good at it. And then there is my music; I sing soprano. The problems of other people might sound small, but in principle, itâs always the same things â that you canât adjust to society, that you want to do something but you donât have the space, that you have too few friends, or you donât find a partner.

I found flyers from the menâs network in the church around the corner from me. I just came here. It was nice. I quickly found a connection and could talk about my problems. They said, âYes, now you are starting anew.â I also worked for two months, which was really an adventure, because I have slight autistic characteristics. These are everyday joys, where I always say that it may be difficult, but it is a kind of joy not to be excluded and to be able to take part in everything. A lot of connections are also made for me. Itâs always who you know â that someone says, we can do this and that. And if you have an idea, and it doesnât work well, it is good that someone tells you to keep at it. You need that. I didnât have that before. I have also seen that other people were told they should keep going and thatâs how they made advance â because they were told âItâs not up for debate. You are not giving up.â That is what you need. Here, people donât judge and grade, rather they ask what you need, and you think about it together."

Es waren dort immer mal wieder Jugendliche da, die fÃ¼r ein paar Monate in der Familie gelebt und mitgearbeitet haben. Mein Bruder war zu der Zeit schon SozialpÃ¤dagoge, von daher wusste ich, dass es das gibt. Aber dort habe ich gemerkt, dass ich gerne mit Menschen arbeite.

In meinem Studium habe ich gemerkt, eigentlich will ich Ã¼berhaupt nichts mehr mit Menschen zu tun haben â nein, das stimmt natÃ¼rlich nicht, aber ich habe sehr viel AStA, Hochschulkonferenz und sowas gemacht, hochschulpolitische Arbeit. Ich habe gemerkt, dass ich in dem Bereich Bildungsarbeit, politische Arbeit tÃ¤tig sein will. Dann war es auch ein bisschen Zufall, dass ich hier im MÃ¤nnernetzwerk gelandet bin.

Ich hatte schon in meinem Bachelor ein bisschen den Schwerpunkt auf SexualpÃ¤dagogik und sexuelle Bildung gelegt und zum Beispiel auch ein lÃ¤ngeres Praktikum bei der Aidshilfe gemacht. Ich habe gemerkt, dass das mein Ding ist. Das passte hier total gut rein. Bei Jugendarbeit ist SexualitÃ¤t sowieso oft Thema. Ich habe das auch ein bisschen mehr professionalisiert und eine Weiterbildung zum Sexualtherapeuten gemacht. Das ist jetzt mein Schwerpunkt. Ich finde, es ist eine sehr politische TÃ¤tigkeit, zum Thema SexualitÃ¤t und Vielfalt zu arbeiten.

Allgemein finde ich, ist SexualitÃ¤t ein Thema von uns Menschen, das uns stark ausmacht, das aber durch die Tabuisierung, die Ã¼ber Jahrhunderte gewachsen ist, nicht besprochen wird. Einerseits ist es omniprÃ¤sent in unserer Gesellschaft, auch in GesprÃ¤chen, aber nicht wirklich tiefgrÃ¼ndig und nicht wirklich mit einem Blick auch nach innen - was hat das mit mir zu tun, wie will ich SexualitÃ¤t leben, wie sexuell bin ich? Das alles einerseits auf das Thema SexualitÃ¤t bezogen, andererseits aber auch auf das Thema Geschlecht und GeschlechtsidentitÃ¤t. HauptsÃ¤chlich geht es darum, sichere RÃ¤ume zu schaffen, um einen Austauschraum dafÃ¼r zu finden. Das Ziel ist die FÃ¶rderung von sexueller Selbstbestimmung, wie auch immer das dann aussieht.
 In SexualitÃ¤t zeigen sich oft Themen, die eigentlich gar nicht sexuell sind, die irgendetwas im nichtsexuellen Bereich verhandeln, wo eigene Themen angesprochen werden, Kindheitsthemen, eigene Beziehungsthemen, NÃ¤he, Distanz, so etwas. Ich glaube, dass sexuelle Gesundheit auch viel mit inneren psychischen Prozessen zu tun hat. Deshalb glaube ich, dass viel mehr Leute das thematisieren und sich angucken mÃ¼ssten. "I decided to study social pedagogy while I was in France for a year volunteering after I finished high school. I was there on a sort of farm, where every once in a while, there were young people, who lived with the family and worked on the farm. My brother was already a social worker then, so I knew that that was an option, but in France, I noticed that I like to work with people.

During my studies, I noticed that actually, I didnât want anything to do with people â no, thatâs not true of course, but I did a lot with the general students committee and the student council, and stuff like that, university political work. I realized that I wanted to be active in the area of educational work or political work. Then it was a little bit of a coincidence that I landed here in the menâs network.

During my Bachelorâs, I had already had a focus on sexual pedagogy and sexual education; for example, I did a long internship at an AIDS help organization. I realized that that was my thing. It fits here really well. When you are working with young people, sexuality is often a subject. I made it a bit more professional and did a continuing education course on sexual therapy. That is now my focus. I think that work with the subject of sexuality and diversity is a very political activity.

In general, I think that sexuality is a subject that really determines us people, but because of taboos, which have grown up over hundreds of years, it isnât discussed. On one side, it is omnipresent in our society, even in conversations, but it is not really considered deeply and with a view inward â what does it have to do with me? How do I want to live my sexuality? How sexual am I? On the one hand, this has to do with the subject of sexuality, but on the other side, it is also the subject of sex and gender identity. Mainly, itâs about creating safe spaces in order to be able to talk about it. The goal is to support sexual determination, however that looks.

In sexuality, subjects come up that are actually not sexual, that have to do with something in the non-sexual area, where personal subjects can be addressed â childhood themes, relationship themes. Closeness, distance, etc. I think that sexual health has a lot to do with inner psychic processes. Thatâs why I think that many more people have to thematize them and look at them. But working against that are the taboos, and especially with men, a lot of insecurity â how sexual am I allowed to be? On one side, there is this label of the âever-potent,â and on the other side, there is the question, âAm I allowed to admit this at all? Is this ok?â There are many questions that are never talked about. I always say, âOf course, be attentive to other people, but most importantly, be attentive to yourself. Learn your boundaries.â I think that if you are aware of yourself, you can also be aware of those around you."

Die Leute fragen mich immer, wo ich herkomme. Ich komme aus dem Rheinland, aus Bonn, aus Deutschland. Und dann fragen sie noch mal, wo ich eigentlich herkomme. Und dann fragen sie nach den Eltern, den GroÃeltern, den UrgroÃeltern und ich sage, deutsch, deutsch, deutsch. Das akzeptieren sie nicht. "I studied political science for three years. Now, I live in Berlin and do stuff for movies and TV. I came here to study, back then. I wanted to be very far away from home, just somewhere else. I didn't know much about Dresden. My parents were really concerned. My father is from Cameroon and he said that black people could have problems here. I said that I didn't want where I study to be limited. And in retrospect, I had a lot of positive experiences, especially in the Neustadt and at the university. I met so many cool people, but unfortunately, there were also negative incidents. I was never physical attacked but verbally. Once, a man in the tram used the N-word and then someone was standing at the tram stop directly next to me with a white supremacy t-shirt ... a hardcore Nazi, right next to me, a queasy feeling. I came back for BRN of course. It's a special place, a microcosm with cool, alternative people. I felt comfortable here.

People always ask me where I come from. I come from the Rhineland, from Bonn, from Germany. And then they ask me again where I actually come from. And then they ask about my parents, grandparents, and great-grandparents, and I say German, German, German. They don't accept it. I think it's sad that hasn't arrived here. Germans today have all possible skin colors, eye colors, and speak with different accents. German doesn't always mean being white. These are old categories and habits that people have to put aside. It's just not in keeping with the times."

"I am from Lecce in Puglia â if Italy is a boot, Puglia is the heel. For me, it was really hard to move to Germany. I moved to Dresden completely alone. I knew no one, and it was the most frightening and exciting thing I have ever done. I have traveled a lot â before coming here, I spent two months in New York studying marketing, public relations, and human resources at Columbia University. I was thinking about doing my Masterâs there, but since I am Italian, I could not live so far from my family. I am the only child. I donât know why my parents didnât have more kids â maybe I was such an effort for my parents, they couldnât have more. I was enough for them. But seriously, everything good that I have done in my life is because of my mom and dad. I am not just talking about economic support, but that was also very necessary, because everything costs money in Italy. Education is not for free.

I chose to come to Germany, because it has the best universities in Europe. And itâs not like I was crazy about France. But it was so hard to move here. I know that we are all Europeans, and itâs much harder for people moving here from the East, but I experienced cultural shock. Germans are so different from Italians. Now, I think itâs a nice exchange. Among my friends, I am the only one who defends German. I am like the lawyer arguing for the German language.

There are two or three words that I really love. One is Fernweh (longing for far-off places). Fernweh isnât the same thing as Wanderlust, meaning the desire to travel. For me, whatever is far from what I have already experienced is appealing. Itâs not a matter of kilometers, itâs mentality. Wir haben in unserem Wohnhaus auch zwei FlÃ¼chtlinge aus Syrien. Die leben schon ein Jahr dort. Die trennen ihren MÃ¼ll, sagen Guten Tag und Auf Wiedersehen â wunderbar, keine Schwierigkeiten.

"I worked in the production of sanitary porcelain until 1990. In 1990, I became unemployed, and then I had work every once in a while. In the last ten years, I worked as a building manager until I retired at age 63. That work was fun, but there was too little money. Back then, there wasn't a minimum wage, so I was working for 4.50 euro an hour, after taxes. There is poverty in Germany; you can believe me. I have a soup kitchen on my street, where I go eat every day. There, you can see how many poor people there are. I don't have a big pension -- it's a starvation pension, and I worked for 43 years. I get along, but you have to count every cent. It's sad in this country.

Nevertheless, I am not joining those idiots, Pegida. I don't like their opinions at all; the refugees aren't taking anything from us. They are fleeing from war. Sure, there are criminals who take the chance, but you can't generalize about all of them. No foreigner has taken anything from me. It's the government that pays too little social security. We have two refugees from Syria in our apartment building. They have lived there for a year. They separate their trash, say hello and good bye -- wonderful, no difficulties.

I would like this horror show to end. I don't understand how the people still believe this rabble-rousing. Ms. Merkel has permitted poverty in Germany. But stirring people up against foreigners, who already don't have much, who have war, that's not ok. Otherwise, I am happy in Dresden. I love Dresden. Dresden is actually colorful. The world has to be colorful. Germany can't just belong to the Germans, but to all people."

"I worked in the production of sanitary porcelain until 1990. In 1990, I became unemployed, and then I had work every once in a while. In the last ten years, I worked as a building manager until I retired at age 63. That work was fun, but there was too little money. Back then, there wasn't a minimum wage, so I was working for 4.50 euro an hour, after taxes. There is poverty in Germany; you can believe me. I have a soup kitchen on my street, where I go eat every day. There, you can see how many poor people there are. I don't have a big pension -- it's a starvation pension, and I worked for 43 years. I get along, but you have to count every cent. It's sad in this country.

" I have had some difficulties since I arrived in Dresden, but I have also had very positive experiences. I volunteer for the Iberoamerican association, and I work at TU Dresden. I have lived in Dresden for about eight years. I am trying to âintegrate,â as the Germans say, and be part of the cityâs transformation. I can bring a little bit from my culture to my job as a teacher at the university. I like that job very much.

Unfortunately, we havenât gotten a permanent contract in all these years. Every semester, we are afraid of what will happen because we have no job security without a contract. I cannot even apply for the citizenship test because of the job thing. An unlimited working contract is required. Saxony has such an absurd bureaucracy. They donât give a chance to people who are motivated and willing to work for this country. If you tell me that I only have three months here and no clue about what could happen to me, you put me in a very complicated situation. One can not even start thinking of personal objectives. There are a lot of people in Dresden in the same situation as me. In my case, after living 10 years in Germany, it is very difficult for me to imagine going back to Colombia and starting over again. I have my family here, my friends, my job, my partner, and a lot of positive things like you guys who work for a better place for us all.

When I said that I want to be part of the cityâs transformation, I meant that I want to help achieve acceptance of us foreigners, who we are, and how we are -- how we speak, feel, and laugh. Hopefully one day, I wonât have to be afraid to go around speaking Spanish. Also, I want people to recognize that we come with skills and expertise. Sometimes, I feel like people out there look at us like weird bugs. If I go out there with my hair like this, speaking Spanish, I become that weird bug. I want to be seen as I am.

In the beginning it didnât affect me but year after year, it really gets to you. Itâs gotten worse in the last three years, and I think itâs because of political influences. The AFD and others that are pro-German and anti-foreigner. The arrival of all the refugees has increased the debate, and people feel like their points of view are legitimized by those parties and Pegida.

I identify with the refugees. I cannot isolate myself and think that I am some kind of special foreigner. I see all foreigners as equal. We are all fighting to have a space in this society. Some came because of war, some came because of starvation, because living conditions are better here. I think any reason is legitimate. I donât understand why thereâs such hatred. If I stay here, I will continue fighting against those fascists. I will do it legally, organizing cultural, political discussions, going to more demonstrations, and going to schools and talking about multiculturality. Young people are the hope; they are the ones that can rescue the principles of solidarity.

I want to call on all Dresdeners, born here or not, to build a racism-free society together. We should accept each other as we are. In many parts of German society, integration is understood as assimilation. You have to give away a little bit of who you are to almost convert into a German. If Germans were go to Colombia, nobody would ask them to change and behave like Colombians. Thereâs a fusion of cultures that makes society even more interesting and pushes the stereotypes aside. Letâs make a fusion, take the positive qualities from everyone, and approach others as they are, as people. I donât want to change to be accepted; I wish that we were all accepted for who we are."

"My tip for young people would be to move a lot, don't sit so much in front of the computer and eat healthier -- lots of fruits and vegetables. And you always have to look for a task. I am 83 years old, and I still tasks, which I have chosen for myself. I always have something to do. I have four children, eight grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. Until last year, I had doing phenological observations for the German Weather Service for 24 years. Now it's all digital, but I still drew on millimeter paper.

In January 2014, I started to take care of refugee children. I teach them a little German. I am their German grandma. I play and learn with them or tell them something. I do this just by myself, not with an association or something. If I want to do something, then I don't have to present myself -- I just go and do it. Before the refugees came, I prepared migrant children for school. I just showed up, and today, I am friends with one of the mothers. She couldn't understand back then that someone would come and say that they had thought of something. I am really satisfied with my life."

I was born in 1937. I started school when Hitler was still in power. In the GDR, under Ulbricht, I was imprisioned by state security. Then, under Honecker, I put together a peace group, worked as a minister, and I built up a community center in a high-rise housing estate. Not every minister, who got the privilege of starting a totally new church, could do it. Back then, it was still called Karl-Marx-Stadt, now itâs Chemnitz. I have gotten around Saxony a little. I was in Dresden for school, then I was in Leipzig, then Karl- Marx-Stadt, and at the end, in Dresden as a minister. I have been retired for twenty years.

We in the peace group were insolent, especially with the elections. For the last GDR elections, we did a recount and established that it was falsified, of course. But itâs not just that ten percent didnât vote and ten percent voted no, rather that eighty percent went along and voted for Honecker, as if he was their favorite guy. Later, they all wanted the opposite and then they voted for Helmut Kohl and wanted to get their bananas, their West German currency. Before they were Communist red, then they were all CDU black, but before all that, everything was fascist brown. That is actually the tragic thing â that people donât get smarter. Like Erich KÃ¤stner wrote, âPeople donât get smarter, specially not Christians. Despite all the folding of hands. They would prefer for everything to be in vain and for everything to stay the same.â

We didnât want everything to stay the same and thatâs why we interfered as long as we could. I was also the co-founder of the New Forum. I was the first signer on the New Forum. That was a wild time back then in September/October/November of 1989. You were happy if you could take a deep breath because you were constantly being asked to do something. It was a giant movement throughout the whole GDR, not that we wanted to leave, rather the opposite. We wanted to stay here, so that it would change. It didnât happen like we thought. It was a fantastical situation for us, like sitting at a lake and dreaming of how I would want the GDR to be so that I could stay there. And already by Christmas, it was clear that this wish list wasnât going to be fulfilled, when on December 19th, Helmut Kohl spoke here at the Frauenkirche about blooming landscapes, and people felt frenetically attracted to him, like he was the redeemer, and reached out to him as if he was the saviour of the world. Then, in 1990, a lot changed, and the West swallowed the East. On the other hand, no one wants to go back. Itâs a difficult situation. We grew up in a time that was very difficult, including for Christians, with all the oppression, but also with the courage â you tried to endure, express your opinion, and stand upright for it.

I am absolutely against the Christian Democratic Union (CDU). I think the CSU is even worse. Our bishop once said that the âCâ must stand for conservative, then it would be true. I am happy that there are also Christians in other parties, since I am much closer to the Greens, already starting in the past, with the New Forum and the peace work. That was our most important concern in the GDR period and again today. Itâs tragic that so little has changed â that young people still become soldiers and that we have ministers who just naturally went into the peopleâs army, even though they could have been ancillary soldiers and refused to serve with weapons. I said that to them, and then they got huffy, instead of saying, âyes, maybe we could have.â It's more than eighty percent, who didnât want to have any disadvantages; instead they went along everywhere, so that they got everything. Not a lot has changed. If the beer is cold enough and the slippers are warm enough, the TV program lame enough, most people are content."

"Pegida ist eine Katastrophe. Gerade dann, wenn wir unser Friedensgebet in der Kreuzkirche zu Ende haben, kommen meistens die Pegidaleute vorbei. WÃ¤ren die damals in der Kneipe, wo sie sich bei einem Bier Pegida ausgedacht haben, geblieben, hÃ¤tten sie von mir aus noch ein Bier trinken kÃ¶nnen. Aber diese Bewegung unter die Leute zu bringen â es ist enttÃ¤uschend, dass die mitmachen. Ich habe in den drei Jahren mit vielen versucht zu reden: Pegida-Ordner, die jedes mal dabei gewesen sind, auch christliche Gemeindemitglieder, die da mitmarschieren, offensichtlich auch intelligente Leute, wo ich denke, das kann ich mir gar nicht vorstellen. Mein letzter Eindruck ist, das mehr so Ã¤ltere MÃ¤nner dabei sind. Das sind so diese typischen DDR-BÃ¼rger, die immer mitgemacht haben und die dann 1990 von Helmut Kohl nicht das bekommen haben, wie sie es sich gewÃ¼nscht haben, die gebratenen Tauben schon vorgekaut in den Mund gesteckt.

Der Chef, der Pegida erfunden hat mit seinen Bierkumpeln, der ist so alt wie mein Sohn, der war 1989 sechzehn Jahre alt. Mein Sohn war mit in den Oppositionsgruppen, aber den Bachmann kenne ich von damals nicht. Die Leute, die damals aktiv waren, die kennen sich alle untereinander. Ich will nicht Ã¼ber die einzelnen Leute urteilen, die dabei sind. Es ist nicht so, dass die damals 1989 krÃ¤ftig Opposition gemacht haben und nun heute enttÃ¤uscht sind, sondern das sind Meckerfritzen und Leute, die zum Teil auch keine Lust haben zum arbeiten oder schon in Rente sind. Am Anfang konnte man mit keinem reden. Jetzt kann man einzelne fragen, da bekommt man bloÃ Phrasen gedroschen und ich habe noch kein GesprÃ¤ch gefÃ¼hrt, wo ich gesagt habe, wir haben uns an irgendeiner Stelle getroffen oder auf eine Grundmeinung geeinigt. Nur blÃ¶de Parolen, Schlagworte, mit denen sie um sich hauen, ohne dass sie darÃ¼ber nachdenken.

Die marschieren jetzt bei Pegida und brÃ¼llen âLÃ¼genpresseâ und âWir sind das Volkâ. Die haben uns diesen Spruch geklaut. Ich habe mal einen gefragt, der âLÃ¼genpresseâ gebrÃ¼llt hat: âWas lesen Sie fÃ¼r eine Zeitung?â âGar keine.â Aber er brÃ¼llt LÃ¼genpresse. Es ist zum Teil so eine Art Familientreffen, wenn die ihre Demo vorbereiten, da stehen die ersten schon da und spielen Schifferklavier, verteilen LiederblÃ¤tter, singen irgendwelche deutsche Volkslieder, dann kommen die ersten mit ihren Fahnen und begrÃ¼Ãen sich untereinander, kennen sich alle schon untereinander. Es sind zum GlÃ¼ck nicht alles Dresdner, die kommen von sonstwo her. Aber es ist jeder peinlich, der da kommt. Der Eindruck von Dresden wird versaut

Die Schwierigkeit ist, dass man nicht genau an die Pegidaleute ran kommt. Es gibt alle mÃ¶glichen schlauen Pegidaversteher, die BÃ¼cher darÃ¼ber schreiben und alles genau wissen. Man kann nicht 200 oder 2.000 befragen und daraus ein ResÃ¼mee ziehen. Manche kommen jeden Montag, sind immer dieselben, geben sich zum Teil groÃe MÃ¼he, bauen Plakate, lassen ihre Kinder was aufkleben. Dann kommt einer jeden Montag mit dem Foto von der Frauenkirche. Da steht drauf: âDas wird mal keine Moscheeâ, der marschiert damit an der Kreuzkirche vorbei. Ich habe mal zu welchen gesagt, wann waren sie das letzte mal in der Kirche. Wenn sie so gegen die Islamisierung des Abendlandes sind, mÃ¼ssten sie doch dafÃ¼r sein, dass das christlich bleibt oder christlich geprÃ¤gt. Das hat damit nichts zu tun, sage einer. Sicher geht er nicht in die Kirche. Wenn die so gegen die Islamisierung wÃ¤ren, mÃ¼ssten sich jeden Sonntag die Kirchen so fÃ¼llen, das keiner mehr einen Platz findet. Das tun sie ja auch nicht. Und ich halte den Islam fÃ¼r keine Bedrohung fÃ¼r Deutschland, es ist eine Minderheit. Sie haben ihr Recht, hier als Muslime zu leben, so wie andere das auch haben. Es ist schlimm genug, dass die Menschen so zersplittert sind, auch in Glaubensdingen.

Ich gehÃ¶re hier mit zu der Gruppe, die am 8.10. das Gedenken ausrichtet, als wir hier in Dresden die friedliche Revolution auf der Prager StraÃe hatten, als die Polizei ihre Schilde runter getan hat und die Dresdner 20 gewÃ¤hlt worden sind, der erste demokratische Dialog, der mÃ¶glich war. Dann stehen hier so 100 bis 120 Dresdner und gedenken der damaligen Zeit. Es ist wichtig, dass das nicht so ein Alte-Leute-Treffen ist, Veteranen, die sich von damals kennen und sich gegenseitig daran erfreuen, wie mutig sie damals waren, sondern dass wir es weiter geben an die nachfolgende Generation. Ich sehe bei meinen Enkeln, dass jetzt eine Generation heranwÃ¤chst, die sich gar nicht vorstellen kÃ¶nnen, wie das damals war. Die heutigen MÃ¶glichkeiten, dass Europa grenzenlos weit ist, ihnen alles offen steht, dass sie das fÃ¼r normal halten. WÃ¤hrend wir immer noch dafÃ¼r dankbar sind, das sich das so geÃ¤ndert hat."

"Pegida is a catastrophe. The Pegida people come by exactly when we have finished our peace prayer in the Kreuzkirche. If they had stayed in the bar where they thought up Pegida while drinking a beer, they couldâve had another one, as far as I am concerned. But the fact that this movement has become popular â itâs disappointing that people participate. I have tried to talk to a lot of them in these three years â Pegida stewards, who are there every time, but also Christian congregation members who march with them, obviously intelligent people, where I think, I just canât imagine it. My last impression was that itâs more older men. Itâs these typical GDR citizens, who always went along, and then in 1990, they didnât get what they wanted, the roasted pigeon stuck pre-chewed in their mouths.

The boss who invented Pegida with his beer drinking pals is about as old as my son, who was sixteen in 1989. My son was in the opposition group, but I donât know Bachmann from back then. The people who were active back then, they all know each other. I donât want to judge individuals that are with them, but itâs not like they put up strong opposition in 1989 and are disappointed today. No, they are grumblers and people who â in part â donât want to work or are already retired. At the beginning, you couldnât talk to any of them. Now, you can ask questions of individuals, but you get just get phrases ranted at you, and I have not yet had a conversation where I have said, we have met at some point or have come to a basic common opinion. Just stupid phrases, catch words, with which they flail around without thinking.

They are marching with Pegida and yelling, âLying Press!â and âWe are the people!.â They stole that saying from us. I once asked one of them who yelled âLying Press!,â âWhat newspaper do you read?â âNone at all.â But he screams âLying Press.â Itâs partially a kind of family meeting; when they are setting up their demonstrations, the first ones are already there and play accordion, pass out song texts, sing some German folk songs, and then the first ones with their flags come and greet each other. Luckily, they arenât all from Dresden; some come from somewhere else. But itâs embarrassing for everyone who goes. The impression of Dresden is spoiled.

The difficulty is that you canât really get to the Pegida people. There are all sorts of smart Pegida interpreters, who write books and know everything. You canât ask 200 or 2000 and derive a summary from that. Some come every Monday, always the same, put in a lot of effort in part, make posters, let their children paste things to them. Then, one comes every Monday with a photo of the Frauenkirche. Written on it is, âThis wonât be a mosque.â He walks with it past the Kreuzkirche. I have asked some of them when the last time they were in church was. If they are so against Islamization of the Occident, they must want it to stay Christian or shaped by Christianity. That doesnât have anything to do with it, said one. He certainly doesnât go to church. If they were so against the Islamization, they should fill the churches every Sunday so that no one could find a place. Thatâs not what they are doing. And I donât think Islam is a threat to Germany; itâs a minority. They have the right to live here as Muslims just like other people. Itâs bad enough that people are so splintered in belief questions.

I belong to the the group that holds a memorial on October 8th â the day we had the Peaceful Revolution on Prager StraÃe, when the police took down the shields, and we voted for the Dresden 20, the first democratic dialogue, which was possible. On that day, about 100 to 120 Dresdeners stand here and remember that time. Itâs important that itâs not just an old person meeting â veterans who know each other from back then and are pleased with how brave we were. Instead, we need to pass this on to the next generation. With my grandchildren, I see a generation that has grown up not being able to imagine how it was back then. The possibilities today, a borderless Europe, that everything is open to them â they think thatâs normal. Whereas we are still thankful that the world has changed in this way."

Es ist nicht so, dass die damals 1989 krÃ¤ftig Opposition gemacht haben und nun heute enttÃ¤uscht sind, sondern das sind Meckerfritzen und Leute, die zum Teil auch keine Lust haben zum arbeiten oder schon in Rente sind. Am Anfang konnte man mit keinem reden. Jetzt kann man einzelne fragen, da bekommt man bloÃ Phrasen gedroschen und ich habe noch kein GesprÃ¤ch gefÃ¼hrt, wo ich gesagt habe, wir haben uns an irgendeiner Stelle getroffen oder auf eine Grundmeinung geeinigt. Nur blÃ¶de Parolen, Schlagworte, mit denen sie um sich hauen, ohne dass sie darÃ¼ber nachdenken.

Die marschieren jetzt bei Pegida und brÃ¼llen âLÃ¼genpresseâ und âWir sind das Volkâ. Die haben uns diesen Spruch geklaut. Ich habe mal einen gefragt, der âLÃ¼genpresseâ gebrÃ¼llt hat: âWas lesen Sie fÃ¼r eine Zeitung?â âGar keine.â Aber er brÃ¼llt LÃ¼genpresse. Es ist zum Teil so eine Art Familientreffen, wenn die ihre Demo vorbereiten, da stehen die ersten schon da und spielen Schifferklavier, verteilen LiederblÃ¤tter, singen irgendwelche deutsche Volkslieder, dann kommen die ersten mit ihren Fahnen und begrÃ¼Ãen sich untereinander, kennen sich alle schon untereinander. Es sind zum GlÃ¼ck nicht alles Dresdner, die kommen von sonstwo her. Aber es ist jeder peinlich, der da kommt. Der Eindruck von Dresden wird versaut

Die Schwierigkeit ist, dass man nicht genau an die Pegidaleute ran kommt. Es gibt alle mÃ¶glichen schlauen Pegidaversteher, die BÃ¼cher darÃ¼ber schreiben und alles genau wissen. Man kann nicht 200 oder 2.000 befragen und daraus ein ResÃ¼mee ziehen. Manche kommen jeden Montag, sind immer dieselben, geben sich zum Teil groÃe MÃ¼he, bauen Plakate, lassen ihre Kinder was aufkleben. Dann kommt einer jeden Montag mit dem Foto von der Frauenkirche. Da steht drauf: âDas wird mal keine Moscheeâ, der marschiert damit an der Kreuzkirche vorbei. Ich habe mal zu welchen gesagt, wann waren sie das letzte mal in der Kirche. Wenn sie so gegen die Islamisierung des Abendlandes sind, mÃ¼ssten sie doch dafÃ¼r sein, dass das christlich bleibt oder christlich geprÃ¤gt. Das hat damit nichts zu tun, sage einer. Sicher geht er nicht in die Kirche. Wenn die so gegen die Islamisierung wÃ¤ren, mÃ¼ssten sich jeden Sonntag die Kirchen so fÃ¼llen, das keiner mehr einen Platz findet. Das tun sie ja auch nicht. Und ich halte den Islam fÃ¼r keine Bedrohung fÃ¼r Deutschland, es ist eine Minderheit. Sie haben ihr Recht, hier als Muslime zu leben, so wie andere das auch haben. Es ist schlimm genug, dass die Menschen so zersplittert sind, auch in Glaubensdingen.

Ich gehÃ¶re hier mit zu der Gruppe, die am 8.10. das Gedenken ausrichtet, als wir hier in Dresden die friedliche Revolution auf der Prager StraÃe hatten, als die Polizei ihre Schilde runter getan hat und die Dresdner 20 gewÃ¤hlt worden sind, der erste demokratische Dialog, der mÃ¶glich war. Ich sehe bei meinen Enkeln, dass jetzt eine Generation heranwÃ¤chst, die sich gar nicht vorstellen kÃ¶nnen, wie das damals war. Die heutigen MÃ¶glichkeiten, dass Europa grenzenlos weit ist, ihnen alles offen steht, dass sie das fÃ¼r normal halten. WÃ¤hrend wir immer noch dafÃ¼r dankbar sind, das sich das so geÃ¤ndert hat."

"Pegida is a catastrophe. The Pegida people come by exactly when we have finished our peace prayer in the Kreuzkirche. If they had stayed in the bar where they thought up Pegida while drinking a beer, they couldâve had another one, as far as I am concerned. But the fact that this movement has become popular â itâs disappointing that people participate. I have tried to talk to a lot of them in these three years â Pegida stewards, who are there every time, but also Christian congregation members who march with them, obviously intelligent people, where I think, I just canât imagine it. My last impression was that itâs more older men. Itâs these typical GDR citizens, who always went along, and then in 1990, they didnât get what they wanted, the roasted pigeon stuck pre-chewed in their mouths.

The boss who invented Pegida with his beer drinking pals is about as old as my son, who was sixteen in 1989. My son was in the opposition group, but I donât know Bachmann from back then. The people who were active back then, they all know each other. I donât want to judge individuals that are with them, but itâs not like they put up strong opposition in 1989 and are disappointed today. No, they are grumblers and people who â in part â donât want to work or are already retired. At the beginning, you couldnât talk to any of them. Now, you can ask questions of individuals, but you get just get phrases ranted at you, and I have not yet had a conversation where I have said, we have met at some point or have come to a basic common opinion. Just stupid phrases, catch words, with which they flail around without thinking.

They are marching with Pegida and yelling, âLying Press!â and âWe are the people!.â They stole that saying from us. I once asked one of them who yelled âLying Press!,â âWhat newspaper do you read?â âNone at all.â But he screams âLying Press.â Itâs partially a kind of family meeting; when they are setting up their demonstrations, the first ones are already there and play accordion, pass out song texts, sing some German folk songs, and then the first ones with their flags come and greet each other. Luckily, they arenât all from Dresden; some come from somewhere else. But itâs embarrassing for everyone who goes. The impression of Dresden is spoiled.

The difficulty is that you canât really get to the Pegida people. There are all sorts of smart Pegida interpreters, who write books and know everything. You canât ask 200 or 2000 and derive a summary from that. Some come every Monday, always the same, put in a lot of effort in part, make posters, let their children paste things to them. Then, one comes every Monday with a photo of the Frauenkirche. Written on it is, âThis wonât be a mosque.â He walks with it past the Kreuzkirche. I have asked some of them when the last time they were in church was. If they are so against Islamization of the Occident, they must want it to stay Christian or shaped by Christianity. That doesnât have anything to do with it, said one. He certainly doesnât go to church. If they were so against the Islamization, they should fill the churches every Sunday so that no one could find a place. Thatâs not what they are doing. And I donât think Islam is a threat to Germany; itâs a minority. They have the right to live here as Muslims just like other people. Itâs bad enough that people are so splintered in belief questions.

I belong to the the group that holds a memorial on October 8th â the day we had the Peaceful Revolution on Prager StraÃe, when the police took down the shields, and we voted for the Dresden 20, the first democratic dialogue, which was possible. On that day, about 100 to 120 Dresdeners stand here and remember that time. Itâs important that itâs not just an old person meeting â veterans who know each other from back then and are pleased with how brave we were. Instead, we need to pass this on to the next generation. With my grandchildren, I see a generation that has grown up not being able to imagine how it was back then. The possibilities today, a borderless Europe, that everything is open to them â they think thatâs normal. Whereas we are still thankful that the world has changed in this way."

"Vor drei Jahren, als wir nach Dresden gekommen sind, habe ich von dem Projekt Bildungspatenschaften gehÃ¶rt. Mein wichtigstes Ziel war, dass die Kinder die deutsche Sprache lernen. Mein Sohn war damals in der fÃ¼nften Klasse. Er bekam einen sehr netten Paten. Er meinem Sohn bei den Hausaufgaben geholfen und mir auch, wenn ich Hilfe gebraucht habe bei meinem Deutschkurs. Er ist immer zwei Stunden in der Woche zu uns gekommen. Mein Sohn hat in der Schule sehr gut die Sprache gelernt, viel schneller als ich. Der Pate ist dann in eine andere Stadt zum Studieren gezogen. FÃ¼r meinen kleinen Sohn, er war in der dritten Klasse, hatte ich dann einen anderen Paten. Er hat auch viel gemacht - Hausaufgaben, FuÃball spielen, ins Kino gehen. Mein Sohn ist jetzt im Gymnasium und braucht keinen Paten, da er die deutsche Sprache sehr gut gelernt hat. Andere Kinder brauchen das mehr. Er ist jetzt bei einer anderen Familie.

Ich habe die deutsche Sprache ein Jahr lang gelernt und dann beim AuslÃ¤nderrat ein paar Praktika gemacht, im Kindergarten und im Johannstadttreff. In Syrien war ich Arabischlehrerin. Ich habe in Damaskus an der UniversitÃ¤t arabische Literatur und Sprache studiert. Das Zertifikat wird hier nicht anerkannt. Ich gebe an der Volkshochschule Arabischkurse. Ich bin auch am Gymnasium und an Grundschulen, wo Kinder ihre Muttersprache Arabisch lernen. Beim AuslÃ¤nderrat habe ich als Dolmetscher geholfen. Ich helfe bei den VertrÃ¤gen und am Anfang beim Kennenlernen der Paten.

Mein Ziel war es, eine Arbeit zu finden. Ich hÃ¤tte nicht gedacht, dass es so schwer ist. Ich habe gekÃ¤mpft und mich beworben als Dolmetscher, Lehrerin, Sozialarbeiter und hatte auch eine Zusage fÃ¼r die Evangelische Hochschule. Aber ich habe meine DeutschprÃ¼fung nicht geschafft und daher die Zusage verloren. Ich muss jetzt erst meine DeutschprÃ¼fung bestehen. Im Moment habe ich nur HonorarvertrÃ¤ge. Ich weiÃ nicht, ob das weitergeht. Der Arabischunterricht ist freiwillig und vielleicht geht es nÃ¤chstes Jahr nicht weiter. An der Volkshochschule ist es auch so. Ich weiÃ nicht, wie lange ich dort die Kurse geben kann. Alles ist nicht so sicher und deshalb habe ich gedacht, ich muss jetzt noch einmal studieren, obwohl ich bereits ein Studium habe.

Es war von Anfang an so, dass ich die Leute mag, die beim AuslÃ¤nderrat arbeiten. Ich habe nach meiner ersten ehrenamtlichen TÃ¤tigkeit in deren Kindergarten die Bildungspatenschaften und den Frauentreff kennen gelernt. Ich komme jeden Montag, damit ich meine Sprache verbessern kann und ich habe das GefÃ¼hl, sie sind wie beste Freunde. Ich bin immer froh, wenn ich dabei sein kann, mit oder fÃ¼r den AuslÃ¤nderrat, auch wenn es nur ehrenamtlich ist. FÃ¼r mich ist es die Erfahrung, dass ich jeden Tag etwas lernen und anderen helfen kann."
--
"Three years ago, when we came to Dresden, I heard about the educational mentorship program. My most important goal was that my children learn the German language. My son was in the fifth grade then. He was given a very nice mentor. He helped my son with his homework and even helped me with my German course when I needed it. He always came to us for two hours a week. My son learned the language in school very well, much faster than I did. The mentor then moved to another city to go to university. For my younger son, who was in the third grade back then, we had another mentor. He also did a lot â homework, played football, went to movies. My son is now in high school and doesnât need a mentor, since he has learned German really well. Other children need it more, and the mentor is now with another family.

I learned German for a year and then did a couple internships at the AuslÃ¤nderrat, in the kindergarten (that they run) and the Johannstadt meet up. In Syria, I was an Arabic teacher. I studied Arabic literature and language at the university in Damascus. My degree wasnât recognized here. I am teaching some Arabic courses at the community college. I also teach at high schools and primary schools where children learn Arabic as their mother tongue. I help out at the AuslÃ¤nderrat as a translator. I help with contracts and with the initial getting-to- know-each-other phase of the mentors.

My goal was to find a job. I didnât think it would be so difficult. I fought and applied as a translator, teacher, social worker. I had an acceptance from the school for social work, but I didnât pass my German test and therefore lost my place. I now have to pass my German test. Right now, I just have temporary contracts. I donât know how it will go in the future. The Arabic courses in the schools are voluntary, and maybe they wonât be offered next year. Itâs the same at the community college. I donât know how long I can give courses there. Nothing is so secure and thatâs why I thought I should go back to university even though I already have a degree.

From the start, I liked the people who work at the AuslÃ¤nderrat. I got to know about the educational mentorships and the womenâs meeting after my first volunteer work in their kindergarten. I come every Monday, so that I can improve my German, and I have the feeling that they are like my best friends. I am always happy when I can help out, with or for the AuslÃ¤nderrat, even when itâs volunteer. For me, itâs the experience that I learn something every day and can help others."

"Es ist Montag und ich stehe schon wieder hier. Ich wÃ¤re eigentlich lieber bei meiner Familie zu Hause oder mit meiner Familie an der Elbe oder baden oder sonst irgendwo. Ich bin aber hier, weil dieser ungezogene Haufen namens Pegida diese schÃ¶ne Stadt jeden Montag in Geiselhaft nimmt. Die StraÃenbahn muss umgeleitet werden, die Busse fahren nicht wie sie sollen, man kann sich nicht einfach auf den Platz, wo die gerade sind, in die Sonne stellen und ganz viele Menschen trauen sich gar nicht vor die TÃ¼r, weil sie nicht aussehen, als kÃ¤men sie von hier. Das finde ich sehr traurig und deswegen stehe ich dann doch wieder hier.

Ich finde, die sind ein bisschen wie Terroristen. Aber wahrscheinlich ist auch die Stadt Dresden wie so eine Geisel mit Stockholm-Syndrom, die sagt: âOh, hier kommt der liebe Onkel â macht doch, was ihr wollt! Ihr wollt ins Stadtzentrum? Gerne! Was, jede Woche? Ok, machen wir eine Daueranmeldung, keine Problem!â Entsprechend agiert die VersammlungsbehÃ¶rde, entsprechend ist die Polizei drauf. Das Ã¤rgert mich. Ich erkenne hier die dunkle Seite meiner Stadt. Die braucht Dresden nicht, Dresden hat so viele schÃ¶ne, funkelnde Seiten. Die meisten Leute, die hier bei Pegida stehen, sind ja nicht mal Dresdner."
--
"It's Monday, and I am standing here again. I would rather be with my family at home or at the Elbe or swimming or anywhere else. But I am here, because of this ill-mannered crowd, called Pegida, takes this nice city hostage every Monday. The trams have to make detours, the buses aren't running like they should. You can't just stand in the sun on this square where they are. A lot of people don't even dare to go out because they don't look like they come from here. I think it's really sad, and that's why I am here again.

I think they are a little like terrorists. But probably the city of Dresden is also like a hostage with Stockholm syndrome, who says, "Oh, here comes our dear uncle -- do what you want! You want to be in the city center? Certainly! What, every week? Ok, we will set up a permanent registration, no problem!" The administrative authority acts accordingly, the police also. That really annoys me. I recognize the dark side of my city. Dresden doesn't need them, Dresden has so many nice, sparkly sides. Most people who are standing here with Pegida aren't even Dresdeners."

"Ich habe in Syrien Jura studiert. Als ich nach Deutschland kam, musste ich feststellen, dass mein Zertifikat hier nicht anerkannt wird. Ich muss noch einmal von vorn anfangen. Das war nicht so toll, wenn man gerade fertig geworden ist, soll man noch mal neu beginnen. Aber man muss es versuchen. Ich will hier wieder Jura studieren, obwohl die meisten sagen, dass das sehr schwer ist und ich hier nicht zurechtkommen werde. Aber egal, was ich studieren mÃ¶chte, es wird auf jeden Fall schwierig, weil es in einer anderen Sprache ist. Und hier ist alles schneller. Bei uns ist nicht alles so organisiert wie hier, sondern chaotisch. Mir gefÃ¤llt das hier sehr gut. Ich habe deutsche Freunde. Ich hatte auch schon fÃ¼r sechs Monate eine deutsche Freundin, aber das hat nicht geklappt. Sie hat mir Deutsch beigebracht und ich ihr Arabisch. Wir sind noch gute Freunde.

Meine Eltern haben viele Schwierigkeiten damit, hier in Deutschland zu leben. Mein Vater ist 50, ihm fÃ¤llt es sehr schwer, eine neue Sprache zu lernen. Meiner Mutter geht es genauso. Es ist alles so anders als bei uns. Die BÃ¼rokratie ist auch manchmal ein Problem. Meiner Meinung nach kÃ¶nnte es einfacher sein, damit wir schneller in den Arbeitsmarkt kommen und fÃ¼r die Gesellschaft nÃ¼tzlich sein kÃ¶nnen.

Ich bin jetzt 25 und muss neu anfangen.. Es ist schwierig, auf etwas zu warten und es dauert so lange. In Syrien hÃ¤tte ich mein eigenes BÃ¼ro als Rechtsanwalt. Die Leute wÃ¼rden zu mir kommen und ich kÃ¶nnte ihnen helfen. Ich habe schnell deutsch gelernt, damit ich an die Uni kann. NÃ¤chsten Monat habe ich meine DaF-PrÃ¼fung. Ich hoffe, dass ich im Wintersemester anfangen kann."

"I studied law in Syria. When I came to Germany, I realized that my degree wouldnât be recognized here. I had to start over again. That wasnât so great; after having just finished, you have to start again. But you have to try. I want to study law here again, although most people say that it is really difficult, and I wonât be able to manage here. But no matter what I study, it will be difficult, because itâs in an another language. And here, everything is faster. At home, everything isnât so organized as it is here; instead itâs chaotic. I like it here very much. I have German friends. He was HIV- and Hepatitis B positive, and so no one dared to touch him. We cleaned the wound thoroughly and changed the dressing, and we continued to do so for almost a week. At the end of the week the smell was gone. The patient was moved to a regular ward, and we were transferred to another hospital and almost forgot the case.

Then, almost 5 months later, a group of people approached me and lay down and touched my feet. Lying on the ground and touching the feet is a symbol of utmost respect and devotion in India. This group of people was the family of the patient that my friend and I had cared for months ago. He was recovering very well, and the family gave their thanks in this way.

This episode changed my perception of being a doctor. I believe now that, yes I am in the right profession."

"What are you doing now?"

"Well now I am working at a refugee camp as a volunteer doctor -- doing the best I can with resources I have. We can talk about the stories I hear every day from the refugees some other day."
